entry.note: At the end of monosyllables containing a single vowel, it is often doubled, as in fall full bell; but not after digraphs, as in foul fool prowl growl foal. In English words, the terminating syllable le is unaccented, the e is silent, and l is preceded by a voice glide, as in able eagle, pronounced ā"b'l ē"g'l. See Guide to Pronunciation, §241.

sn.def: L is the twelfth letter of the English alphabet, and a vocal consonant. It is usually called a semivowel or liquid. Its form and value are from the Greek, through the Latin, the form of the Greek letter being from the Phœnician, and the ultimate origin prob. Egyptian. Etymologically, it is most closely related to r and u; as in pilgrim, peregrine, couch (fr. collocare), aubura (fr. LL. alburnus).
As a numeral, L stands for fifty in the English, as in the Latin language.
sn.q: For 50 the Romans used the Chalcidian chi, �, which assumed the less difficult lapidary type, �, and was then easily assimilated to L.

sn.def: An extension at right angles to the length of a main building, giving to the ground plan a form resembling the letter L; sometimes less properly applied to a narrower, or lower, extension in the direction of the length of the main building; a wing.
A short right-angled pipe fitting, used in connecting two pipes at right angles.
Having the general shape of the (capital) letter L; as, an L beam, or L-beam.
Elevated; -- a symbol for el. as an abbreviation of elevated in elevated road or railroad.

def2.def: An elevated road; as, to ride on the L .

entry.def: A syllable applied to the sixth tone of the scale in music in solmization.
The tone A; -- so called among the French and Italians.

entry.ety: Cf. Lo

sn.def: Look; see; behold; -- sometimes followed by you.
An exclamation of surprise; -- commonly followed by me; as, La me!

entry.ety: D., also leger. Cf. 2d Leaguer Lair
entry.def: A camp, especially one surrounded by a circular formation of travelers' wagons for temporary defense.
entry.q: Wagons . . . can be readily formed into a laager, a camp, by being drawn into a circle, with the oxen placed inside and so kept safe from the attacks of wild beasts.

entry.ety: From Laager n.
entry.def: To form into, or camp in, a laager, or protected camp.
A lace. See Lace.

entry.ety: Cf. OD. labben to babble
entry.def: To prate; to gossip; to babble; to blab.

sn.def: A telltale; a prater; a blabber.
sn.q: I am nolab.

sn.def: Laboratory.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to a laboratory; as, a lab bench.

A follower of Jean de Labadie , a religious teacher of the 17th century, who left the Roman Catholic Church and taught a kind of mysticism, and the obligation of community of property among Christians.

entry.note: Sodium hypochlorite is the same compound used in the commercial trademarked bleach Clorox(TM). It has both disinfectant and bleaching activity.
entry.ety: From Labarraque , a Parisian apothecary
entry.def: An aqueous solution of sodium hypochlorite, extensively used as a disinfectant.

entries.entry: ‖Lab"a*rum n.; pl.Labara #. L The standard adopted by the Emperor Constantine after his conversion to Christianity. It is described as a pike bearing a silk banner hanging from a crosspiece, and surmounted by a golden crown. It bore a monogram of the first two letters (ΧΡ) (which appear like the English letters X and P), of the name of Christ in its Greek form. Later, the name was given to various modifications of this standard.

entry.def: See Ladanum.

entry.ety: See Labefy
entry.def: The act of labefying or making weak; the state of being weakened; decay; ruin.
entry.q: There is in it such a labefaction of all principles as may be injurious to morality.

entry.ety: L. labefacere; labare to totter + facere to make
entry.def: To weaken or impair.

entry.ety: OF. label sort of ribbon or fringe, label in heraldry, F. lambeau shred, strip, rag; of uncertain origin; cf. L. labellum, dim. of labrum lip, edge, margin, G. lappen flap, patch, rag, tatter (cf. Lap of a dress), W. llab llabed, label, flap, Gael. leab leob, slice, shred, hanging lip

sn.def: A tassel.
A slip of silk, paper, parchment, etc., affixed to anything, and indicating, usually by an inscription, the contents, ownership, destination, etc.; as, the label of a bottle or a package.
A slip of ribbon, parchment, etc., attached to a document to hold the appended seal; also, the seal.
A writing annexed by way of addition, as a codicil added to a will.
A barrulet, or, rarely, a bendlet, with pendants, or points, usually three, especially used as a mark of cadency to distinguish an eldest or only son while his father is still living.
A brass rule with sights, formerly used, in connection with a circumferentor, to take altitudes.
The name now generally given to the projecting molding by the sides, and over the tops, of openings in mediæval architecture. It always has a square form, as in the illustration.
In mediæval art, the representation of a band or scroll containing an inscription.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Labeled lā"bĕld or Labelled; p. pr. & vb. n. Labeling or Labelling

sn.def: To affix a label to; to mark with a name, etc.; as, to label a bottle or a package.
To affix in or on a label.

entry.def: One who labels.

entries.entry:
‖La*bel"lum lȧ*bĕl"lŭm n.; pl. L. Labella lȧ*bĕl"lȧ, E. Labellums lȧ*bĕl"lŭmz. L., dim. of labrum lip
Bot The lower or apparently anterior petal of an orchidaceous flower, often of a very curious shape.
Zoöl A small appendage beneath the upper lip or labrum of certain insects.

entry.ety: L. labens, p. pr. of labi to slide, glide
entry.def: Slipping; sliding; gliding.
See Labium.

entry.ety: LL. labialis, fr. L. labium lip: cf. F. labial. See Lip

sn.def: Of or pertaining to the lips or labia; as, labial veins.
Furnished with lips; as, a labial organ pipe.

sd.def: Articulated, as a consonant, mainly by the lips, as b, p, m, w.
Modified, as a vowel, by contraction of the lip opening, as � (f�d), ō (ōld), etc., and as eu and u in French, and öü in German. See Guide to Pronunciation, §§ 11, 178.

sn.def: Of or pertaining to the labium; as, the labial palpi of insects. See Labium.
A letter or character representing an articulation or sound formed or uttered chiefly with the lips, as b p w.
An organ pipe that is furnished with lips; a flue pipe.
One of the scales which border the mouth of a fish or reptile.

entry.def: The quality of being labial; as, the labialism of an articulation; conversion into a labial, as of a sound which is different in another language.
The modification of an articulation by contraction of the lip opening.
To modify by contraction of the lip opening.
In a labial manner; with, or by means of, the lips.
To labialize.

entry.ety: NL. labiatus, fr. L. labium lip
entry.def: Having the limb of a tubular corolla or calyx divided into two unequal parts, one projecting over the other like the lips of a mouth, as in the snapdragon, sage, and catnip.
Belonging to a natural order of plants (Labiatæ), of which the mint, sage, and catnip are examples. They are mostly aromatic herbs.
A plant of the order Labiatæ.
Same as Labiate a..

entry.ety: Labiate + L. flos floris, flower
entry.def: Having labiate flowers, as the snapdragon.

entry.ety: Gr. labi`s -i`dos, a forceps + meter: cf. F. labidometre
entry.def: A forceps with a measuring attachment for ascertaining the size of the fetal head.

entry.ety: L. labilis apt to slip, fr. labi to slip

sn.def: Liable to slip, err, fall, or apostatize.
Liable or likely to change.

Easily decomposed or inactivated when subjected to heat, radiation, or mildly acidic or alkaline conditions; -- of chemical compounds; as, enzymes from thermophilic organisms are not as labile as those from mesophiles.
Liability to lapse, err, or apostatize.
The property of changing readily.
The property of being labile{3}; -- of chemical compounds; as, the lability of some natural products makes them difficult to isolate and identify.

entry.ety: Cf. F. labimetre
entry.def: See Labidometer.

entry.ety: Labium + dental
entry.def: Formed or pronounced by the cooperation of the lips and teeth, as f and v.

entry.ety: Labium + nasal
entry.def: Formed by the lips and the nose.

entry.ety: Labium + -plasty
entry.def: A plastic operation for making a new lip, or for replacing a lost tissue of a lip.

entry.ety: From Labium
entry.def: Having the appearance of being labiate; -- said of certain polypetalous corollas.
A labial palp.

entries.entry:
‖La`bi*pal"pus n.; pl.Labipalpi. NL. See Labium, and Palpus
Zoöl One of the labial palpi of an insect. See Illust. under Labium.

‖La"bi*um n.; pl. L. Labia #, E. Labiums #. L
A lip, or liplike organ.
The lip of an organ pipe.
pl. Anat The folds of integument at the opening of the vulva.
Zoöl
The organ of insects which covers the mouth beneath, and serves as an under lip. It consists of the second pair of maxillæ, usually closely united in the middle line, but bearing a pair of palpi in most insects. It often consists of a thin anterior part (ligula or palpiger) and a firmer posterior plate (mentum).
Inner margin of the aperture of a shell.

entry.def: an East Indian name for several twining leguminous plants related to the bean, but commonly applied to the hyacinth bean (Dolichos Lablab).

entry.ety: OE. labour, OF. labour laber labur, F. labeur, L. labor; cf. Gr. lamba`nein to take, Skr. labh to get, seize

sn.def: Physical toil or bodily exertion, especially when fatiguing, irksome, or unavoidable, in distinction from sportive exercise; hard, muscular effort directed to some useful end, as agriculture, manufactures, and like; servile toil; exertion; work.
sn.q: God hath setLabor and rest, as day and night, to men Successive.

sn.def: Intellectual exertion; mental effort; as, the labor of compiling a history.
That which requires hard work for its accomplishment; that which demands effort.
sn.q: Being a labor of so great a difficulty, the exact performance thereof we may rather wish than look for.

sn.def: Travail; the pangs and efforts of childbirth.
sn.q: The queen's in labor, They say, in great extremity; and feared She'll with the labor end.

sn.def: Any pang or distress.
The pitching or tossing of a vessel which results in the straining of timbers and rigging.
A measure of land in Mexico and Texas, equivalent to an area of 1771/7 acres.
A stope or set of stopes.
sn.syn: Work; toil; drudgery; task; exertion; effort; industry; painstaking. See Toll.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Labored; p. pr. & vb. n. Laboring
entry.ety: OE. labouren, F. labourer, L. laborare. See Labor n.

sn.def: To exert muscular strength; to exert one's strength with painful effort, particularly in servile occupations; to work; to toil.
sn.q: Adam, well may we labor still to dress This garden.

sn.def: To exert one's powers of mind in the prosecution of any design; to strive; to take pains.

To be oppressed with difficulties or disease; to do one's work under conditions which make it especially hard, wearisome; to move slowly, as against opposition, or under a burden; to be burdened; -- often with under, and formerly with of.
sn.q: The stone that labors up the hill.
The line too labors, and the words move slow.
To cure the disorder under which he labored.
Come unto me, all ye that labor and are heavy laden, and I will give you rest.

sn.def: To be in travail; to suffer the pangs of childbirth; to be in labor.
To pitch or roll heavily, as a ship in a turbulent sea.

entry.ety: F. labourer, L. laborare

sn.def: To work at; to work; to till; to cultivate by toil.
sn.q: The most excellent lands are lying fallow, or only labored by children.

sn.def: To form or fabricate with toil, exertion, or care.
sn.q: Tolaborarms for Troy.

sn.def: To prosecute, or perfect, with effort; to urge strenuously; as, to labor a point or argument.
To belabor; to beat.

entry.ety: L. laborans, p. pr. of laborare to labor
entry.def: A chemist.

entries.entry:
Lab"o*ra*to*ry n.; pl.Laboratories #. Shortened fr. elaboratory; cf. OF. elaboratoire, F. laboratoire. See Elaborate Labor.
elaboratory
The workroom of a chemist; also, a place devoted to experiments in any branch of natural science; as, a chemical, physical, or biological laboratory . Hence, by extension, a place where something is prepared, or some operation is performed; as, the liver is the laboratory of the bile.
Hence: Any place, activity or situation suggestive of a scientific laboratory{1}, especially in being conducive to learning new facts by experimentation or by systematic observation; as, the states serve as laboratories where different new policies may be tested prior to adoption throughout the country.

Labor Day. In most of the States and Territories of the United States, a day, usually the first Monday of September, set aside as a legal holiday, in honor of, or in the interest of, workingmen as a class. Also, a similar holiday in Canada, Australia, etc.

sn.def: Bearing marks of labor and effort; elaborately wrought; not easy or natural; as, labored poetry; a labored style.
appearing to require strong effort; as, labored breathing.

entry.def: In a labored manner; with labor.

entry.ety: Written also labourer
entry.def: One who labors in a toilsome occupation; a person who does work that requires strength rather than skill, as distinguished from that of an artisan.

cs.cd: the oar which requires most strength and exertion; often used figuratively; as, to have, or pull, the laboring oar in some difficult undertaking.

sn.def: That labors; performing labor; esp., performing coarse, heavy work, not requiring skill also, set apart for labor; as, laboring days.
sn.q: The sleep of a laboring man is sweet.

sn.def: Suffering pain or grief.

entry.ety: L. laboriosus, fr. labor labor: cf. F. laborieux

sn.def: Requiring labor, perseverance, or sacrifices; toilsome; tiresome.
sn.q: Dost thou love watchings, abstinence, or toil,Laborious virtues all? Learn these from Cato.

sn.def: Devoted to labor; diligent; industrious; as, a laborious mechanic.

entry.def: Not involving labor; not laborious; easy.
Laborious.

Saving labor; adapted to supersede or diminish the labor of men; designed to replace or conserve human and especially manual labor; as, labor-saving machinery; labor-saving appliances{4}; labor-saving devices like washing machines.

sn.def: Made with, or requiring, great labor, pains, or diligence.
Likely or inclined to roll or pitch, as a ship in a heavy sea; having a tendency to labor.

entry.def: Same as labor; -- British spelling.

sn.def: same as labored; -- British spelling

entry.def: a laborer; someone who works with their hands.

sn.def: characterized by toilsome effort; same as laborious; -- British spelling.
sn.syn: arduous, backbreaking, back-breaking, grueling, gruelling, hard, heavy, laborious, punishing, slavish, strenuous, toilsome.

entry.def: a member of the British Labour Party.

entry.cs: Labrador duck Zoöl a sea duck (Camtolaimus Labradorius) allied to the eider ducks. It was formerly common on the coast of New England, but is now supposed to be extinct, no specimens having been reported since 1878. Labrador feldspar. See Labradorite. Labrador tea Bot a name of two low, evergreen shrubs of the genus Ledum Ledum palustre and Ledum latifolium), found in Northern Europe and America. They are used as tea in British America, and in Scandinavia as a substitute for hops.
entry.def: A region of British America on the Atlantic coast, north of Newfoundland.
A kind of feldspar commonly showing a beautiful play of colors, and hence much used for ornamental purposes. The finest specimens come from Labrador. See Feldspar.

entry.ety: L. labrum; cf. It. labbro, pl. labbra
entry.def: Lips.

entry.ety: L. labrum lip
entry.def: A piece of wood, shell, stone, or other substance, worn in a perforation of the lip or cheek by many savages.

entry.ety: Labrus + -oid
entry.def: Like the genus Labrus; belonging to the family Labridæ, an extensive family of marine fishes, often brilliantly colored, which are very abundant in the Indian and Pacific Oceans. The tautog and cunner are American examples.

entry.ety: L. labrosus, fr. labrum lip
entry.def: Having thick lips.

entries.entry:
‖La"brum n.; pl. L. Labra #, E. Labrums #. L
A lip or edge, as of a basin.
Zoöl
An organ in insects and crustaceans covering the upper part of the mouth, and serving as an upper lip. See Illust. of Hymenoptera.
The external margin of the aperture of a shell. See Univalve.
‖La"brus n.; pl.Labri -brī. L., a sort of fish Zoöl A genus of marine fishes, including the wrasses of Europe. See Wrasse.

entry.def: Of, pertaining to, or derived from, the laburnum.
A poisonous alkaloid found in the unripe seeds of the laburnum.

entry.note: ☞ Scotch laburnum (Cytisus alpinus) is similar, but has smooth leaves; purple laburnum is Cytisus purpureus.
entry.ety: L
entry.def: A small leguminous tree (Cytisus Laburnum), native of the Alps. The plant is reputed to be poisonous, esp. the bark and seeds. It has handsome racemes of yellow blossoms.

entry.note: ☞ The Labyrinth of Classical Mythology was a vast maze constructed by Daedalus on the island of Crete, in order to confine the Minotaur; the task was done at the command of King Minos. One theory suggests that the myth had some basis in the structure of the palace of King Minos at Knossos, in Crete, it being a multistoried royal palace with labyrinthine passages between rooms.
entry.usage: Labyrinth Maze. Labyrinth, originally; the name of an edifice or excavation, carries the idea of design, and construction in a permanent form, while maze is used of anything confused or confusing, whether fixed or shifting. Maze is less restricted in its figurative uses than labyrinth. We speak of the labyrinth of the ear, or of the mind, and of a labyrinth of difficulties; but of the mazes of the dance, the mazes of political intrigue, or of the mind being in a maze.
entry.ety: L. labyrinthus, Gr. laby`rinthos: cf. F. labyrinthe

sn.def: An edifice or place full of intricate passageways which render it difficult to find the way from the interior to the entrance; as, the Egyptian and Cretan labyrinths .
Any intricate or involved inclosure; especially, an ornamental maze or inclosure in a park or garden, having high hedges separating confusingly convoluted passages.
Any object or arrangement of an intricate or involved form, or having a very complicated nature.
sn.q: The serpent . . . fast sleeping soon he found, In labyrinth of many a round self-rolled.
The labyrinth of the mind.

sn.def: An inextricable or bewildering difficulty.
sn.q: I' the maze and winding labyrinths o' the world.

sn.def: The internal ear. See Note under Ear.
A series of canals through which a stream of water is directed for suspending, carrying off, and depositing at different distances, the ground ore of a metal.
A pattern or design representing a maze, -- often inlaid in the tiled floor of a church, etc.

entry.def: Pertaining to, or resembling, a labyrinth; intricate; labyrinthian.
Intricately winding; like a labyrinth; perplexed; labyrinthal.

entry.ety: See Labyrinth, and Branchia
entry.def: Of or pertaining to the Labyrinthici.

entry.ety: L. labyrinthicus: cf. F. labyrinthique
entry.def: Like or pertaining to a labyrinth.

entry.note: ☞ They have, connected with the gill chamber, a special cavity in which a labyrinthiform membrane is arranged so as to retain water to supply the gills while the fish leaves the water and travels about on land, or even climbs trees.
entry.ety: NL. See Labyrinth
entry.def: An order of teleostean fishes, including the Anabas, or climbing perch, and other allied fishes.

entry.ety: Labyrinth + -form: cf. F. labyrinthiforme
entry.def: Having the form of a labyrinth; intricate.
Pertaining to, or like, a labyrinth; labyrinthal; labyrinthian.

entry.ety: Gr. laby`rinthos labyrinth + 'odoy`s 'odo`ntos, tooth
entry.def: A genus of very large fossil amphibians, of the Triassic period, having bony plates on the under side of the body. It is the type of the order Labyrinthodonta. Called also Mastodonsaurus.
Of or pertaining to the Labyrinthodonta.

entry.ety: NL. See Labyrinthodon
entry.def: An extinct order of Amphibia, including the typical genus Labyrinthodon, and many other allied forms, from the Carboniferous, Permian, and Triassic formations. By recent writers they are divided into two or more orders. See Stegocephala.

entry.ety: Hind. lak lākh lāksh, Skr. laksha a mark, sign, lakh
entry.def: One hundred thousand; also, a vaguely great number; as, a lac of rupees.

entry.note: ☞ Stick-lac is the substance in its natural state, incrusting small twigs. When broken off, and the coloring matter partly removed, the granular residuum is called seed-lac. When melted, and reduced to a thin crust, it is called shell-lac or shellac. Lac is an important ingredient in sealing wax, dyes, varnishes, and lacquers.

cs.cd: a resinous exudation of the tree Croton lacciferum, resembling lac.
a scarlet dye obtained from stick-lac.
the coloring matter of lac dye when precipitated from its solutions by alum.
an exudation of the tree Croton Draco.

entry.ety: Per. lak; akin to Skr. lākshā: cf. F. lague, It. & NL. lacca. Cf. Lake a color, Lacquer Litmus
entry.def: A resinous substance produced mainly on the banyan tree, but to some extent on other trees, by the Laccifer laccaformerly Coccus lacca), a scale-shaped insect, the female of which fixes herself on the bark, and exudes from the margin of her body this resinous substance.

entry.ety: Cf. F. laccique
entry.def: Pertaining to lac, or produced from it; as, laccic acid.

entry.ety: Cf. F. laccine
entry.def: A yellow amorphous substance obtained from lac.

entry.ety: Gr. � a cistern + -lite -lith
entry.def: A mass of igneous rock intruded between sedimentary beds and resulting in a mammiform bulging of the overlying strata.

entry.cs:
Alençon lace a kind of point lace, entirely of needlework, first made at Alençon in France, in the 17th century. It is very durable and of great beauty and cost.
Bone lace Brussels lace
etc. See under Bone Brussels, etc.
Gold laceorSilver lace
lace having warp threads of silk, or silk and cotton, and a weft of silk threads covered with gold (or silver), or with gilt. Lace leather thin, oil-tanned leather suitable for cutting into lacings for machine belts. Lace lizard Zoöl a large, aquatic, Australian lizard (Hydrosaurus giganteus), allied to the monitors. Lace paper paper with an openwork design in imitation of lace. Lace piece Shipbuilding the main piece of timber which supports the beak or head projecting beyond the stem of a ship.
Lace pillow, and Pillow lace . See under Pillow.
entry.ety: OE. las, OF. laz, F. lacs, dim. lacet, fr. L. laqueus noose, snare; prob. akin to lacere to entice. Cf. Delight Elicit Lasso Latchet

sn.def: That which binds or holds, especially by being interwoven; a string, cord, or band, usually one passing through eyelet or other holes, and used in drawing and holding together parts of a garment, of a shoe, of a machine belt, etc.
sn.q: His hat hung at his back down by a lace.
For striving more, the more in laces strong Himself he tied.

sn.def: A snare or gin, especially one made of interwoven cords; a net.
sn.q: Vulcanus had caught thee [Venus] in his lace.

sn.def: A fabric of fine threads of linen, silk, cotton, etc., often ornamented with figures; a delicate tissue of thread, much worn as an ornament of dress.
sn.q: Our English dames are much given to the wearing of costly laces.

sn.def: Spirits added to coffee or some other beverage.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Laced āst; p. pr. & vb. n. Lacing

sn.def: To fasten with a lace; to draw together with a lace passed through eyelet holes; to unite with a lace or laces, or, figuratively. with anything resembling laces.
sn.q: When Jenny's stays are newly laced.

sn.def: To adorn with narrow strips or braids of some decorative material; as, cloth laced with silver.
To beat; to lash; to make stripes on.
sn.q: I'll lace your coat for ye.

sn.def: To add something to (a food or beverage) so as to impart flavor, pungency, or some special quality; as, to lace a punch with alcohol; to lace the Kool-Aid with LSD.
To twine or draw as a lace; to interlace; to intertwine.
sn.q: The Gond . . . picked up a trail of the Karela, the vine that bears the bitter wild gourd, and laced it to and fro across the temple door.

entry.def: To be fastened with a lace, or laces; as, these boots lace .
A small tree or shrub (Hoheria populnea) of New Zealand having a profusion of axillary clusters of honey-scented paper-white flowers and whose bark is used for cordage.
A shrub in the West Indies (Lagetta Iintearia); -- so called from the lacelike layers of its inner bark.

cs.cd: a prostitute.
a strong stocking which can be tightly laced; -- used in cases of weak legs, varicose veins, etc.

sn.def: Fastened with a lace or laces; decorated with narrow strips or braid. See Lace v. t.
Decorated with the fabric lace.
sn.q: A shirt with laced ruffles.

entry.ety: L. Lacedamonius, Gr. Lakedaimo`nios, fr. Lakedai`mwn Lacedæmon
entry.def: Of or pertaining to Lacedæmon or Sparta, the chief city of Laconia in the Peloponnesus.
To attack vigorously; -- used of physical or verbal attacks; as, the boss laced into him for coming to the meeting late.

entries.entry: Lace"man n.; pl.Lacemen. A man who deals in lace.

entry.ety: L. lacerabilis: cf. F. lacérable
entry.def: That can be lacerated or torn.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Lacerated; p. pr. & vb. n. Lacerating
entry.ety: L. laceratus, p. p. of lacerare to lacerate, fr. lacer mangled, lacerated; cf. Gr. � a rent, rending, � to tear; perh. akin to E. slay
entry.def: To tear; to rend; to separate by tearing; to mangle; as, to lacerate the flesh.
To afflict; to torture; as, to lacerate the heart.

entry.ety: L. laceratus p. p.

sn.def: Rent; torn; mangled; as, a lacerated wound.
sn.q: By each other's fury lacerate

sn.def: Jagged, or slashed irregularly, at the end, or along the edge.

entry.def: torn roughly; -- of skin.

entry.ety: L. laceratio: cf. F. lacération

sn.def: The act of lacerating.
A breach or wound made by lacerating.

entry.def: Lacerating, or having the power to lacerate; as, lacerative humors.

entry.ety: OE. lacerte. See Lacertus
entry.def: A muscle of the human body.

entry.ety: L. lacertus the arm
entry.def: A fathom.

entry.note: ☞ Formerly it included nearly all the known lizards. It is now restricted to certain diurnal Old World species, like the green lizard (Lacerta viridis) and the sand lizard (Lacerta agilis), of Europe.
entry.ety: L. a lizard. See Lizard

sn.def: A genus of lizards. See Lizard.
The Lizard, a northern constellation.

entry.ety: Cf. F. lacertien
entry.def: Like a lizard; of or pertaining to the Lacertilia.
Any lizard of the family Lacertidae, a family of Old World terrestrial lizard.
A natural family of Old World lizards.

entry.note: ☞ They are closely related to the snakes, and like the latter, usually have the body covered with scales or granules. They usually have eyelids, and most of then have well-formed legs; but in some groups (amphisbæna, glass-snake, etc.) the legs are absent and the body is serpentlike. None are venomous, unless Heloderma be an exception. The order includes the chameleons, the Cionocrania, or typical lizards, and the amphisbænas. See Amphisbæna Gecko Gila monster, and Lizard.
entry.ety: NL., fr. L. lacertus a lizard
entry.def: An order of Reptilia, which includes the lizards.
Same as Lacertian.

entry.ety: Lacertilia + -oid
entry.def: Like or belonging to the Lacertilia.
Lacertian.

entries.entry: ‖La*cer"tus lȧ*sẽr"tŭs n.; pl.Lacerti -tī. L., the upper arm Anat A bundle or fascicle of muscular fibers.

entry.def: Any one of several species of neuropterous insects of the genus Chrysopa and allied genera. They have delicate, lacelike wings and brilliant eyes. Their larvæ are useful in destroying aphids. Called also lace-winged fly, and goldeneyed fly.
Having thin, transparent, reticulated wings; as, the lace-winged flies.

entry.ety: OF. lachesse, fr. lache lax, indolent, F. lâche, ultimately fr. L. laxus loose, lax. See Lax
entry.def: Neglect; negligence; remissness; neglect to do a thing at the proper time; especially, a delay in asserting a claim, sufficient to cause a person to lose the right to adjuducation of the claim by a court.
entry.q: It ill became him to take advantage of such a laches with the eagerness of a shrewd attorney.

entry.ety: L. lacrimabilis, fr. lacrima a tear
entry.def: Lamentable.

entry.ety: L., lit., Christ's tears
entry.def: A rich, sweet, red Neapolitan wine.

entry.ety: Cf. F. lacrymal. See Lachrymose

sn.def: Of or pertaining to tears; as, lachrymal effusions.
Pertaining to, or secreting, tears; as, the lachrymal gland.
Pertaining to the lachrymal{2} organs; as, lachrymal bone; lachrymal duct.

entry.def: See Lachrymatory.
Tears; also, lachrymal feelings or organs.
entry.q: People go to the theaters to have . . . their risibles and lachrymals set agoing.

entry.def: Containing, or intended to contain, tears; lachrymal.
To weep.

entry.ety: L. lacrimatio, from lacrimare to shed tears, fr. lacrima tear
entry.def: The act of shedding tears; weeping.
A chemical substance that causes tears to flow; same as lacrimator.

entries.entry:
Lach"ry*ma*to*ry n.; pl. -ries #. Cf. F. lacrymatoire
Antiq A “tear-bottle;” a narrow-necked vessel found in sepulchers of the ancient Romans; -- so called from a former notion that the tears of the deceased person's friends were collected in it. Called also lachrymal or lacrymal.

entry.def: Relating to or inducing tears; -- especially of chemical substances.

entry.ety: L. lacrima tear + -form; cf. F. lacrymiforme
entry.def: Having the form of a tear; tear-shaped.

entry.ety: L. lacrymosus, better lacrimosus, fr. lacrima lacrumaalso badly spelt lachryma) a tear, for older dacrima, akin to E. tear. See Tear the secretion
entry.def: Generating or shedding tears; given to shedding tears; suffused with tears; tearful.
entry.q: You should have seen his lachrymose visnomy.

sn.def: The act of securing, fastening, or tightening, with a lace or laces.
A lace;
a thong of thin leather for uniting the ends of belts.
A rope or line passing through eyelet holes in the edge of a sail or an awning to attach it to a yard, gaff, etc.
A system of bracing bars, not crossing each other in the middle, connecting the channel bars of a compound strut.
A quantity of a substance, such as an alcoholic liquor, added to a food or a drink; as, punch with a lacing of rum.
A beating, especially with a lash.

entries.entry:
La*cin"i*a n.; pl. L. Laciniæ #. L., the lappet or flap of a garment
Bot
One of the narrow, jagged, irregular pieces or divisions which form a sort of fringe on the borders of the petals of some flowers.
A narrow, slender portion of the edge of a monophyllous calyx, or of any irregularly incised leaf.
Zoöl The posterior, inner process of the stipes on the maxillæ of insects.

entry.ety: See Lacinia

sn.def: Fringed; having a fringed border.
Cut into deep, narrow, irregular lobes; slashed.

entry.ety: See Lacinia
entry.def: Consisting of, or abounding in, very minute laciniæ.

entries.entry: ‖La*cin"u*la n.; pl.Lacinulæ #, E. Lacinulas #. NL Bot A diminutive lacinia.

entry.ety: OE. lak; cf. D. lak slander, laken to blame, OHG. lahan, AS. leán

sn.def: Blame; cause of blame; fault; crime; offense.
Deficiency; want; need; destitution; failure; as, a lack of sufficient food.
sn.q: She swooneth now and now for lakke of blood.
Let his lack of years be no impediment.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Lacked lăkt; p. pr. & vb. n. Lacking

sn.def: To blame; to find fault with.
sn.q: Love them and lakke them not.

sn.def: To be without or destitute of; to want; to need.
sn.q: If any of you lack wisdom, let him ask of God.

sn.def: To be wanting; often, impersonally, with of, meaning, to be less than, short, not quite, etc.
sn.q: What hour now? I think it lacks of twelve.
Peradventure there shall lack five of the fifty.

sn.def: To be in want.
sn.q: The young lions do lack, and suffer hunger.

entry.ety: Cf. Alack
entry.def: Exclamation of regret or surprise.

entry.ety: From Lackadaisy interj

sn.def: Affectedly pensive; languidly sentimental; dreamy.
Lacking spirit or liveliness; lethargic; listless; languid.
Indolent; lazy; idle, especially in a dreamy manner.

entry.ety: From Lackaday interj
entry.def: An expression of languor.
Lackadaisical.

entry.ety: Abbreviated from alackaday
entry.def: Alack the day; alas; -- an expression of sorrow, regret, dissatisfaction, or surprise.
One who is deficient in understanding; a witless person.
One who lacks or is in want.
See Lacquer.

entries.entry:
Lack"ey
Lackey caterpillar Zoöl the caterpillar, or larva, of any bombycid moth of the genus Clisiocampa; -- so called from its party-colored markings. The common European species (Clisiocampa neustria) is striped with blue, yellow, and red, with a white line on the back. The American species (Clisiocampa Americana and Clisiocampa sylvatica) are commonly called tent caterpillars. See Tent caterpillar, under Tent. Lackey moth Zoöl the moth which produces the lackey caterpillar.
n.; pl.Lackeys #. F. laquais; cf. Sp. & Pg. lacayo; of uncertain origin; perh. of German origin, and akin to E. lick v.
An attending male servant; a footman; a servile follower. Like a Christian footboy or a gentleman's lackey.

entry.def: To attend as a lackey; to wait upon.
entry.q: A thousand liveried angels lackey her.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Lackeyed; p. pr. & vb. n. Lackeying
entry.def: To act or serve as lackey; to pay servile attendance.
A lack of luster.

sn.def: Wanting luster or brightness.
sn.q: Lacklustereye.

sn.def: Lacking spirit, liveliness, or enthusiasm; dull.
Mediocre; as, a lackluster performance.

entry.def: See Litmus.
Of or pertaining to Laconia, a division of ancient Greece; Spartan.

def2.def: An inhabitant of Laconia; esp., a Spartan.

entry.usage: Laconic Concise. Concise means without irrelevant or superfluous matter; it is the opposite of diffuse. Laconic means concise with the additional quality of pithiness, sometimes of brusqueness.
entry.ety: L. Laconicus Laconian, Gr. ��, fr. �� a Laconian, Lacedæmonian, or Spartan: cf. F. laconique

sn.def: Expressing much in few words, after the manner of the Laconians or Spartans; brief and pithy; concise; brusque; epigrammatic. In this sense laconic is the usual form.
sn.q: I grow laconic even beyond laconicism; for sometimes I return only yes, or no, to questionary or petitionary epistles of half a yard long.
His sense was strong and his style laconic.

sn.def: Laconian; characteristic of, or like, the Spartans; hence, stern or severe; cruel; unflinching.
sn.q: His head had now felt the razor, his back the rod; all that laconical discipline pleased him well.
sn.syn: Short; brief; concise; succinct; sententious; pointed; pithy.

entry.def: Laconism.
See Laconic a.
In a laconic manner.
Same as Laconism.

entry.ety: Gr. �, fr. � to imitate Lacedæmonian manners, to speak laconically: cf. F. laconisme

sn.def: A vigorous, brief manner of expression; laconic style.
An instance of laconic style or expression.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Laconized; p. pr. & vb. n. Laconizing
entry.ety: Gr. �. See Laconic
entry.def: To imitate the manner of the Laconians, especially in brief, pithy speech, or in frugality and austerity.

entry.ety: F. lacre a sort of sealing wax, Pg. lacte, fr. laca lac. See Lac the resin
entry.def: A varnish, consisting of a solution of shellac in alcohol, often colored with gamboge, saffron, or the like; -- used for varnishing metals, papier-maché, and wood. The name is also given to varnishes made of other ingredients, esp. the tough, solid varnish of the Japanese, with which ornamental objects are made.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Lacquered; p. pr. & vb. n. Lacquering
entry.def: To cover with lacquer.
entry.q: Lacquer'dchair.

entry.def: One who lacquers, especially one who makes a business of lacquering.
The act or business of putting on lacquer; also, the coat of lacquer put on.
shedding tears; same as lachrymation.
a chemical substance that causes tears to flow; same as lachrymator.
relating to or inducing tears; -- especially of chemical substances; same as lachrymatory.

entry.ety: It. See Lachrymose
entry.def: Plaintive; -- a term applied to a mournful or pathetic movement or style.

entry.ety: F. la crosse, lit., the crosier, hooked stick. Cf. Crosier
entry.def: A game of ball, originating among the North American Indians, now the popular field sport of Canada, and played also in England and the United States. Each player carries a long-handled racket, called a “crosse”. The ball is not handled but caught with the crosse and carried on it, or tossed from it, the object being to carry it or throw it through one of the goals placed at opposite ends of the field.
See Lachrymatory n., and Lachrymal a.
See Lachrymary Lachrymatory Lachrymose.

entry.ety: L. lac lactis, milk: cf. F. laitage. See Lacteal
entry.def: The produce of animals yielding milk; milk and that which is made from it.

cs.cd: a lactam in which the amide bond is contained within a four-membered ring, which includes the amide nitrogen and the carbonyl carbon.
an antibiotic containing a beta-lactam, such as a penicillin cephalosporin, or carbapenem; also called a beta-lactam antibiotic.

entry.ety: Lactone + amido
entry.def: One of a series of anhydrides of an amido type, analogous to the lactones, as oxindol; a cyclic amide.
Pertaining to, or designating, an amido acid related to lactic acid, and called also amido-propionic acid.

entry.ety: Lactic + amide
entry.def: An acid amide derived from lactic acid, and obtained as a white crystalline substance having a neutral reaction. It is metameric with alanine.

entry.ety: L. lactans, p. pr. of lactare to suck, fr. lac lactis, milk
entry.def: Suckling; giving suck.

entry.ety: L. lac lactis, milk
entry.def: A preparation of casein from milk, used in printing calico.

entry.ety: L. lactarius, fr. lac lactis, milk: cf. F. lactaire
entry.def: Milky; full of white juice like milk.
entry.q: Lactaryor milky plants.

entry.def: a dairyhouse.

entry.ety: L. lac lactis, milk: cf. F. lactate
entry.def: A salt of lactic acid.
actively producing milk; -- of female mammals.
The secretion and yielding of milk by the mammary gland; giving suck.

entry.ety: L. lacteus milky, fr. lac lactis, milk. Cf. Galaxy Lettuce

sn.def: Pertaining to, or resembling, milk; milky; as, the lacteal fluid.
Pertaining to, or containing, chyle; as, the lacteal vessels.

entry.def: One of the lymphatic vessels which convey chyle from the small intestine through the mesenteric glands to the thoracic duct; a chyliferous vessel.
Milkily; in the manner of milk.

entry.ety: See Lacteal

sn.def: Milky; consisting of, or resembling, milk.
sn.q: Thislacteanwhiteness.

sn.def: Lacteal; conveying chyle.

entry.ety: See Lacteal

sn.def: Milky; resembling milk.
sn.q: Thelacteouscircle.

sn.def: Lacteal; conveying chyle; as, lacteous vessels.

entry.def: In a lacteous manner; after the manner of milk.

entry.ety: Cf. F. lactescence

sn.def: The state or quality of producing milk, or milklike juice; resemblance to milk; a milky color.
sn.q: This lactescence does commonly ensue when . . . fair water is suddenly poured upon the solution.

sn.def: The latex of certain plants. See Latex.

entry.ety: L. lactescens, p. pr. of lactescere to turn to milk, incho. fr. lactere to be milky, fr. lac lactis, milk: cf. F. lactescent

sn.def: Having a milky look; becoming milky.
Producing milk or a milklike juice or fluid, as the milkweed. See Latex.

entry.cs: Lactic acid Physiol. Chem a sirupy, colorless fluid, soluble in water, with an intensely sour taste and strong acid reaction. There is one center of optical activity, and this results in the observation of three isomeric modifications all having the formula C3H6O3; one is dextrorotatory (L-lactic acid), the other levorotatory (D-lactic acid), and the third an optically inactive mixture of the first two (DL-lactic acid); chemically it is 2-hydroxypropanoic acid. Sarcolactic acid or paralactic acid occurs chiefly in dead muscle tissue, while ordinary lactic acidDL-lactic acid) results from fermentation, such as the fermentation of milk by lactic acid bacteria. The two acids are alike in having the same constitution (expressed by the name ethylidene lactic acid), but the latter is optically inactive, while sarcolactic acid rotates the plane of polarization to the right. The third acid, ethylene lactic acid, accompanies sarcolactic acid in the juice of flesh, and is optically inactive. Lactic ferment an organized ferment (Bacterium lacticumorBacterium lactis), which produces lactic fermentation, decomposing the sugar of milk into carbonic and lactic acids, the latter, of which renders the milk sour, and precipitates the casein, thus giving rise to the so-called spontaneous coagulation of milk. Lactic fermentation. See under Fermentation.
entry.ety: L. lac lactis, milk: cf. F. lactique. See Lacteal, and cf. Galactic
entry.def: Of or pertaining to milk; procured from sour milk or whey; as, lactic acid; lactic fermentation, etc.

entry.ety: Lactic + anhydride
entry.def: A white, crystalline substance, obtained from lactic acid by distillation, and regarded as an anhydride; also, by extension, any similar substance.

entry.ety: l. lac lactis, milk + -ferous: cf. F. lactifère
entry.def: Bearing or containing milk or a milky fluid; as, the lactiferous vessels, cells, or tissue of various vascular plants.

entry.ety: L. lac lactis, milk + facere to make
entry.def: Producing or yielding milk.

entry.ety: L. lac lactis, milk + fugare to expel
entry.def: A medicine to check the secretion of milk, or to dispel a supposed accumulation of milk in any part of the body.

entry.ety: Lactic + imido
entry.def: One of a series of anhydrides resembling the lactams, but of an imido type; as, isatine is a lactim . Cf. Lactam.

entry.ety: Lactic + imide
entry.def: A white, crystalline substance obtained as an anhydride of alanine, and regarded as an imido derivative of lactic acid.

entry.ety: L. lac lactis, milk: cf. F. lactine. Cf. Galactin
entry.def: See Lactose.

entry.ety: L. lac lactis, milk + E. albumin
entry.def: The albumin present in milk, apparently identical with ordinary serum albumin. It is distinct from the casein of milk.

entry.ety: L. lac lactis, milk + E. butyrometer
entry.def: An instrument for determining the amount of butter fat contained in a given sample of milk.

entry.ety: L. lac lactis, milk + E. densimeter
entry.def: A form of hydrometer, specially graduated, for finding the density of milk, and thus discovering whether it has been mixed with water or some of the cream has been removed.

entry.ety: L. lac lactis, milk + meter: cf. F. lactomètre. Cf. Galactometer
entry.def: An instrument for estimating the purity or richness of milk, as a measuring glass, a specific gravity bulb, or other apparatus.

One of a series of organic compounds, being cyclic esters which may be regarded as anhydrides of certain hydroxy acids. In general, they are colorless liquids, having a weak aromatic odor. They are so called because the typical lactone is derived from lactic acid.

entry.ety: From Lactone
entry.def: Of, pertaining to, or derived from, a lactone.

entry.ety: From Lactose
entry.def: Pertaining to, or designating, an acid obtained by the oxidation of milk sugar (lactose).

entry.ety: L. lac lactis, milk + E. protein
entry.def: A peculiar albuminous body considered a normal constituent of milk.
Lactiferous.
entry.q: Lactoryor milky plants.

entry.ety: L. lac lactis + scope
entry.def: An instrument for estimating the amount of cream contained in milk by ascertaining its relative opacity.

sn.def: The main sugar present in milk, called also sugar of milk or milk sugar. When isolated pure it is obtained crystalline; it is separable from the whey by evaporation and crystallization. It is a disaccharide with the formula C12H22O11, being chemically 4-(β-D-galactosido)-D-glucose. It has a slightly sweet taste, is dextrorotary, and is much less soluble in water than either cane sugar or glucose. Formerly called lactin. When hydrolyzed it yields glucose and galactose. In cells it may be hydrolyzed by the enzyme β-galactosidase.
See Galactose.

entry.def: A physiological condition in which lactose cannot be hydrolyzed in the intestine, leading to uncomfortable gaseousness, cramps, or diarrhea after eating a lactose-containing food such as milk or ice cream. The symptoms may be prevented by ingesting a preparation of beta-galactosidase before or together with dairy products.

entry.ety: L., lettuce. See Lettuce
entry.def: A genus of composite herbs, several of which are cultivated for salad; lettuce.

entry.ety: NL., fr. L. lactuca lettuce
entry.def: The inspissated juice of the common lettuce, sometimes used as a substitute for opium.
Pertaining to, or derived from, the juice of the Lactuca virosa; -- said of certain acids.

entry.ety: From Lactuca: cf. F. lactucine
entry.def: A white, crystalline substance, having a bitter taste and a neutral reaction, and forming one of the essential ingredients of lactucarium.

entry.ety: From Lactuca
entry.def: A white, crystalline, tasteless substance, found in the milky sap of species of Lactuca, and constituting an essential ingredient of lactucarium.

entry.ety: Lactic + urea + amic
entry.def: Pertaining to, or designating, an organic amido acid, which is regarded as a derivative of lactic acid and urea.

entry.ety: Lactic + -yl
entry.def: An organic residue or radical (CH3.CHOH.CO-) derived from lactic acid.

entries.entry:
‖La*cu"na lȧ*kū"nȧ n.; pl. L. Lacunæ lȧ*kū"næ; E. Lacunas lȧ*kū"nȧz. L., ditch, pit, lake, orig., anything hollow. See Lagoon
A small opening; a small pit or depression; a small blank space; a gap or vacancy; a hiatus.
Biol A small opening; a small depression or cavity; a space, as a vacant space between the cells of plants, or one of the spaces left among the tissues of the lower animals, which serve in place of vessels for the circulation of the body fluids, or the cavity or sac, usually of very small size, in a mucous membrane.

entry.def: Pertaining to, or having, lacunæ; as, a lacunar circulation.

entries.entry: La*cu"nar n.; pl. E. Lacunars lȧ*kū"nẽrz, L. Lacunaria lăk`�*nā"rĭ*ȧ. L Arch The ceiling or under surface of any part, especially when it consists of compartments, sunk or hollowed without spaces or bands between the panels. Gwilt One of the sunken panels in such a ceiling.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: A lacuna.

entry.ety: L. lacunosus full of holes or hollows; cf. F. lacuneux. See Lacuna
entry.def: Furrowed or pitted; having shallow cavities or lacunæ; as, a lacunose leaf.

entry.cs: Lacustrine deposits Geol the deposits which have been accumulated in fresh-water areas. Lacustrine dwellings. See Lake dwellings, under Lake.
entry.ety: L. lacus lake: cf. F. lacustral lacustre
entry.def: Found in, or pertaining to, lakes or ponds, or growing in them; as, lacustrine flowers.
Ornamentation by means of lacquer painted or carved, or simply colored, sprinkled with gold or the like; -- said especially of Oriental work of this kind.
p. p. of Lead, to guide.

entry.cs: Lad's love. Bot See Boy's love, under Boy.
entry.ety: OE. ladde, of Celtic origin; cf. W. llawd, Ir. lath. √123. Cf. Lass

sn.def: A boy; a youth; a stripling.
sn.q: Cupid is a knavishlad.
There is a lad here, which hath five barley loaves and two small fishes.

sn.def: A companion; a comrade; a mate.

entry.ety: L. ladanum ledanum, Gr. la`danon lh`danon, fr. lh^don name of a shrub, mastic; cf. Per. lādan lāden. Cf. Laudanum
entry.def: A gum resin gathered from certain Oriental species of Cistus. It has a pungent odor and is chiefly used in making plasters, and for fumigation.
imp. of Lead, to guide.

entry.cs: Fish ladder. See under Fish. Ladder beetle Zoöl an American leaf beetle (Chrysomela scalaris). The elytra are silvery white, striped and spotted with green; the under wings are rose-colored. It feeds upon the linden tree. Ladder handle an iron rail at the side of a vertical fixed ladder, to grasp with the hand in climbing. Ladder shell Zoöl a spiral marine shell of the genus Scalaria. See Scalaria.
entry.ety: OE. laddre, AS. hlǣder hlǣdder; akin to OFries. hladder, OHG. leitara, G. leiter, and from the root of E. lean, v. √40. See Lean v. i., and cf. Climax

sn.def: A frame usually portable, of wood, metal, or rope, for ascent and descent, consisting of two side pieces to which are fastened cross strips or rounds forming steps.
sn.q: Some the engines play, And some, more bold, mount ladders to the fire.

sn.def: That which resembles a ladder in form or use;
that by means of which one attains to eminence; as, to climb the corporate ladder .
sn.q: Lowliness is young ambition's ladder.

entry.def: a chair with a ladder-back{2}.

sn.def: a chair backrest consisting of 2 uprights with several connecting slats.

entry.def: Having horizontal stripes on the back, reminiscent of a ladder; -- used of birds; as, a ladder-backed woodpecker.
Same as hook-and-ladder company hook-and-ladder truck.
resistant to runs or (in Britain) ladders; -- of hosiery.
A lad; a male sweetheart.

entry.vmorph: imp. Laded; p. p. Laded Laden lād'n; p. pr. & vb. n. Lading
entry.ety: AS. hladan to heap, load, draw (water); akin to D. & G. laden to load, OHG. hladan ladan, Icel. hlaða, Sw. ladda, Dan. lade, Goth. afhlaþan. Cf. Load Ladle Lathe for turning, Last a load

sn.def: To load; to put a burden or freight on or in; -- generally followed by that which receives the load, as the direct object.
sn.q: And they laded their asses with the corn.

sn.def: To throw in or out, with a ladle or dipper; to dip; as, to lade water out of a tub, or into a cistern.
sn.q: And chides the sea that sunders him from thence, Saying, he'll lade it dry to have his way.

sn.def: To transfer (the molten glass) from the pot to the forming table.

entry.ety: See Lade v. t.

sn.def: To draw water.
To admit water by leakage, as a ship, etc.

entry.ety: Prov. E., a ditch or drain. Cf. Lode Lead to conduct

sn.def: The mouth of a river.
A passage for water; a ditch or drain.

entry.def: One who leads a pack horse; a miller's servant.
Loaded; freighted; burdened; as, a laden vessel; a laden heart.
entry.q: Ah sinful nation, a people laden with iniquity.
A ship laden with gold.

entry.def: Ladylike; not rough; gentle.
entry.q: Stroked with aladiedland.

entry.def: The small-flowered Fuchsia (Fuchsia coccinea), and other closely related species.

entry.ety: Lady + -fy

entry.ety: From L. Latinus Latin. See Latin

sn.def: A Romansch dialect spoken in some parts of Switzerland and the Tyrol.
A person speaking Ladin as a mother tongue.

entry.cs: Bill of lading. See under Bill.

sn.def: The act of loading.
That which lades or constitutes a load or cargo; freight; burden; as, the lading of a ship.

entries.entry: La*di"no n.; pl.Ladinos #. Sp One of the half-breed descendants of whites and Indians; a mestizo; -- so called throughout Central America. They are usually of a yellowish orange tinge.

La*di"no n.; pl. -nos
The mixed Spanish and Hebrew language spoken by Sephardim.
A cunningly vicious horse. Southeastern U. S
A ladin.

entry.def: A little lad.

cs.cd: the wood of a South African tree (Cassine Colpoon), used for carving.

entry.ety: AS. hlædel, fr. hladan to load, drain. See Lade v. t.

sn.def: A cuplike spoon, often of large size, with a long handle, used in lading or dipping.
sn.q: When the materials of glass have been kept long in fusion, the mixture casts up the superfluous salt, which the workmen take off with ladles.

The float of a mill wheel; -- called also ladle board.

sd.def: An instrument for drawing the charge of a cannon.
A ring, with a handle or handles fitted to it, for carrying shot.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Ladled; p. pr. & vb. n. Ladling
entry.def: To take up and convey in a ladle; to dip with, or as with, a ladle; as, to ladle out soup; to ladle oatmeal into a kettle.

entries.entry: La"dle*ful n.; pl.Ladlefuls. A quantity sufficient to fill a ladle.

entry.ety: Sp. ladron, L. latro servant, robber, Gr. (�) a servant
entry.def: A robber; a pirate; hence, loosely, a rogue or rascal.

entries.entry:
La"dy
Ladies' man a man who affects the society of ladies. Lady altar an altar in a lady chapel. Shipley. Lady chapel a chapel dedicated to the Virgin Mary. Lady court the court of a lady of the manor. Lady crab Zoöl a handsomely spotted swimming crab (Platyonichus ocellatus) very common on the sandy shores of the Atlantic coast of the United States. Lady fern. Bot See Female fern, under Female, and Illust. of Fern. Lady in waiting a lady of the queen's household, appointed to wait upon or attend the queen. Lady Mass a Mass said in honor of the Virgin Mary. Shipley. Lady of the manor a lady having jurisdiction of a manor; also, the wife of a manor lord. Lady's maid a maidservant who dresses and waits upon a lady. Thackeray. Our Lady the Virgin Mary.
lā"d� n.; pl.Ladies lā"dĭz. OE. ladi læfdi, AS. hlǣfdige hlǣfdie; AS. hlāf loaf + a root of uncertain origin, possibly akin to E. dairy. See Loaf, and cf. Lord
A woman who looks after the domestic affairs of a family; a mistress; the female head of a household. Agar, the handmaiden of Sara, whence comest thou, and whither goest thou? The which answered, Fro the face of Sara my lady.
A woman having proprietary rights or authority; mistress; -- a feminine correlative of lord. Lord orladyof high degree. Of all these bounds, even from this line to this, . . . We make thee lady.
A woman to whom the particular homage of a knight was paid; a woman to whom one is devoted or bound; a sweetheart. The soldier here his wasted store supplies, And takes new valor from his lady's eyes.
A woman of social distinction or position. In England, a title prefixed to the name of any woman whose husband is not of lower rank than a baron, or whose father was a nobleman not lower than an earl. The wife of a baronet or knight has the title of Lady by courtesy, but not by right.
A woman of refined or gentle manners; a well-bred woman; -- the feminine correlative of gentleman.
A wife; -- not now in approved usage.
Hence: Any woman; as, a lounge for ladies; a cleaning lady ; also used in combination; as, saleslady .
Zoöl The triturating apparatus in the stomach of a lobster; -- so called from a fancied resemblance to a seated female figure. It consists of calcareous plates.
La"dy a. Belonging or becoming to a lady; ladylike. lady lady trifles.” Shak.

entry.def: Same as ladybird.
entry.syn: ladybug, lady beetle, ladybird, ladybird beetle.

entry.note: ☞ The ladybirds are usually more or less hemispherical in form, with a smooth, polished surface, and often colored red, brown, or black, with small spots of brighter colors. Both the larvæ and the adult beetles of most species feed on aphids, and for this reason they are very beneficial to agriculture and horticulture.
entry.ety: Equiv. to, bird of Our Lady
entry.def: Any one of numerous species of small beetles of the genus Coccinella and allied genera (family Coccinellidæ); -- called also ladybug ladyclock lady cow lady fly ladybeetle, and lady beetle. Coccinella seplempunctata in one of the common European species. See Coccinella.
Same as Ladybird.
See Ladybird.
The day of the annunciation of the Virgin Mary, March 25. See Annunciation.
A large, handsome oceanic fish (Albula vulpes), found both in the Atlantic and Pacific oceans; -- called also bonefish grubber French mullet, and macabé.
A labroid fish (Harpe rufa) of Florida and the West Indies.
The state or quality of being a lady; the personality of a lady.
a lady appointed to attend to a queen or princess.
A gallant who captivates the hearts of women.
entry.q: A renowned dandy andlady-killer.

entry.def: The art or practice of captivating the hearts of women.
entry.q: Better for the sake of womankind that this dangerous dog should leave off lady-killing.

entry.note: ☞ The diminutive does not refer to size, but is equivalent to “dear.”
entry.ety: Lady + -kin
entry.def: A little lady; -- applied by the writers of Queen Elizabeth's time, in the abbreviated form Lakin, to the Virgin Mary.

sn.def: Like a lady in appearance or manners; well-bred.
sn.q: She was ladylike, too, after the manner of the feminine gentility of those days.

sn.def: Becoming or suitable to a lady; as, ladylike manners.
sn.q: With fingersladylike.

sn.def: Delicate; tender; feeble; effeminate.
sn.q: Too ladylike a long fatigue to bear.

entry.def: The quality or state of being ladylike.
A sweetheart or mistress.
A West Indian shrub (Brunfelsia americana) with fragrant showy yellowish-white flowers.
entry.syn: lady of the night, Brunfelsia americana.

entry.def: The common bedstraw (Galium verum); also, a slender-leaved East Indian shrub (Pharnaceum Mollugo), with white flowers in umbels.

entry.note: ☞ This term is sometimes applied to other plants of the same genus.
entry.def: A climbing plant with fragrant blossoms (Clematis vitalba).
A kind of broadcloth of light weight, used for women's dresses, cloaks, etc.
An umbelliferous plant (Scandix Pecten-Veneris), its clusters of long slender fruits remotely resembling a comb.
An herb growing in dense tufts; the thrift (Armeria vulgaris).
An erect or climbing shrub (Fuchsia coccinea) of Brazil with deep pink to red flowers.

entry.note: different from lady's fingers

sn.def: The kidney vetch, Anthyllis vulneraria; called also lady's fingers.
A variety of small cake of about the dimensions of a finger.
A long, slender variety of the potato.
One of the branchiæ of the lobster.

A tall coarse annual (Abelmoschus esculentus) of Old World tropics widely cultivated in southern U. S. and West Indies for its long mucilaginous green pods used as basis for soups and stews; it is sometimes placed in the genus Hibiscus.
sn.syn: okra, gumbo, okra plant, Abelmoschus esculentus, Hibiscus esculentus.

entry.def: Ribbon grass.
A plant of the genus Briza Briza media); a variety of quaking grass.
The rank or position of a lady; -- given as a title (preceded by her or your).
entry.q: Your ladyship shall observe their gravity.

entry.def: A slender climbing plant; dodder.
Same as lady's slipper.
See Venus's looking-glass, under Venus.

entries.entry: La"dy's man"tle lā"dĭz măn"t'l. Bot A genus of rosaceous herbs (Alchemilla), esp. the European Alchemilla vulgaris, which has leaves with rounded and finely serrated lobes.
La"dy's seal" lā"dĭz sēl".Bot The European Solomon's seal (Polygonatum verticillatum). The black bryony (Tamus communis).

entry.def: Any orchidaceous plant of the genus Cypripedium, the labellum of which resembles a slipper. Less commonly, in the United States, the garden balsam (Impatiens Balsamina).
A plant of the genus Cardamine Cardamine pratensis); cuckoo flower.
The harebell.
An annual weed (Polygonum Persicaria), having a lanceolate leaf with a dark spot in the middle.
A name given to several species of the orchidaceous genus Spiranthes, in which the white flowers are set in spirals about a slender axis and remotely resemble braided hair.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. � a dark, furious storm
entry.def: A genus of huge, carnivorous, dinosaurian reptiles from the Cretaceous formation of the United States. They had very large hind legs and tail, and are supposed to have been bipedal. Some of the species were about eighteen feet high.
See Lammergeir.
One of the Læmodipoda.

entry.ety: NL., from Gr. � throat + � twice + �, �, foot
entry.def: A division of amphipod Crustacea, in which the abdomen is small or rudimentary and the legs are often reduced to five pairs. The whale louse, or Cyamus, and Caprella are examples.
Of or pertaining to the Læmodipoda.
The fourth Sunday of Lent; -- so named from the Latin word Lætarerejoice), the first word in the antiphone of the introit sung that day in the Roman Catholic service.

entry.ety: See Levigate
entry.def: Having a smooth surface, as if polished.
A prefix. See Levo.
Same as Levorotatory. Cf. Dextrorotatory.
See Levulose.
The dollar fish.
A market fish, the goody, or spot (Liostomus xanthurus), of the southern coast of the United States.
p. p. of Leave.
imp. of Leave.

entry.ety: Of Celtic origin: cf. Gael. & Ir. lagweak, feeble, faint, W. llag llac, slack, loose, remiss, sluggish; prob. akin to E. lax languid

sn.def: Coming tardily after or behind; slow; tardy.
sn.q: Came too lag to see him buried.

sn.def: Last; long-delayed; -- obsolete, except in the phrase lag end.
sn.q: Thelag endof my life.

sn.def: Last made; hence, made of refuse; inferior.
sn.q: Lagsouls.

cs.cd: the interval by which the time of high water falls behind the mean time, in the first and third quarters of the moon; -- opposed to priming of the tide, or the acceleration of the time of high water, in the second and fourth quarters; depending on the relative positions of the sun and moon.
an iron bolt with a square head, a sharp-edged thread, and a sharp point, adapted for screwing into wood; a screw for fastening lags.

sn.def: One who lags; that which comes in last.
sn.q: Thelagof all the flock.

sn.def: The fag-end; the rump; hence, the lowest class.
sn.q: The common lag of people.

sn.def: The amount of retardation of anything, as of a valve in a steam engine, in opening or closing.
See Graylag.

The failing behind or retardation of one phenomenon with respect to another to which it is closely related; as, the lag of magnetization compared with the magnetizing force (hysteresis); the lag of the current in an alternating circuit behind the impressed electro-motive force which produced it.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Lagged; p. pr. & vb. n. Lagging
entry.def: To walk or more slowly; to stay or fall behind; to linger or loiter.
entry.q: I shall notlagbehind.
entry.syn: To loiter; linger; saunter; delay; be tardy.

sn.def: To cause to lag; to slacken.
sn.q: Tolaghis flight.

sn.def: To cover, as the cylinder of a steam engine, with lags. See Lag n., 4.

entry.def: One transported for a crime.
To transport for crime.
entry.q: She lags us if we poach.

entry.def: See Ligan.

entry.ety: See Alligator
entry.def: An alligator.

entries.entry: ‖La*ge"na n.; pl. L. Lagenæ #, E. Lagenas #. L., a flask; cf. Gr. �, � Anat The terminal part of the cochlea in birds and most reptiles; an appendage of the sacculus, corresponding to the cochlea, in fishes and amphibians.

entry.ety: See Lagena
entry.def: Like, or pertaining to, Lagena, a genus of Foraminifera having a straight, chambered shell.

entry.ety: See Lagena, and -form
entry.def: Shaped like a bottle or flask; flag-shaped.
A small genus of herbs of Australia and South America having small solidary white or purple flowers similar to true daisies of genus Bellis.
Lager beer.

entry.ety: G. lager bed, storehouse + bier beer. See Lair, and Beer
entry.def: Originally a German beer, but now also made in immense quantities in the United States; -- so called from its being laid up or stored for some months before use.
Wine which has been kept for some time in the cellar.

entry.ety: Lag + -ard
entry.def: Slow; sluggish; backward.
One who lags; a loiterer.
A laggard.

sn.def: The clothing (esp., an outer, wooden covering), as of a steam cylinder, applied to prevent the radiation of heat; a covering of lags; -- called also deading and cleading.
Lags, collectively; narrow planks extending from one rib to another in the centering of arches.

entry.def: In a lagging manner; loiteringly.
Laggingly.

entry.ety: Etym. uncertain

sn.def: In Louisiana, a trifling present given to customers by tradesmen; a gratuity.
sn.q: Lagniappe . . .is something thrown in, gratis, for good measure.

sn.def: A tip or gratuity.
Anything obtained gratuitously or unexpectedly.

entry.def: One of the Lagomorpha.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. lagw`s a hare + morfh` form
entry.def: an order of rodent-like mammals, comprising the hares, rabbits, and pikas. They have four incisors in the upper jaw. Called also Duplicidentata. They were formerly classified together with the rodents, but the Rodentia and Lagomorpha are now classed as separate orders.

cs.cd: a coral island consisting of a narrow reef encircling a lagoon.

entry.ety: It. or Sp. laguna, L. lacuna ditch, pool, pond, lacus lake. See Lake, and cf. Lacuna

sn.def: A shallow sound, channel, pond, or lake, especially one into which the sea flows; as, the lagoons of Venice.
A lake in a coral island, often occupying a large portion of its area, and usually communicating with the sea. See Atoll.

entry.ety: NL. lagophtalmia, fr. Gr. lagw`s hare + 'ofqalmo`s eye; -- so called from the notion that a hare sleeps with his eyes open.]
entry.def: A morbid condition in which the eye stands wide open, giving a peculiar staring appearance.

entry.ety: Gr. lagw`s a hare + poy`s podo`s, foot
entry.def: Having a dense covering of long hair, like the foot of a hare.
A mammal genus comprising the hare wallabies.
A mammal genus comprising the viscachas.
A mammal genus comprising the woolly monkeys.

entry.ety: Norw. lagting lagthing; lag company, society (akin to E. law lay) + ting thing, parliament. See Thing
entry.def: See Legislatature, below.
See Lagoon.

entry.ety: L. laicus: cf. F. laïque. See Lay laic
entry.def: Of or pertaining to a layman or the laity.
entry.q: Laicalliterature.
An unprincipled, unedified, and laic rabble.

entry.def: A layman.
The state or quality of being laic; the state or condition of a layman.
As a layman; after the manner of a layman; as, to treat a matter laically .

cs.cd: paper marked with parallel lines or water marks, as if ribbed, from parallel wires in the mold. It is called blue laid cream laid, etc., according to its color.

entry.def: of Lay.
Ugly; loathsome.
entry.q: This laidly and loathsome worm.

entry.def: p. p. of Lie v. i.
See Lanier.

entry.ety: OE. leir, AS. leger; akin to D. leger, G. lager couch, lair, OHG. legar, Goth. ligrs, and to E. lie. See Lie to be prostrate, and cf. Layer Leaguer

sn.def: A place in which to lie or rest; especially, the bed or couch of a wild beast.
A burying place.
A pasture; sometimes, food.

entry.ety: See Lord
entry.def: A lord; a landholder, esp. one who holds land directly of the crown.
The state of being a laird; an estate; landed property.
See Lamaism.

entry.ety: F., let alone
entry.def: Noninterference; -- an axiom of some political economists, deprecating interference of government by attempts to foster or regulate commerce, manufactures, etc., by bounty or by restriction; as, the doctrine of laissez faire; the laissez faire system of government.

entry.ety: See Lay a.

sn.def: The people, as distinguished from the clergy; the body of the people not in orders.
sn.q: A rising up of the laity against the sacerdotal caste.

sn.def: The state of a layman.
Those who are not of a certain profession, as law or medicine, in distinction from those belonging to it.

entry.def: Sap green.

entry.ety: F. laque, fr. Per. See Lac
entry.def: A pigment formed by combining some coloring matter, usually by precipitation, with a metallic oxide or earth, esp. with aluminium hydrate; as, madder lake; Florentine lake; yellow lake, etc.

entry.ety: Cf. G. laken
entry.def: A kind of fine white linen, formerly in use.

entry.ety: AS. lācan læcan, to spring, jump, lāc play, sport, or fr. Icel. leika to play, sport; both akin to Goth. laikan to dance. √120. Cf. Knowledge
entry.def: To play; to sport.

entry.note: ☞ Lakes are for the most part of fresh water; the salt lakes, like the Great Salt Lake of Utah, have usually no outlet to the ocean.
entry.cs:
Lake dwellers Ethnol people of a prehistoric race, or races, which inhabited different parts of Europe. Their dwellings were built on piles in lakes, a short distance from the shore. Their relics are common in the lakes of Switzerland. Lake dwellings Archæol dwellings built over a lake, sometimes on piles, and sometimes on rude foundations kept in place by piles; specifically, such dwellings of prehistoric times. Lake dwellings are still used by many savage tribes. Called also lacustrine dwellings. See Crannog. Lake fly Zoöl any one of numerous species of dipterous flies of the genus Chironomus. In form they resemble mosquitoes, but they do not bite. The larvæ live in lakes. Lake herring Zoöl the cisco (Coregonus Artedii).
Lake poets Lake school
a collective name originally applied in contempt, but now in honor, to Southey, Coleridge, and Wordsworth, who lived in the lake country of Cumberland, England, Lamb and a few others were classed with these by hostile critics. Called also lakers and lakists. Lake sturgeon Zoöl a sturgeon (Acipenser rubicundus), of moderate size, found in the Great Lakes and the Mississippi River. It is used as food. Lake trout Zoöl any one of several species of trout and salmon; in Europe, esp. Salmo fario; in the United States, esp. Salvelinus namaycush of the Great Lakes, and of various lakes in New York, Eastern Maine, and Canada. A large variety of brook trout (Salvelinus fontinalis), inhabiting many lakes in New England, is also called lake trout. See Namaycush. Lake whitefish. Zoöl See Whitefish. Lake whiting Zoöl an American whitefish (Coregonus Labradoricus), found in many lakes in the Northern United States and Canada. It is more slender than the common whitefish.
entry.ety: AS. lac, L. lacus; akin to AS. lagu lake, sea, Icel. lögr; OIr. loch; cf. Gr. la`kkos pond, tank. Cf. Loch Lough
entry.def: A large body of water contained in a depression of the earth's surface, and supplied from the drainage of a more or less extended area.
See Lake dwellers, under Lake.
land bordering a lake.
A little lake.
One that is connected with a lake or lakes, as in habitation, toil, etc.:
One of the poets of the Lake school. See Lake poets, under Lake n.
A fish living in, or taken from, a lake, esp. the namaycush.
A lake steamer or canal boat.
entry.q: The bridge tender . . . thought the Cowies “a little mite” longer than that laker.

entry.def: the shore of a lake.
the shore of a lake.
The water pepper (Polygonum Hydropiper), an aquatic plant of Europe and North America.
Same as Lac, one hundred thousand.
See Ladykin.
See Lack.
Pertaining to a lake.

entry.ety: From Lake the pigment
entry.def: Transparent; -- said of blood rendered transparent by the action of some solvent agent on the red blood corpuscles.

entry.ety: L. lallare to sing lalla, or lullaby: cf. F. lallation
entry.def: An imperfect enunciation of the letter r, in which it sounds like l.
The powdered leaves of the baobab tree, used by the Africans to mix in their soup, as the southern negroes use powdered sassafras. Cf. Couscous.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Lammed; p. pr. & vb. n. Lamming
entry.ety: Icel. lemja to beat, or lama to bruise, both fr. lami lama, lame. See Lame
entry.def: To beat soundly; to thrash.
See Llama.

cs.cd: the supreme pontiff in the lamaistic hierarchy. Until the Chinese occupied Tibet he resided in Lhasa, but now (1998) is in exile. See Lamaism.

entry.ety: Tibet. blamapronounced lä"ma) a chief, a high priest
entry.def: In Tibet, Mongolia, etc., a priest or monk of the belief called Lamaism.
Of or pertaining to Lamaism.
A modified form of Buddhism which prevails in Tibet, Mongolia, and some adjacent parts of Asia; -- so called from the name of its priests. See 2d Lama.
One who believes in Lamaism.
Of or pertaining to Lamaism.

entry.ety: F. lamantin lamentin, prob. from the name of the animal in the Antilles. Cf. Manater
entry.def: The manatee.
Pertaining to, or involved in, the doctrines of Lamarckianism.
Lamarckism.

entry.ety: From Lamarck, a distinguished French naturalist
entry.def: The theory that structural variations, characteristic of species and genera, are produced in animals and plants by the direct influence of physical environments, and esp., in the case of animals, by effort, or by use or disuse of certain organs. It is a discredited theory, not believed by modern biologists.

entry.ety: See 2d Lama
entry.def: A monastery or convent of lamas, in Tibet, Mongolia, etc.

entry.cs:
Lamb of God The Lamb
Script the Jesus Christ, in allusion to the paschal lamb. The twelve apostles of the Lamb. Rev. xxi. 14. Behold the Lamb of God, which taketh away the sin of the world. John i. 29. Lamb's lettuce Bot an annual plant with small obovate leaves (Valerianella olitoria), often used as a salad; corn salad.
lamb lettuce
Lamb's tongue a carpenter's plane with a deep narrow bit, for making curved grooves. Knight. Lamb's wool. The wool of a lamb. Ale mixed with the pulp of roasted apples; -- probably from the resemblance of the pulp of roasted apples to lamb's wool. Obs Goldsmith.
entry.ety: AS. lamb; akin to D. & Dan. lam, G. & Sw. lamm, OS., Goth., & Icel. lamb

sn.def: The young of the sheep.
Any person who is as innocent or gentle as a lamb.
A simple, unsophisticated person; in the cant of the Stock Exchange, one who ignorantly speculates and is victimized.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Lambed; p. pr. & vb. n. Lambing
entry.def: To bring forth a lamb or lambs, as sheep.
A feast at the time of shearing lambs.
Same as lambaste.

entry.ety: Lam + baste to beat
entry.def: To beat severely;
to beat with a cane.

sn.def: to scold, reprimand, or berate harshly.
sn.syn: rebuke, rag, reproof, reprimand, jaw, dress down, scold, chide, berate, bawl out, jaw at, remonstrate with, chew out, chew up, have words with, lambast.

entry.ety: L. lambere to lick. See Lambent
entry.def: Taken by licking with the tongue.
entry.q: Sirups andlambativemedicines.

entry.def: A medicine taken by licking with the tongue; a lincture.

cs.cd: a moth so called from a mark on its wings, resembling the Greek letter lambda (Λ).

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. la`mbda

sn.def: The name of the Greek letter Λ, λ, corresponding with the English letter L, l.
The point of junction of the sagittal and lambdoid sutures of the skull.
A subatomic particle carrying no charge, having a mass equal to 2183 times that of an electron; it decays rapidly, typically forming a nucleon and a pion.

entry.ety: L. lambdacismus, Gr. �, fr. la`mbda the letter lambda (Λ)

sn.def: A fault in speaking or in composition, which consists in too frequent use of the letter l, or in doubling it erroneously.
A defect in pronunciation of the letter l when doubled, which consists in giving it a sound as if followed by y, similar to that of the letters lli in billion.
The use of the sound of l for that of r in pronunciation; lallation; as, Amelican for American.

entry.ety: Gr. �, la`mbda the letter lambda (Λ) + e"i^dos shape
entry.def: Shaped like the Greek letter lambda (Λ); as, the lambdoid suture between the occipital and parietal bones of the skull.
Same as Lambdoid.

entry.ety: L. lambens -enlis, p. pr. of lambere to lick; akin to lap. See Lap to drink by licking

sn.def: Playing on the surface; touching lightly; gliding over.
sn.q: Alambentflame.
Alambentstyle.

sn.def: Twinkling or gleaming; fickering.
sn.q: Thelambentpurity of the stars.

entry.def: A small genus of Australian shrubs.

entry.ety: So called from Lambert, an English botanist
entry.def: The gigantic sugar pine of California and Oregon (Pinus Lambertiana). It has the leaves in fives, and cones a foot long. The timber is soft, and like that of the white pine of the Eastern States.
A genus of scorpion shells of shallow tropical waters of eastern hemisphere.

A small American ericaceous shrub (Kalmia angustifolia), resembling mountain laurel but having narrower leaves and small red flowers; -- called also calfkill sheepkill sheep laurel, etc. It is supposed to poison young sheep and other animals that eat it at times when the snow is deep and they cannot find other food.
entry.syn: sheep laurel, pig laurel, Kalmia angustifolia.

entry.def: A small lamb.
Like a lamb; gentle; meek; inoffensive.

entry.ety: Cf. F. lambeau. Cf. Label
entry.def: Same as Base n., 19.

entry.ety: F. Cf. Lamboys Label

sn.def: A kind of pendent scarf or covering attached to the helmet, to protect it from wet or heat.
A leather flap hanging from a cuirass.
A piece of ornament drapery or short decorative hanging, pendent from a shelf or from the casing above a window, hiding the curtain fixtures, or the like.
The skin of a lamb; especially, a skin dressed with the wool on, and used as a mat. Also used adjectively.
A kind of woolen.

entry.def: See Lansquenet.

entry.note: It is sometimes collected from the wild and eaten as a vegetable
entry.def: A name given to several common weedy European plants of the Goosefoot family, introduced into N. America, and sometimes used as pot herbs, as Chenopodium album and Atriplex patulsa.
entry.syn: lamb's quarters, pigweed, wild spinach, Chenopodium album.

entry.def: Lambdoid.

cs.cd: a person who can not fulfill his contracts.

An elected politician who is completing a term after having been defeated at an election; also, an office holder who cannot or chooses not to run again for the same office; -- So called from the presumed lack of political power of one who is soon to be out of office.
Any office holder who is serving out a term after a replacement has been selected.

entry.ety: OE. lame, AS. lama; akin to D. lam, G. lahm, OHG., Dan., & Sw. lam, Icel. lami, Russ. lomate to break, lomota rheumatism

sd.def: Moving with pain or difficulty on account of injury, defect, or temporary obstruction of a function; as, a lame leg, arm, or muscle.
To some degree disabled by reason of the imperfect action of a limb; crippled; as, a lame man.

sn.def: Hence, hobbling; limping; inefficient; imperfect; as, a lame answer.
sn.q: Alameendeavor.
O, most lame and impotent conclusion!

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Lamed lāmd; p. pr. & vb. n. Laming
entry.def: To make lame.
entry.q: If you happen to let child fall and lame it.

entry.def: The 12th letter of the Hebrew alphabet, corresponding to l.
See Lamella.

entries.entry:
La*mel"la n.; pl. L. Lamellæ #, E. Lamellas #. L. lamella, dim. of lamina plate, leaf, layer: cf. F. lamelle. Cf. Lamina Omelet
a thin plate or scale of anything, as a thin scale growing from the petals of certain flowers; or one of the thin plates or scales of which certain shells are composed.

entry.ety: Cf. F. lamellaire
entry.def: Flat and thin; lamelliform; composed of lamellæ.
Of or pertaining to lamella or to lamellæ; lamellar.

entry.ety: See Lamella
entry.def: Composed of, or furnished with, thin plates or scales. See Illust. of Antennæ.
One of the Lamellibranchiaalso called Pelecypoda). Also used adjectively.

entry.note: ☞ They usually have two (rarely but one) flat, lamelliform gills on each side of the body. They have an imperfectly developed head, concealed within the shell, whence they are called Acephala . Called also Conchifera, and Pelecypoda. See Bivalve.
entry.ety: NL. See lamella, and Branchia Branchiate
entry.def: An earlier name for the class of Mollusca including all those that have bivalve shells, as the clams, oysters, mussels, etc., now called Pelecypoda or Bivalvia .
Having lamellar gills; belonging to the Lamellibranchiaalso called Pelecypoda).

def2.def: One of the Lamellibranchiaalso called Pelecypoda).

entry.ety: Lamella + L. cornu a horn: cf. F. lamellicorne. See Lamella
entry.def: Having antennæ terminating in a group of flat lamellæ; -- said of certain coleopterous insects.
Terminating in a group of flat lamellæ; -- said of antennæ.

entry.ety: NL. See Lamellicorn
entry.def: A group of lamellicorn, plant-eating beetles; -- called also Lamellicornes.

entry.ety: Lamella + -ferous: cf. F. lamellifère
