entry.def: Bearing, or composed of, lamellæ, or thin layers, plates, or scales; foliated.

entry.ety: Lamella + -form : cf. F. lamelliforme
entry.def: Thin and flat; scalelike; lamellar.

entry.ety: Lamella + rostral : cf. F. lamellirostre
entry.def: Having a lamellate bill, as ducks and geese.

entry.ety: NL. See Lamella, and Rostrum
entry.def: A group of birds embracing the Anseres and flamingoes, in which the bill is lamellate.

entry.ety: Cf. F. lamelleux
entry.def: Composed of, or having, lamellæ; lamelliform.

entry.ety: See Lame
entry.def: In a lame, crippled, disabled, or imperfect manner; as, to walk lamely; a figure lamely drawn.
The condition or quality of being lame; as, the lameness of an excuse or an argument.

entry.ety: F. lamenter, L. lamentari, fr. lamentum a lament
entry.def: To express or feel sorrow; to weep or wail; to mourn.
entry.q: Jeremiah lamented for Josiah.
Ye shall weep and lament, but the world shall rejoice.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Lamented; p. pr. & vb. n. Lamenting
entry.def: To mourn for; to bemoan; to bewail.
entry.q: One laughed at follies, one lamented crimes.
entry.syn: To deplore; mourn; bewail. See Deplore.

entry.ety: L. lamentum. Cf. Lament v.

sn.def: Grief or sorrow expressed in complaints or cries; lamentation; a wailing; a moaning; a weeping.
sn.q: Torment, and loud lament, and furious rage.

sn.def: An elegy or mournful ballad, or the like.

entry.ety: L. lamentabilis: cf. F. lamentable

sn.def: Mourning; sorrowful; expressing grief; as, a lamentable countenance.
sn.q: Lamentableeye.

sn.def: Fitted to awaken lament; to be lamented; sorrowful; pitiable; regrettable; unfortunate; as, a lamentable misfortune, or error.
sn.q: Lamentablehelplessness.

sn.def: Miserable; pitiful; paltry; -- in a contemptuous or ridiculous sense.

entry.ety: F. lamentation, L. lamentatio

sn.def: The act of bewailing; audible expression of sorrow; wailing; moaning.
sn.q: In Rama was there a voice heard, lamentation and weeping.

sn.def: A book of the Old Testament attributed to the prophet Jeremiah, and taking its name from the nature of its contents.

entry.def: Mourned for; bewailed.
entry.q: This humble praise, lamented shade ! receive.

entry.def: One who laments.
See Lamantin.
Lamentation.
entry.q: Lamentings heard i' the air.

entry.def: In a lamenting manner.

entry.ety: F. lame a thin plate, L. lamina
entry.def: Small steel plates combined together so as to slide one upon the other and form a piece of armor.

entry.ety: Cf. It. lametta, dim. of lama a thin plate
entry.def: Foil or wire made of gold, silver, or brass.

entry.ety: L., fr. Gr. �
entry.def: A monster capable of assuming a woman's form, who was said to devour human beings or suck their blood; a vampire; a sorceress; a witch.

entries.entry:
Lam"i*na lăm"ĭ*nȧ n.; pl. L. Laminæ -nē E. Laminas -nȧz. L. cf. Lamella
A thin plate or scale; a layer or coat lying over another; -- said of thin plates or platelike substances, as of bone or minerals.
Bot The blade of a leaf; the broad, expanded portion of a petal or sepal of a flower.
Zoöl A thin plate or scale; specif., one of the thin, flat processes composing the vane of a feather.

entry.def: The quality or state of being laminable.
Capable of being split into laminæ or thin plates, as mica; capable of being extended under pressure into a thin plate or strip.
entry.q: When a body can be readily extended in all directions under the hammer, it is said to be malleable; and when into fillets under the rolling press, it is said to be laminable.

entry.ety: Cf. F. laminaire. See Lamina
entry.def: In, or consisting of, thin plates or layers; having the form of a thin plate or lamina.

entry.ety: NL. See Lamina
entry.def: A genus of great seaweeds with long and broad fronds; kelp, or devil's apron. The fronds commonly grow in clusters, and are sometimes from thirty to fifty feet in length. See Illust. of Kelp.
Pertaining to seaweeds of the genus Laminaria, or to that zone of the sea (from two to ten fathoms in depth) where the seaweeds of this genus grow.

entry.ety: See Lamina
entry.def: A broad-leafed fossil alga.
Laminar.

entry.ety: See Lamina
entry.def: Consisting of, or covered with, laminæ, or thin plates, scales, or layers, one over another; laminated.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Laminated; p. pr. & vb. n. Laminating
entry.ety: See Lamina

sn.def: To cause to separate into thin plates or layers; to divide into thin plates.
To form, as metal, into a thin plate, as by rolling.
To form by uniting two or more layers (in sheet form) of a material, so that the layers are bonded tightly.
To unite (layers in sheet form) by bonding, so as to create a single object with multiple layers; -- used with the material in sheet form as the object; as, to laminate plywood.

entry.def: To separate into laminæ.

cs.cd: a timber arch made of layers of bent planks secured by treenails.

sn.def: Consisting of, or covered with, laminae, or thin plates, sheets, scales, or layers, one over another; laminate.
Constructed of thin sheets of material, bonded together to form a composite structure having multiple layers.

entry.def: Forming, or separating into, scales or thin layers.
The process of laminating, or the state of being laminated.

entry.ety: Lamina + -ferous
entry.def: Having a structure consisting of laminæ, or thin layers.

entry.ety: Lamina + L. planta sole of the foot
entry.def: Having the tarsus covered behind with a horny sheath continuous on both sides, as in most singing birds, except the larks.

entry.ety: NL. See Lamina, and -itis
entry.def: Inflammation of the laminæ or fleshy plates along the coffin bone of a horse; founder.
Somewhat lame.
See Lam.

entry.ety: AS. hlāmmesse hlāfmæsse, loaf mass, bread feast, or feast of first fruits; hlāf loaf + mæsse mass. See Loaf, and Mass religious service
entry.def: The first day of August; -- called also Lammas day, and Lammastide.

entry.ety: G. lämmergeier; lamm, pl. lämmer, lamb + geier vulture
entry.def: A very large vulture (Gypaëtus barbatus), which inhabits the mountains of Southern Europe, Asia, and Northern Africa. When full-grown it is nine or ten feet in extent of wings. It is brownish black above, with the under parts and neck rusty yellow; the forehead and crown white; the sides of the head and beard black. It feeds partly on carrion and partly on small animals, which it kills. It has the habit of carrying tortoises and marrow bones to a great height, and dropping them on stones to obtain the contents, and is therefore called bonebreaker and ossifrage. It is supposed to be the ossifrage of the Bible. Called also bearded vulture and bearded eagle.
A natural family of oceanic sharks.

entry.ety: NL., fr. L. lamina a scale + unguis a nail
entry.def: Same as Hyracoidea.

entry.ety: OE. (with excrescent p), fr. F. lame, L. lamina. See Lamina
entry.def: A thin plate or lamina.

entry.cs: Æolipile lamp a hollow ball of copper containing alcohol which is converted into vapor by a lamp beneath, so as to make a powerful blowpipe flame when the vapor is ignited. Weale. Arc lamp Elec a form of lamp in which the voltaic arc is used as the source of light. Dëbereiner's lamp an apparatus for the instantaneous production of a flame by the spontaneous ignition of a jet of hydrogen on being led over platinum sponge; -- named after the German chemist Döbereiner, who invented it. Called also philosopher's lamp. Flameless lamp an aphlogistic lamp. Lamp burner the part of a lamp where the wick is exposed and ignited. Knight. Lamp fount a reservoir for oil, in a lamp. Lamp jack. See 2d Jack n., 4 & . Lamp shade a screen, as of paper, glass, or tin, for softening or obstructing the light of a lamp. Lamp shell Zoöl any brachiopod shell of the genus Terebratula and allied genera. The name refers to the shape, which is like that of an antique lamp. See Terebratula. Safety lamp a miner's lamp in which the flame is surrounded by fine wire gauze, preventing the kindling of dangerous explosive gases; -- called also, from Sir Humphry Davy the inventor, Davy lamp. To smell of the lamp to bear marks of great study and labor, as a literary composition.
entry.ety: F. lampe, L. lampas -adis, fr. Gr. � , �, torch, fr. � to give light, to shine. Cf. Lampad Lantern

sn.def: A light-producing vessel, device, instrument or apparatus;
a vessel with a wick used for the combustion of oil or other inflammable liquid, for the purpose of producing artificial light; also, a similar device using a gas as the combustible fuel;
an electric lamp. See sense {3}.
Figuratively, anything which enlightens intellectually or morally; anything regarded metaphorically a performing the uses of a lamp.
sn.q: Thy word is a lamp unto my feet, and a light unto my path.
Ages elapsed ere Homer's lamp appeared.

sn.def: A device or mechanism for producing light by electricity, usually having a glass bulb or tube containing the light-emitting element. Most lamps belong to one of two categories, the Incandescent lamp See under Incandescent) or the fluorescent lamp. However, see also arc lamp , below.
A device that emits radiant energy in the form of heat, infrared, or ultraviolet rays; as, a heat lamp.

entry.ety: Gr. � , �. See Lamp
entry.def: A lamp or candlestick.
entry.q: By him who 'mid the golden lampads went.

entry.ety: Gr. �, fr. �, �, torch. See Lamp
entry.def: One who gained the prize in the lampadrome.

entry.ety: Gr. �; �, �, torch + � course, race, fr. � to run
entry.def: A race run by young men with lighted torches in their hands. He who reached the goal first, with his torch unextinguished, gained the prize.

entry.ety: F. lampas
entry.def: An inflammation and swelling of the soft parts of the roof of the mouth immediately behind the fore teeth in the horse; -- called also lampers.

entry.ety: Cf. F. lampate
entry.def: A supposed salt of lampic acid.

entry.ety: Lamp + black
entry.def: The fine impalpable soot obtained from the smoke of carbonaceous substances which have been only partly burnt, as in the flame of a smoking lamp. It consists of finely divided carbon, with sometimes a very small proportion of various impurities. It is used as an ingredient of printers' ink, and various black pigments and cements.
See Lamprey.

entry.note: ☞ The name is also applied to other river lampreys.
entry.ety: See Lamprey
entry.def: The river lamprey (Ammocœtes fluviatilis syn. Lampetra fluviatilis).
See Lampas.

entry.ety: F. lampique, fr. lampe lamp. See Lamp
entry.def: Pertaining to, or produced by, a lamp; -- formerly said of a supposed acid.
Shining; brilliant.
entry.q: Lampingeyes.

entry.def: Being without a lamp, or without light; hence, being without appreciation; dull.
entry.q: Your ladies' eyes are lampless to that virtue.

entry.def: Light from a lamp.
entry.q: This world's artificial lamplights.

sn.def: One who, or that which, lights a lamp;
a person who in former times lighted street lamps which were illuminated by a combustible gas; -- such lamps are now little used, and primarily as nostalgic ornaments.
sn.q: He made the night a little brighter Wherever he did go, The old lamplighter Of long, long ago.

sn.def: The calico bass.
A device used to light lamps.

entry.def: Illuminated by a lamp.

entry.ety: F. lampon a drinking song, fr. lampons let us drink, -- the burden of such a song, fr. lamper to guzzle, to drink much and greedily; of German origin, and akin to E. lap to drink. Prob. so called because drinking songs often contain personal slander or satire

sn.def: A personal satire in writing; usually, malicious and abusive censure written only to reproach and distress.
sn.q: Like her who missed her name in a lampoon, And grieved to find herself decayed so soon.

sn.def: Any satire ridiculing or mocking a person, activity, or institution by representing its character or behavior in an exaggerated or grotesque form; the representation may be written, filmed, or performed as a live skit, and may be intended as a severe reproach, or as good-natured humor.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Lampooned; p. pr. & vb. n. Lampooning
entry.def: To subject to abusive ridicule expressed in a work of art; to make (a person, behavior, or institution) the subject of a lampoon.
entry.q: Ribald poets had lampooned him.

entry.def: The writer of a lampoon.
entry.q: Libelers,lampooners, and pamphleteers.

entry.def: The act of lampooning; a lampoon, or lampoons.
A post (generally a pillar of iron) supporting a lamp or lantern for lighting a street, park, etc.
See Lamprey.

entries.entry:
Lam"prey ☞ The common or sea lamprey of America and Europe (Petromyzon marinus), which in spring ascends rivers to spawn, is considered excellent food by many, and is sold as a market fish in some localities. The smaller river lampreys mostly belong to the genus Ammocœles, or Lampetra, as Ammocœles fluviatilis, of Europe, and Ammocœles æpypterus of America. All lampreys attach themselves to other fishes, as parasites, by means of the suckerlike mouth. lăm"pr� n.; pl.Lampreys lăm"prĭz. OE. lampreie, F. lamproie, LL. lampreda lampetra, from L. lambere to lick + petra rock, stone. The lampreys are so called because they attach themselves with their circular mouths to rocks and stones, whence they are also called rocksuckers. See Lap to drink, Petrify
Zoöl An eel-like marsipobranch of the genus Petromyzon, and allied genera; called also lamprey eel and lamper eel. The lampreys have a round, sucking mouth, without jaws, but set with numerous minute teeth, and one to three larger teeth on the palate (see Illust. of Cyclostomi). There are seven small branchial openings on each side.
lamprel lampron

entry.ety: Cf. OE. lampreon. See Lamprey
entry.def: See Lamprey.
a protective ornamental covering used to screen the light bulb in a lamp from direct view.
A mollusklike marine animal with bivalve shell having a pair of arms bearing tentacles for capturing food, found worldwide.
A natural family of insects comprising the fireflies.

entry.ety: See Lampyris
entry.def: An insect of the genus Lampyris, or family Lampyridæ. See Lampyris.

entry.ety: L., glowworm, Gr. (�)
entry.def: A genus of coleopterous insects, including the glowworms.

entry.ety: Local Area Network
entry.def: A local area network; a network{3} connecting computers and word processors and other electronic office equipment within a small area, to create an inter-office system, typically within one building or one site of a corporation. Contrasted to WAN, a wide-area network.

sn.def: an island in the Hawaiian chain.
a veranda or roofed patio often furnished and used as a living room.

entry.ety: From Lanarkshire, a county in Scotland
entry.def: A mineral consisting of sulphate of lead, occurring either massive or in long slender prisms, of a greenish white or gray color.

entry.ety: L. lanaria, fr. lanarius belonging to wool, lana wool
entry.def: A place for storing wool.

entry.ety: L. lanatus, fr. lana wool, down

sn.def: Wooly; covered with fine long hair, or hairlike filaments.
covered with dense often matted or curly hairs.

entry.def: A steam boiler having two flues which contain the furnaces and extend through the boiler from end to end.

sn.def: A city in Northwest England on the river Lune.
The English royal house that reigned from 1399 to 1461; its symbol was a red rose; called also the House of Lancaster.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to the monitorial system of instruction followed by Joseph Lancaster , of England, in which advanced pupils in a school teach pupils below them.

sn.def: Of or pertaining to Lancaster{2}; as, Lancastrian royalty.
Of or pertaining to the city of Lancaster{1}; as, Lancastrian city center.
Of or pertaining to the members of the house of Lancaster; as, Lancastrian members.
Of or pertaining to the inhabitants of Lancaster; as, the Lancastrian population.
A member (or supporter) of the house of Lancaster.
A resident of Lancaster{1}.

cs.cd: in the Middle Ages, and subsequently, a knight or roving soldier, who was free to engage for any state or commander that purchased his services; hence, a person who assails institutions or opinions on his own responsibility without regard to party lines or deference to authority. See also freelance n. and a., and freelancer.
a socket attached to a saddle or stirrup strap, in which to rest the but of a lance.
same as Lancepesade.
a lansquenet.
the fer-de-lance.
a kind of fuse filled with a composition which burns with a suffocating odor; -- used in the counter operations of miners.
to engage in a tilt or contest.

entry.ety: OE. lance, F. lance fr. L. lancea; cf. Gr. lo`gchh. Cf. Launch

sn.def: A weapon of war, consisting of a long shaft or handle and a steel blade or head; a spear carried by horsemen, and often decorated with a small flag; also, a spear or harpoon used by whalers and fishermen.
sn.q: A braver soldier never couched lance.

sn.def: A soldier armed with a lance; a lancer.
A small iron rod which suspends the core of the mold in casting a shell.
An instrument which conveys the charge of a piece of ordnance and forces it home.
One of the small paper cases filled with combustible composition, which mark the outlines of a figure.
A lancet.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Lanced; p. pr. & vb. n. Lancing

sn.def: To pierce with a lance, or with any similar weapon.
sn.q: Seized the due victim, and with fury lanced Her back.

sn.def: To open with a lancet; to pierce; as, to lance a vein or an abscess.
To throw in the manner of a lance. See Lanch.
A lancepesade.
An enlisted member of the United States Marine Corps ranking between a private first class and a corporal.
The lowest rank of corporal; -- a term used in the British military.

entry.def: A slender marine fish of the genus Ammodytes, especially Ammodytes tobianus of the English coast; -- called also sand lance.

entry.ety: OF. lancegaie, corrupted from the same source as E. assagai, under the influence of F. lance lance. See Assagai
entry.def: A kind of spear anciently used. Its use was prohibited by a statute of Richard II.
entry.q: In his hand a launcegay, A long sword by his side.

entry.ety: Lance + -let
entry.def: A small fishlike animal (Amphioxus lanceolatus), remarkable for the rudimentary condition of its organs. It is the type of the class Leptocardia. See Amphioxus Leptocardia.
Like a lance.

entry.ety: L. lanceola a little lance, dim. of lancea lance: cf. F. lancéolaire
entry.def: Lanceolate.

entry.ety: L. lanceolatus: cf. F. lancéolé. See Lanceolar
entry.def: Rather narrow, tapering to a point at the apex, and sometimes at the base also; as, a lanceolate leaf.

entry.ety: F. lancepessade lanspessade anspessade, It. lancia spezzata a broken lance or demilance, a demilance roan, a light horseman, bodyguard
entry.def: An assistant to a corporal; a private performing the duties of a corporal; -- called also lance corporal.

entry.ety: Cf. F. lancier

sn.def: One who lances; one who carries a lance; especially, a member of a mounted body of men armed with lances, attached to the cavalry service of some nations.
A lancet.
A set of quadrilles of a certain arrangement.
A set of quadrilles for 8 or 16 couples.
Music appropriate for a set of lancers{1}.

cs.cd: a pointed arch, of which the width, or span, is narrow compared with the height.
a name given to a style of architecture, in which lancet arches are common; -- peculiar to England and 13th century.

entry.ety: F. lancette, dim. of lance lance. See Lance

sn.def: A surgical knife-like instrument of various forms, commonly sharp-pointed and two-edged, used in venesection, and in opening abscesses, etc.
An iron bar used for tapping a melting furnace.

entry.def: A large, elongated, scaleless, voracious, deep-sea fish (Alepidosaurus ferox), having long, sharp, lancetlike teeth and a long saillike dorsal fin.

sn.def: The doctor, or surgeon fish.

cs.cd: a myrtaceous tree (Backhousia Australis).

entry.def: A tough, elastic wood, often used for the shafts of gigs, archery bows, fishing rods, and the like. Also, the tree which produces this wood, Duguetia Quitarensisa native of Guiana and Cuba), and several other trees of the same family (Anonaseæ).

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Lanched lȧncht; p. pr. & vb. n. Lanching. See Launch Lance
entry.def: To throw, as a lance; to let fly; to launch.
entry.q: See Whose arm can lanch the surer bolt.

entry.ety: Lance + -ferous
entry.def: Bearing a lance.

entry.ety: Lance + -form: cf. F. lanciforme
entry.def: Having the form of a lance.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Lancinated; p. pr. & vb. n. Lancinating
entry.ety: L. lancinatus, p. p. of lancinare to fear
entry.def: To tear; to lacerate; to pierce or stab.
Piercing; seeming to pierce or stab; as, lancinating pains (i.e., severe, darting pains.
A tearing; laceration.
entry.q: Lancinationsof the spirit.

entry.def: Urine. See Lant.

entry.note: ☞ In the expressions “to be, or dwell, upon land,” “to go or fare, on land,” as used by Chaucer, land denotes the country as distinguished from the town.
entry.cs:
Land agent a person employed to sell or let land, to collect rents, and to attend to other money matters connected with land. Land boat a vehicle on wheels propelled by sails. Land blink a peculiar atmospheric brightness seen from sea over distant snow-covered land in arctic regions. See Ice blink. Land breeze. See under Breeze. Land chain. See Gunter's chain. Land crab Zoöl any one of various species of crabs which live much on the land, and resort to the water chiefly for the purpose of breeding. They are abundant in the West Indies and South America. Some of them grow to a large size. Land fish a fish on land; a person quite out of place. Shak. Land force a military force serving on land, as distinguished from a naval force. Land, ho! Naut a sailor's cry in announcing sight of land. Land ice a field of ice adhering to the coast, in distinction from a floe. Land leech Zoöl any one of several species of blood-sucking leeches, which, in moist, tropical regions, live on land, and are often troublesome to man and beast. Land measure the system of measurement used in determining the area of land; also, a table of areas used in such measurement.
Land of bondageorHouse of bondage
in Bible history, Egypt; by extension, a place or condition of special oppression. Land o' cakes Scotland. Land of Nod sleep. Land of promise in Bible history, Canaan: by extension, a better country or condition of which one has expectation. Land of steady habits a nickname sometimes given to the State of Connecticut. Land office a government office in which the entries upon, and sales of, public land are registered, and other business respecting the public lands is transacted. U.S Land pike. Zoöl The gray pike, or sauger. The Menobranchus. Land service military service as distinguished from naval service. Land rail. Zoöl The crake or corncrake of Europe. See Crake. An Australian rail (Hypotænidia Phillipensis); -- called also pectoral rail. Land scrip a certificate that the purchase money for a certain portion of the public land has been paid to the officer entitled to receive it. U.S Land shark a swindler of sailors on shore. Sailors' Cant Land side That side of anything in or on the sea, as of an island or ship, which is turned toward the land. The side of a plow which is opposite to the moldboard and which presses against the unplowed land. Land snail Zoöl any snail which lives on land, as distinguished from the aquatic snails are Pulmonifera, and belong to the Geophila; but the operculated land snails of warm countries are Diœcia, and belong to the Tænioglossa. See Geophila, and Helix. Land spout a descent of cloud and water in a conical form during the occurrence of a tornado and heavy rainfall on land. Land steward a person who acts for another in the management of land, collection of rents, etc.
Land tortoise Land turtle
Zoöl any tortoise that habitually lives on dry land, as the box tortoise. See Tortoise. Land warrant a certificate from the Land Office, authorizing a person to assume ownership of a public land. U.S Land wind. Same as Land breezeabove). To make land Naut to sight land. To set the land to see by the compass how the land bears from the ship. To shut in the land to hide the land, as when fog, or an intervening island, obstructs the view.
entry.ety: AS. land lond; akin to D., G., Icel., Sw., Dan., and Goth. land.

sn.def: The solid part of the surface of the earth; -- opposed to water as constituting a part of such surface, especially to oceans and seas; as, to sight land after a long voyage.
sn.q: They turn their heads to sea, their sterns to land.

sn.def: Any portion, large or small, of the surface of the earth, considered by itself, or as belonging to an individual or a people, as a country, estate, farm, or tract.
sn.q: Go view the land, even Jericho.
Ill fares the land, to hastening ills a prey, Where wealth accumulates and men decay.
A poor parson dwelling upon landi.e., in the country].

sn.def: Ground, in respect to its nature or quality; soil; as, wet land; good or bad land.
The inhabitants of a nation or people.
sn.q: These answers, in the silent night received, The king himself divulged, the land believed.

sn.def: The mainland, in distinction from islands.
The ground or floor.
sn.q: Herself upon the land she did prostrate.

sn.def: The ground left unplowed between furrows; any one of several portions into which a field is divided for convenience in plowing.

Any ground, soil, or earth whatsoever, as meadows, pastures, woods, etc., and everything annexed to it, whether by nature, as trees, water, etc., or by the hand of man, as buildings, fences, etc.; real estate.
The lap of the strakes in a clinker-built boat; the lap of plates in an iron vessel; -- called also landing.

In any surface prepared with indentations, perforations, or grooves, that part of the surface which is not so treated, as the level part of a millstone between the furrows, or the surface of the bore of a rifled gun between the grooves.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Landed; p. pr. & vb. n. Landing

sn.def: To set or put on shore from a ship or other water craft; to disembark; to debark.
sn.q: I 'll undertake to land them on our coast.

sn.def: To catch and bring to shore; to capture; as, to land a fish.

To set down after conveying; to cause to fall, alight, or reach; to bring to the end of a course; as, he landed the quoit near the stake; to be thrown from a horse and landed in the mud; to land one in difficulties or mistakes.
To pilot (an airplane) from the air onto the land; as, to land the plane on a highway.
To come to the end of a course; to arrive at a destination, literally or figuratively; as, he landed in trouble; after hithchiking for a week, he landed in Los Angeles.
To go on shore from a ship or boat; to disembark.
To reach and come to rest on land after having been in the air; as, the arrow landed in a flower bed; the golf ball landed in a sand trap; our airplane landed in Washington.

entry.ety: G. Landamman; land land, country + amimann bailiff. See Land, and Ambassador

sn.def: A chief magistrate in some of the Swiss cantons.
The president of the diet of the Helvetic republic.

entry.ety: From the town Ladau in Germany; cf. F. landau. See Land Island
entry.def: A four-wheeled covered vehicle, the top of which is divided into two sections which can be let down, or thrown back, in such a manner as to make an open carriage.

entry.ety: Cf. F. landaulet, dim, of landau. See Landau
entry.def: A small landau.

entries.entry:
‖Land"drost` n.; pl. -drosten # . Sometimes incorrectly Landtrost . D., fr. land land + drost a kind of official; akin to G. truchsess
In South Africa A chief magistrate in rural districts. He was replaced in 1827 by “resident magistrates.” The president of the Heemraad.

sn.def: Having an estate in land.
sn.q: The House of Commons must consist, for the most part, of landed men.

sn.def: Consisting in real estate or land; as, landed property; landed security.
One who lands, or makes a landing.
sn.q: Thelanderin a lonely isle.

sn.def: A person who waits at the mouth of the shaft to receive the kibble of ore.

cs.cd: the sighting of land in conformity with the navigator's reckoning and expectation.

sn.def: A sudden transference of property in land by the death of its owner.
Sighting or making land when at sea.

entry.def: An overflowing of land by river; an inundation; a freshet.

entry.note: ☞ The title was first adopted by some German counts in the twelfth century, to distinguish themselves from the inferior counts under their jurisdiction. Three of them were princes of the empire.
entry.ety: G. landgraf; land land + graf earl, count; cf. D. landgraaf, F. landgrave
entry.def: A German nobleman of a rank corresponding to that of an earl in England and of a count in France.

entry.ety: Cf. F. landgraviat

sn.def: The territory held by a landgrave.
The office, jurisdiction, or authority of a landgrave.

entry.ety: G. landgräfin; cf. D. landgravin
entry.def: The wife of a landgrave.
A holder, owner, or proprietor of land.

sn.def: ownership of land; the state or fact of owning land.
A holding in the form of land; the land owned by a person.

cs.cd: charges or fees paid on goods unloaded from a vessel.
a small, bag-shaped net, used in fishing to take the fish from the water after being hooked.
a floating platform attached at one end to a wharf in such a manner as to rise and fall with the tide, and thus facilitate passage between the wharf and a vessel lying beside the stage.
a customhouse officer who oversees the landing of goods, etc., from vessels; a landwaiter.

entry.def: Of, pertaining to, or used for, setting, bringing, or going, on shore.

entry.cs: Landing place. me as Landing n., 2 and 3.

sn.def: A going or bringing on shore.
A place for landing, as from a ship, a carriage. etc.
The level part of a staircase, at the top of a flight of stairs, or connecting one flight with another.
The act or process of bringing an aircraft to land after having been in the air; as, the pilot made a perfect three-point landing . Contrasted with take-off.

entry.def: The wheels and attached structures under an airplane that support it and allow it to move when on the ground; also, the floats or pontoons of an amphibious airplane together with their supporting structures. Landing gear may be fixed rigidly in place, or retractable when in flight.
A runway at an airport, at which airplanes land{3}; the long smooth surface used for takeoff or landing{4}.

entries.entry:
land"la`dy n.; pl.landladies #. Cf. landlord
A woman having real estate which she leases to a tenant or tenants.
The mistress of an inn or lodging house.

entry.def: In Ireland, a combination of tenant farmers and other, organized, with Charles Stewart Parnell as president, in 1879 with a view to the reduction of farm rents and a reconstruction of the land laws.
entry.q: The Land League, of which Michael Davitt was the founder, originated in Mayo in August, and at a Dublin in October the organization was extended to all Ireland, with Parnell as president.

entry.def: See Landlouper.
Having no property in land.
To inclose, or nearly inclose, as a harbor or a vessel, with land.

sn.def: Inclosed, or nearly inclosed, by land; having no border on the sea; as, a landlocked country.
Confined to a fresh-water lake by reason of waterfalls or dams; -- said of fishes that would naturally seek the sea, after spawning; as, the landlocked salmon.

entry.def: Same as Landlouper.

entry.ety: See Land, and Lord

sn.def: The lord of a manor, or of land; the owner of land or houses which he leases to a tenant or tenants.
The master of an inn or of any form of lodging house; as, the landlord collects the rents on the first of the month.
sn.q: Upon our arrival at the inn, my companion fetched out the jolly landlord.

entry.def: The state of being a landlord; the characteristics of a landlord; specifically, in Great Britain, the relation of landlords to tenants, especially as regards leased agricultural lands.
The state of a landlord.

entry.ety: D. landlooper, lit., landrunner; land land + loopen to run. See Land, and Leap
entry.def: A vagabond; a vagrant.
entry.q: Bands oflandloupers.

entry.def: Vagrant; wandering about.

entry.ety: Prop. fr. land + lubber, or possibly corrupted fr. laudlouper
entry.def: One who passes his life on land; -- so called among seamen in contempt or ridicule.
Like a landlubber: inexperienced in seamanshap.

entries.entry:
Land"man n.; pl.Landmen.
A man who lives or serves on land; -- opposed to seaman.
Eng An occupier of land.

cs.cd: important events by which eras or conditions are determined.

entry.ety: AS. landmearc. See Land, and Mark a sign

sn.def: A mark to designate the boundary of land; any mark or fixed object (as a marked tree, a stone, a ditch, or a heap of stones) by which the limits of a farm, a town, or other portion of territory may be known and preserved.
Any conspicuous object on land that serves as a guide; some prominent object, as a hill or steeple.
A structure that has special significance, such as a building with historical associations;
a building that is protected from destruction or alteration by special laws intended to preserve structures of historical significance; as, a landmark preservation law.
An event or accomplishment of great significance; as, Brown v. Board of Education was a landmark of the civil rights movement. Also used attributively, as a landmark court decision.

entry.def: a large continuous extent of land; as, the Eurasian landmass .
Connecticut; -- a nickname alluding to the moral character of its inhabitants, implied by the rigid laws (see Blue laws) of the early period.
An owner of land.
The owning of land.

def2.def: Having property in land; of or pertaining to landowners.

entry.def: Pecuniarily embarrassed through owning much unprofitable land.

entry.ety: Land + reeve an officer
entry.def: A subordinate officer on an extensive estate, who acts as an assistant to the steward.

cs.cd: The art of laying out grounds and arranging trees, shrubbery, etc., in such a manner as to produce a picturesque effect.

entry.ety: D. landschap; land land + -schap, equiv. to E. -schip; akin to G. landschaft, Sw. landskap, Dan. landskab. See Land and -schip

sn.def: A portion of land or territory which the eye can comprehend in a single view, including all the objects it contains.
A picture representing a scene by land or sea, actual or fancied, the chief subject being the general aspect of nature, as fields, hills, forests, water. etc. Compare seascape.
The pictorial aspect of a country.
sn.q: The landscape of his native country had taken hold on his heart.

entry.def: Working as a landscape gardner.
A painter of landscapes.

entry.ety: See Landscape
entry.def: A landscape.
entry.q: Straight my eye hath caught new pleasures, Whilst the landskip round it measures.

sn.def: The slipping down of a mass of land from a mountain, hill, etc.
The land which slips down.
An election victory in which the winning candidate receives a substantial majority of the votes, usually meaning at least ten per cent more than any opposing candidate.
Any overwhelming victory.

entries.entry:
Lands"man n.; pl.Landsmen #.
One who lives on the land; -- opposed to seaman.
Naut A sailor on his first voyage.

entry.ety: Dan. landsthing landsting, fr. land land + thing ting, parliament. See Land; Thing
entry.def: See Legislature, below.

entry.ety: Sw
entry.def: See Varnpligtige.

entry.ety: See Strait
entry.def: A narrow strip of land.

entry.ety: G. See Land; Storm
entry.mark: In Germany and other European nations, and Japan:
entry.def: A general levy in time of war.

The forces called out on such levy, composed of all men liable to service who are not in the army, navy, or Landwehr; the last line of defense, supposed to be called out only in case of invasion or other grave emergency. See Army organization, above.

entry.ety: G. See Land; Day
entry.def: The diet or legislative body; as, the Landtag of Prussia. See Legislature, below.
See Landing waiter, under Landing a.
Toward the land.

entry.ety: G., fr. land land, country + wehr defense
entry.def: That part of the army, in Germany and Austria, which has completed the usual military service and is exempt from duty in time of peace, except that it is called out occasionally for drill.

cs.cd: by himself; himself alone.

entry.ety: See Lone
entry.def: Alone.

entry.ety: OE. lane lone, AS. lone lone; akin to D. laan, OFries. lana lona
entry.def: A passageway between fences or hedges which is not traveled as a highroad; an alley between buildings; a narrow way among trees, rocks, and other natural obstructions; hence, in a general sense, a narrow passageway; as, a lane between lines of men, or through a field of ice.
entry.q: It is become a turn-again lane unto them which they can not go through.

entry.def: Long.
A curious colubriform snake of the genus Xyphorhynchus, from Madagascar. It is brownish red, and its nose is prolonged in the form of a sharp blade.
One of numerous species of long-winged, shrikelike birds of Australia and the East Indies, of the genus Artamus, and allied genera; called also wood swallow.
A linen roller used in dressing wounds.
A wolf (Canis pallipes), found in India, allied to the jackal.
A kind of shot formerly used at sea for tearing sails and rigging. It consisted of bolts, nails, and other pieces of iron fastened together or inclosed in a canister.
A kind of loaded die.

entry.note: Sometimes compounded with shot
entry.def: See Langrage.

entry.ety: Scot. lang long + syne since
entry.def: Long since; long ago.

entry.ety: See Loo
entry.def: An old game at cards. See Loo.

entry.note: ☞ Language consists in the oral utterance of sounds which usage has made the representatives of ideas. When two or more persons customarily annex the same sounds to the same ideas, the expression of these sounds by one person communicates his ideas to another. This is the primary sense of language, the use of which is to communicate the thoughts of one person to another through the organs of hearing. Articulate sounds are represented to the eye by letters, marks, or characters, which form words.

☞ Computer languages are classed a low-level if each instruction specifies only one operation of the computer, or high-level if each instruction may specify a complex combination of operations. Machine language and assembly language are low-level computer languages. FORTRAN COBOL and C are high-level computer languages. Other computer languages, such as JAVA, allow even more complex combinations of low-level operations to be performed with a single command. Many programs, such as databases, are supplied with special languages adapted to manipulate the objects of concern for that specific program. These are also high-level languages.

cs.cd: a teacher of languages.

entry.usage: Language Speech Tongue Idiom Dialect. Language is generic, denoting, in its most extended use, any mode of conveying ideas; speech is the language of articulate sounds; tongue is the Anglo-Saxon term for language, esp. for spoken language; as, the English tongue. Idiom denotes the forms of construction peculiar to a particular language; dialects are varieties of expression which spring up in different parts of a country among people speaking substantially the same language.
entry.ety: OE. langage, F. langage, fr. L. lingua the tongue, hence speech, language; akin to E. tongue. See Tongue, cf. Lingual

sn.def: Any means of conveying or communicating ideas;
human speech; the expression of ideas by the voice; sounds, expressive of thought, articulated by the organs of the throat and mouth.
The expression of ideas by writing, or any other instrumentality.
The forms of speech, or the methods of expressing ideas, peculiar to a particular nation.
The characteristic mode of arranging words, peculiar to an individual speaker or writer; manner of expression; style.
sn.q: Others for language all their care express.

sn.def: The inarticulate sounds by which animals inferior to man express their feelings or their wants.
The suggestion, by objects, actions, or conditions, of ideas associated therewith; as, the language of flowers.
sn.q: There was . . . language in their very gesture.

sn.def: The vocabulary and phraseology belonging to an art or department of knowledge; as, medical language; the language of chemistry or theology.
A race, as distinguished by its speech.
sn.q: All the people, the nations, and the languages, fell down and worshiped the golden image.

sn.def: Any system of symbols created for the purpose of communicating ideas, emotions, commands, etc., between sentient agents.

Any set of symbols and the rules for combining them which are used to specify to a computer the actions that it is to take; also referred to as a computer lanugage or programming language; as, JAVA is a new and flexible high-level language which has achieved popularity very rapidly.
sn.syn: Speech; tongue; idiom; dialect; phraseology; diction; discourse; conversation; talk.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Languaged; p. pr. & vb. n. Languaging
entry.def: To communicate by language; to express in language.
entry.q: Others were languaged in such doubtful expressions that they have a double sense.

entry.def: Having a language; skilled in language; -- chiefly used in composition.
entry.q: Many-languagednations.

entry.def: Lacking or wanting language; speechless; silent.

entry.ety: F. langue tongue. See Language
entry.def: Tongued; having the tongue visible.
entry.q: Lions . . . represented as armed and langued gules.

entry.ety: F., language of oc yes
entry.def:
The dialect, closely akin to French, formerly spoken south of the Loire (in which the word for “yes” was
oc); Provençal.

entries.entry:
‖Langue` d'oïl". F., language of oïl yes The dialect formerly spoken north of the Loire (in which the word for “yes” was
oïl, F. oui).

entry.ety: It., p. pr. of languire. See Languish
entry.def: In a languishing manner; pathetically.

entry.ety: F. languette, dim. of langue tongue, L. lingua

sn.def: Anything resembling the tongue in form or office; specif., the slip of metal in an organ pipe which turns the current of air toward its mouth.
That part of the hilt, in certain kinds of swords, which overlaps the scabbard.

entry.ety: L. languidus, fr. languere to be faint or languid: cf. F. languide. See Languish

sn.def: Drooping or flagging from exhaustion; indisposed to exertion; without animation; weak; weary; heavy; dull.
sn.q: Languid, powerless limbs.
Fire their languid souls with Cato's virtue.

sn.def: Slow in progress; tardy.
sn.q: No motion so swift orlanguid.

sn.def: Promoting or indicating weakness or heaviness; as, a languid day.
sn.q: Feebly she laugheth in the languid moon.
Their idleness, aimless flirtations and languid airs.
sn.syn: Feeble; weak; faint; sickly; pining; exhausted; weary; listless; heavy; dull; heartless.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Languished; p. pr. & vb. n. Languishing
entry.ety: OE. languishen languissen, F. languir, L. languere; cf. Gr. � to slacken, � slack, Icel. lakra to lag behind; prob. akin to E. lag lax, and perh. to E. slack. See -ish

sn.def: To become languid or weak; to lose strength or animation; to be or become dull, feeble or spiritless; to pine away; to linger in a weak or deteriorating condition; to wither or fade.
sn.q: We . . . do languish of such diseases.
Cease, fond nature, cease thy strife, And let me languish into life.
For the fields of Heshbon languish.

sn.def: To assume an expression of weariness or tender grief, appealing for sympathy.
To be neglected and unattended to; as, the proposal languished on the director's desk for months.
sn.syn: To pine; wither; fade; droop; faint.

entry.def: To cause to droop or pine.
See Languishment.
entry.q: What, of death, too, That rids our dogs of languish?
And the blue languish of soft Allia's eye.

entry.def: One who languishes.

sn.def: Becoming languid and weak; pining; losing health and strength.
Amorously pensive; indicating melancholy; as, languishing eyes, or look.
Suffering neglect; neglected.
Continuing in a weak or deteriorating state; lingering.

entry.def: In a languishing manner.

sn.def: The state of languishing.
sn.q: Lingeringlanguishment.

sn.def: Tenderness of look or mien; amorous pensiveness.

entry.def: Languishment.

entry.ety: OE. langour, OF. langour, F. langueur, L. languor. See Languish

sn.def: A state of the body or mind which is caused by exhaustion of strength and characterized by a languid feeling; feebleness; lassitude; laxity.
Any enfeebling disease.
sn.q: Sick men with divers languors.

sn.def: Listless indolence; dreaminess.
sn.q: German dreams, Italianlanguors.
sn.syn: Feebleness; weakness; faintness; weariness; dullness; heaviness; lassitude; listlessness.

entry.ety: From Languor: cf. F. langoureux
entry.def: Producing, or tending to produce, languor; characterized by languor.
entry.q: Whom late I left in languorous constraint.
To wile the length from languorous hours, and draw The sting from pain.

entry.def: To languish.

entry.ety: Native name Anglicized
entry.def: One of several species of East Indian and Asiatic fresh-water fishes of the genus Ophiocephalus, remarkable for their power of living out of water, and for their tenacity of life; -- called also walking fishes.
See Lanyard.

entry.ety: Laniary + -form
entry.def: Shaped like a laniary, or canine, tooth.

entry.ety: L. laniarius, fr. lanius butcher, laniare to tear in pieces: cf. F. laniaire
entry.def: Lacerating or tearing; as, the laniary canine teeth.

entry.ety: L. Laniary a.

sn.def: The shambles; a place of slaughter.
A laniary, or canine, tooth.

entry.ety: L. laniatus, p. p. of laniare
entry.def: To tear in pieces.

entry.ety: L. laniatio
entry.def: A tearing in pieces.

entry.ety: F. lanière. See Lanyard

sn.def: A thong of leather; a whip lash.
A strap used to fasten together parts of armor, to hold the shield by, and the like.

entry.ety: L. lanifer; lana wool + ferre to bear: cf. F. lanifère
entry.def: Bearing or producing wool.

entry.ety: L. lanificus; lana wool + facere to make
entry.def: Working in wool.

entry.ety: L. lanificium: cf. OF. lanifice
entry.def: Anything made of wool.

entry.ety: L. laniger; lano wool + gerere to hear
entry.def: Bearing or producing wool.

entry.ety: NL. Laniusfr. L. lanius a butcher), the typical genus + -oid
entry.def: Of or pertaining to the shrikes (family Laniidæ).

cs.cd: long, thin hair.

entry.ety: AS. hlanc; cf. G. lenken to turn, gelenk joint, OHG. hlanca hip, side, flank, and E. link of a chain

sn.def: Slender and thin; not well filled out; not plump; shrunken; lean.
sn.q: Meager and lank with fasting grown.
Who would not choose . . . to have rather a lank purse than an empty brain?

sn.def: Languid; drooping.
sn.q: Who, piteous of her woes, reared her lank head.

entry.def: To become lank; to make lank.
The condition or quality or being lanky.
In a lank manner.
The state or quality of being lank.
Somewhat lank; tall, thin, bony and ungraceful.
entry.q: The lanky Dinka, nearly seven feet in height.

entry.ety: F. lanier, OF. also, lasnier. Cf. Lanyard
entry.def: A long-tailed falcon (Falco lanarius), of Southern Europe, Asia, and Northern Africa, resembling the American prairie falcon.

entry.note: ☞ Under the same name, it is prepared from wool for commercial purposes, and forms an admirable basis for ointments, being readily absorbed by the skin.
entry.ety: L. lana wool + oleum oil
entry.def: A peculiar fatlike body, made up of cholesterin and certain fatty acids, found in feathers, hair, wool, and keratin tissues generally.
Same as lanseh.
The small, yellow to whitish brown berrylike fruit of an East Indian tree (Lansium domesticum). It has a fleshy pulp, with an agreeable tart subacid taste.

entry.ety: F., fr. G. landsknecht a foot soldier, also a game of cards introduced by these foot soldiers; land country + knecht boy, servant. See Land, and Knight

sn.def: A German foot soldier in foreign service in the 15th and 16th centuries; a soldier of fortune; -- a term used in France and Western Europe.
A game at cards, vulgarly called lambskinnet.
sn.q: They play] their little game of lansquenet.

entry.def: Urine.

entry.ety: Cf. Lance
entry.def: Any one of several species of small, slender, marine fishes of the genus Ammedytes. The common European species (Ammedytes tobianus) and the American species (Ammedytes Americanus) live on sandy shores, buried in the sand, and are caught in large quantities for bait. Called also launce, and sand eel.
See Lanterloo.
See Lanthanum.

entry.ety: Formed by transposition of the letters of allantoin and -uric
entry.def: Pertaining to, or designating, a nitrogenous organic acid of the uric acid group, obtained by the decomposition of allantoin, and usually called allanturic acid.
An old name of loo.

entry.note: ☞ Fig. 1 represents a hand lantern; fig. 2, an arm lantern; fig. 3, a breast lantern; -- so named from the positions in which they are carried.

cs.cd: a lantern with a single opening, which may be closed so as to conceal the light; -- called also bull's-eye.
long, thin jaws; hence, a thin visage.

a kind of pinion or wheel having cylindrical bars or trundles, instead of teeth, inserted at their ends in two parallel disks or plates; -- so called as resembling a lantern in shape; -- called also wallower, or trundle.
any translucent, marine, bivalve shell of the genus Anatina, and allied genera.

an optical instrument consisting of a case inclosing a light, and having suitable lenses in a lateral tube, for throwing upon a screen, in a darkened room or the like, greatly magnified pictures from slides placed in the focus of the outer lens.

entry.ety: F. lanterne, L. lanterna laterna, from Gr. lampth`r light, torch. See Lamp

sn.def: Something inclosing a light, and protecting it from wind, rain, etc.; -- sometimes portable, as a closed vessel or case of horn, perforated tin, glass, oiled paper, or other material, having a lamp or candle within; sometimes fixed, as the glazed inclosure of a street light, or of a lighthouse light.

sd.def: An open structure of light material set upon a roof, to give light and air to the interior.
A cage or open chamber of rich architecture, open below into the building or tower which it crowns.
A smaller and secondary cupola crowning a larger one, for ornament, or to admit light; such as the lantern of the cupola of the Capitol at Washington, or that of the Florence cathedral.

sn.def: A lantern pinion or trundle wheel. See Lantern pinionbelow).

A kind of cage inserted in a stuffing box and surrounding a piston rod, to separate the packing into two parts and form a chamber between for the reception of steam, etc.; -- called also lantern brass.
A perforated barrel to form a core upon.
See Aristotle's lantern.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Lanterned; p. pr. & vb. n. Lanterning
entry.ety: Cf. F. lanterner to hang at the lamp post, fr. lanterne. See Lantern
entry.def: To furnish with a lantern; as, to lantern a lighthouse.
A small fish having rows of luminous organs along each side; some surface at night.

any one of several species of large, handsome, brightly marked, tropical hemipterous insects of the genera Laternaria Fulgora, and allies, of the family Fulgoridæ. The largest species is Laternaria phosphorea of Brazil. The head has a snoutlike process in some species which was formerly thought to emit a phosphorescent light.
Having lantern jaws or long, thin jaws; as, a lantern-jawed person.
Any rare earth element of the lanthanide series (atomic numbers 57 through 71).
Hydrous carbonate of lanthanum, found in tabular white crystals.
Same as lanthanide.
A natural family of stout-bodied lizards.
A genus withonly one species.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. lanqa`nein to lie hid, to be concealed
entry.def: A rare element of the rare earth group of the metals, of atomic number 57, allied to aluminum. It occurs in certain rare minerals, as cerite, gadolinite, orthite, etc., and was so named from the difficulty of separating it from cerium, didymium, and other rare earth elements with which it is usually associated. Atomic weight 138.9. Symbol La.

entry.ety: Gr. lanqa`nein to lie hid + E. opium
entry.def: An alkaloid found in opium in small quantities, and extracted as a white crystalline substance.
See Lantern.

entry.ety: L. lanuginosus, fr. lanugo -ginis, woolly substance, down, fr. lana wool: cf. F. lanugineux
entry.def: Covered with down, or fine soft hair; downy.

entry.ety: See Lanuginose
entry.def: The soft woolly hair which covers most parts of the mammal fetus, and in man is shed before or soon after birth.

entry.ety: F. lanière thong, strap, OF. lasniere, fr. lasne strap, thong, L. lacinia lappet. flap, edge of a garment. Cf. Lanier

sn.def: A short piece of rope or line for fastening something in ships; as, the lanyards of the gun ports, of the buoy, and the like; esp., pieces passing through the dead-eyes, and used to extend shrouds, stays, etc.
A strong cord, about twelve feet long, with an iron hook at one end a handle at the other, used in firing cannon with a friction tube.

entry.def: See Lanier.

entry.ety: L., fr. Gr. �

sn.def: A priest of Apollo, during the Trojan war. (See 2
A marble group in the Vatican at Rome, representing the priest Laocoön, with his sons, infolded in the coils of two serpents, as described by Virgil.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to Laodicea, a city in Phrygia Major; like the Christians of Laodicea; lukewarm in religion.
a country in Southeast Asia.
a native or inhabitant of Laos.

sn.def: of or pertaining to Laos; as, the Laotian Prime Minister.
of or pertaining to the inhabitants of Laos; as, Laotian refugees.

entry.def: A Chinese philosopher who founded Taoism in the 6th-century b.c.

entry.note: ☞ The lap of shingles or slates in roofing is the distance one course extends over the second course below, the distance over the course immediately below being called the cover.

cs.cd: a joint made by one layer, part, or piece, overlapping another, as in the scarfing of timbers.
a lap joint made by welding together overlapping edges or ends.
lap of the valve with respect to the exhaust port.
lap with respect to the admission, or steam, port.

entry.ety: OE. lappe, AS. læppa; akin to D. lap patch, piece, G. lappen, OHG. lappa, Dan. lap, Sw. lapp

sn.def: The loose part of a coat; the lower part of a garment that plays loosely; a skirt; an apron.
An edge; a border; a hem, as of cloth.
sn.q: If he cuts off but a lap of truth's garment, his heart smites him.

sn.def: The part of the clothing that lies on the knees or thighs when one sits down; that part of the person thus covered; figuratively, a place of rearing and fostering; as, to be reared in the lap of luxury.
sn.q: Men expect that happiness should drop into their laps.

sn.def: That part of any substance or fixture which extends over, or lies upon, or by the side of, a part of another; as, the lap of a board; also, the measure of such extension over or upon another thing.

The amount by which a slide valve at its half stroke overlaps a port in the seat, being equal to the distance the valve must move from its mid stroke position in order to begin to open the port. Used alone, lap refers to outside lap. See Outside lapbelow).
The state or condition of being in part extended over or by the side of something else; or the extent of the overlapping; as, the second boat got a lap of half its length on the leader.
One circuit around a race track, esp. when the distance is a small fraction of a mile; as, to run twenty laps; to win by three laps. See Lap, to fold, 2.
In card playing and other games, the points won in excess of the number necessary to complete a game; -- so called when they are counted in the score of the following game.
A sheet, layer, or bat, of cotton fiber prepared for the carding machine.

A piece of brass, lead, or other soft metal, used to hold a cutting or polishing powder in cutting glass, gems, and the like, or in polishing cutlery, etc. It is usually in the form of wheel or disk, which revolves on a vertical axis.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Lapped; p. pr. & vb. n. Lapping

sn.def: To rest or recline in a lap, or as in a lap.
sn.q: To lap his head on lady's breast.

sn.def: To cut or polish with a lap, as glass, gems, cutlery, etc. See 1st Lap, 10.

cs.cd: to lay one partly over another.
to unite them in such a way as to preserve the same breadth and depth throughout, as by scarfing.

entry.ety: OE. lappen to fold (see Lap n.); cf. also OE. wlappen, perh. another form of wrappen, E, wrap

sn.def: To fold; to bend and lay over or on something; as, to lap a piece of cloth.
To wrap or wind around something.
sn.q: About the paper . . . I lapped several times a slender thread of very black silk.

sn.def: To infold; to hold as in one's lap; to cherish.
sn.q: Her garment spreads, and laps him in the folds.

sn.def: To lay or place over anything so as to partly or wholly cover it; as, to lap one shingle over another; to lay together one partly over another; as, to lap weather-boards; also, to be partly over, or by the side of (something); as, the hinder boat lapped the foremost one.
To lay together one over another, as fleeces or slivers for further working.

entry.def: To be turned or folded; to lie partly upon or by the side of something, or of one another; as, the cloth laps back; the boats lap; the edges lap.
entry.q: The upper wings are opacous; at their hinder ends, where they lap over, transparent, like the wing of a flay.

entry.ety: OE. lappen lapen, AS. lapian; akin to LG. lappen, OHG. laffan, Icel. lepja, Dan. lade, Sw. läppja, L. lambere; cf. Gr. �, W. llepio. Cf. Lambent

sn.def: To take up drink or food with the tongue; to drink or feed by licking up something.
sn.q: The dogs by the River Nilus's side, being thirsty, lap hastily as they run along the shore.

sn.def: To make a sound like that produced by taking up drink with the tongue.
sn.q: I heard the ripple washing in the reeds, And the wild water lapping on the crag.

entry.def: To take into the mouth with the tongue; to lick up with a quick motion of the tongue.
entry.q: They 'II take suggestion as a cat laps milk.

sn.def: The act of lapping with, or as with, the tongue; as, to take anything into the mouth with a lap .
The sound of lapping.

entry.ety: Gr. � loins + � tumor
entry.def: A rupture or hernia in the lumbar regions.

A slender endoscope, containing fiber-optic viewing capability and miniature surgical devices, which can be inserted through a small incision in the abdominal wall, allowing a surgeon to perform minor surgery with minimal damage to the abdominal muscles.
Laparotomy performed with a laparoscope.

entry.ety: Gr. � loins + te`mnein to cut
entry.def: A cutting through the walls of the abdomen, as in the Cæsarean section.
A board used on the lap as a substitute for a table, as by tailors.

sn.def: A small dog which is or can be fondled in the lap.
One who does the bidding of another; a servile follower.

entry.ety: Dim. of lap a fold
entry.def: That part of a garment which is turned back; specifically, the lap, or fold, of the front of a coat in continuation of collar.
Furnished with lapels.

entries.entry: Lap"ful n.; pl.Lapfuls. As much as the lap can contain.

entry.ety: L. lapicida, fr. lapis stone + caedere to cut
entry.def: A stonecutter.
Of or pertaining to stone; inscribed on stone; as, a lapidarian record.

entry.ety: L. lapidarius, fr. lapis -idis, stone
entry.def: Consisting of stones.

entries.entry:
Lap"i*da*ry
Lapidary's lathe Lapidary's mill Lapidary's wheel
a machine consisting essentially of a revolving lap on a vertical spindle, used by a lapidary for grinding and polishing.
n.; pl.Lapidaries #. L. lapidarius, fr. lapidarius pertaining to stone: cf. F. lapidaire
An artificer who cuts, polishes, and engraves precious stones; hence, a dealer in precious stones.
A virtuoso skilled in gems or precious stones; a connoisseur of lapidary work.

cs.cd: that style which is proper for monumental and other inscriptions; terse; sententious.

entry.ety: L. lapidarius pertaining to stone: cf. F. lapidaire

sn.def: Of or pertaining to the art of cutting stones, or engraving on stones, either gems or monuments; as, lapidary ornamentation.
Of or pertaining to monumental inscriptions; as, lapidary adulation.

entry.ety: L. lapidatus, p. p. of lapidare, fr. lapis stone
entry.def: To stone.

entry.ety: L. lapidatio: cf. F. lapidation
entry.def: The act of stoning.

entry.ety: L. lapideus, fr. lapis stone
entry.def: Of the nature of stone.

sn.def: The state or quality of being lapidescent.
A hardening into a stone substance.
A stony concretion.

entry.ety: L. lapidescens, p. pr. of lapidescere to become stone, fr. lapis -idis, stone: cf. F. lapidescent
entry.def: Undergoing the process of becoming stone; having the capacity of being converted into stone; having the quality of petrifying bodies.
Any substance which has the quality of petrifying other bodies, or of converting or being converted into stone.

entry.ety: L. lapis -idis, stone + facere to make: cf. F. lapidifique
entry.def: Forming or converting into stone.

entry.ety: Cf. F. lapidification
entry.def: The act or process of lapidifying; fossilization; petrifaction.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Lapidified; p. pr. & vb. n. Lapidifying
entry.ety: Cf. f. lapidifier. See Lapidific, and -fy
entry.def: To convert into stone or stony material; to petrify.
To become stone or stony.

entry.ety: L. lapis -idis, a stone
entry.def: A lapidary.

entry.ety: See Lapilli
entry.def: The state of being, or the act of making, stony.

entry.ety: L. lapillus a little stone, dim. of lapis stone
entry.def: Volcanic ashes, consisting of small, angular, stony fragments or particles.

entries.entry:
‖La"pis
Lapis calaminaris n. NL Min Calamine. Lapis infernalis n. L Fused nitrate of silver; lunar caustic.
n.; pl.Lapides #. L A stone.

entry.def: An albuminous mineral of a rich blue color; also called lapis. Same as Lazuli, which see.
Having a lap joint, or lap joints, as many kinds of woodwork and metal work.
A native or inhabitant of Lapland; -- called also Lapp.
Of or pertaining to Lapland.

entry.ety: Lap of a garment + ling
entry.def: One who has been fondled to excess; one fond of ease and sensual delights; -- a term of contempt.
Same as Laplander. Cf. Lapps.

entry.ety: L. lappaceus burlike, fr. lappa a bur
entry.def: Resembling the capitulum of burdock; covered with forked points.

entry.ety: From Lap to drink
entry.def: One who takes up food or liquid with his tongue.

cs.cd: one of several species of bombycid moths, which have stout, hairy caterpillars, flat beneath. Two common American species (Gastropacha Americana, and Tolype velleda) feed upon the apple tree.

entry.ety: Dim. of lap a fold
entry.def: A small decorative fold or flap, esp. of lace or muslin, in a garment or headdress.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Lappeted; p. pr. & vb. n. Lappeting
entry.def: To decorate with, or as with, a lappet.
Of or pertaining to Lapland, or the Lapps.

def2.def: The language of the Lapps. See Lappish.

cs.cd: A machine for forming fiber info a lap. See its Lap, 9.

entry.def: A kind of machine blanket or wrapping material used by calico printers.
Of or pertaining to the Lapps; Laplandish.

def2.def: The language spoken by the Lapps in Lapland. It is related to the Finnish and Hungarian, and is not an Aryan language.

entry.def: Laplandish; Lappish.

entries.entry: Lapps n. pl.; sing. Lapp . Ethnol A branch of the Mongolian race, now living in the northern parts of Norway, Sweden, and the adjacent parts of Russia.

entry.def: Lapsible.

entry.ety: L. lapsus, fr. labi, p. p. lapsus, to slide, to fall: cf. F. laps. See Sleep

sn.def: A gliding, slipping, or gradual falling; an unobserved or imperceptible progress or passing away,; -- restricted usually to immaterial things, or to figurative uses.
sn.q: The lapse to indolence is soft and imperceptible.
Bacon was content to wait the lapse of long centuries for his expected revenue of fame.

sn.def: A slip; an error; a fault; a failing in duty; a slight deviation from truth or rectitude.
sn.q: To guard against those lapses and failings to which our infirmities daily expose us.

sn.def: The termination of a right or privilege through neglect to exercise it within the limited time, or through failure of some contingency; hence, the devolution of a right or privilege.
A fall or apostasy.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Lapsed #; p. pr. & vb. n. Lapsing

sn.def: To pass slowly and smoothly downward, backward, or away; to slip downward, backward, or away; to glide; -- mostly restricted to figurative uses.
sn.q: A tendency to lapse into the barbarity of those northern nations from whom we are descended.
Homer, in his characters of Vulcan and Thersites, has lapsed into the burlesque character.

sn.def: To slide or slip in moral conduct; to fail in duty; to fall from virtue; to deviate from rectitude; to commit a fault by inadvertence or mistake.
sn.q: To lapse in fullness Is sorer than to lie for need.

sd.def: To fall or pass from one proprietor to another, or from the original destination, by the omission, negligence, or failure of some one, as a patron, a legatee, etc.
To become ineffectual or void; to fall.
sd.q: If the archbishop shall not fill it up within six months ensuing, it lapses to the king.

sn.def: To let slip; to permit to devolve on another; to allow to pass.
sn.q: An appeal may be deserted by the appellant's lapsing the term of law.

sn.def: To surprise in a fault or error; hence, to surprise or catch, as an offender.
sn.q: For which, if be lapsed in this place, I shall pay dear.

cs.cd: a devise, or legacy, which fails to take effect in consequence of the death of the devisee, or legatee, before that of the testator, or for other cause.

sn.def: Having slipped downward, backward, or away; having lost position, privilege, etc., by neglect; -- restricted to figurative uses.
sn.q: Once more I will renew His lapsed powers, though forfeit.

sn.def: Ineffectual, void, or forfeited; as, a lapsed policy of insurance; a lapsed legacy.

entry.def: Liable to lapse.
See Lopsided.
A stone for the lap, on which shoemakers beat leather.
Made with boards whose edges lap one over another; clinker-built; -- said of boats. Contrasted with carvel-built.

entry.ety: See lap v. i.

sn.def: To take up (drink or food) with the tongue; to drink by licking up.
To accept or enjoy enthusiatically and uncritically.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to Laputa, an imaginary flying island described in Gulliver's Travels as the home of chimerical philosophers.
fanciful; preposterous; absurd in science or philosophy.
entry.q: Laputanideas.

entry.def: Having edges or ends united by a lap weld; as, a lap-welded pipe.

entry.ety: OE. lapwynke leepwynke, AS. hleápewince; hleápan to leap, jump + (prob.) a word akin to AS. wincian to wink, E. wink, AS. wancol wavering; cf. G. wanken to stagger, waver. See Leap, and Wink
entry.def: A small European bird of the Plover family (Vanellus cristatus, or Vanellus vanellus). It has long and broad wings, and is noted for its rapid, irregular fight, upwards, downwards, and in circles. Its back is coppery or greenish bronze. Its eggs are the “plover's eggs” of the London market, esteemed a delicacy. It is called also peewit dastard plover, and wype. The gray lapwing is the Squatarola cinerea.
Work in which one part laps over another.
A lackey.

entries.entry: La"que*ar n.; pl.Laquearia #. L Arch A lacunar.

entry.ety: L. laqueus a noose
entry.def: Using a noose, as a gladiator.
entry.q: Retiary and laqueary combatants.

entries.entry: Lar lär n.; pl.Lares #, sometimes Lars #. L Rom. Myth A tutelary deity; a deceased ancestor regarded as a protector of the family. The domestic Lares were the tutelar deities of a house; household gods. Hence, Fig: Hearth or dwelling house. Nor will she her dear Lar forget, Victorious by his benefit. The Lars and Lemures moan with midnight plaint. Looking backward in vain toward their Lares and lands.

entry.def: A species of gibbon (Hylobates lar), found in Burmah. Called also white-handed gibbon.

An extensive series of strata, principally developed in the Rocky Mountain region, as in the Laramie Mountains, and formerly supposed to be of the Tertiary age, but now generally regarded as Cretaceous, or of intermediate and transitional character. It contains beds of lignite, often valuable for coal, and is hence also called the lignitic group. See Chart of Geology.

entry.note: ☞ Larboard is a nearly obsolete term, having been superseded by port to avoid liability of confusion with starboard, owing to similarity of sound.
entry.ety: Lar- is of uncertain origin, possibly the same as lower, i. e., humbler in rank, because the starboard side is considered by mariners as higher in rank; cf. D. laag low, akin to E. low. See Board n., 8
entry.def: The left-hand side of a ship to one on board facing toward the bow; port; -- opposed to starboard.
On or pertaining to the left-hand side of a vessel; port; as, the larboard quarter.
One who commits larceny.

entry.ety: Cf. OE. larrecinos. See Larceny
entry.def: Having the character of larceny; as, a larcenous act; committing larceny.
entry.q: Thelarcenousand burglarious world.

entries.entry:
Lar"ce*ny
Grand larcenyandPetit larceny are
distinctions having reference to the nature or value of the property stolen. They are abolished in England.
Mixed larcenyorCompound larceny
that which, under statute, includes in it the aggravation of a taking from a building or the person. Simple larceny that which is not accompanied with any aggravating circumstances.
n.; pl.Larcenies #. F. larcin, OE. larrecin, L. latrocinium, fr. latro robber, mercenary, hired servant; cf. Gr. (�) hired servant. Cf. Latrociny
Law The unlawful taking and carrying away of things personal with intent to deprive the right owner of the same; theft. Cf. Embezzlement.

entry.note: The European larch is Larix Europæa. The American or black larch is Larix Americana, the hackmatack or tamarack. The trees are generally of a drooping, graceful appearance.
entry.ety: Cf. OE. laregeCotgrave), It. larice, Sp. larice alerce, G. lärche; all fr. L. larix -icis, Gr. la`rix
entry.def: A genus of coniferous trees, having deciduous leaves, in fascicles (see Illust. of Fascicle).
Of or pertaining to the larch.

cs.cd: an illuminating and lubricating oil expressed from lard.
the internal fat of the hog, separated in leaves or masses from the kidneys, etc.; also, the same melted.

entry.ety: F., bacon, pig's fat, L. lardum laridum; cf. Gr. (�) fattened, fat

sn.def: Bacon; the flesh of swine.
The fat of swine, esp. the internal fat of the abdomen; also, this fat melted and strained.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Larded; p. pr. & vb. n. Larding
entry.ety: F. larder. See Lard n.

sn.def: To stuff with bacon; to dress or enrich with lard; esp., to insert lardons of bacon or pork in the surface of, before roasting; as, to lard poultry.
sn.q: And larded thighs on loaded altars laid.

sn.def: To fatten; to enrich.
sn.q: The oak] with his nuts larded many a swine.
Falstaff sweats to death. And lards the lean earth as he walks along.

sn.def: To smear with lard or fat.
sn.q: In his buff doublet larded o'er with fat Of slaughtered brutes.

sn.def: To mix or garnish with something, as by way of improvement; to interlard.
sn.q: Let no alien Sedley interpose To lard with wit thy hungry Epsom prose.

entry.def: To grow fat.

entry.ety: See Lardaceous
entry.def: A peculiar amyloid substance, colored blue by iodine and sulphuric acid, occurring mainly as an abnormal infiltration into the spleen, liver, etc.

cs.cd: Lardaceous degeneration
amyloid degeneration.

entry.ety: Cf. F. lardacé
entry.def: Consisting of, or resembling, lard.

entry.ety: OF. lardier. See Lard n.
entry.def: A room or place where meat and other articles of food are kept before they are cooked.
One in charge of the larder.

entry.ety: Cf. OE. larderie
entry.def: A larder.

entry.ety: F. lardon, fr. lard lard
entry.def: A bit of fat pork or bacon used in larding.

entry.ety: See Lardery
entry.def: A larder.
Containing, or resembling, lard; of the character or consistency of lard.

entry.ety: See Lore
entry.def: Lore; learning.
Pasture; feed. See Lair.
To feed; to fatten.
See 1st Lar.

entry.note: ☞ For linear dimensions, and mere extent, great, and not large, is used as a qualifying word; as, great length, breadth, depth; a great distance; a great height.
entry.cs:
At large. Without restraint or confinement; as, to go at large; to be left at large . Diffusely; fully; in the full extent; as, to discourse on a subject at large . Common at large. See under Common n.
Electors at large Representative at large
electors, or a representative, as in Congress, chosen to represent the whole of a State, in distinction from those chosen to represent particular districts in a State. U. S
To give large To go large To run largeorTo sail large
Naut to have the wind crossing the direction of a vessel's course in such a way that the sails feel its full force, and the vessel gains its highest speed. See Large a., 8.
entry.ety: F., fr. L. largus. Cf. Largo

sn.def: Exceeding most other things of like kind in bulk, capacity, quantity, superficial dimensions, or number of constituent units; big; great; capacious; extensive; -- opposed to small; as, a large horse; a large house or room; a large lake or pool; a large jug or spoon; a large vineyard; a large army; a large city.
Abundant; ample; as, a large supply of provisions.
sn.q: We have yet large day.

sn.def: Full in statement; diffuse; full; profuse.
sn.q: I might be very large upon the importance and advantages of education.

sn.def: Having more than usual power or capacity; having broad sympathies and generous impulses; comprehensive; -- said of the mind and heart.
Free; unembarrassed.
sn.q: Of burdens all he set the Paynims large.

sn.def: Unrestrained by decorum; -- said of language.
sn.q: Somelargejests he will make.

sn.def: Prodigal in expending; lavish.
Crossing the line of a ship's course in a favorable direction; -- said of the wind when it is abeam, or between the beam and the quarter.
sn.syn: Big; bulky; huge; capacious; comprehensive; ample; abundant; plentiful; populous; copious; diffusive; liberal.

entry.def: Freely; licentiously.
A musical note, formerly in use, equal to two longs, four breves, or eight semibreves.
Possessing much land.

entries.entry: Large"-hand`ed a. Having large hands. Fig: Taking, or giving, in large quantities; rapacious or bountiful.

entry.def: Having a large or generous heart or disposition; noble; liberal.
In a large manner.
The quality or state of being large.

sn.def: large in area, scope or degree; as, a large-scale attack on AIDS is needed.
constructed or drawn to a big scale{4}; as, large-scale maps. See 3rd scale n., sense 4.
widespread; applying to all or most members of a category or group.

entry.ety: F. largesse, fr. large. See Large a.

sn.def: Liberality; generosity; bounty.
sn.q: Fulfilled of largesse and of all grace.

sn.def: A present; a gift; a bounty bestowed.
sn.q: The heralds finished their proclamation with their usual cry of “Largesse largesse, gallant knights!” and gold and silver pieces were showered on them from the galleries.

sn.def: greatest in size of those under consideration.
maximal.

entry.ety: Cf. F. larget
entry.def: A short piece of bar iron for rolling into a sheet; a small billet.

entry.ety: It., dim. of largo largo
entry.def: Somewhat slow or slowly, but not so slowly as largo, and rather more so than andante.

entry.ety: L. largificus; largus large + facere
entry.def: Generous; ample; liberal.

entry.ety: L. largifluus; large abundantly + fluere to flow
entry.def: Flowing copiously.

entry.ety: Cf. L. largiloquus
entry.def: Grandiloquent.
Somewhat large.

entry.ety: L. largitio, fr. largiri, p. p. largitus, to give bountifully
entry.def: The bestowment of a largess or gift.

entry.ety: It., large, L. largus, See Large
entry.def: Slow or slowly; -- more so than adagio; next in slowness to grave, which is also weighty and solemn.

def2.def: A movement or piece in largo time.

entry.def: A suborder of birds including the gulls; terns; jaegers; and skimmers.

entry.ety: Sp. la reata the rope; la the + reata rope. Cf. Reata
entry.def: A long, slender rope made of hemp or strips of hide, esp. one with a noose; -- used as a lasso for catching cattle, horses, etc., and for picketing a horse so that he can graze without wandering.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Lariated; p. pr. & vb. n. Lariating
entry.def: To secure with a lariat fastened to a stake, as a horse or mule for grazing; also, to lasso or catch with a lariat.
The natural family of birds including the gulls and terns; the gull family.
Of or pertaining to the Gull family (Laridæ).
The genus of trees comrising the larches.
Of, or derived from, the larch (Larix); as, larixinic acid.

entry.ety: Perh fr. AS. lāc play, sport. Cf. Lake v. i.
entry.def: A frolic; a jolly time.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Larked lärkt; p. pr. & vb. n. Larking
entry.def: To sport; to frolic.

entry.note: ☞ The European skylark, or lark of the poets (Alauda arvensis), is of a brown mottled color, and is noted for its clear and sweet song, uttered as it rises and descends almost perpendicularly in the air. It is considered a table delicacy, and immense numbers are killed for the markets. Other well-known European species are the crested, or tufted, lark (Alauda cristata), and the wood lark (Alauda arborea). The pipits, or titlarks, of the genus Anthusfamily Motacillidæ) are often called larks. See Pipit. The American meadow larks, of the genus Sturnella, are allied to the starlings. See Meadow Lark. The Australian bush lark is Mirafra Horsfieldii. See Shore lark.

cs.cd: a fringilline bird (Calamospiza melanocorys) found on the plains of the Western United States.
a sparrow (Chondestes grammacus), found in the Mississippi Valley and the Western United States.

entry.ety: OE. larke laverock, AS. lāwerce; akin to D. leeuwerik, LG. lewerke, OHG. lērahha, G. lerche, Sw. lärka, Dan. lerke, Icel. lævirki
entry.def: Any one numerous species of singing birds of the genus Alauda and allied genera (family Alaudidæ). They mostly belong to Europe, Asia, and Northern Africa. In America they are represented by the shore larks, or horned larks, of the genus Otocoris. The true larks have holaspidean tarsi, very long hind claws, and, usually, dull, sandy brown colors.
To catch larks; as, to go larking .
Having the sandy brown color of the European larks.

entry.ety: See 3d Lark, for sense 1, and 1st Lark, for sense 2

sn.def: A catcher of larks.
One who indulges in a lark or frolic.

entry.def: Indian cress.

A genus of ranunculaceous plants (Delphinium), having showy flowers, and a spurred calyx. They are natives of the North Temperate zone. The commonest larkspur of the gardens is Delphinium Consolida. The flower of the bee larkspur (Delphinium elatum) has two petals bearded with yellow hairs, and looks not unlike a bee.

entry.ety: F., fr. larme tear, drop, L. lacrima. See Lachrymose
entry.def: See Tearpit.

entry.ety: Larus + -oid
entry.def: Like or belonging to the Gull family (Laridæ).

entry.note: ☞ Larrikin is often popularly explained by the following anecdote (which is without foundation): An Irish policeman at Melbourne, on bringing a notorious rough into court, was asked by the magistrate what the prisoner had been doing, and replied, “He was a-larrikin'i. e., a-larking] about the streets.”
