entries.entry: Leg lĕg v. t. To use as a leg, with it as object: To bow. Obs To run. Low

Leg"a*cy
Legacy duty a tax paid to government on legacies. Wharton. Legacy hunter one who flatters and courts any one for the sake of a legacy.
lĕg"ȧ*s� n.; pl.Legacies -sĭz. L. (assumedlegatia, for legatum, from legare to appoint by last will, to bequeath as a legacy, to depute: cf. OF. legat legacy. See Legate
A gift of property by will, esp. of money or personal property; a bequest. Also Fig.; as, a legacy of dishonor or disease.
A business with which one is intrusted by another; a commission; -- obsolete, except in the phrases last legacy dying legacy, and the like. My legacy and message wherefore I am sent into the world. He came and told his legacy.

entry.cs: Legal cap. See under Cap. Legal tender. The act of tendering in the performance of a contract or satisfaction of a claim that which the law prescribes or permits, and at such time and place as the law prescribes or permits. That currency, or money, which the law authorizes a debtor to tender and requires a creditor to receive. It differs in different countries.
entry.ety: L. legalis, fr. lex legis, law; prob. orig., that which lies or is fixed (cf. L. lectus bed), and if so akin to E. lie law: cf. F. légal. Cf. Lie to be prostrate, Loyal Leal

sn.def: Created by, permitted by, in conformity with, or relating to, law; as, a legal obligation; a legal standard or test; a legal procedure; a legal claim; a legal trade; anything is legal which the laws do not forbid.

sd.def: According to the law of works, as distinguished from free grace; or resting on works for salvation.
According to the old or Mosaic dispensation; in accordance with the law of Moses.

sn.def: Governed by the rules of law as distinguished from the rules of equity; as, legal estate; legal assets.
sn.syn: Lawful; constitutional; legitimate; licit; authorized. See Lawful.

entry.def: A style of writing or speaking heavily emphasizing the abstruse technical vocabulary of the law, to the point where a speech or document may be incomprehensible to non-specialists.

sn.def: the act of legalizing; same as legalization.

entry.def: Strictness, or the doctrine of strictness, in conforming to law.
One who practices or advocates strict conformity to law; in theology, one who holds to the law of works. See Legal, 2 .

entry.ety: Cf. LL. legalitas, F. légalité. Cf. Loyalty

sn.def: The state or quality of being legal; conformity to law.
A conformity to, and resting upon, the letter of the law.

entry.def: The act of making legal.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Legalized -īzd; p. pr. & vb. n. Legalizing -ī`zĭng
entry.ety: Cf. F. légaliser

sn.def: To make legal.
To interpret or apply in a legal spirit.

entry.def: In a legal manner.
See Legatine.

entry.ety: L. legatarius, fr. legaturius enjoined by a last will: cf. F. légataire. See Legacy
entry.def: A legatee.

entry.note: ☞ Legates are of three kinds: (a Legates a latere, now always cardinals. They are called ordinary or extraordinary legates, the former governing provinces, and the latter class being sent to foreign countries on extraordinary occasions. (b Legati missi, who correspond to the ambassadors of temporal governments. (c Legati nati, or legates by virtue of their office, as the archbishops of Salzburg and Prague.
entry.ety: OE. legat, L. legatus, fr. legare to send with a commission or charge, to depute, fr. lex legis, law: cf. F. légat, It. legato. See Legal

sn.def: An ambassador or envoy.
An ecclesiastic representing the pope and invested with the authority of the Holy See.

sd.def: An official assistant given to a general or to the governor of a province.
Under the emperors, a governor sent to a province.

entry.ety: See Legacy
entry.def: One to whom a legacy is bequeathed.
The office of a legate.

sn.def: Of or pertaining to a legate; as, legatine power.
Made by, proceeding from, or under the sanction of, a legate; as, a legatine constitution.

entry.ety: L. legatio: cf. F. légation, It. legazione. See Legate

sn.def: The sending forth or commissioning one person to act for another.
sn.q: The Divinelegationof Moses.

sn.def: A legate, or envoy, and the persons associated with him in his mission; an embassy; or, in stricter usage, a diplomatic minister and his suite; a deputation.
The place of business or official residence of a diplomatic minister at a foreign court or seat of government.
A district under the jurisdiction of a legate.

entry.ety: It., tied, joined, fr. legare to tie, bind, L. ligare
entry.def: Connected; tied; -- a term used when successive tones are to be produced in a closely connected, smoothly gliding manner. It is often indicated by a tie, thus �, �, or �, �, written over or under the notes to be so performed; -- opposed to staccato.

entry.ety: L., fr. legare: cf. OF. legateur. See Legacy
entry.def: A testator; one who bequeaths a legacy.

entry.ety: It. See Ligature
entry.def: A tie or brace; a syncopation.
Legateship.

entries.entry: Leg bridge. A type of bridge for small spans in which the floor girders are rigidly secured at their extremities to supporting steel legs, driven into the ground as piling, or resting on mudsills.

entry.ety: Abbrev. fr. allege to assert
entry.def: To allege; to assert.
See Ledgment.

entry.cs: Golden legend. See under Golden.
entry.ety: OE. legende, OF. legende, F. légende, LL. legenda, fr. L. legendus to be read, fr. legere to read, gather; akin to Gr. le`gein to gather, speak. Cf. Collect Dialogue Lesson Logic

sn.def: That which is appointed to be read; especially, a chronicle or register of the lives of saints, formerly read at matins, and in the refectories of religious houses.
A story respecting saints; especially, one of a marvelous nature.
Any wonderful story coming down from the past, but not verifiable by historical record; a myth; a fable.
sn.q:
And in this legend all that glorious deed
Read, whilst you arm you.

sn.def: An inscription, motto, or title, esp. one surrounding the field in a medal or coin, or placed upon an heraldic shield or beneath an engraving or illustration.

entry.def: To tell or narrate, as a legend.
Of or pertaining to a legend or to legends; consisting of legends; like a legend; fabulous.
entry.q: Legendarywriters.
Legendary stories of nurses and old women.

entry.ety: Cf. OF. legendaire, LL. legendarius

sn.def: A book of legends; a tale or narrative.
sn.q: Read the Countess of Pembroke's “Arcadia,” a gallant legendary full of pleasurable accidents.

sn.def: One who relates legends.

entry.ety: See Ledger

sn.def: Anything that lies in a place; that which, or one who, remains in a place.
A minister or ambassador resident at a court or seat of government.
sn.q: Sir Edward Carne, the queen's leger at Rome.

sn.def: A ledger.

entry.def: Lying or remaining in a place; hence, resident; as, leger ambassador.

cs.cd: a line added above or below the staff to extend its compass; -- called also added line.

entry.ety: F. léger, fr. LL. (assumedleviarius, fr. L. levis light in weight. See Levity
entry.def: Light; slender; slim; trivial.

entry.ety: F. léger light, nimble + de of + main hand, L. manus. See 3d Leger, and Manual
entry.def: Sleight of hand; a trick of sleight of hand; hence, any artful deception or trick.
entry.q: He of legierdemayne the mysteries did know.
The tricks and legerdemain by which men impose upon their own souls.

entry.def: One who practices sleight of hand; a prestidigitator.

entry.ety: F. légèreté. See 3d Leger
entry.def: Lightness; nimbleness.

entry.ety: See Lay v. t.
entry.def: To lay.

entry.ety: Abbrev. fr. alegge
entry.def: To lighten; to allay.

entry.ety: From Leg
entry.def: Having (such or so many) legs; -- used in composition; as, a long-legged man; a two-legged animal.

entry.ety: It
entry.def: Light or graceful; in a light, delicate, and brisk style.

entry.ety: From Leg
entry.def: A cover for the leg, like a long gaiter.
a. & vb. n., from Leg v. t.

sn.def: having tall spindly stems; -- of plants.
Having long legs.

entry.def: A straw plaiting used for bonnets and hats, made from the straw of a particular kind of wheat, grown for the purpose in Tuscany, Italy; -- so called from Leghorn, the place of exportation.
The quality of being legible; legibleness.

entry.ety: L. legibilis, fr. legere to read: cf. OF. legible. See Legend

sn.def: Capable of being read or deciphered; distinct to the eye; plain; -- used of writing or printing; as, a fair, legible manuscript.
sn.q:
The stone with moss and lichens so overspread,
Nothing is legible but the name alone.

sn.def: Capable of being discovered or understood by apparent marks or indications; as, the thoughts of men are often legible in their countenances.

entry.def: The state or quality of being legible.
In a legible manner.

entry.ety: L. lex legis, law + -ficarein comp.) to make. See -fy
entry.def: Of or pertaining to making laws.
entry.q: Practically, in many cases, authority or legific competence has begun in bare power.

cs.cd: an order instituted by the French government in 1802, when Bonaparte was First Consul, as a reward for merit, both civil and military.

entry.ety: OE. legioun, OF. legion, F. légion, fr. L. legio, fr. legere to gather, collect. See Legend

sn.def: A body of foot soldiers and cavalry consisting of different numbers at different periods, -- from about four thousand to about six thousand men, -- the cavalry being about one tenth.
A military force; an army; military bands.
A great number; a multitude.
sn.q: Where one sin has entered, legions will force their way through the same breach.

sn.def: A group of orders inferior to a class.

entry.ety: L. legionarius: cf. F. légionnaire
entry.def: Belonging to a legion; consisting of a legion or legions, or of an indefinitely great number; as, legionary soldiers; a legionary force.
entry.q: Thelegionarybody of error.

entries.entry: Le"gion*a*ry lē"jŭn*�*r� n.; pl.Legionaries -rĭz. A member of a legion.

entry.def: Formed into a legion or legions; legionary.
A body of legions; legions, collectively.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Legislated -lā`tĕd; p. pr. & vb. n. Legislating -lā`tĭng
entry.ety: See Legislator
entry.def: To make or enact a law or laws.
entry.q: Solon, in legislating for the Athenians, had an idea of a more perfect constitution than he gave them.

entry.def: the act of making or enacting laws; legislation{1}.

entry.ety: Cf. F. législation, L. legis latio. See Legislator
entry.def: The act of legislating; preparation and enactment of laws; the laws enacted.
entry.q: Pythagoras joined legislation to his philosophy.

entry.ety: Cf. F. législatif

sn.def: Making, or having the power to make, a law or laws; lawmaking; -- distinguished from executive; as, a legislative act; a legislative body.
sn.q: The supreme legislative power of England was lodged in the king and great council, or what was afterwards called the Parliament.

sn.def: Of or pertaining to the making of laws; suitable to legislation; as, the transaction of legislative business; the legislative style.

entry.def: In a legislative manner.

entry.ety: L. legis lator, prop., a proposer of a law; lex legis, law + lator a proposer, bearer, fr. latus, used as p. p. of ferre to bear: cf. F. législateur. See Legal, and Tolerate
entry.def: A lawgiver; one who makes laws for a state or community; a member of a legislative body.
entry.q: The legislators in ancient and heroical times.
Many of the legislators themselves had taken an oath of abjuration of his Majesty's person and family.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to a legislator or legislature.
The office of a legislator.
A woman who makes laws.

entry.note: ☞ The legislature of Great Britain consists of the Lords and Commons, with the king or queen, whose sanction is necessary to every bill before it becomes a law. The legislatures of most of the United States consist of two houses or branches; but the sanction or consent of the governor is required to give their acts the force of law, or a concurrence of two thirds of the two houses after he has refused his sanction and assigned his objections.

The legislatures of some of the more important states having constitutional government are as follows, the general name (or a translation of it) of the legislative body collectively being given under the heading legislature or parliament:

-------------------------------------------------------------- *In the self-governing colonies of Great Britain the legislative body usually consists of two chambers, the names of the legislature and the chambers varying. Thus in Australia the Federal Parliament is composed of the Senate and the House of Commons, in New Zealand the General Assembly is composed of the Legislative Council and the House of Representatives, etc. #Members of the Storthing are chosen for three years by direct election by manhood suffrage, forty-one being elected from the towns and eighty-two from the rural districts. The Storthing on assembling divides into the Lagthing including one fourth and the Odelsthing including three fourths of the total membership of the Storthing. All new laws are laid first before the Odelsthing. If the two houses do not agree they vote in joint session, a majority of two thirds of those voting being necessary to a decision. § While theoretically general, the suffrage is so classified as often practically to disfranchise those who are not property holders.
entry.ety: Cf. F. législature
entry.def: The body of persons in a state or kingdom invested with power to make and repeal laws; a legislative body.
entry.q: Without the concurrent consent of all three parts of the legislature, no law is, or can be, made.

entry.ety: F. légiste, LL. legista, fr. L. lex legis, law. See Legal
entry.def: One skilled in the laws; a writer on law.

entry.ety: See Legitimate a.
entry.def: The portion of movable estate to which the children are entitled upon the death of the father.

entry.ety: See Legitimate a.
entry.def: The state, or quality, of being legitimate, or in conformity with law; hence, the condition of having been lawfully begotten, or born in wedlock.
entry.q: The doctrine of Divine Right, which has now come back to us, like a thief from transportation, under the alias of Legitimacy.

entry.ety: LL. legitimatus, p. p. of legitimare to legitimate, fr. L. legitimus legitimate. See Legal

sn.def: Accordant with law or with established legal forms and requirements; lawful; as, legitimate government; legitimate rights; the legitimate succession to the throne; a legitimate proceeding of an officer; a legitimate heir.
Lawfully begotten; born in wedlock.
Authorized; real; genuine; not false, counterfe`t, or spurious; as,$legitimate poems of Chaucer; legitimate inscriptions.
Conforming to known principles, or accepted rules; as, legitimate reasoning; a legitimate standard, or method; a legitimate combination of colors.
sn.q: Tillotson still keeps his place as a legitimate English classic.

sn.def: Following by logical sequence; reasonable; as, a legitimate result; a legitimate inference.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Legitimated -mā`tĕd; p. pr. & vb. n. Legitimating -mā`tĭng
entry.def: To make legitimate, lawful, or valid; esp., to put in the position or state of a legitimate person before the law, by legal means; as, to legitimate a bastard child.
entry.q: To enact a statute of that which he dares not seem to approve, even to legitimate vice.

entry.def: In a legitimate manner; lawfully; genuinely.
The state or quality of being legitimate; lawfulness; genuineness.

entry.ety: Cf. F. légitimation

sn.def: The act of making legitimate.
sn.q: The coining or legitimation of money.

sn.def: Lawful birth.

entry.def: See Legitimist.
To legitimate.
The principles or plans of legitimists.

entry.ety: Cf. F. légitimiste

sn.def: One who supports legitimate authority; esp., one who believes in hereditary monarchy, as a divine right.
Specifically, a supporter of the claims of the elder branch of the Bourbon dynasty to the crown of France.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Legitimized -mīzd; p. pr. & vb. n. Legitimizing
entry.def: To legitimate.
Not having a leg.
Having the general shape or outline of a leg of mutton; as, a leg-of-mutton, or shoulder-of-mutton, sail.

entry.ety: See Legal, and Literary
entry.def: Pertaining to the literature of law.
An attempt to make somebody believe something that is not true, done as a joke.
The act of attempting to make somebody believe something that is not true, done as a joke.

entry.ety: L. leguleius pettifogger, fr. lex legis, law
entry.def: Lawyerlike; legal.
entry.q: Leguleianbarbarism.

entry.note: ☞ In the latter circumstance, it differs from a siliqua, in which the seeds are attached to both sutures. In popular use, a legume is called a pod, or cod; as, pea pod, or peas cod.
entry.ety: F. légume, L. legumen, fr. legere to gather. So called because they may be gathered without cutting. See Legend

sn.def: A pod dehiscent into two pieces or valves, and having the seed attached at one suture, as that of the pea.
The fruit of leguminous plants, as peas, beans, lupines; pulse.

entries.entry: ‖Le*gu"men l�*gū"mĕn n.; pl. L. Legumina -mĭ*nȧ, E. Legumens -mĕnz. L Same as Legume.

entry.ety: Cf. F. légumine
entry.def: An albuminous substance resembling casein, found as a characteristic ingredient of the seeds of leguminous and grain-bearing plants.

entry.ety: Cf. F. légumineux

sn.def: Pertaining to pulse; consisting of pulse.
Belonging to, or resembling, a very large natural order of plants (Leguminosæ), which bear legumes, including peas, beans, clover, locust trees, acacias, and mimosas.

entry.ety: See Leger, and Ledger
entry.def: See Leger n., 2.
The type and sole genus of the family Leiopelmatidae.
A natural family of primitive New Zealand frogs.
A genus having only one species, the sand myrtle.
Of or pertaining to the Leiotrichi.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. lei^os smooth + qri`x tricho`s, hair
entry.def: The division of mankind which embraces the smooth-haired races.

entry.ety: See Leiotrichi
entry.def: Having smooth, or nearly smooth, hair.

entry.note: ☞ It makes large mounds of sand and vegetable material, in which its eggs are laid to be hatched by the heat of the decomposing mass.
entry.ety: NL
entry.def: A genus of Australian gallinaceous birds including but a single species (Leipoa ocellata), about the size of a turkey. Its color is variegated, brown, black, white, and gray. Called also native pheasant.
See Lipothymic.
A spear armed with three or more prongs, for striking fish.

entry.ety: See Leisure

sn.def: Leisurely.
Vacant of employment; not occupied; idle; leisure; as leisurable hours.

entry.def: At leisure.

entry.cs: At leisure. Free from occupation; not busy. In a leisurely manner; at a convenient time.
entry.ety: OE. leisere leiser, OF. leisir, F. loisir, orig., permission, fr. L. licere to be permitted. See License

sn.def: Freedom from occupation or business; vacant time; time free from employment.
sn.q: The desire of leisure is much more natural than of business and care.

sn.def: Time at one's command, free from engagement; convenient opportunity; hence, convenience; ease.
sn.q: He sighed, and had no leisure more to say.

entry.def: Unemployed; as, leisure hours.
Having leisure.
entry.q: Theleisuredclasses.

entry.def: Characterized by leisure; taking abundant time; not hurried; as, a leisurely manner; a leisurely walk.
In a leisurely manner.

entry.ety: G., leading motive

sn.def: a guiding theme; in Wagnerian opera, a marked melodic phrase or short musical passage which always accompanies the reappearance of a certain person, situation, abstract idea, or allusion in the course of the play; a sort of musical label. Also called Leading motive.
a recurring theme in the activities of a person or group.

entry.def: A genus of trees or shrubs coextensive with the family Leitneriaceae, and including the corkwood (Leitneria floridana).
A natural family of trees coextensive with the genus Leitneria; commonly isolated in a distinct order.

entry.ety: acronym from Lunar Excursion Module
entry.def: A lunar excursion module, a spacecraft designed to transport people from a command module in orbit around the moon to the surface of the moon and back again.
A genus of tropical American cacti, usually tall and branching with stout spines and funnel-shaped flowers and globular or ovoid often edible fruit.

entry.ety: OE. lemman lefman; AS. leóf dear + mann man. See Lief, and Man
entry.def: A sweetheart, of either sex; a gallant, or a mistress; -- usually in a bad sense.
A fruit tree (Citrus limonia) which is a hybrid between the mandarin orange and the lemon, having a very acid fruit with an orange peel; also, the fruit of this tree, the rangpur.

entry.ety: OE. leem leme leam, AS. leóma light, brightness; akin to E. light n. √122
entry.def: A ray or glimmer of light; a gleam.
To shine.

entries.entry:
Lem"ma lĕm"mȧ n.; pl. L. Lemmata -mȧ*tȧ, E. Lemmas -mȧz. L. lemma, Gr. lh^mma anything received, an assumption or premise taken for granted, fr. lamba`nein to take, assume. Cf. Syllable
Math., Logic A preliminary or auxiliary proposition demonstrated or accepted for immediate use in the demonstration of some other proposition, as in mathematics or logic.
A word that is included in a glossary or list of headwords; a headword.

entry.note: ☞ Lemmatization of search words in a computerized Information Retrieval System may allow more effective retrieval of documents of interest to the searcher.
entry.def: The act or process of lemmatizing; conversion into a lemma{2}.
To convert into a lemma{2}; to normalize the form of (a word) to that form used as the headword in a dictionary, glossary, or index; as, “ride” is the lemmatized form for “riding” and “ridden”.
A leman.

entry.note: ☞ The common Northern European lemming (Myodes lemmus) is remarkable for making occasional devastating migrations in enormous numbers from the mountains into the lowlands.
entry.ety: Nor. lemming lemende; cf. Sw. lemel, Lapp. lummik
entry.def: Any one of several species of small arctic rodents of the genera Myodes and Cuniculus, resembling the meadow mice in form. They are found in both hemispheres.
A genus of minute acquatic herbs floating on or below the water surface of still water consisting of a leaflike frond or plant body and single root.
A natural family of small free-floating thalloid plants.

cs.cd: an aluminous earth of a grayish yellow color; sphragide; -- formerly sold as medicine, having astringent properties.
a reddle of firm consistence and deep red color; -- used by artificers in coloring.

entry.ety: L. Lemnius, fr. Lemnus, Gr. Lh^mnos
entry.def: Of or pertaining to the isle of Lemnos.

entry.ety: L. lemniscatus adorned with ribbons, fr. lemniscus a ribbon hanging down, Gr. lhmni`skos
entry.def: A curve in the form of the figure 8, with both parts symmetrical, generated by the point in which a tangent to an equilateral hyperbola meets the perpendicular on it drawn from the center.

entries.entry:
‖Lem*nis"cus lĕm*nĭs"kŭs n.; pl. Lemnisci -sī n. L. See Lemniscata
Zoöl One of two oval bodies hanging from the interior walls of the body in the Acanthocephala.

cs.cd: a fragrant East Indian grass (Andropogon Shœnanthus, and perhaps other allied species), which yields the grass oil used in perfumery.
a yellow European sole (Solea aurantiaca).

a white crystalline substance, inappropriately named, as it consists of an acid potassium oxalate and contains no citric acid, which is the characteristic acid of lemon; -- called also salts of sorrel. It is used in removing ink stains. See Oxalic acid, under Oxalic.

entry.ety: F. limon, Per. līmūn; cf. Ar. laimūn, Sp. limon, It. limone. Cf. Lime a fruit

sn.def: An oval or roundish fruit resembling the orange, and containing a pulp usually intensely acid. It is produced by a tropical tree of the genus Citrus, the common fruit known in commerce being that of the species Citrus Limonum or Citrus Medicavar. Limonum). There are many varieties of the fruit, some of which are sweet.
The tree which bears lemons; the lemon tree.

entry.ety: F. limonade; cf. Sp. limonada, It. limonata. See Lemon
entry.def: A beverage consisting of lemon juice mixed with water and sweetened.
entry.q: If you have lemons, makelemonade

sn.def: hard tough elastic wood of the lemonwood tree; used for making bows and fishing rods.
A South African evergreen having hard tough wood.
tasting like lemons.

entry.ety: L., a ghost, specter. So called on account of its habit of going abroad by night
entry.def: One of a family (Lemuridæ) of nocturnal mammals allied to the monkeys, but of small size, and having a sharp and foxlike muzzle, and large eyes. They feed upon birds, insects, and fruit, and are mostly natives of Madagascar and the neighboring islands, one genus (Galago) occurring in Africa. The slow lemur or kukang of the East Indies is Nycticebus tardigradus. See Galago Indris, and Colugo.

entry.ety: L. See Lemur
entry.def: Spirits or ghosts of the departed; specters.
entry.q: The Lars and Lemures moan with midnight plaint.

entry.ety: So named from the supposition that it was the original home of the lemurs
entry.def: A hypothetical land, or continent, supposed by some to have existed formerly in the Indian Ocean, of which Madagascar is a remnant.
Same as Lemuroid.
Lemuroid.

entry.ety: Lemur + -oid
entry.def: Like or pertaining to the lemurs or the Lemuroidea.

entry.ety: NL. See Lemur, and -oid
entry.def: A suborder of primates, including the lemurs, the aye-aye, and allied species.

entry.ety: L
entry.def: A procuress.

Rays emanating from the outer surface of a plate composed of any material permeable by cathode rays, as aluminium, which forms a portion of a wall of a vacuum tube, or which is mounted within the tube and exposed to radiation from the cathode. Lenard rays are similar in all their known properties to cathode rays. So called from the German physicist Philipp Lenard (b. 1862), who first described them.

entries.entry: Lenard tube. Elec A tube for producing Lenard rays.

entry.note: ☞ This use of the word is rare in the United States, except with reference to money.

cs.cd: to give assistance; to help.
cs.mcol: To lend one's earsorTo lend an ear
cs.cd: to give attention.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Lent lĕnt; p. pr. & vb. n. Lending
entry.ety: OE. lenen, AS. lǣnan, fr. lǣn loan; akin to G. lehnen to lend. See Loan

sn.def: To allow the custody and use of, on condition of the return of the same; to grant the temporary use of; as, to lend a book; -- opposed to borrow.
sn.q: Give me that ring. I'll lend it thee, my dear, but have no power To give it from me.

sn.def: To allow the possession and use of, on condition of the return of an equivalent in kind; as, to lend money or some article of food.
sn.q: Thou shalt not give him thy money upon usury, nor lend him thy victuals for increase.

sn.def: To afford; to grant or furnish in general; as, to lend assistance; to lend one's name or influence.
sn.q: Cato, lend me for a while thy patience.
Mountain lines and distant horizons lend space and largeness to his compositions.

sn.def: To let for hire or compensation; as, to lend a horse or gig.

entry.def: Such as can be lent.
One who lends.
entry.q: The borrower is servant to the lender.

entry.def: See Lends.

sn.def: The act of one who lends.
That which is lent or furnished.

entry.def: the temporary transfer of goods and services to an ally to aid in a common cause; as, lend-lease during World War II was extremely generous.

entry.ety: AS. lend lenden; akin to D. & G. lende, OHG. lenti, Icel. lend, and perh to E. loin
entry.def: Loins.

entry.ety: See Lend
entry.def: To lend; to grant; to permit.

entry.ety: L. lenis smooth
entry.def: Smooth; as, the lene breathing.
Applied to certain mute consonants, as pk, and tor Gr. π, κ, τ).
The smooth breathing (spiritus lenis).
Any one of the lene consonants, as pk, or tor Gr. π, κ, τ).
Longer; longest; -- obsolete compar. and superl. of long.

entry.cs: At length. At or in the full extent; without abbreviation; as, let the name be inserted at length. At the end or conclusion; after a long period. See Syn. of At last, under Last. At arm's length. See under Arm.
entry.ety: OE. lengthe, AS. lengð, fr. lang long, long; akin to D. lengte, Dan. længde, Sw. längd, Icel. lengd. See Long a.

sn.def: The longest, or longer, dimension of any object, in distinction from breadth or width; extent of anything from end to end; the longest line which can be drawn through a body, parallel to its sides; as, the length of a church, or of a ship; the length of a rope or line.
A portion of space or of time considered as measured by its length; -- often in the plural.
sn.q: Large lengths of seas and shores.
The future but a length behind the past.

sn.def: The quality or state of being long, in space or time; extent; duration; as, some sea birds are remarkable for the length of their wings; he was tired by the length of the sermon, and the length of his walk.
A single piece or subdivision of a series, or of a number of long pieces which may be connected together; as, a length of pipe; a length of fence.
Detail or amplification; unfolding; continuance as, to pursue a subject to a great length.
sn.q: May Heaven, great monarch, still augment your bliss With length of days, and every day like this.

sn.def: Distance.
sn.q: He had marched to the length of Exeter.

entry.def: To lengthen.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Lengthened -'nd; p. pr. & vb. n. Lengthening -'n*ĭng
entry.def: To extent in length; to make longer in extent or duration; as, to lengthen a line or a road; to lengthen life; -- sometimes followed by out.
entry.q: What if I please to lengthen out his date.

entry.def: To become longer.
Long.
In a lengthy manner; at great length or extent.
The state or quality of being lengthy; prolixity.
In the direction of the length; running or extending in the direction of the length of a thing; in a longitudinal direction. Contrasted with crosswise.
Having length; rather long or too long; prolix; not brief; -- said chiefly of discourses, writings, and the like.
entry.q: Lengthyperiods.
Somelengthyadditions.
These would be details toolengthy.
To cut shortlengthyexplanations.

entry.mhw: Le"ni*ence lē"nĭ*�ns or lēn"y�ns; 106 Le"ni*en*cy lē"nĭ*�n*s� or lēn"y�n*s�,
entry.def: The quality or state of being lenient; lenity; clemency.

entry.ety: L. leniens -entis, p. pr. of lenire to soften, fr. lenis soft, mild. Cf. Lithe

sn.def: Relaxing; emollient; softening; assuasive; -- sometimes followed by of.
sn.q: Lenientof grief.
O�� relax the fibers, are lenient, balsamic.
Time, that on all things lays his lenient hand.

sn.def: Mild; clement; merciful; not rigorous or severe; as, a lenient disposition; a lenient judge or sentence.

entry.def: A lenitive; an emollient.
In a lenient manner.

entry.ety: L. lenis soft, mild + -fy: cf. F. lénifier
entry.def: To assuage; to soften; to mitigate; to alleviate.

entry.ety: L. lenimentum: cf. OF. leniment. See Lenient
entry.def: An assuasive.

A city in the European part of Soviet Russia; the former capital of Russia. The name was formerly St. Petersburg and Petrograd, and was changed back to Saint Petersburg Sankt Peterburg in Russian) in 1992.
entry.syn: St. Petersburg, Peterburg, Petrograd, Saint Petersburg.

entry.def: a form of communism based on the writings of Marx and Lenin; called also Marxism-Leninism.
entry.syn: bolshevism, collectivism, Marxism-Leninism, Marxism, Sovietism, sovietism.

entry.ety: Cf. F. lénitif. See Lenient
entry.def: Having the quality of softening or mitigating, as pain or acrimony; assuasive; emollient.

entry.ety: Cf. F. lénitif

sd.def: A medicine or application that has the quality of easing pain or protecting from the action of irritants.
A mild purgative; a laxative.

sn.def: That which softens or mitigates; that which tends to allay passion, excitement, or pain; a palliative.
sn.q: There is one sweet lenitive at least for evils, which Nature holds out; so I took it kindly at her hands, and fell asleep.

entry.def: The quality of being lenitive.

entry.ety: L. lenitudo
entry.def: The quality or habit of being lenient; lenity.

entry.ety: L. lenitas, fr. lenis soft, mild: cf. OF. lenité. See Lenient
entry.def: The state or quality of being lenient; mildness of temper or disposition; gentleness of treatment; softness; tenderness; clemency; -- opposed to severity and rigor.
entry.q: His exceeding lenity disposes us to be somewhat too severe.
entry.syn: Gentleness; kindness; tenderness; softness; humanity; clemency; mercy.

entry.def: A general name for a group of Algonquin tribes which formerly occupied the coast region of North America from Connecticut to Virginia. They included the Mohicans, Delawares, Shawnees, and several other tribes.

entry.ety: Cf. It. leno weak, flexible
entry.def: A light open cotton fabric used for window curtains.

entry.ety: L. lenocinans, p. pr. of lenocinari to pander, cajole; akin to leno pimp
entry.def: Given to lewdness.

entries.entry:
Lens ☞ Of spherical lenses, there are six varieties, as shown in section in the figures herewith given: viz., a plano-concave; b double-concave; c plano-convex; d double-convex; e converging concavo-convex, or converging meniscus; f diverging concavo-convex, or diverging meniscus.
Crossed lens Opt a double-convex lens with one radius equal to six times the other. Crystalline lens. Anat See Eye. Fresnel lens Opt a compound lens formed by placing around a central convex lens rings of glass so curved as to have the same focus; used, especially in lighthouses, for concentrating light in a particular direction; -- so called from the inventor.
Multiplying lensorMultiplying glass
Opt a lens one side of which is plane and the other convex, but made up of a number of plane faces inclined to one another, each of which presents a separate image of the object viewed through it, so that the object is, as it were, multiplied. Polyzonal lens. See Polyzonal.
lĕnz n.; pl.Lenses -ĕz. L. lens a lentil. So named from the resemblance in shape of a double convex lens to the seed of a lentil. Cf. Lentil
Opt A piece of glass, or other transparent substance, ground with two opposite regular surfaces, either both curved, or one curved and the other plane, and commonly used, either singly or combined, in optical instruments, for changing the direction of rays of light, and thus magnifying objects, or otherwise modifying vision. In practice, the curved surfaces are usually spherical, though rarely cylindrical, or of some other figure.
Lenses

entry.def: imp. & p. p. of Lend.

cs.cd: the daffodil; -- so named from its blossoming in spring.

entry.ety: OE. lente lenten leynte, AS. lengten lencten, spring, lent, akin to D. lente, OHG. lenzin langiz, G. lenz, and perh. fr. AS. lang long, E. long, because at this season of the year the days lengthen
entry.def: A fast of forty days, beginning with Ash Wednesday and continuing till Easter, observed by some Christian churches as commemorative of the fast of our Savior.

entry.ety: L. lentus; akin to lenis soft, mild: cf. F. lent. See Lenient

sn.def: Slow; mild; gentle; as, lenter heats.
See Lento.

entry.ety: It
entry.def: Slowly; in slow time.

entry.ety: It., p. pr. of lentare to make slow. See Lent a.
entry.def: Slackening; retarding. Same as Rallentando.
Lent.

cs.cd: black or violet.

entry.ety: From OE. lenten lent. See Lent n.

sn.def: Of or pertaining to the fast called Lent; used in, or suitable to, Lent; as, the Lenten season.
sn.q: She quenched her fury at the flood, And with a Lenten salad cooled her blood.

sn.def: Spare; meager; plain; somber; unostentatious; not abundant or showy.
sn.q: Lentenentertainment.
Lentenanswer.
Lentensuit.

entry.def: The season of Lenten or Lent.

entry.ety: F. lenticelle, dim. fr. L. lens lentis, a lentil. Cf. Lentil
entry.def: One of the small, oval, rounded spots upon the stem or branch of a plant, from which the underlying tissues may protrude or roots may issue, either in the air, or more commonly when the stem or branch is covered with water or earth.
A small, lens-shaped gland on the under side of some leaves.
Producing lenticels; dotted with lenticels.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: Lenticel.

entries.entry:
‖Len*tic"u*la lĕn*tĭk"�*lȧ n.; pl. E. Lenticulas -lȧz, L. Lenticulæ -lē. L. See Lenticel
Med A kind of eruption upon the skin; lentigo; freckle.
Opt A lens of small size.
Bot A lenticel.

entry.ety: L. lenticularis: cf. F. lenticulaire. See Lenticel
entry.def: Resembling a lentil in size or form; having the form of a double-convex lens.
In the manner of a lens; with a curve.

entry.ety: L. lens lentis, lentil + -form: cf. F. lentiforme
entry.def: Lenticular.

entry.ety: See Lentiginous
entry.def: Bearing numerous dots resembling freckles.

entry.ety: L. lentiginosus. See Lentigo
entry.def: Of or pertaining to lentigo; freckly; scurfy; furfuraceous.

entry.ety: L., fr. lens lentis, lentil

entry.note: ☞ The lentil of the Scriptures probably included several other vetchlike plants.

cs.cd: a small bivalve shell of the genus Ervillia, family Tellinidæ.

entry.ety: F. lentille, fr. L. lenticula, dim. of lens lentis, lentil. Cf. Lens
entry.def: A leguminous plant of the genus Ervum Ervum Lens), of small size, common in the fields in Europe. Also, its seed, which is used for food on the continent.
The most important genus of mushrooms in the Far East.

entry.ety: L. lentiscus lentiscum: cf. F. lentisque
entry.def: A tree; the mastic. See Mastic.
very slow; very slowly; -- of music tempo.

entry.ety: L. lentitudo, fr. lentus slow: cf. OF. lentitude. See Lent a.
entry.def: Slowness; sluggishness.

entry.def: Slow; in slow time; slowly; -- rarely written lente.

entry.ety: Lens + -oid
entry.def: Having the form of a lens; lens-shaped.

entry.ety: L., fr. lentus pliant, tough, slow. See Lent a.

sn.def: Tenacity; viscidity, as of fluids.
Slowness; delay; sluggishness.

entry.ety: L. lentus. See Lentor
entry.def: Viscid; viscous; tenacious.
entry.q: Spawn of a lentous and transparent body.

entry.ety: F. le the + envoi a sending. See Envoy

sn.def: One or more detached verses at the end of a literary composition, serving to convey the moral, or to address the poem to a particular person; -- orig. employed in old French poetry.
A conclusion; a result.

cs.cd: a small constellation between Leo and the Great Bear.

entry.ety: L. See Lion

sn.def: The Lion, the fifth sign of the zodiac, marked thus [♌] in almanacs.
A northern constellation east of Cancer, containing the bright star Regulus at the end of the handle of the Sickle.

entry.ety: AS. leód people, nation, man, chief; akin to OS. liud, OHG. liut, pl. liuti, G. leute, pl., fr. AS. leódan to grow, akin to Goth. liudan, OS. liodan OHG. liotan to grow; cf. Skr. ruh. √123
entry.def: People; a nation; a man.
A lion.
See Lionced.
Of or pertaining to Leon, in Spain.

def2.def: A native or natives of Leon.

entry.ety: From Leo: cf. F. léonides, pl
entry.def: One of the shooting stars which constitute the star shower that recurs near the fourteenth of November at intervals of about thirty-three years; -- so called because these shooting stars appear on the heavens to move in lines directed from the constellation Leo.

cs.cd: a kind of verse, in which the end of the line rhymes with the middle; -- so named from Leo, or Leoninus, a Benedictine and canon of Paris in the twelfth century, who wrote largely in this measure, though he was not the inventor. The following line is an example:

entry.ety: L. leoninus, fr. leo leonis, lion: cf. F. léonin. See Lion
entry.def: Pertaining to, or characteristic of, the lion; as, a leonine look; leonine rapacity.
entry.q: Gloria factorum temere conceditur horum.

entry.def: A small genus of tropical herbs and subshrubs of S Africa.
A genus of marmosets including some of the tamarins. Called also Leontopithecus and Leontideus .
entry.syn: genus Leontocebus, genus Leontideus, genus Leontopithecus.

entry.def: A genus of plants including the edelweiss (Leontopodium alpinum).

entry.ety: Gr. le`wn le`ontos, lion + 'odoy`s 'odo`ntos, tooth. Cf. Lion's-tooth Dandelion
entry.def: A genus of liguliflorous composite plants, including the fall dandelion (Leontodon autumnale), and formerly the true dandelion; -- called also lion's tooth.
A genus of stout Old World herbs having cut-lobed leaves and flowers in whorls.

entry.cs: Hunting leopard. See Cheetah. Leopard cat Zoöl any one of several species or varieties of small, spotted cats found in Africa, Southern Asia, and the East Indies; esp., Felis Bengalensis. Leopard marmot. See Gopher, 2.
entry.ety: OE. leopart leparde lebarde libbard, OF. leopard liepart, F. léopard, L. leopardus, fr. Gr. leo`pardos; le`wn lion + pa`rdos pard. See Lion, and Pard
entry.def: A large, savage, carnivorous mammal (Felis leopardus). It is of a yellow or fawn color, with rings or roselike clusters of black spots along the back and sides. It is found in Southern Asia and Africa. By some the panther (Felis pardus) is regarded as a variety of leopard.

cs.cd: Any of several herbs of the genus Doronicum, such as the great false leopardbane Doronicum pardalianches) of North America and the oriental false leopardbane Doronicum orientale syn. Doronicum caucasicum).

entry.def: Any of several herbs of the genus Doronicumas Doronicum acaule syn. Arnica acaulis) having alternate often clasping stem leaves cultivated for their long stalks of yellow flower heads. See leopard's bane.
A female leopard.
A name of several harmless plants, as Arnica montana Arnica acaulis syn. Doronicum acaule), Senecio Doronicum, and Paris quadrifolia.
See Letterwood.

entries.entry: lep lĕp obs. strong imp. of Leap . Leaped.

entry.def: A natural family of crustaceans including the goose barnacles.

entry.ety: L. lepas lepadis, limpet, Gr. lepa`s lepa`dos
entry.def: Same as Lepadoid.

entry.ety: Lepas + -oid
entry.def: A stalked barnacle of the genus Lepas, or family Lepadidæ; a goose barnacle. Also used adjectively.

entry.ety: Gr. lepi`s a scale: cf. F. lépale
entry.def: A sterile transformed stamen.
The name of a battle in which Turkish seapower was destroyed by the Christian League in 1571.

entry.ety: L., a limpet, fr. Gr. lepa`s
entry.def: Any one of various species of Lepas, a genus of pedunculated barnacles found attached to floating timber, bottoms of ships, Gulf weed, etc.; -- called also goose barnacle. See Barnacle.

entry.ety: OE. lepre leprosy, F. lèpre, L. leprae lepra, fr. Gr. le`pra, fr. lepro`s scaly, fr. le`pos scale, le`pein to peel
entry.def: A person affected with leprosy.
Affected or tainted with leprosy.
To affect with leprosy.
Leprous; infectious; corrupting; poisonous.
entry.q: Theleperousdistillment.

entry.ety: L. lepidus
entry.def: Pleasant; jocose.
entry.q: The joyous and lepid consul.

entry.def: An organic base, C9H6.N.CH3, metameric with quinaldine, and obtained by the distillation of cinchonine.
An order of fossil arborescent plants arising during the Lower Devonian and conspicuous throughout the Carboniferous.
One of an extinct family of trees allied to the modern club mosses, and including Lepidodendron and its allies.
Allied to, or resembling, Lepidodendron.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. lepi`s -i`dos, a scale + de`ndron tree
entry.def: A genus of fossil trees of the Devonian and Carboniferous ages, having the exterior marked with scars, mostly in quincunx order, produced by the separation of the leafstalks.

entry.ety: Gr. lepi`s -i`dos, a scale + E. ganoid
entry.def: Any one of a division (Lepidoganoidei) of ganoid fishes, including those that have scales forming a coat of mail. Also used adjectively.

entry.ety: Gr. lepi`s -i`dos, a scale + -lite: cf. F. lépidolithe
entry.def: A species of mica, of a lilac or rose-violet color, containing lithia. It usually occurs in masses consisting of small scales. See Mica.

entry.ety: Gr. lepi`s -i`dos, a scale + me`las me`laina, black
entry.def: An iron-potash mica, of a raven-black color, usually found in granitic rocks in small six-sided tables, or as an aggregation of minute opaque scales. See Mica.

entry.ety: Cf. F. lépidoptère
entry.def: One of the Lepidoptera.

entry.note: ☞ They have a tubular proboscis, or haustellum, formed by the two slender maxillæ. The labial palpi are usually large, and the proboscis, when not in use, can be coiled up spirally between them. The mandibles are rudimentary. The larvæ, called caterpillars, are often brightly colored, and they commonly feed on leaves. The adults feed chiefly on the honey of flowers.
entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. lepi`s -i`dos, a scale + ptero`n a feather, wing
entry.def: An order of insects, which includes the butterflies and moths. They have broad wings, covered with minute overlapping scales, usually brightly colored.
Of or pertaining to the Lepidoptera.
Same as lepidopterous.
An insect that in the adult state has four wings more or less covered with tiny scales; a lepidopterous insect.
One who studies the Lepidoptera.
An insect that in the adult state has four wings more or less covered with tiny scales.
See lepidopteral.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. lepi`s -i`dos, a scale + say^ros a lizard
entry.def: A division of reptiles, including the serpents and lizards; the Plagiotremata.

entry.ety: Gr. lepi`s -i`dos, a scale + seirh`n a siren
entry.def: An eel-shaped ganoid fish of the order Dipnoi, having both gills and lungs. It inhabits the rivers of South America. The name is also applied to a related African species (Protopterus annectens). The lepidosirens grow to a length of from four to six feet. Called also doko.

entry.ety: Gr. lepidwto`s covered with scales, fr. lepi`s -i`dos, a scale
entry.def: Having a coat of scurfy scales, as the leaves of the oleaster.
any fungus of the genus Lepiota.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. le`pisma peel, fr. lepi`s -i`dos, a scale
entry.def: A genus of wingless thysanurous insects having an elongated flattened body, covered with shining scales and terminated by seven unequal bristles. A common species (Lepisma saccharina) is found in houses, and often injures books and furniture; it feeds on starch and eats sized paper and starched clothes. Called also shiner silverfish silver witch silver moth, and furniture bug.

entry.ety: Lepisma + -oid
entry.def: Like or pertaining to the Lepisma.
A genus of freshwater sunfishes, inclding some of the breams.
A mammal of the family Leporidae, including the rabbits and hares.
A natural family of mammals comprising the hares and rabbits.

sn.def: red breed of domestic rabbits, also called Belgian hare.

entry.ety: L. leporinus, fr. lepus leporis, hare. See Leveret
entry.def: Of or pertaining to a hare; like or characteristic of, a hare.
A motherless calf in a range herd of cattle.

entry.note: ☞ The term lepra was formerly given to various skin diseases, the leprosy of modern authors being Lepra Arabum. See Leprosy.
entry.ety: L. See Leper
entry.def: Leprosy.
Leprosy.

A small mischevous elf or spirit in Irish folklore; it is often depicted in literature as a dwarfish bearded old man; -- legend tells that if a leprechaun is captured, he will reveal the location of his hidden pot of gold.

entry.ety: See Leprous
entry.def: Covered with thin, scurfy scales.
The state or quality of being leprous or scaly; also, a scale.

entry.note: ☞ The disease now called leprosy, also designated as Lepra or Lepra Arabum, and Elephantiasis Græcorum, is not the same as the leprosy of the ancients. The latter was, indeed, a generic name for many varieties of skin disease (including our modern leprosy, psoriasis, etc.), some of which, among the Hebrews, rendered a person ceremonially unclean. A variety of leprosy of the Hebrews (probably identical with modern leprosy) was characterized by the presence of smooth, shining, depressed white patches or scales, the hair on which participated in the whiteness, while the skin and adjacent flesh became insensible. It was an incurable disease.
entry.ety: See Leprous
entry.def: A cutaneous disease which first appears as blebs or as reddish, shining, slightly prominent spots, with spreading edges. These are often followed by an eruption of dark or yellowish prominent nodules, frequently producing great deformity. In one variety of the disease, anæsthesia of the skin is a prominent symptom. In addition there may be wasting of the muscles, falling out of the hair and nails, and distortion of the hands and feet with destruction of the bones and joints. It is incurable, and is probably contagious.

entry.ety: OF. leprous lepros, F. lépreux, fr. L. leprosus, fr. lepra leprae, leprosy. See Leper

sn.def: Infected with leprosy; pertaining to or resembling leprosy.
sn.q: His hand wasleprousas snow.

sn.def: Leprose.

entry.def: Leprosy.

entry.ety: Leptus + -form
entry.def: Having a form somewhat like leptus; -- said of active insect larvæ having three pairs of legs. See Larva.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. lepto`s small + kardi`a the heart
entry.def: The lowest class of Vertebrata, including only the Amphioxus. The heart is represented only by a simple pulsating vessel. The blood is colorless; the brain, renal organs, and limbs are wanting, and the backbone is represented only by a simple, unsegmented notochord. See Amphioxus.
Of or pertaining to the Leptocardia.
Having a long slender tail.

entry.ety: Gr. lepto`s small, thin + da`ktylos finger, toe
entry.def: A bird or other animal having slender toes.

entry.ety: See leptodactyl
entry.def: A natural family of New World frogs; in some classifications it is essentially coextensive with the family Bufonidae.
Having slender toes.
The type genus of the Leptodactylidae; in some classifications it is placed in the family Bufonidae.
A genus of leaf-footed bugs.

entry.ety: Gr. leptologi`a; lepto`s small, subtile + lo`gos discourse
entry.def: A minute and tedious discourse on trifling things.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. lepto`s small + meningitis
entry.def: Inflammation of the pia mater or of the arachnoid membrane.

an elementary particle that participates in weak interactions but does not participate in the strong interaction; it has a baryon number of 0. Some known leptons are the electron, the negative muon, the tau-minus particle, and the neutrinos associated with each of these particles.
A genus including some ferns sometimes placed in genus Todea.
A genus of birds including the adjutant bird (Leptoptilus dubius, also called adjutant stork) and marabous.

entry.ety: Gr. lepto`s small + "ri`s "rino`s, the nose
entry.def: Having the nose narrow; -- said especially of the skull. Opposed to platyrhine.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. lepto`s thin, slender + 'o`strakon shell of a testacean
entry.def: An order of Crustacea, including Nebalia and allied forms.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. lepto`s small + qri`x hair
entry.def: A genus of bacteria, characterized by having their filaments very long, slender, and indistinctly articulated.

entry.ety: See Leptothrix n.
entry.def: Having the form of a little chain; -- applied to bacteria when, as in multiplication by fission, they form a chain of filiform individuals.

entry.ety: NL., from Gr. lepto`s thin, small
entry.def: The six-legged young, or larva, of certain mites; -- sometimes used as a generic name. See Harvest mite, under Harvest.
See Granulite.
The type genus of the Leporidae, comprising the hares.
the sea personified; father of Manannan; corresponds to the Welsh Llyr.

entry.ety: See Lore knowledge
entry.def: Learning; lesson; lore.

entry.ety: OE. leeren leren, AS. lǣran. See Lore Learn
entry.def: To learn; to teach.
Empty.

entry.ety: AS. lira flesh; cf. Icel. lær thigh
entry.def: Flesh; skin.
entry.q: His whiteleer.

entry.ety: From lere v. t.
entry.def: Learned.
entry.q: Lewed man orlered.

entry.note: ☞ The genus is restricted by modern zoölogists to a limited number of species similar to Lernæa branchialis found on the gills of the cod.
entry.ety: NL., fr. L. Lernaeus Lernæan, fr. Lerna, Gr. Le`rnh, a forest and marsh near Argos, the mythological abode of the hydra
entry.def: A Linnæan genus of parasitic Entomostraca, -- the same as the family Lernæidæ.

entry.ety: NL. See Lernæa
entry.def: A suborder of copepod Crustacea, including a large number of remarkable forms, mostly parasitic on fishes. The young, however, are active and swim freely. See Illustration in Appendix.

entry.ety: See Lernæa
entry.def: One of a family (Lernæidæ) of parasitic Crustacea found attached to fishes and other marine animals. Some species penetrate the skin and flesh with the elongated head, and feed on the viscera. See Illust. in Appendix.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: A small rodent (Eliomys nitela) of Europe and Northern Africa, allied to the dormouse.
A leash.

sn.def: Of or pertaining to the island anciently called Lesbos, now Mitylene, in the Grecian Archipelago.
Amatory; erotic; -- in allusion to the reputed sensuality of the Lesbian people and literature; as, Lesbian novels.
homosexual; -- applied to female homosexuals.

entry.def: a female homosexual.
Homosexual relations between women.

entries.entry: Lesbian love. See Lesbianism.

entry.def: To lose.
See Leze majesty.

entries.entry: Le"sion lē"zhŭn n. F. lésion, L. laesio, fr. laedere laesum, to hurt, injure A hurt; an injury. Specifically: Civil Law Loss sustained from failure to fulfill a bargain or contract. Burrill. Med Any morbid change in the exercise of functions or the texture of organs.

entry.def: Any shrubby or herbaceous plant of the genus Lespedeza, widely used for forage, soil improvement, and especially hay in the Southern U.S.
A genus of low-growing hairy herbs, comprising some of the bladderpods.

entry.ety: AS. leás loose, false; akin to OS. lōs loose, false, D. los loose, loos false, sly, G. los loose, Icel. lauss loose, vacant, Goth. laus empty, vain, and also to E. loose lose. √127. See Lose, and cf. Loose Leasing
entry.def: A privative adjective suffix, denoting without destitute of not having; as witless, childless, fatherless.
Unless.

entry.note: ☞ The substantive which less qualifies is often omitted; as, the purse contained lessmoney) than ten dollars. See Less n.
entry.ety: OE. lesse, AS. lǣssa; akin to OFries. lēssa; a compar. from a lost positive form. Cf. Lesser Lest Least. Less has the sense of the comparative degree of little
entry.def: Smaller; not so large or great; not so much; shorter; inferior; as, a less quantity or number; a horse of less size or value; in less time than before.
entry.q: Thus in lesstime] than a hundred years from the coming of Augustine, all England became Christian.

entry.ety: AS. lǣs. See Less adj., and cf. Lest
entry.def: Not so much; in a smaller or lower degree; as, less bright or loud; less beautiful.

sn.def: A smaller portion or quantity.
sn.q: The children of Israel did so, and gathered, some more, some less.

sn.def: The inferior, younger, or smaller.
sn.q: The less is blessed of the better.

entry.def: To make less; to lessen.

entry.ety: F. laissé, p. p. of laisser. See Lease v. t.
entry.def: The person to whom a lease is given, or who takes an estate by lease.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Lessened -'nd; p. pr. & vb. n. Lessening
entry.ety: From Less a.
entry.def: To make less; to reduce; to make smaller, or fewer; to diminish; to lower; to degrade; as, to lessen a kingdom, or a population; to lessen speed, rank, fortune.
entry.q: Charity . . . shall lessen his punishment.
St. Paul chose to magnify his office when ill men conspired to lessen it.
entry.syn: To diminish; reduce; abate; decrease; lower; impair; weaken; degrade.

entry.def: To become less; to shrink; to contract; to decrease; to be diminished; as, the apparent magnitude of objects lessens as we recede from them; his care, or his wealth, lessened.
entry.q: The objection lessens much, and comes to no more than this: there was one witness of no good reputation.

entry.def: One who, or that which, lessens.
entry.q: His wife . . . is the lessener of his pain, and the augmenter of his pleasure.

entry.def: becoming less in dimension or degree; as, the lessening distance between us.
a change downward; a decrease; a reduction.

entry.note: ☞ Lesser is used for less, now the compar. of little, in certain special instances in which its employment has become established by custom; as, Lesser Asia (i. e., Asia Minor), the lesser light, and some others; also in poetry, for the sake of the meter, and in prose where its use renders the passage more euphonious.
entry.ety: This word is formed by adding anew the compar. suffix -erin which r is from an original s) to less. See Less a.
entry.def: Less; smaller; inferior.
entry.q: God made . . . the lesser light to rule the night.
The more my prayer, the lesser is my grace.
The larger here, and there the lesser lambs.
By the same reason may a man, in the state of nature, punish the lesser breaches of the law.

entry.def: Less.

entry.ety: F. laissées, from laisser to leave. See Lease v. t.
entry.def: The leavings or dung of beasts.

entry.ety: OE. lessoun, F. leçon lesson, reading, fr. L. lectio a reading, fr. legere to read, collect. See Legend, and cf. Lection

sn.def: Anything read or recited to a teacher by a pupil or learner; something, as a portion of a book, assigned to a pupil to be studied or learned at one time.
That which is learned or taught by an express effort; instruction derived from precept, experience, observation, or deduction; a precept; a doctrine; as, to take or give a lesson in drawing.
sn.q: A smooth and pleasinglesson.
Emprinteth well this lesson in your mind.

sn.def: A portion of Scripture read in divine service for instruction; as, here endeth the first lesson .
A severe lecture; reproof; rebuke; warning.
sn.q: She would give her a lesson for walking so late.

sn.def: An exercise; a composition serving an educational purpose; a study.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Lessoned -s'nd; p. pr. & vb. n. Lessoning
entry.def: To teach; to instruct.
entry.q: To rest the weary, and to soothe the sad, Doth lesson happier men, and shame at least the bad.

entry.ety: See Lessee Lease v. t.
entry.def: One who leases; the person who lets to farm, or gives a lease.
not visited by many travelers; as, the tourist's desire to visit less-traveled countries.
To listen.

entry.ety: See List to choose
entry.def: Lust; desire; pleasure.
Last; least.

entry.ety: OE. leste, fr. AS. ðȳ lǣs ðē the less that, where ðȳ is the instrumental case of the definite article, and ðē is an indeclinable relative particle, that who which. See The Less a.

sn.def: For fear that; that . . . not; in order that . . . not.
sn.q: Love not sleep, lest thou come to poverty.
Wherefore let him that thinketh he standeth take heed lest he fall.

sn.def: That (without the negative particle); -- after certain expressions denoting fear or apprehension.
sn.q: I fearedLest I might anger thee.

entry.ety: Pg., prob. fr. Fr. l'est the east
entry.def: A dry sirocco in the Madeira Islands.

entry.ety: From two French dim. endings -elL. -ellus) and -et, as in bracelet
entry.def: A noun suffix having a diminutive force; as in streamlet, wavelet, armlet .

entry.ety: OE. letten, AS. lettan to delay, to hinder, fr. læt slow; akin to D. letten to hinder, G. verletzen to hurt, Icel. letja to hold back, Goth. latjan. See Late
entry.def: To retard; to hinder; to impede; to oppose.
entry.q: He was so strong that no man might him let.
He who now letteth will let, until he be taken out of the way.
Mine ancient wound is hardly whole, And lets me from the saddle.

sn.def: A retarding; hindrance; obstacle; impediment; delay; -- common in the phrase without let or hindrance, but elsewhere archaic.
sn.q: Consider whether your doings be to the let of your salvation or not.

sn.def: A stroke in which a ball touches the top of the net in passing over.

entry.note: ☞ In this sense, when followed by an infinitive, the latter is commonly without the sign to; as to let us walk, i. e., to permit or suffer us to walk. Sometimes there is entire omission of the verb; as, to letto be or to go] loose.

☞ The active form of the infinitive of let, as of many other English verbs, is often used in a passive sense; as, a house to leti. e., for letting, or to be let). This form of expression conforms to the use of the Anglo-Saxon gerund with todative infinitive) which was commonly so employed. See Gerund, 2. “ Your elegant house in Harley Street is to let.” Thackeray. In the imperative mood, before the first person plural, let has a hortative force. “ Rise up, let us go.” Mark xiv. 42. “ Let us seek out some desolate shade.” Shak.
entry.cs:
To let alone to leave; to withdraw from; to refrain from interfering with. To let blood to cause blood to flow; to bleed. To let down. To lower. To soften in tempering; as, to let down tools, cutlery, and the like.
To let flyorTo let drive
to discharge with violence, as a blow, an arrow, or stone. See under Drive, and Fly.
To let inorTo let into . To permit or suffer to enter; to admit. To insert, or imbed, as a piece of wood, in a recess formed in a surface for the purpose. To let loose to remove restraint from; to permit to wander at large. To let off. To discharge; to let fly, as an arrow; to fire the charge of, as a gun. To release, as from an engagement or obligation. Colloq To let out. To allow to go forth; as, to let out a prisoner. To extend or loosen, as the folds of a garment; to enlarge; to suffer to run out, as a cord. To lease; to give out for performance by contract, as a job. To divulge. To let slide to let go; to cease to care for. Colloq “ Let the world slide.” Shak.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Let Letted lĕt"tĕd Obs.); p. pr. & vb. n. Letting
entry.ety: OE. leten lætenpast tense lat let, p. p. laten leten lete), AS. lǣtanpast tense lēt, p. p. lǣten); akin to OFries. lēta, OS. lātan, D. laten, G. lassen, OHG. lāzzan, Icel. lāta, Sw. låta, Dan. lade, Goth. lētan, and L. lassus weary. The original meaning seems to have been, to let loose, let go, let drop. Cf. Alas Late Lassitude Let to hinder

sn.def: To leave; to relinquish; to abandon.
sn.mark: Obs. or Archaic, except when followed by alone or be
sn.q: He . . . prayed him his voyage for to let.
Yet neither spins nor cards, ne cares nor frets, But to her mother Nature all her care she lets.
Let me alone in choosing of my wife.

sn.def: To consider; to think; to esteem.
To cause; to make; -- used with the infinitive in the active form but in the passive sense; as, let make, i. e., cause to be made; let bring, i. e., cause to be brought.
sn.q: This irous, cursed wretchLet this knight's son anon before him fetch.
He . . . thus let do slay hem all three.
Anon he let two coffers make.

sn.def: To permit; to allow; to suffer; -- either affirmatively, by positive act, or negatively, by neglecting to restrain or prevent.
sn.q: Pharaoh said, I will let you go.
If your name be Horatio, as I am let to know it is.

sn.def: To allow to be used or occupied for a compensation; to lease; to rent; to hire out; -- often with out; as, to let a farm; to let a house; to let out horses.
To give, grant, or assign, as a work, privilege, or contract; -- often with out; as, to let the building of a bridge; to let out the lathing and the plastering.

cs.cd: to tell; to tattle; to divulge something.
to become less severe; to diminish; to cease; as, when the storm lets up.

sn.def: To forbear.
To be let or leased; as, the farm lets for $500 a year. See note under Let v. t.

entry.cs: The let-alone principle The let-alone doctrineorThe let-alone policy . Polit. Econ See Laissez faire.
entry.def: Letting alone.
See Leach.

entry.ety: See Lech Lecher

sn.def: Strong desire; passion; especially, lust.
sn.q: Some people have a letch for unmasking impostors, or for avenging the wrongs of others.

sn.def: A lecher.

entry.def: See Leachy.
To let; to leave.
p. p. of Lete.

entry.ety: Lauric + ether + alcohol
entry.def: One of the higher alcohols of the paraffine series obtained from spermaceti as a white crystalline solid. It is so called because it occurs in the ethereal salt of lauric acid.

entry.ety: L. lethalis letalis, fr. lethum letum, death: cf. F. léthal
entry.def: Deadly; mortal; fatal.
entry.q: Thelethalblow.

entry.ety: Cf. F. léthalité
entry.def: The quality of being lethal; mortality.

entry.ety: L. lethargicus, Gr. lhqargiko`s: cf. F. léthargique. See Lethargy
entry.def: Pertaining to, affected with, or resembling, lethargy; morbidly drowsy; dull; heavy.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Lethargized -jīzd; p. pr. & vb. n. Lethargizing -jī`zĭng
entry.def: To make lethargic.
entry.q: All bitters are poison, and act by stilling, and depressing, and lethargizing the irritability.

entries.entry:
Leth"ar*gy -j� n.; pl.-gies -jĭz. F. léthargie, L. lethargia, Gr. lhqargi`a, fr. lh`qargos forgetful, fr. lh`qh forgetfulness. See Lethe
Morbid drowsiness; continued or profound sleep, from which a person can scarcely be awaked.
A state of inaction or indifference. Europe lay then under a deep lethargy.

entry.def: To lethargize.

entry.ety: See Lethal
entry.def: Death.

entry.ety: L., fr. Gr. lh`qh, prop., forgetfulness; akin to lanqa`nesqai to forget, lanqa`nein to escape notice

sn.def: A river of Hades whose waters when drunk caused forgetfulness of the past.
Oblivion; a draught of oblivion; forgetfulness.

entry.ety: L. Lethaeus, Gr. lh`qaios or lhqai^os
entry.def: Of or pertaining to Lethe; resembling in effect the water of Lethe.
Caused by Lethe.
entry.q: Letheeddullness.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. lh`qh
entry.def: Sulphuric ether used as an anæsthetic agent.
To subject to the influence of letheon.

entry.ety: L. lethifer letifer, fr. lethum letum, death + ferre to bear, to bring: cf. F. léthifère
entry.def: Deadly; bringing death or destruction.
Lethean.
A device for letting off, releasing, or giving forth, as the warp from the cylinder of a loom.
To let; to hinder. See Let, to hinder.

entry.ety: From Let to permit
entry.def: One who lets or permits; one who lets anything for hire.

entry.ety: From Let to hinder
entry.def: One who retards or hinders.

entry.cs:
Dead letter Drop letter
etc. See under Dead Drop, etc. Letter book a book in which copies of letters are kept. Letter box a box for the reception of letters to be mailed or delivered. Letter carrier a person who carries letters; a postman; specif., an officer of the post office who carries letters to the persons to whom they are addressed, and collects letters to be mailed. Letter cutter one who engraves letters or letter punches. Letter lock a lock that can not be opened when fastened, unless certain movable lettered rings or disks forming a part of it are in such a position (indicated by a particular combination of the letters) as to permit the bolt to be withdrawn. A strange lock that opens with AMEN. Beau. & Fl. Letter paper paper for writing letters on; especially, a size of paper intermediate between note paper and foolscap. See Paper. Letter punch a steel punch with a letter engraved on the end, used in making the matrices for type. Letters of administration Law the instrument by which an administrator or administratrix is authorized to administer the goods and estate of a deceased person.
Letter of attorney Letter of credit , etc. See under Attorney Credit, etc. Letter of license a paper by which creditors extend a debtor's time for paying his debts.
Letters closeorLetters clause
Eng. Law letters or writs directed to particular persons for particular purposes, and hence closed or sealed on the outside; -- distinguished from letters patent. Burrill. Letters of orders Eccl a document duly signed and sealed, by which a bishop makes it known that he has regularly ordained a certain person as priest, deacon, etc.
Letters patent Letters overtorLetters open
Eng. Law a writing executed and sealed, by which power and authority are granted to a person to do some act, or enjoy some right; as, letters patent under the seal of England. The common commercial patent is a derivative form of such a right. Letter-sheet envelope a stamped sheet of letter paper issued by the government, prepared to be folded and sealed for transmission by mail without an envelope. Letters testamentary Law an instrument granted by the proper officer to an executor after probate of a will, authorizing him to act as executor. Letter writer. One who writes letters. A machine for copying letters. A book giving directions and forms for the writing of letters.
entry.ety: OE. lettre, F. lettre, OF. letre, fr. L. littera litera, a letter; pl., an epistle, a writing, literature, fr. linere litum, to besmear, to spread or rub over; because one of the earliest modes of writing was by graving the characters upon tablets smeared over or covered with wax. Pliny, xiii. 11. See Liniment, and cf. Literal

sn.def: A mark or character used as the representative of a sound, or of an articulation of the human organs of speech; a first element of written language.
sn.q: And a superscription also was written over him in letters of Greek, and Latin, and Hebrew.

sn.def: A written or printed communication; a message expressed in intelligible characters on something adapted to conveyance, as paper, parchment, etc.; an epistle.
sn.q: The style of letters ought to be free, easy, and natural.

sn.def: A writing; an inscription.
sn.q: None could expound what this letter meant.

sn.def: Verbal expression; literal statement or meaning; exact signification or requirement.
sn.q: We must observe the letter of the law, without doing violence to the reason of the law and the intention of the lawgiver.
I broke the letter of it to keep the sense.

sn.def: A single type; type, collectively; a style of type.
sn.q: Under these buildings . . . was the king's printing house, and that famous letter so much esteemed.

sn.def: Learning; erudition; as, a man of letters .
A letter; an epistle.

A telegram longer than an ordinary message sent at rates lower than the standard message rate in consideration of its being sent and delivered subject to priority in service of regular messages. Such telegrams are called by the Western Union Company day lettersornight letters according to the time of sending, and by The Postal Telegraph Company day lettergramsornight lettergrams.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Lettered -tẽrd; p. pr. & vb. n. Lettering
entry.def: To impress with letters; to mark with letters or words; as, a book gilt and lettered .
A bomb disguised as a letter and sent through the mail, usually rigged to explode and kill or harm the recipient when opened.
to send a letter-bomb to.
a postcard that folds so that the message is inside.

sn.def: Literate; educated; versed in literature.
sn.q: Are you notlettered?
The unlettered barbarians willingly accepted the aid of the lettered clergy, still chiefly of Roman birth, to reduce to writing the institutes of their forefathers.

sn.def: Of or pertaining to learning or literature; learned.
sn.q: Aletterededucation.

sn.def: Inscribed or stamped with letters.

entry.def: One who makes, inscribes, or engraves, alphabetical letters.
See Letter{8, above.

sn.def: The act or business of making, or marking with, letters, as by cutting or painting.
The letters made; as, the lettering of a sign.
Not having a letter.
Illiterate.

entry.def: See Lecturn.
correct to the last detail; especially being in or following the exact words; as, a letter-perfect rendition of the soliloquy.
Print; letters and words impressed on paper or other material by types; -- often used of the reading matter in distinction from the illustrations.
entry.q: Letterpress printing, printing directly from type, in distinction from printing from plates.

entry.def: Letters; literature.
entry.q: To teach himletterureand courtesy.

entry.def: The beautiful and highly elastic wood of a tree of the genus Brosimum Brosimum Aubletii), found in Guiana; -- so called from black spots in it which bear some resemblance to hieroglyphics; also called snakewood, and leopardwood. It is much used for bows and for walking sticks.
Of or pertaining to the Letts; Lettish.
Of or pertaining to a branch of the Slavic family, subdivided into Lettish, Lithuanian, and Old Prussian.

def2.def: The language of the Letts; Lettish.
The language of the Lettic race, including Lettish, Lithuanian, and Old Prussian.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to the Letts.

def2.def: The language spoken by the Letts. See Lettic.

entry.def: See Letterure.

entries.entry: Letts lĕts n. pl.; sing. Lett lĕt . Ethnol An Indo-European people, allied to the Lithuanians and Old Prussians, and inhabiting a part of the Baltic provinces of Russia.

entry.cs: Hare's lettuce Lamb's lettuce . See under Hare, and Lamb. Lettuce opium. See Lactucarium. Sea lettuce certain papery green seaweeds of the genus Ulva.
entry.ety: OE. letuce, prob. through Old French from some Late Latin derivative of L. lactuca lettuce, which, according to Varro, is fr. lac lactis, milk, on account of the milky white juice which flows from it when it is cut: cf. F. laitue. Cf. Lacteal Lactucic

sn.def: A composite plant of the genus Lactuca Lactuca sativa), the leaves of which are used as salad. Plants of this genus yield a milky juice, from which lactucarium is obtained. The commonest wild lettuce of the United States is Lactuca Canadensis.
United States currency; dollar bills; greenbacks.

entry.def: Electuary.

entry.ety: See Let to forbear
entry.def: Abatement; also, cessation; as, it blew a gale for three days without any let-up .
Same as Leuco-.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. leyko`s white + de`ndron tree
entry.def: A genus of evergreen shrubs from the Cape of Good Hope, having handsome foliage. Leucadendron argenteum is the silverboom of the colonists.

entry.ety: Leuc- + aniline
entry.def: A colorless, crystalline, organic base, obtained from rosaniline by reduction, and also from other sources. It forms colorless salts.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. leyko`s white + a"i^ma blood
entry.def: See Leucocythæmia.
Pertaining to, or designating, an acid obtained from leucin, and called also oxycaproic acid.

entry.ety: Gr. leyko`s white
entry.def: a naturally occurring alpha-amino acid (CH3)2CH.CH2.CH(NH2)-COOH), one of the building units of almost all proteins of living organisms, both animal and vegetable. It is one of the essential amino acids (not synthesized by the human body, a required component for proper nutrition), and is hydrophobic in character when bound in proteins. In isolated form it is a white, crystalline, zwitterionic substance formed, e. g. by the decomposition of proteins by pancreatic digestion, by the action of boiling dilute mineral acid, or by putrefaction. Chemically it is to be considered as amido-caproic acid. It occurs as two optical isomers, the L- and D-forms. The L-form, L-leucine, is the natural form, present in most proteins.
A genus of freshwater fishes including the dace (Leuciscus leuciscus).

entry.ety: Gr. leyko`s white: cf. F. leucite

sn.def: A mineral having a glassy fracture, occurring in translucent trapezohedral crystals. It is a silicate of alumina and potash KAlSi2O6. It is found in the volcanic rocks of Italy, especially at Vesuvius.
A leucoplast.

entry.def: Containing leucite; as, leucitic rocks.

entry.ety: Leucite + -oid
entry.def: The trapezohedron or tetragonal trisoctahedron; -- so called as being the form of the mineral leucite.

entry.ety: Gr. leyko`s white
entry.def: A combining form signifying white colorless; specif. Chem, denoting an extensive series of colorless organic compounds, obtained by reduction from certain other colored compounds; as, leucaniline, leucaurin, etc.

entry.note: ☞ They all consist of more or less spherical masses of protoplasm, without any surrounding membrane or wall, and are capable of motion.
entry.ety: Leuco- + Gr. ky`tos a hollow vessel
entry.def: A colorless corpuscle, as one of the white blood corpuscles, or those found in lymph, marrow of bone, connective tissue, etc.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. leyko`s white + ky`tos a hollow vessel + a"i^ma blood
entry.def: A disease in which the white corpuscles of the blood are largely increased in number, and there is enlargement of the spleen, or the lymphatic glands; leuchæmia.

entry.ety: Leucocyte + genesis
entry.def: The formation of leucocytes.

entry.ety: Leuco- + Ethiopic
entry.def: White and black; -- said of a white animal of a black species, or the albino of the negro race.

entry.ety: Leuco- + Aethiops
entry.def: An albino.

entry.ety: Leuc- + L. oleum oil
entry.def: A nitrogenous organic base from coal tar, and identical with quinoline. Cf. Quinoline.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. ley`kwma, fr. leyko`s white
entry.def: A white opacity in the cornea of the eye; -- called also albugo.

entry.ety: Leuco- + -maine, as in ptomaine
entry.def: An animal base or alkaloid, appearing in the tissue during life; hence, a vital alkaloid, as distinguished from a ptomaine or cadaveric poison.

entry.ety: Leuc- + croconic
entry.def: Pertaining to, or designating, a complex organic acid, obtained as a yellowish white gum by the oxidation of croconic acid.

entry.ety: Leuco- + Gr. pa`schein paqei^n to suffer
entry.def: The state of an albino, or of a white child of black parents.

entry.ety: Gr. leykofanh`s appearing bright or white; leyko`s white + fai`nein to show: cf. G. leukophan
entry.def: A mineral of a greenish yellow color; it is a silicate of glucina, lime, and soda with fluorine. Called also leucophanite.

entry.ety: Gr. leykoflegmati`a; leyko`s white + fle`gma phlegm: cf. F. leucophlegmasie
entry.def: A dropsical habit of body, or the commencement of anasarca; paleness, with viscid juices and cold sweats.

entry.ety: Cf. F. leucophlegmatique, Gr. leykofle`gmatos
entry.def: Having a dropsical habit of body, with a white bloated skin.

entry.ety: Leuco- + Gr. fy`llon a leaf
entry.def: A colorless substance isomeric with chlorophyll, contained in parts of plants capable of becoming green.

entry.ety: Gr. leyko`fyllos; leyko`s white + fy`llon a leaf
entry.def: Having white or silvery foliage.

entry.ety: Leuco- + Gr. pla`ssein to mold
entry.def: One of certain very minute whitish or colorless granules occurring in the protoplasm of plants and supposed to be the nuclei around which starch granules will form.

entry.ety: Leuco- + pyrites
entry.def: A mineral of a color between white and steel-gray, with a metallic luster, and consisting chiefly of arsenic and iron.

entry.ety: Leuco- + Gr. "rei^n to flow
entry.def: A discharge of a white, yellowish, or greenish, viscid mucus, resulting from inflammation or irritation of the membrane lining the genital organs of the female; the whites.

entry.ety: NL., from Gr. leyko`s + 'o`ryx a kind of gazelle
entry.def: A large antelope of North Africa (Oryx leucoryx), allied to the gemsbok.

entry.ety: Leuco- + -scope
entry.def: An instrument, devised by Professor Helmholtz, for testing the color perception of the eye, or for comparing different lights, as to their constituent colors or their relative whiteness.

entry.ety: NL. Leucosia, the typical genus (fr. Gr. leyko`s white) + -oid
entry.def: Like or pertaining to the Leucosoidea, a tribe of marine crabs including the box crab or Calappa.

entry.ety: Leuco- + sphere
entry.def: The inner corona.

entry.ety: Leuco- + allantoic + uric
entry.def: Pertaining to, or designating, a nitrogenous organic substance of the uric acid group, called leucoturic acid or oxalantin. See Oxalantin.

entry.ety: Gr. leyko`s
entry.def: White; -- applied to albinos, from the whiteness of their skin and hair.

entry.ety: Leuco- + Gr. xe`nos stranger
entry.def: A nearly opaque white mineral, in part identical with titanite, observed in some igneous rocks as the result of the alteration of titanic iron.
Leucocythæmia.
See Luke, etc.
See Leucoplast.
