The system of animal nature; animals in general, or considered collectively. Full nature swarms with life.
An essential constituent of life, esp: the blood. The words that I speak unto you . . . they are life. The warm life came issuing through the wound.
A history of the acts and events of a life; a biography; as, Johnson wrote the life of Milton.
Enjoyment in the right use of the powers; especially, a spiritual existence; happiness in the favor of God; heavenly felicity.
Something dear to one as one's existence; a darling; -- used as a term of endearment.

sn.def: The blood necessary to life; vital blood.
Fig.: That which gives strength and energy.
sn.q: Money [is] the lifeblood of the nation.

entry.def: A strong, buoyant boat especially designed for saving the lives of shipwrecked people.
Full of vitality.
Giving life or spirit; having power to give life; inspiriting; invigorating; as, life-giving love and praise.
entry.q: returning the life-giving humus to the land.

entry.def: Land held by a life estate.

entry.usage: Lifeless Dull Inanimate Dead. In a moral sense, lifeless denotes a lack of vital energy; inanimate, a lack of expression as to any feeling that may be possessed; dull implies a torpor of soul which checks all mental activity; dead supposes a destitution of feeling. A person is said to be lifeless who has lost the spirits which he once had; he is said to be inanimate when he is naturally wanting in spirits; one is dull from an original deficiency of mental power; he who is dead to moral sentiment is wholly bereft of the highest attribute of his nature.
entry.def: Destitute of life, or deprived of life; not containing, or inhabited by, living beings or vegetation; dead, or apparently dead; spiritless; powerless; dull; as, a lifeless carcass; lifeless matter; a lifeless desert; a lifeless wine; a lifeless story.
entry.syn: Dead; soulless; inanimate; torpid; inert; inactive; dull; heavy; unanimated; spiritless; frigid; pointless; vapid; flat; tasteless.

entry.def: not having life.

entry.ety: Cf. Lively
entry.def: Like a living being; resembling life; giving an accurate representation; as, a lifelike portrait.

sn.def: The anem given to one of the creases on the palm; its length is said by palmists to indicate how long one will live.
A line or rope which raises or lowers a deep-sea diver.
A line from a vessel that people in a body of water can cling to to save themselves from drowning.

entry.ety: Life + long. Cf. Livelong
entry.def: Lasting or continuing through life.

entry.ety: Cf. Lively a.
entry.def: In a lifelike manner.
Companion for life.
To enliven.
An unarmed woody rhizomatous perennial plant (Aralia racemosa) distinguished from wild sarsaparilla by more aromatic roots and panicled umbels; it grows from Southeastern North America to Mexico.
entry.syn: American spikenard, petty morel, Aralia racemosa.

entry.def: An apparatus, made in very various forms, and of various materials, for saving one from drowning by buoying up the body while in the water.
That saves life, or is suited to save life, esp. from drowning; as, the life-saving service; a life-saving station.
Of full size; of the natural size; of the same size as an original; as, a life-size sculpture; a life-size portrait of the general.
being the seat or source of life; performing a necessary function in the living body; as, the need for life-sustaining air and water.
Animated; sprightly.
Spring or source of life.
A nerve, or string, that is imagined to be essential to life.
The time that life continues.
Weary of living.
Livelihood.

entry.ety: AS. lyft air. See Loft
entry.def: The sky; the atmosphere; the firmament.

entry.note: ☞ In old writers, lift is sometimes used for lifted.
entry.cs: To lift up to raise or elevate; in the Scriptures, specifically, to elevate upon the cross. John viii. 28. To lift up the eyes. To look up; to raise the eyes, as in prayer. Ps. cxxi. 1. To lift up the feet to come speedily to one's relief. Ps. lxxiv. 3. To lift up the hand. To take an oath. Gen. xiv. 22. To pray. Ps. xxviii. 2. To engage in duty. Heb. xii. 12. To lift up the hand against to rebel against; to assault; to attack; to injure; to oppress. Job xxxi. 21. To lift up one's head to cause one to be exalted or to rejoice. Gen. xl. 13. Luke xxi. 28. To lift up the heel against to treat with insolence or unkindness. John xiii.18. To lift up the voice to cry aloud; to call out. Gen. xxi. 16.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Lifted; p. pr. & vb. n. Lifting
entry.ety: Icel. lypta, fr. lopt air; akin to Sw. lyfta to lift, Dan. löfte, G. lüften; -- prop., to raise into the air. See Loft, and cf. 1st Lift

sn.def: To move in a direction opposite to that of gravitation; to raise; to elevate; to bring up from a lower place to a higher; to upheave; sometimes implying a continued support or holding in the higher place; -- said of material things; as, to lift the foot or the hand; to lift a chair or a burden.
To raise, elevate, exalt, improve, in rank, condition, estimation, character, etc.; -- often with up.
sn.q: The Roman virtues lift up mortal man.
Lest, being lifted up with pride.

sn.def: To bear; to support.
To collect, as moneys due; to raise.

sn.ety: Perh. a different word, and akin to Goth. hliftus thief, hlifan to steal, L. clepere, Gr. kle`ptein. Cf. Shoplifter
sn.def: To steal; to carry off by theft (esp. cattle); as, to lift a drove of cattle.
sn.q: He ne'er lift up his hand but conquered.

sn.def: To try to raise something; to exert the strength for raising or bearing.
sn.q: Strained by lifting at a weight too heavy.

sn.def: To rise; to become or appear raised or elevated; as, the fog lifts; the land lifts to a ship approaching it.
To steal; also, to live by theft.

entry.cs: Dead lift. See under Dead. Swift. Lift bridge a kind of drawbridge, the movable part of which is lifted, instead of being drawn aside. Lift gate a gate that is opened by lifting. Lift hammer. See Tilt hammer. Lift lock a canal lock. Lift pump a lifting pump. Lift tenter Windmills a governor for regulating the speed by adjusting the sails, or for adjusting the action of grinding machinery according to the speed. Lift wall Canal Lock the cross wall at the head of the lock.

sn.def: Act of lifting; also, that which is lifted.
The space or distance through which anything is lifted; as, a long lift .
Help; assistance, as by lifting.
A ride in a vehicle, given by the vehicle's owner to another person as a favor -- usually in “give a lift” or “got a lift”; as, to give one a lift in a wagon; Jack gave me a lift into town.
sn.q: The goat gives the fox a lift.

entry.sn:
That by means of which a person or thing lifts or is lifted; as:
A hoisting machine; an elevator; a dumb waiter. Chiefly Brit
An exercising machine.

sn.def: A rise; a degree of elevation; as, the lift of a lock in canals.
A lift gate. See Lift gate, below.
A rope leading from the masthead to the extremity of a yard below; -- used for raising or supporting the end of the yard.
One of the steps of a cone pulley.
A layer of leather in the heel.
That portion of the vibration of a balance during which the impulse is given.
A brightening of the spirits; encouragement; as, the campaign workers got a lift from the President's endorsement.

entry.def: Such as can be lifted.
turned upward; as, she left the room with her face lifted .

sn.def: One who, or that which, lifts.
A tool for lifting loose sand from the mold; also, a contrivance attached to a cope, to hold the sand together when the cope is lifted.

entry.cs: Lifting bridge a lift bridge. Lifting jack. See 2d Jack, 5. Lifting machine. See Health lift, under Health. Lifting pump. Mach A kind of pump having a bucket, or valved piston, instead of a solid piston, for drawing water and lifting it to a high level. A pump which lifts the water only to the top of the pump, or delivers it through a spout; a lift pump. Lifting rod a vertical rod lifted by a rock shaft, and imparting motion to a puppet valve; -- used in the engines of river steamboats. Lifting sail Naut one which tends to lift a vessel's bow out of water, as jibs and square foresails.
entry.def: Used in, or for, or by, lifting.
the initial ascent of a rocket from its launching pad.

entry.ety: See Lie to be prostrate
entry.def: To recline; to lie still.

entry.ety: L. ligamentum, fr. ligare to bind; cf. f. ligament. Cf. Lien n. Ligature

sn.def: Anything that ties or unites one thing or part to another; a bandage; a bond.
sn.q: Interwoven is the love of liberty with every ligament of your hearts.

sd.def: A tough band or plate of dense, fibrous, connective tissue or fibrocartilage serving to unite bones or form joints.
A band of connective tissue, or a membranous fold, which supports or retains an organ in place; as, the gastrophrenic ligament, connecting the diaphragm and stomach.

entry.ety: Cf. F. ligamenteux
entry.def: Composing a ligament; of the nature of a ligament; binding; as, a strong ligamentous membrane.

entry.ety: Cf. L. ligare to bind, to tie, ligamen band, bandage, E. ligament, or ligsam
entry.def: Goods sunk in the sea, with a buoy attached in order that they may be found again. See Jetsam and Flotsam.

An enzyme which catalyzes creation of a covalent bond between two substrates, resulting in a larger product which is a combination of the two starting materials; especially, DNA ligase, an enzyme which creates a phosphate bond between 5′ and 3′ ends of a DNA chain, resulting in a longer chain of DNA. DNA ligase is important in normal biosynthesis of DNA in the replication cycle of cells.

entry.ety: L. ligatus, p. p. of ligare

sn.def: To tie with a ligature; to bind around; to bandage.
To concatenate two strands of (nucleic acid, usually DNA), in an end-to-end fashion, using a ligase.

entry.ety: L. ligatio, fr. ligare to bind. Cf. Liaison

sn.def: The act of binding, or the state of being bound.
That which binds; bond; connection.
sn.q: Tied with tape, and sealed at each fold and ligation.

entry.ety: See Ligate
entry.def: An instrument for ligating, or for placing and fastening a ligature.

entry.ety: L. ligatura, fr. ligare ligatum, to bind: cf. F. ligature. Cf. Ally League Legatura Liable Ligament

sn.def: The act of binding.
Anything that binds; a band or bandage.

sd.def: A thread or string for tying the blood vessels, particularly the arteries, to prevent hemorrhage.
A thread or wire used to remove tumors, etc.

sn.def: The state of being bound or stiffened; stiffness; as, the ligature of a joint.
Impotence caused by magic or charms.
A curve or line connecting notes; a slur.
A double character, or a type consisting of two or more letters or characters united, as æﬁﬄ.

entry.def: To ligate; to tie.
To lie; to tell lies.

entry.ety: OF. ligeance ligance. See Liege
entry.def: The connection between sovereign and subject by which they were mutually bound, the former to protection and the securing of justice, the latter to faithful service; allegiance.
See Ledgment.
To lie or recline.

sn.def: A baited line attached to a float, for night fishing. See Leger a.
See Ledger, 2.

entry.note: ☞ Light was regarded formerly as consisting of material particles, or corpuscules, sent off in all directions from luminous bodies, and traversing space, in right lines, with the known velocity of about 186,300 miles per second; but it is now generally understood to consist, not in any actual transmission of particles or substance, but in the propagation of vibrations or undulations in a subtile, elastic medium, or ether, assumed to pervade all space, and to be thus set in vibratory motion by the action of luminous bodies, as the atmosphere is by sonorous bodies. This view of the nature of light is known as the undulatory or wave theory; the other, advocated by Newton (but long since abandoned), as the corpuscular emission, or Newtonian theory. A more recent theory makes light to consist in electrical oscillations, and is known as the electro-magnetic theory of light.
☞ Light is used figuratively to denote that which resembles physical light in any respect, as illuminating, benefiting, enlightening, or enlivening mankind.
entry.cs:
Ancient lights Law Calcium light Flash light, etc. See under Ancient Calcium, etc. Light ball Mil a ball of combustible materials, used to afford light; -- sometimes made so as to be fired from a cannon or mortar, or to be carried up by a rocket. Light barrel Mil an empty power barrel pierced with holes and filled with shavings soaked in pitch, used to light up a ditch or a breach. Light dues Com tolls levied on ships navigating certain waters, for the maintenance of lighthouses. Light iron a candlestick. Obs Light keeper a person appointed to take care of a lighthouse or light-ship. Light money charges laid by government on shipping entering a port, for the maintenance of lighthouses and light-ships. The light of the countenance favor; kindness; smiles. Lord, lift thou up the light of thy countenance upon us. Ps. iv. 6. Northern lights. See Aurora borealis, under Aurora. To bring to light to cause to be disclosed. To come to light to be disclosed. To see the light to come into the light; hence, to come into the world or into public notice; as, his book never saw the light .
To stand in one's own light to take a position which is injurious to one's own interest.
entry.ety: OE. light liht, AS. leóht; akin to OS. lioht, D. & G. licht, OHG. lioht, Goth. liuhaþ, Icel. ljōs, L. lux light, lucere to shine, Gr. leyko`s white, Skr. ruc to shine. √122. Cf. Lucid Lunar Luminous Lynx

sn.def: That agent, force, or action in nature by the operation of which upon the organs of sight, objects are rendered visible or luminous.
That which furnishes, or is a source of, light, as the sun, a star, a candle, a lighthouse, etc.
sn.q: Then he called for a light, and sprang in.
And God made two great lights; the greater light to rule the day, and the lesser light to rule the night.

sn.def: The time during which the light of the sun is visible; day; especially, the dawn of day.
sn.q: The murderer, rising with the light, killeth the poor and needy.

sn.def: The brightness of the eye or eyes.
The medium through which light is admitted, as a window, or window pane; a skylight; in architecture, one of the compartments of a window made by a mullion or mullions.
sn.q: There were windows in three rows, and light was against light in three ranks.

sn.def: Life; existence.
sn.q: O, spring to light, auspicious Babe, be born !

sn.def: Open view; a visible state or condition; public observation; publicity.
sn.q: The duke yet would have dark deeds darkly answered; he would never bring them to light.

sn.def: The power of perception by vision.
sn.q: My strength faileth me; as for the light of my eyes, it also is gone from me.

sn.def: That which illumines or makes clear to the mind; mental or spiritual illumination; enlightenment; knowledge; information.
sn.q: He shall never know That I had any light of this from thee.

sn.def: Prosperity; happiness; joy; felicity.
sn.q: Then shall thy light break forth as the morning, and thy health shall spring forth speedily.

sn.def: The manner in which the light strikes upon a picture; that part of a picture which represents those objects upon which the light is supposed to fall; the more illuminated part of a landscape or other scene; -- opposed to shade. Cf. Chiaroscuro.
Appearance due to the particular facts and circumstances presented to view; point of view; as, to state things fairly and put them in the right light .
sn.q: Frequent consideration of a thing . . . shows it in its several lights and various ways of appearance.

sn.def: One who is conspicuous or noteworthy; a model or example; as, the lights of the age or of antiquity.
sn.q: Joan of Arc, A light of ancient France.

sn.def: A firework made by filling a case with a substance which burns brilliantly with a white or colored flame; as, a Bengal light .

entry.ety: AS. leóht. See Light n.

sn.def: Having light; not dark or obscure; bright; clear; as, the apartment is light .
White or whitish; not intense or very marked; not of a deep shade; moderately colored; as, a light color; a light brown; a light complexion.

cs.cd: to kindle the material of a fire.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Lighted līt"ĕd or Lit lĭt; p. pr. & vb. n. Lighting
entry.ety: AS. lȳhtan līhtan, to shine. √122. See Light n.

sn.def: To set fire to; to cause to burn; to set burning; to ignite; to kindle; as, to light a candle or lamp; to light the gas; -- sometimes with up.
sn.q: If a thousand candles be all lighted from one.
And the largest lamp is lit.
Absence might cure it, or a second mistressLight up another flame, and put out this.

sn.def: To give light to; to illuminate; to fill with light; to spread over with light; -- often with up.
sn.q: Ah, hopeless, lasting flames! like those that burn To light the dead.
One hundred years ago, to have lit this theater as brilliantly as it is now lighted would have cost, I suppose, fifty pounds.
The sun has set, and Vesper, to supply His absent beams, has lighted up the sky.

sn.def: To attend or conduct with a light; to show the way to by means of a light.
sn.q: His bishops lead him forth, and light him on.

sn.def: To become ignited; to take fire; as, the match will not light .
To be illuminated; to receive light; to brighten; -- with up; as, the room light up very well.

entry.cs:
Light cavalry Light horse
Mil light-armed soldiers mounted on strong and active horses. Light eater one who eats but little. Light infantry infantry soldiers selected and trained for rapid evolutions. Light of foot. Having a light step. Fleet. Light of heart gay, cheerful. Light oil Chem the oily product, lighter than water, forming the chief part of the first distillate of coal tar, and consisting largely of benzene and toluene. Light sails Naut all the sails above the topsails, with, also, the studding sails and flying jib. Dana. Light sleeper one easily wakened. Light weight a prize fighter, boxer, wrestler, or jockey, who is below a standard medium weight. Cf. Feather weight, under Feather. Cant To make light of to treat as of little consequence; to slight; to disregard. To set light by to undervalue; to slight; to treat as of no importance; to despise.
entry.ety: OE. light liht, AS. līht leóht; akin to D. ligt, G. leicht, OHG. līhti, Icel. lēttr, Dan. let, Sw. lätt, Goth. leihts, and perh. to L. leviscf. Levity), Gr. 'elachy`s small, Skr. laghu light. √125

sn.def: Having little, or comparatively little, weight; not tending to be the center of gravity with force; not heavy.
sn.q: These weights did not exert their natural gravity, . . . insomuch that I could not guess which was light or heavy whilst I held them in my hand.

sn.def: Not burdensome; easy to be lifted, borne, or carried by physical strength; as, a light burden, or load.
sn.q: Ye shall find rest unto your souls. For my yoke is easy, and my burden is light.

sn.def: Easy to be endured or performed; not severe; not difficult; as, a light affliction or task.
sn.q: Light sufferings give us leisure to complain.

sn.def: Easy to be digested; not oppressive to the stomach; as, light food; also, containing little nutriment.
Not heavily armed; armed with light weapons; as, light troops; a troop of light horse.
Not encumbered; unembarrassed; clear of impediments; hence, active; nimble; swift.
sn.q: Unmarried men are best friends, best masters . . . but not always best subjects, for they are light to run away.

sn.def: Not heavily burdened; not deeply laden; not sufficiently ballasted; as, the ship returned light .
Slight; not important; as, a light error.
Well leavened; not heavy; as, light bread.
Not copious or heavy; not dense; not inconsiderable; as, a light rain; a light snow; light vapors.
Not strong or violent; moderate; as, a light wind.
Not pressing heavily or hard upon; hence, having an easy, graceful manner; delicate; as, a light touch; a light style of execution.
Easy to admit influence; inconsiderate; easily influenced by trifling considerations; unsteady; unsettled; volatile; as, a light, vain person; a light mind.
sn.q: There is no greater argument of a light and inconsiderate person than profanely to scoff at religion.

sn.def: Indulging in, or inclined to, levity; wanting dignity or solemnity; trifling; gay; frivolous; airy; unsubstantial.
sn.q: Seneca can not be too heavy, nor Plautus too light.
Specimens of New England humor laboriously light and lamentably mirthful.

sn.def: Not quite sound or normal; somewhat impaired or deranged; dizzy; giddy.
sn.q: Are his wits safe? Is he not light of brain ?

sn.def: Easily bestowed; inconsiderately rendered.
sn.q: To a fair semblance doth light faith annex.

sn.def: Wanton; unchaste; as, a woman of light character.
sn.q: A light wife doth make a heavy husband.

sn.def: Not of the legal, standard, or usual weight; clipped; diminished; as, light coin.
Loose; sandy; easily pulverized; as, a light soil.

entry.def: Lightly; cheaply.

entry.ety: See Light not heavy, and cf. Light to alight, and Lighten to make less heavy
entry.def: To lighten; to ease of a burden; to take off.
entry.q: From his head the heavy burgonet did light.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Lighted līt"ĕdorLit lĭt; p. pr. & vb. n. Lighting
entry.ety: AS. līhtan to alight orig., to relieve (a horse) of the rider's burden, to make less heavy, fr. līht light. See Light not heavy, and cf. Alight Lighten to make light

sn.def: To dismount; to descend, as from a horse or carriage; to alight; -- with from off on upon at in.
sn.q: When she saw Isaac, she lighted off the camel.
Slowly rode across a withered heath, And lighted at a ruined inn.

sn.def: To feel light; to be made happy.
sn.q: It made all their hearts to light.

sn.def: To descend from flight, and rest, perch, or settle, as a bird or insect.
sn.q: The beelights on that, and this, and tasteth all.
On the tree tops a crested peacock lit.

sn.def: To come down suddenly and forcibly; to fall; -- with on or upon.
sn.q: On me, me only, as the source and spring Of all corruption, all the blame lights due.

sn.def: To come by chance; to happen; -- with on or upon; formerly with into.
sn.q: The several degrees of vision, which the assistance of glasses (casually at first lit on) has taught us to conceive.
They shall light into atheistical company.
And here we lit on Aunt Elizabeth, And Lilia with the rest.

entry.def: Such as can be lighted.
Armed with light weapons or accouterments.
Light-ship.

A glass bulb with metallic contacts on the outside connected to a wire filament (usually tungsten) inside that emits light when heated by passage of electricity through the filament; -- used as the replaceable light-emitting component of an electric lamp, flashlight, lighting fixture, etc.
entry.syn: light bulb, bulb, incandescent lamp, electric light, electric-light bulb.

entry.def: having low color saturation; pale-colored.
not designed for heavy or demanding work; as, a light-duty detergent. Opposite of heavy-duty.
imp. of Light, to alight.

sn.def: set afire or burning.
Illuminated by artificial light; as, lighted by a high-powered searchligh.

entry.ety: See Light to alight
entry.def: To descend; to light.
entry.q: O Lord, let thy mercy lighten upon us.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Lightened līt"'nd; p. pr. & vb. n. Lightening
entry.ety: OE. lightenen. See Light to kindle, illuminate

sn.def: To burst forth or dart, as lightning; to shine with, or like, lightning; to display a flash or flashes of lightning; to flash.
sn.q: This dreadful night, That thunders, lightens, opens graves, and roars As doth the lion.

sn.def: To grow lighter; to become less dark or lowering; to brighten; to clear, as the sky.

entry.ety: See Light to illuminate

sn.def: To make light or clear; to light; to illuminate; as, to lighten an apartment with lamps or gas; to lighten the streets.
sn.mark: In this sense less common than light.
sn.q: A key of fire ran all along the shore, And lightened all the river with a blaze.

sn.def: To illuminate with knowledge; to enlighten.
sn.mark: In this sense less common than enlighten
sn.q: Lighten my spirit with one clear heavenly ray.

sn.def: To emit or disclose in, or as in, lightning; to flash out, like lightning.
sn.q: His eye . . . lightens forth Controlling majesty.

sn.def: To free from trouble and fill with joy.
sn.q: They looked unto him, and were lightened.

entry.ety: See Light not heavy

sn.def: To make lighter, or less heavy; to reduce in weight; to relieve of part of a load or burden; as, to lighten a ship by unloading; to lighten a load or burden.
To make less burdensome or afflictive; to alleviate; as, to lighten the cares of life or the burden of grief.
To cheer; to exhilarate.
sn.q: Lightens my humor with his merry jests.

entry.def: The process of changing to a lighter color.

cs.cd: A small portable device which produces a flame when a button is pushed, carried on the person to allow one to light cigarettes conveniently, and taking the place of a match. It may have a reservoir of liquid fuel conveyed by a wick, or may contain compressed butane as the fuel.

entry.def: One who, or that which, lights; as, a lighter of lamps.

cs.cd: a screw for adjusting the distance between the stones in a grinding mill by raising or lowering the bridgetree.

entry.ety: D. ligter, fr. ligt light. See Light not heavy
entry.def: A large boat or barge, mainly used in unloading or loading vessels which can not reach the wharves at the place of shipment or delivery.
To convey by a lighter, as to or from the shore; as, to lighter the cargo of a ship.

sn.def: The price paid for conveyance of goods on a lighter.
The act of unloading into a lighter, or of conveying by a lighter.

entries.entry: Light"er*man līt"ẽr*măn n.; pl.Lightermen līt"ẽr*m�n. A person employed on, or who manages, a lighter.

entry.def: Dexterous in taking and conveying away; thievish; pilfering; addicted to petty thefts.
Having a light, springy step; moving lightly and nimbly; nimble in running or dancing; active; as, light-foot Iris. Opposite of heavy-footed.
Full of light; bright.
entry.q: Lightfulpresence.

entry.def: Having a light green color, similar to the color of fresh grass.

entries.entry: light-haired adj. being or having light colored skin and hair; as, a certain light-haired girl. Contrasted to brunet.Narrower terms: redheaded blond, blonde.

sn.def: Not having a full complement of men; as, a vessel light-handed .
having a metaphorically delicate touch.
sn.q: the translation is . . . light-handed . . . and generally unobtrusive.

sn.def: Disordered in the head; dizzy; feeling faint; delirious.
Thoughtless; heedless; volatile; unsteady; fickle; loose; lacking seriousness; given to frivolity; as, light-headed teenagers.
sn.q: Light-headed, weak men.
sn.syn: airheaded, dizzy, empty-headed, featherbrained, giddy, lightheaded, silly.

entry.def: Free from grief or anxiety; gay; cheerful; merry.
Lively in walking or running; brisk; light-footed.

entries.entry:
Light"-horse`man līt"hôrs`m�n n.; pl.-men līt"hôrs`m�n.
A soldier who serves in the light horse. See under 5th Light.
Zoöl A West Indian fish of the genus Ephippus, remarkable for its high dorsal fin and brilliant colors.

Light"house` līt"hous` n.; pl.Lighthouses līt"houz`ĕz. A tower or other building with a powerful light at top, erected at the entrance of a port, or at some important point on a coast, to serve as a guide to mariners at night; a pharos.

entry.def: A name sometimes applied to the process of annealing metals.
Nimble; swift of foot.
Destitute of light; dark.
total absence of light; blackness.

sn.def: With little weight; with little force; as, to tread lightly; to press lightly.
sn.q: Yet shall thy grave with rising flowers be drest, And the green turf lie lightly on thy breast.
Him thus intent Ithuriel with his spear Touched lightly.

sn.def: Swiftly; nimbly; with agility.
sn.q: So mikle was that barge, it might not lightly sail.
Watch what thou seest and lightly bring me word.

sn.def: Without deep impression.
sn.q: The soft ideas of the cheerful note,Lightly received, were easily forgot.

sn.def: In a small degree; slightly; not severely.
sn.q: At the first he lightly afflicted the land of Zebulun . . . and afterward did more grievously afflict her.

sn.def: With little effort or difficulty; easily; readily.
sn.q: That lightly come, shall lightly go.
They come lightly by the malt, and need not spare it.

sn.def: Without reason, or for reasons of little weight.
sn.q: Flatter not the rich, neither do thou willingly or lightly appear before great personages.

sn.def: Commonly; usually.
sn.q: The great thieves of a state are lightly the officers of the crown.

sn.def: Without dejection; cheerfully.
sn.q: Seeming to bear itlightly.

sn.def: Without heed or care; with levity; gayly; airily.
sn.q: Matrimony . . . is not by any to be enterprised, nor taken in hand, unadvisedly, lightly, or wantonly.

sn.def: Not chastely; wantonly.

entries.entry: Light"man līt"măn n.; pl.-men līt"mĕn. A man who carries or takes care of a light.

sn.def: Unsettled; unsteady; volatile; not considerate.
showing inappropriate levity.

entry.ety: From Light not heavy
entry.def: The state, condition, or quality, of being light or not heavy; buoyancy; levity; fickleness; nimbleness; delicacy; grace.
entry.syn: Levity; volatility; instability; inconstancy; unsteadiness; giddiness; flightiness; airiness; gayety; liveliness; agility; nimbleness; sprightliness; briskness; swiftness; ease; facility.

entry.ety: From Light bright

sn.def: Illumination, or degree of illumination; as, the lightness of a room.
Absence of depth or of duskiness in color; as, the lightness of a tint; lightness of complexion.

cs.cd: a rare form of lightning sometimes seen as a globe of fire moving from the clouds to the earth.
lightning in angular, zigzag, or forked flashes.
more or less vivid and extensive flashes of electric light, without thunder, seen near the horizon, esp. at the close of a hot day.

a device, at the place where a wire enters a building, for preventing injury by lightning to an operator or instrument. It consists of a short circuit to the ground interrupted by a thin nonconductor over which lightning jumps. Called also lightning discharger.
a luminous beetle. See Firefly.
a lightning rod.
a quick, penetrating glance of a brilliant eye.
a metallic rod set up on a building, or on the mast of a vessel, and connected with the earth or water below, for the purpose of protecting the building or vessel from lightning.

a diffused glow of electric light flashing out from the clouds, and illumining their outlines. The appearance is sometimes due to the reflection of light from distant flashes of lightning by the nearer clouds.

entry.ety: For lightening, fr. lighten to flash

sn.def: A discharge of atmospheric electricity, accompanied by a vivid flash of light, commonly from one cloud to another, sometimes from a cloud to the earth. The sound produced by the electricity in passing rapidly through the atmosphere constitutes thunder.
The act of making bright, or the state of being made bright; enlightenment; brightening, as of the mental powers.

entry.def: Lightening.

sn.def: An old tune of a dance, the name of which made it a proverbial expression of levity, especially in love matters.
sn.q: Best sing it to the tune oflight-o'-love.

sn.def: Hence: A light or wanton woman; a woman inconstant in love. Called also light-of-love.

entry.def: A small room from which the magazine of a naval vessel is lighted, being separated from the magazine by heavy glass windows.

entry.ety: So called from their lightness
entry.def: The lungs of an animal or bird; -- sometimes coarsely applied to the lungs of a human being.

sn.def: Affected by light; as, the light-sensitive pigments in the retina.
Decomposing under the influence of light; unstable when exposed to light; -- of chemical compounds.

entry.def: A vessel equipped like a lighthouse, carrying at the masthead a brilliant light, and moored off a shoal or place of dangerous navigation where a permanent lighthouse would be impracticable, to serve as a guide for mariners; as, the Ambrose lightship off New York was rammed and damaged in 1950 by the Santa Monica.

sn.def: Having light; lighted; not dark or gloomy; bright.
sn.q: White walls make rooms more lightsome than black.

sn.def: Gay; airy; cheering; exhilarating.
sn.q: That lightsome affection of joy.
Happiness may walk soberly in dark attire, as well as dance lightsomely in a gala dress.

entry.def: a signal to turn the lights out.
Damaged by accidental exposure to light; light-fogged; -- said of plates or films.
One of less than average weight;
In boxing, wrestling, etc., one weighing not more than 133 pounds (U. S. amateur rules 135 pounds, Eng. 140 pounds).

sn.def: A person of small importance or mental ability, especially one who is unimportant but cheeky and presumptuous.
a wrestler who weighs 139-154 pounds.
Light in weight, as a coin; specif., applied to a man or animal who is a lightweight.
made of thin cloth, of relatively little weight; -- of clothing or fabrics; as, lightweight fabrics.

entry.def: Having light and active wings; volatile; fleeting.
Pine wood abounding in pitch, used for torches in the Southern United States; pine knots, dry sticks, and the like, for kindling a fire quickly or making a blaze.
Illuminated.

entries.entry:
Light-year Light year . Astron
The distance over which light can travel in a year's time in a vacuum, 5.88 trillion miles (9.46 trillion kilometers); -- used as a unit in expressing stellar distances. It is more than 63,000 times as great as the distance from the earth to the sun. The star nearest to the earth's sun is about 4 light years distant.
a very large difference; -- used figuratively to express great differences (of distance, quality, time) in comparisons. Although having the same rank and salary, they werelight-yearsapart in their ability to perform their jobs.

entry.ety: OE. ligne aloes, fr. L. lignum wood + aloe aloe

sn.def: Aloes wood, or agallochum. See Agallochum.
A fragrant tree mentioned in the Bible.

cs.cd: wood coated or prepared so as to resemble marble.

entry.ety: L. ligneus, fr. lignum wood. Cf. Lignous
entry.def: Made of wood; consisting of wood; of the nature of, or resembling, wood; woody.
entry.q: It should be tried with shoots of vines and roots of red roses; for it may be they, being of a moreligneous nature, will incorporate with the tree itself.

entry.ety: L. lignifer; lignum wood + ferre to bear: cf. F. lignifère
entry.def: Yielding or producing wood.

entry.ety: Cf. F. lignification. See Lignify
entry.def: A change in the character of a cell wall, by which it becomes harder. It is supposed to be due to an incrustation of lignin.

entry.ety: L. lignum wood + -form: cf. F. ligniforme
entry.def: Like wood.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Lignified lĭg"nĭ*fīd; p. pr. & vb. n. Lignifying lĭg"nĭ*fī`ĭng
entry.ety: L. lignum wood + -fy: cf. F. lignifier
entry.def: To convert into wood or into a ligneous substance.
To become wood.

entry.note: ☞ Recent authors have distinguished four forms of this substance, naming them lignose lignin lignone, and lignireose.
entry.ety: L. lignum wood: cf. F. lignine
entry.def: A substance characterizing wood cells and differing from cellulose in its conduct with certain chemical reagents.

entry.ety: L. lignum wood + perdere to destroy: cf. F. ligniperde
entry.def: Wood-destroying; -- said of certain insects.
See Lignin.

entry.ety: L. lignum wood: cf. F. lignite
entry.def: Mineral coal retaining the texture of the wood from which it was formed, and burning with an empyreumatic odor. It is of more recent origin than the anthracite and bituminous coal of the proper coal series. Called also brown coal wood coal.

entry.cs: Lignitic group. See Laramie Group.
entry.def: Containing lignite; resembling, or of the nature of, lignite; as, lignitic clay.

entry.ety: Lignite + -ferous
entry.def: Producing or containing lignite; lignitic.

entry.ety: L. lignum wood + cera wax
entry.def: Pertaining to, or designating, an acid of the formic acid series, found in the tar, wax, or paraffine obtained by distilling certain kinds of wood, as the beech.
See Lignin.

entry.ety: L. lignosus, fr. lignum wood: cf. F. ligneux. Cf. Ligneous
entry.def: Ligneous.

sn.def: See Lignin.
An explosive compound of wood fiber and nitroglycerin. See Nitroglycerin.

entries.entry: ‖Lig"num rho"di*um lĭg"nŭm rō"dĭ*ŭm. NL., fr. L. lignum wood + Gr. "ro`don a rose Bot The fragrant wood of several shrubs and trees, especially of species of Rhodorhiza from the Canary Islands, and of the West Indian Amyris balsamifera.

entry.note: ☞ In New Zealand the Metrosideros buxifolia is called lignum-vitæ, and in Australia a species of Acacia. The bastard lignum-vitæ is a West Indian tree (Sarcomphalus laurinus).
entry.ety: L., wood of life; lignum wood + vita, genitive vitæ, life
entry.def: A tree (Guaiacum officinale) found in the warm latitudes of America, from which the guaiacum of medicine is procured. Its wood is very hard and heavy, and is used for various mechanical purposes, as for the wheels of ships' blocks, cogs, bearings, and the like. See Guaiacum.

A trade name applied somewhat indefinitely to some of the volatile products obtained in refining crude petroleum. It is a complex and variable mixture of several hydrocarbons, generally boils below 170° Fahr., and is more inflammable than safe kerosene. It is used as a solvent, as a carburetant for air gas, and for illumination in special lamps.

entry.ety: Cf. D. liggen to lie, E. lie to be prostrate, and E. flotsam jetsam, or ligan
entry.def: Same as Ligan.

entries.entry:
‖Lig"u*la lĭg"�*lȧ n.; pl. L. Ligulæ -lē, E. Ligulas -lȧz. L., a little tongue. See Ligule
Bot See Ligule.
Zoöl
The central process, or front edge, of the labium of insects. It sometimes serves as a tongue or proboscis, as in bees. See Illust. under Labium, and Hymenoptera
A tongue-shaped lobe of the parapodia of annelids. See Parapodium.

cs.cd: a species of compound flower, the florets of which have their corollets flat, spreading out toward the end, with the base only tubular.

entry.ety: Cf. F. ligulé. See Ligule, and cf. Lingulate

sn.def: Like a bandage, or strap; strap-shaped.
Composed of ligules.

entry.ety: L. ligula lingula, little tongue, dim of lingua tongue : cf. F. ligule

sd.def: The thin and scarious projection from the upper end of the sheath of a leaf of grass.
A strap-shaped corolla of flowers of Compositæ.

sn.def: A band of white matter in the wall of fourth ventricle of the brain.

entry.ety: Ligule + L. flos floris, a flower
entry.def: Bearing only ligulate flowers; -- said of a large suborder of composite plants, such as the dandelion, lettuce, hawkweed, etc.

entry.ety: L. ligurius, Gr. ligy`rion liggoy`rion ligkoy`rion lygkoy`rion, equiv. to Heb. leshem
entry.def: A kind of precious stone.
entry.q: The third row a ligure, an agate, and an amethyst.

entry.def: A bitter principle found in the bark of the privet Ligustrum vulgare, and extracted as a white crystalline substance with a warm, bitter taste; -- called also ligustron.
Such as can be liked; such as to attract liking; easy to like; evoking sympathy; as, a likable person.

sn.def: disposed to please.

entry.note: ☞ To, which formerly often followed like, is now usually omitted.
entry.cs: Had likefollowed by the infinitive), had nearly; came little short of.

cs.cd: similar figures.

entry.note: ☞ Like is used as a suffix, converting nouns into adjectives expressing resemblance to the noun; as, manlike, like a man; childlike, like a child; godlike, like a god, etc. Such compounds are readily formed whenever convenient, and several, as crescentlike serpentlike hairlike, etc., are used in this book, although, in some cases, not entered in the vocabulary. Such combinations as bell-like ball-like, etc., are hyphened.
entry.ety: OE. lik ilik gelic, AS. gelīc, fr. pref. ge- + līc body, and orig. meaning, having the same body, shape, or appearance, and hence, like; akin to OS. gilīk, D. gelijk, G. gleich, OHG. gilīh, Icel. līkr glīkr, Dan. lig, Sw. lik, Goth. galeiks, OS. lik body, D. lijk, G. leiche, Icel. līk, Sw. lik, Goth. leik. The English adverbial ending-ly is from the same adjective. Cf. Each Such Which

sn.def: Having the same, or nearly the same, appearance, qualities, or characteristics; resembling; similar to; similar; alike; -- often with in and the particulars of the resemblance; as, they are like each other in features, complexion, and many traits of character.
sn.q: 'T is as like you As cherry is to cherry.
Like master, like man.
He giveth snow like wool; he scattereth the hoar-frost like ashes.

sn.def: Equal, or nearly equal; as, fields of like extent.
sn.q: More clergymen were impoverished by the late war than ever in the like space before.

sn.def: Having probability; affording probability; probable; likely.
sn.q: But it is like the jolly world about us will scoff at the paradox of these practices.
Many were not easy to be governed, nor like to conform themselves to strict rules.

sn.def: Inclined toward; disposed to; as, to feel like taking a walk.
sn.q: Had like to have been my utter overthrow.
Ramona had like to have said the literal truth, . . . but recollected herself in time.

sn.def: That which is equal or similar to another; the counterpart; an exact resemblance; a copy.
sn.q: He was a man, take him for all in all, I shall not look upon his like again.

sn.def: A liking; a preference; inclination; -- usually in pl.; as, we all have likes and dislikes.
The stroke which equalizes the number of strokes played by the opposing player or side; as, to play the like .

entry.note: ☞ Like, as here used, is regarded by some grammarians as a preposition.
entry.ety: AS. gelīce. See Like a.

sn.def: In a manner like that of; in a manner similar to; as, do not act like him.
sn.q: He maketh them to stagger like a drunken man.

sn.def: In a like or similar manner.
sn.q: Like as a father pitieth his children, so the Lord pitieth them that fear him.

sn.def: Likely; probably.
sn.q: Likeenough it will.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Liked līkt; p. pr. & vb. n. Liking
entry.ety: OE. liken to please, AS. līcian gelīcian, fr. gelīc. See Like a.

sn.def: To suit; to please; to be agreeable to.
sn.q: Cornwall him liked best, therefore he chose there.
I willingly confess that it likes me much better when I find virtue in a fair lodging than when I am bound to seek it in an ill-favored creature.

sn.def: To be pleased with in a moderate degree; to approve; to take satisfaction in; to enjoy.
sn.q: He proceeded from looking to liking, and from liking to loving.

sn.def: To liken; to compare.
sn.q: Like me to the peasant boys of France.

cs.cd: to be pleased with.

sn.def: To be pleased; to choose.
sn.q: He may either go or stay, as he best likes.

sn.def: To have an appearance or expression; to look; to seem to be (in a specified condition).
sn.q: You like well, and bear your years very well.

sn.def: To come near; to avoid with difficulty; to escape narrowly; as, he liked to have been too late. Cf. Had like, under Like a.
sn.q: He probably got his death, as he liked to have done two years ago, by viewing the troops for the expedition from the wall of Kensington Garden.

entry.def: See Likable.
Likelihood.

entry.ety: Likely + -hood

sn.def: Appearance; show; sign; expression.
sn.q: What of his heart perceive you in his face By any likelihood he showed to-day ?

sn.def: Likeness; resemblance.
sn.q: There is no likelihood between pure light and black darkness, or between righteousness and reprobation.

sn.def: Appearance of truth or reality; probability; verisimilitude.
Statistical probability; probability of being true or of occurring in the future; as, the likelihood of being abducted by aliens is close to zero..
Likelihood; probability.
Suitableness; agreeableness.

entry.ety: That is, like-like. See Like a.

sn.def: Worthy of belief; probable; credible; as, a likely story.
sn.q: It seems likely that he was in hope of being busy and conspicuous.

sn.def: Having probability; having or giving reason to expect; -- followed by the infinitive; as, it is likely to rain.
Similar; like; alike.
Such as suits; good-looking; pleasing; agreeable; handsome.
Having such qualities as make success probable; well adapted to the place; promising; as, a likely young man; a likely servant.
Improbable; unlikely; -- used ironically; as, a likely story.

entry.def: In all probability; probably.
entry.q: While man was innocent he was likely ignorant of nothing that imported him to know.

entry.def: Having a like disposition or purpose; of the same mind.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Likened līk"'nd; p. pr. & vb. n. Likening

sn.def: To allege, or think, to be like; to represent as like; to compare; as, to liken life to a pilgrimage.
sn.q: Whosoever heareth these sayings of mine, and doeth them, I will liken him unto a wise man which built his house upon a rock.

sn.def: To make or cause to be like.

entry.ety: AS. gelīcnes

sn.def: The state or quality of being like; similitude; resemblance; similarity; as, the likeness of the one to the other is remarkable.
Appearance or form; guise.
sn.q: An enemy in the likeness of a friend.

sn.def: That which closely resembles; a portrait.
sn.q: How he looked] the likenesses of him which still remain enable us to imagine.

sn.def: A comparison; parable; proverb.

sn.syn: Similarity; parallel; similitude; representation; portrait; effigy.

entry.def: See Lickerish Lickerishness.

entry.ety: See Wise n.
entry.def: In like manner; also; moreover; too. See Also.
entry.q: Go, and do thou likewise.
For he seeth that wise men die; likewise the fool and the brutish person perish.

entry.ety: Chin. li kin; li the thousandth part of a tael + kin money

entry.q: “Likin,” which used to be regarded as illegal, as one of the many, “squeezes” imposed by the mandarins, is, in Jamieson's opinion, just as legal as any other form of taxation.

entry.def: Looking; appearing; as, better or worse liking . See Like, to look.
entry.q: Why should he see your faces worse liking than the children which are of your sort?

cs.cd: on condition of being pleasing to or suiting; also, on condition of being pleased with; as, to hold a place of service on liking; to engage a servant on liking.

sn.def: The state of being pleasing; a suiting. See On liking, below.

The state of being pleased with, or attracted toward, some thing or person; hence, inclination; desire; pleasure; preference; -- often with for, formerly with to; as, it is an amusement I have no liking for.
sn.q: If the human intellect hath once taken a liking to any doctrine, . . . it draws everything else into harmony with that doctrine, and to its support.

sn.def: Appearance; look; figure; state of body as to health or condition.
sn.q: I shall think the worse of fat men, as long as I have an eye to make difference of men's liking.
Their young ones are in good liking.
Would he be the degenerate scion of that royal line . . . to be a king on liking and on sufferance?

cs.cd: a low shrub with dense clusters of purplish flowers (Ceanothus thyrsiflorus).

entry.ety: Sp. lilac lila, Ar. līlak, fr. Per. līlaj līlanj līlang nīlaj nīl, the indigo plant, or from the kindred līlak bluish, the flowers being named from the color. Cf. Anil

sn.def: A shrub of the genus Syringa. There are six species, natives of Europe and Asia. Syringa vulgaris, the common lilac, and Syringa Persica, the Persian lilac, are frequently cultivated for the fragrance and beauty of their purplish or white flowers. In the British colonies various other shrubs have this name.
A light purplish color like that of the flower of the purplish lilac.

entry.def: See Syringin.

entry.ety: L. liliaceus, fr. lilium lily. See Lily
entry.def: Of or pertaining to a natural order of which the lily, tulip, and hyacinth are well-known examples.
Like the blossom of a lily in general form.
Having a general resemblance to lilies or to liliaceous plants.
Covered with, or having many, lilies.

entry.def: one of four subclasses or superorders of Monocotyledones; it comprises 17 families including: Liliaceae; Alliaceae; Amaryllidaceae; Iridaceae; Orchidaceae; Trilliaceae.
A flowering plant.

A class comprising seed plants that produce an embryo with a single cotyledon and parallel-veined leaves. It includes the grasses; lilies; palms; and orchids. It is divided into four subclasses or superorders: Alismatidae; Arecidae; Commelinidae; and Liliidae.
entry.syn: Monocotyledones, class Monocotyledones, Monocotyledonae, class Monocotyledonae, class Liliopsida.

entry.def: a female demon who attacks children.
The type genus of the Liliaceae.
To loll.

sn.def: One belonging to a very diminutive race described in Swift's “Voyage to Lilliput” or “Gulliver's Travels”.
A person or thing of very small size.
Of or pertaining to the imaginary island of Lilliput described by Swift, or to its inhabitants.
Of very small size; diminutive; insignificant; dwarfed.

entry.def: An Australian myrtaceous tree (Eugenia Smithii), having smooth ovate leaves, and panicles of small white flowers. The wood is hard and fine-grained.

entry.ety: Cf. Norw. lilla lirla, to sing in a high tone

sn.def: To do anything with animation and quickness, as to skip, fly, or hop.
To sing cheerfully.

entry.def: To utter with spirit, animation, or gayety; to sing with spirit and liveliness.
entry.q: A classic lecture, rich in sentiment, With scraps of thundrous epic lilted out By violet-hooded doctors.

sn.def: Animated, brisk motion; spirited rhythm; sprightliness.
sn.q: The movement, the lilt, and the subtle charm of the verse.

sn.def: A lively song or dance; a cheerful tune.
sn.q: The housewife went about her work, or spun at her wheel, with a lilt upon her lips.

entry.def: having a light rhythmical cadence; as, an easy lilting stride; a lilting melody.

entries.entry:
Lil"y ☞ There are nearly fifty species, all found in the North Temperate zone. Lilium candidum and Lilium longiflorum are the common white lilies of gardens; Lilium Philadelphicum is the wild red lily of the Atlantic States. Lilium Chalcedonicum is supposed to be the “lily of the field” in our Lord's parable; Lilium auratum is the great gold-banded lily of Japan.
African lily Bot the blue-flowered Agapanthus umbellatus. Atamasco lily Bot a plant of the genus Zephyranthes Zephyranthes Atamasco), having a white and pink funnelform perianth, with six petal-like divisions resembling those of a lily. Gray. Blackberry lily Bot the Pardanthus Chinensis, the black seeds of which form a dense mass like a blackberry. Bourbon lily Bot
Lilium candidum. See Illust.
Butterfly lily. Bot Same as Mariposa lily, in the Vocabulary. Lily beetle Zool a European beetle (Crioceris merdigera) which feeds upon the white lily. Lily daffodil Bot a plant of the genus Narcissus, and its flower. Lily encrinite Paleon a fossil encrinite, esp. Encrinus liliiformis. See Encrinite. Lily hyacinth Bot a plant of the genus Hyacinthus. Lily iron a kind of harpoon with a detachable head of peculiar shape, used in capturing swordfish.
Lily of the valley Bot a low perennial herb (Convallaria majalis), having a raceme of nodding, fragrant, white flowers.
Lily pad the large floating leaf of the water lily. U. S Lowell. Tiger lily Bot
Lilium tigrinum, the sepals of which are blotched with black. Turk's-cap lily Bot
Lilium Martagon, a red lily with recurved sepals; also, the similar American lily, Lilium superbum. Water lily Bot the Nymphæa, a plant with floating roundish leaves, and large flowers having many petals, usually white, but sometimes pink, red, blue, or yellow. [See Illust. of Nymphæa
lĭl"� n.; pl.Lilies lĭl"ĭz. AS. lilie, L. lilium, Gr. lei`rion. Cf. Flower-de-luce
Bot A plant and flower of the genus Lilium, endogenous bulbous plants, having a regular perianth of six colored pieces, six stamens, and a superior three-celled ovary.
Bot A name given to handsome flowering plants of several genera, having some resemblance in color or form to a true lily, as Pancratium Crinum Amaryllis Nerine, etc.
That end of a compass needle which should point to the north; -- so called as often ornamented with the figure of a lily or fleur-de-lis. But sailing further, it veers its lily to the west.
Auction Bridge A royal spade; -- usually in pl. See Royal spade, below.

entry.def: Having white, delicate hands.
White-livered; cowardly.
Asiatic perennial tufted herb (Liriope muscari) with grasslike evergreen foliage and clusters of dark mauve grapelike flowers; grown as ground cover.
Any plant of the Lily family or order.

entry.ety: See Limb
entry.def: A limb.

entry.cs: Lima bean. Bot A variety of climbing or pole bean (Phaseolus lunatus), which has very large flattish seeds. The seed of this plant, much used for food. Lima wood Bot the beautiful dark wood of the South American tree Cæsalpinia echinata.

entry.ety: L. limax limacis, slug, snail: cf. F. limacé
entry.def: Pertaining to, or like, Limax, or the slugs.

entry.ety: NL., From L. limax limacis, a slug

entry.ety: F. limaçon, lit., a snail
entry.def: A curve of the fourth degree, invented by Pascal. Its polar equation is r = a cos θ + b.

entry.ety: F., fr. limer to file. See Limation

entry.q: An ounce . . . of silverlymaille.

entry.ety: F. limon, fr. L. limus slime

entry.ety: L. limatus, p. p. of limare to file, fr. lima file : cf. F. limation
entry.def: The act of filing or polishing.

entry.ety: L. limatura. See Limation

sn.def: The act of filing.
That which is filed off; filings.

entry.ety: L
entry.def: A genus of airbreathing mollusks, including the common garden slugs. They have a small rudimentary shell. The breathing pore is on the right side of the neck. Several species are troublesome in gardens. See Slug.

cs.cd: a lawyer or an officer of the law.

entry.ety: OE. lim, AS. lim; akin to Icel. limr limb, lim branch of a tree, Sw. & Dan. lem limb; cf. also AS. lið, OHG. lid gilid, G. glied, Goth. liþus. Cf. Lith Limber

sn.def: A part of a tree which extends from the trunk and separates into branches and twigs; a large branch.
An arm or a leg of a human being; a leg, arm, or wing of an animal.
sn.q: A second Hector for his grim aspect, And large proportion of his strong-knit limbs.

sn.q: That little limb of the devil has cheated the gallows.

sn.def: An elementary piece of the mechanism of a lock.
To supply with limbs.
To dismember; to tear off the limbs of.

entry.ety: L. limbus border. Cf. Limbo Limbus

The border or upper spreading part of a monopetalous corolla, or of a petal, or sepal; blade.
The border or edge of the disk of a heavenly body, especially of the sun and moon.
The graduated margin of an arc or circle, in an instrument for measuring angles.

entry.ety: Etymol. uncertain
entry.def: A cooling periodical wind in the Isle of Cyprus, blowing from the northwest from eight o'clock, A. M., to the middle of the day or later.

entry.ety: L. limbatus, fr. limbus border, edge. See Limbus
entry.def: Bordered, as when one color is surrounded by an edging of another.

entry.ety: Abbrev. of alembic
entry.def: An alembic; a still.
To distill.
Having limbs; -- much used in composition; as, large-limbed; short-limbed.
entry.q: Innumerous living creatures, perfect forms,Limbed and full grown.

cs.cd: short pieces of plank forming part of the lining of a ship's floor immediately above the timbers, so as to prevent the limbers from becoming clogged.
a box on the limber for carrying ammunition.
a rope or chain passing through the limbers of a ship, by which they may be cleared of dirt that chokes them.
the first course of inside planking next the keelson.

entry.ety: For limmer, Icel. limar branches, boughs, pl. of lim; akin to E. limb. See Limb a branch

sn.def: The shafts or thills of a wagon or carriage.
The detachable fore part of a gun carriage, consisting of two wheels, an axle, and a shaft to which the horses are attached. On top is an ammunition box upon which the cannoneers sit.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Limbered lĭm"bẽrd; p. pr. & vb. n. Limbering
entry.def: To attach to the limber; as, to limber a gun.

entry.ety: Akin to limp, a. √125. See Limp a.
