entry.def: To cause to become limber; to make flexible or pliant.
The quality or state of being limber; flexibleness.
of or pertaining to the limbic system; as, the limbic system.

A group of neural structures in the brain below the cerebral cortex, centered on the hypothalamus and including the hippocampus and amygdala, involved with control of emotion, motivation, memory, and some homeostatic regulatory processes.

q.au: Carl Sagan (The Dragons of Eden, New York, Random House, 1977).

entry.q: At the most ancient part of the human brain lies the spinal cord; the medulla and pons, which comprise the hindbrain; and the midbrain. This cobination of spinal cord, hindbrain, and midbrain MacLean calls the neural chassis. It contains the basic neural machinery for reproduction and self-preservation, . . . MacLean has distinguished three sorts of [more recent brain structures controlling] the neural chassis. The most ancient of them surround the midbrain. . . . We share it with the other mammals and the reptiles. It probably evolved several hundred million years ago. MacLean calls it the reptilian or R-complex. Surrounding the R-complex is the limbic system, so called because it borders on the underlying brain. (Our arms and legs are called limbs because they are peripheral to the rest of the body.) We share the limbic system with other mammals, but not, in its full elaboration, with the reptiles. It probably evolved more than one hundred fifty million years ago. Finally, surrounding the rest of the brain and clearly the most recent evolutionary accretion, is the neocortex.

entry.def: Destitute of limbs.

entry.ety: See Limb, and Piecemeal
entry.def: Piecemeal.
entry.q: To tear herlimbmeal.

entry.note: ☞ The limbus patrum was considered as a place for the souls of good men who lived before the coming of our Savior. The limbus infantium was said to be a similar place for the souls of unbaptized infants. To these was added, in the popular belief, the limbus fatuorum, or fool's paradise, regarded as a receptacle of all vanity and nonsense.
entry.ety: L. limbus border, edge in limbo on the border. Cf. Limb border

sn.def: An spiritual region where certain classes of souls were supposed to await the last judgment.
sn.q: As far from help as Limbo is from bliss.
A Limbo large and broad, since called The Paradise of fools.

sn.def: Hence: Any real or imaginary place of restraint or confinement; a prison; as, to put a man in limbo .

A state of waiting, or uncertainty, in which final judgment concerning the outcome of a decision is postponed, perhaps indefinitely; neglect for an indefinite time; as, the proposal was left in limbo while opponents and proponents refused to compromise.
A border or margin; as, the limbus of the cornea.

entry.ety: Jamaican E. limba to bend, fr. E. limber1950MW10
entry.def: A West Indian dance contest, in which participants must dance under a pole which is lowered successively until only one participant can successfully pass under, without falling. It is often performed at celebrations, such as weddings.

entry.ety: See Limbus
entry.def: With slightly overlapping borders; -- said of a suture.
A soft cheese made in the Belgian province of Limburg (Limbourg), and usually not eaten until the curing has developed a peculiar and, to most people, unpleasant odor.

entry.ety: See Leam a string
entry.def: A thong by which a dog is led; a leash.

entry.ety: Formerly line, for earlier lind. See Linden
entry.def: The linden tree. See Linden.

entry.note: The term lime was formerly also applied to variants of the closely related citron, of which there are two varieties, Citrus Medica, var. acida which is intensely sour, and the sweet lime Citrus Medica, var. Limetta) which is only slightly sour. See citron.
entry.ety: F. lime; of Persian origin. See Lemon

sn.def: The fruit of the Citrus aurantifolia, allied to the lemon, but greener in color; also, the tree which bears it.
The color of the lime{1}, a yellowish-green.

entry.note: ☞ Lime is the principal constituent of limestone, marble, chalk, bones, shells, etc.

cs.cd: Calcium hydroxide or slaked lime; also, in a less technical sense, calcium oxide or quicklime.
one who burns limestone, shells, etc., to make lime.
a limestone quarry.
a twig smeared with birdlime; hence, that which catches; a snare.

entry.ety: AS. līm; akin to D. lijm, G. leim, OHG. līm, Icel. līm, Sw. lim, Dan. liim, L. limus mud, linere to smear, and E. loam. √126. Cf. Loam Liniment

sn.def: Birdlime.
sn.q: Like the lime That foolish birds are caught with.

sn.def: Oxide of calcium, CaO; the white or gray, caustic substance, usually called quicklime, obtained by calcining limestone or shells, the heat driving off carbon dioxide and leaving lime. It develops great heat when treated with water, forming slaked lime, and is an essential ingredient of cement, plastering, mortar, etc.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Limed līmd; p. pr. & vb. n. Liming
entry.ety: Cf. AS. gelīman to glue or join together. See Lime a viscous substance

sn.def: To smear with a viscous substance, as birdlime.
sn.q: These twigs, in time, will come to be limed.

sn.def: To entangle; to insnare.
sn.q: We had limed ourselves With open eyes, and we must take the chance.

sn.def: To treat with lime, or oxide or hydrate of calcium; to manure with lime; as, to lime hides for removing the hair; to lime sails in order to whiten them; to lime the lawn to decrease acidity of the soil.
sn.q: Land may be improved by draining, marling, and liming.

sn.def: To cement.
sn.q: Who gave his blood tolimethe stones together.

entry.def: having a yellowish-green color like that of the lime (the fruit).
A sweetened beverage of lime juice and water.

entry.ety: Lime a leash + hound
entry.def: A dog used in hunting the wild boar; a leamer.
A kiln or furnace in which limestone or shells are burned and reduced to lime.
An intense light produced by heating lime. See Calcium light under Calcium.

That part of the stage upon which the limelight is cast, usually where the most important action is progressing or where the leading player or players are placed and upon which the attention of the spectators is therefore concentrated.
a conspicuous position before the public; the center of public attention; -- used mostly in the phrase in the limelight; as, politicians who are never happy except in the limelight .
a threshhold, especially the point where a psychological or physiological effect begins to occur.
Of or pertaining to Lima, or to the inhabitants of Lima, in Peru.

def2.def: A native or inhabitant of Lima.

entry.def: A genus comprising mainly dark northern butterflies with white wing bars.
A limehound; a limmer.

entry.note: It often begins with "There once was a . . ." or "There was a . . ."; asThere was a young lady, Amanda, Whose Ballades Lyriques were quite fin deSiècle, I deem But her Journal Intime Was what sent her papa to Uganda.
entry.ety: Said to be from a song with the same verse construction, current in Ireland, the refrain of which contains the place name Limerick
entry.def: A humorous, often nonsensical, and sometimes risqé poem of five anapestic lines, of which lines 1, 2, and 5 are of three feet, and rhyme, and lines 3 and 4 are of two feet, and rhyme.

A rock consisting chiefly of calcium carbonate or carbonate of lime. It sometimes contains also magnesium carbonate, and is then called magnesian or dolomitic limestone. Crystalline limestone is called marble.

entries.entry: Lime twig. See under 4th Lime.

entry.def: Beset with snares; insnared, as with birdlime.
Water impregnated with lime; esp., an artificial solution of lime for medicinal purposes.

entry.ety: L. limicola a dweller in the mud; limus mud + colere to dwell
entry.def: A group of shore birds, embracing the plovers, sandpipers, snipe, curlew, etc.; the Grallæ.
Shore-inhabiting; of or pertaining to the Limicolæ.

sn.def: of or pertaining to a limen, especially a sensory threshhold.
marginally perceptible.

entry.def: that temporary state during a rite of passage when the participant lacks social status or rank, is required to follow specified forms of conduct, and is expected to show obedience and humility.
The state or quality of being limy.

entry.cs: Elastic limit. See under Elastic. Prison limits a definite, extent of space in or around a prison, within which a prisoner has liberty to go and come.
entry.ety: From L. limes limitis: cf. F. limite; -or from E. limit, v. See Limit v. t.

sn.def: That which terminates, circumscribes, restrains, or confines; the bound, border, or edge; the utmost extent; as, the limit of a walk, of a town, of a country; the limits of human knowledge or endeavor.
sn.q: As eager of the chase, the maid Beyond the forest's verdant limits strayed.

sn.def: The space or thing defined by limits.
sn.q: The archdeacon hath divided it Into three limits very equally.

sn.def: That which terminates a period of time; hence, the period itself; the full time or extent.
sn.q: The dateless limit of thy dear exile.
The limit of your lives is out.

sn.def: A restriction; a check; a curb; a hindrance.
sn.q: I prithee, give no limits to my tongue.

sn.def: A determining feature; a distinguishing characteristic; a differentia.

A determinate quantity, to which a variable one continually approaches, and may differ from it by less than any given difference, but to which, under the law of variation, the variable can never become exactly equivalent.
sn.syn: Boundary; border; edge; termination; restriction; bound; confine.

cs.cd: those parallels of latitude between which only an occultation of a star or planet by the moon, in a given case, can occur.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Limited; p. pr. & vb. n. Limiting
entry.ety: F. limiter, L. limitare, fr. limes limitis, limit; prob. akin to limen threshold, E. eliminate; cf. L. limus sidelong
entry.def: To apply a limit to, or set a limit for; to terminate, circumscribe, or restrict, by a limit or limits; as, to limit the acreage of a crop; to limit the issue of paper money; to limit one's ambitions or aspirations; to limit the meaning of a word.
To beg, or to exercise functions, within a certain limited region; as, a limiting friar.
Capable of being limited.

entry.ety: L. limitaneus. See Limit v. t.
entry.def: Of or pertaining to a limit.
Tending to limit.

entry.ety: L. limitaris. See Limit , v. t.

sn.def: Placed at the limit, as a guard.
sn.q: Proudlimitarycherub.

sn.def: Confined within limits; limited in extent, authority, power, etc.
sn.q: Thelimitaryocean.
The poor, limitary creature calling himself a man of the world.

sn.def: Limiting, or tending to limit; restrictive.
sn.q: Doctrines limitary, if not subversive of the papal power.

entries.entry:
Lim"i*ta*ry n.; pl.limitaries lĭm"ĭ*t�*rĭz.
That which serves to limit; a boundary; border land. Obs
A limiter. See Limiter, 2.

entry.ety: L. limitatus, p. p. of limitare to limit. See Limit v. t.
entry.def: Bounded by a distinct line.

cs.cd: to know the reach and limits of one's abilities.

entry.ety: L. limitatio: cf. F. limitation. See Limit v. t.

sn.def: The act of limiting; the state or condition of being limited; as, the limitation of his authority was approved by the council.
sn.q: They had no right to mistake the limitation . . . of their own faculties, for an inherent limitation of the possible modes of existence in the universe.

sn.def: That which limits; a restriction; a qualification; a restraining condition, defining circumstance, or qualifying conception; as, limitations of thought.
sn.q: The cause of error is ignorance what restraints and limitations all principles have in regard of the matter whereunto they are applicable.

sn.def: A certain precinct within which friars were allowed to beg, or exercise their functions; also, the time during which they were permitted to exercise their functions in such a district.
A limited time within or during which something is to be done.
sn.q: You have stood your limitation, and the tribunes Endue you with the people's voice.

sd.def: A certain period limited by statute after which the claimant shall not enforce his claims by suit.
A settling of an estate or property by specific rules.
A restriction of power; as, a constitutional limitation .

cs.cd: a company in which the liability of each shareholder is limited by the number of shares he has taken, so that he can not be called on to contribute beyond the amount of his shares.

entry.def: Confined within limits; narrow; circumscribed; restricted; as, our views of nature are very limited .
With limitation.
The quality of being limited.

sn.def: One who, or that which, limits.
A friar licensed to beg within certain bounds, or whose duty was limited to a certain district.
sn.q: A limitour of the Gray Friars, in the time of his limitation, preached many times, and had but one sermon at all times.

entry.def: Involving a limit; as, a limitive law, one designed to limit existing powers.
Having no limits; unbounded; boundless.
See Limiter, 2.
Limber.

entry.ety: F. limier. See Leamer

sn.def: A limehound; a leamer.
A mongrel, as a cross between the mastiff and hound.
A low, base fellow; also, a prostitute.
sn.q: Thieves, limmers, and broken men of the Highlands.

sn.def: A man rope at the side of a ladder.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Limned lĭmd; p. pr. & vb. n. Limning lĭm"nĭng or lĭm"ĭng
entry.ety: OE. limnen, fr. luminen, for enluminen, F. enluminer to illuminate, to limn, LL. illuminare to paint. √122. See Illuminate Luminous

sn.def: To draw or paint; especially, to represent in an artistic way with pencil or brush.
sn.q: Let a painter carelessly limn out a million of faces, and you shall find them all different.

sn.def: To picture in words; to describe in graphic terms.
To illumine, as books or parchments, with ornamental figures, letters, or borders.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. limnai^os pertaining to a marsh, fr. li`mh a marsh
entry.def: A genus of fresh-water air-breathing mollusks, abundant in ponds and streams; -- called also pond snail.

entries.entry:
Lim"ner lĭm"nẽr n. F. enlumineur, LL. illuminator. See Limn, and cf. Alluminor
A painter; an artist; esp.: One who paints portraits. One who illuminates books. Archaic

entry.ety: Gr. li`mh a pool
entry.def: See Limoniad.
The act, process, or art of one who limns; the picture or decoration so produced.
entry.q: Adorned with illumination which we now call limning.

entry.def: A genus of shore birds including the dowitchers.
the scientific study of bodies of fresh water for their biological and physical and geological properties.
Limousine; -- a shortened form.

entry.cs: Limoges enamel a kind of enamel ware in which the enamel is applied to the whole surface of a metal plaque, vase, or the like, and painted in enamel colors. The art was brought to a high degree of perfection in Limoges in the 16th century. Limoges ware. Articles decorated with Limoges enamel. Articles of porcelain, etc., manufactured at Limoges.

sn.def: A city of Southern France.
A variety of fine porcelain manufactured at Limoges{1}; also called Limoges ware or Limoges China.

entry.def: a liquid terpene with a lemon odor; found in lemons and oranges and other essential oils.

entry.ety: L. limoniades, pl., Gr. leimwnia`des, fr. leimw`n meadow
entry.def: A nymph of the meadows; -- called also Limniad.

entry.ety: From NL. Citrus Medica, var. Limonum, the scientific name of the lemon
entry.def: A bitter, white, crystalline substance found in orange and lemon seeds.

entry.ety: Gr. leimw`n any moist grassy place, a meadow: cf. F. limonite, G. limonit
entry.def: Hydrous sesquioxide of iron, an important ore of iron, occurring in stalactitic, mammillary, or earthy forms, of a dark brown color, and yellowish brown powder. It includes bog iron. Also called brown hematite.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. limo`s hunger
entry.def: A ravenous appetite caused by disease; excessive and morbid hunger.

entry.ety: L. limosus, fr. limus slime, mud
entry.def: Muddy; slimy; thick.

entry.note: When intended for use in transporting businessmen, the limousine may be equipped with a telephone and other conveniences to permit work during travel. Limousines are often rented for travel to and from airports, and as a luxurious perquisite on special occasions, as weddings or school prm nights. Originally (1913) the term referred to an automobile body with seats and permanent top like a coupé, and with the top projecting over the driver and a projecting front, or an automobile with such a body.
entry.ety: Cf. F. limousine a kind of cloak, fr. Limousin, an old province in central France
entry.def: an elongated, luxurious automobile, designed to be driven by a chauffeur and often having a glass partition between the driver's seat and the passengers' compartment behind.

a wealthy or well-to-do person of liberal political inclination. It is sometimes used as a term of contempt for those espousing the cause of poor people, without having to endure the discomfort that their policies may inflict on others, such as the lower middle class.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Limped lĭmt; 215; p. pr. & vb. n. Limping
entry.ety: Cf. AS. lemphealt lame, OHG. limphen to limp, be weak; perh. akin to E. lame, or to limp, a √120
entry.def: To halt; to walk lamely. Also used figuratively.
A halt; the act of limping.
A scraper for removing poor ore or refuse from the sieve.

entry.ety: Cf. Icel. limpa limpness, weakness, and E. lap n. lop v. t. Cf. Limber a.

sn.def: Flaccid; flabby, as flesh.
Lacking stiffness; flimsy; as, a limp cravat.

entry.ety: Swedish
entry.def: a type of rye bread, made using molasses or brown sugar.
One who limps.

entry.note: ☞ The common European limpets of the genus Patellaesp. Patella vulgata) are extensively used as food. The common New England species is Acmæa testudinalis. Numerous species of limpets occur on the Pacific coast of America, some of them of large size.
entry.ety: Prob. through French fr. L. lepas -adis, Gr. lepa`s -a`dos

sn.def: In a general sense, any hatshaped, or conical, gastropod shell.
Any one of many species of marine shellfish of the order Docoglossa, mostly found adhering to rocks, between tides.
Any species of Siphonaria, a genus of limpet-shaped Pulmonifera, living between tides, on rocks.
A keyhole limpet. See Fissurella.

entry.ety: L. limpidus; akin to Gr. la`mpein to shine: cf. F. limpide. Cf. Lamp

sn.def: Characterized by clearness or transparency; clear; as, a limpid stream.
sn.q: Springs which were clear, fresh, and limpid.

sn.def: Clear and unambiguous; lucid; easy to understand; -- of speech and writing; as, limpid prose.
Calm, untroubled, and without worry; serene.
sn.syn: Clear; transparent; pellucid; lucid; pure; crystal; translucent; bright.

entry.ety: L. limpiditas: cf. F. limpidité
entry.def: The quality or state of being limpid.
Quality of being limpid; limpidity.
A limpet.
In a limping manner.
Limpidity.

Either one of two species of wading birds of the genus Aramus, intermediate between the cranes and rails. The limpkins are remarkable for the great length of the toes. One species (Aramus giganteus) inhabits Florida and the West Indies; the other (Aramus scolopaceus) is found in South America. Called also courlan, and crying bird.
The quality or state of being limp.

entry.ety: See Limp a., and cf. W. llymsi having a fickle motion, weak. Cf. Flimsy
entry.def: Limp; flexible; flimsy.
The Hawaiian name for seaweeds. Over sixty kinds are used as food, and have species names, as Limu Lipoa Limu palawai, etc.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: A limulus.

entry.note: ☞ There are six pairs of leglike organs, surrounding the mouth, most of which terminate in claws; those of the first pair (probably mandibles) are the smallest; the others have the basal joints thickened and spinose, to serve as jaws, while the terminal joints serve as legs. This group is intermediate, in some characteristics, between crustaceans and certain arachnids (scorpions), but the respiration is by means of lamellate gills borne upon the five posterior abdominal appendages, which are flat and united in pairs by their inner edges, and are protected by the lidlike anterior pair, which also bear the genital orifices.
entry.ety: NL. See Limulus, and -oid
entry.def: An order of Merostomata, including among living animals the genus Limulus, with various allied fossil genera, mostly of the Carboniferous period. Called also Xiphosura .

entries.entry: ‖Lim"u*lus lĭm"�*lŭs n.; pl.Limuli -lī. L., dim. of limus sidelong, askance Zoöl The only existing genus of Merostomata. It includes only a few species from the East Indies, and one (Limulus polyphemus) from the Atlantic coast of North America. Called also Molucca crab king crab horseshoe crab, and horsefoot.

entry.ety: See 4th Lime

sn.def: Smeared with, or consisting of, lime; viscous.
sn.q: Limysnares.

sn.def: Containing lime; as, a limy soil.
Resembling lime; having the qualities of lime.

entry.ety: AS. linnan. See Lithe
entry.def: To yield; to stop; to cease.
To cease from.

entry.note: ☞ Written also linn and lyn.
entry.ety: Ir. linn, or Gael. linne; akin to W. llyn a pool, pond, lake, but in senses 2 and 3 prob. from AS. hlynn torrent. Cf. Dunlin

sn.def: A pool or collection of water, particularly one above or below a fall of water.
A waterfall, or cataract; as, a roaring lin .
A steep ravine.

entry.def: See Lineage.

entry.ety: L. linamentum, fr. linum flax
entry.def: Lint; esp., lint made into a tent for insertion into wounds or ulcers.
A genus of herbs and subshrubs having showy flowers: spurred snapdragon.

entry.ety: So called because formerly supposed to occur at Linares, in Spain
entry.def: A hydrous sulphate of lead and copper occurring in bright blue monoclinic crystals.

entry.ety: AS. hlinc a hill
entry.def: A ledge; a right-angled projection.

entry.ety: Native Chinese name
entry.def: An esculent swallow.

entry.ety: AS. lynis the axletree; akin to D. luns linchpin, OS. lunisa, LG. lunse, G. lünse, OHG. lun peg, bolt
entry.def: A pin used to prevent the wheel of a vehicle from sliding off the axletree.
A color of cloth formerly made in Lincoln, England; the cloth itself.
of or pertaining to Abraham Lincoln .
An antibacterial antibiotic obtained from the bacterium Streptomyces lincolnensis and used in the treatment of certain penicillin-resistant infections.

entry.ety: L. lingere linctum, to lick
entry.def: Medicine taken by licking with the tongue.
The linden. See Linden.
A chemical substance (C6H6Cl6) used as an agricultural insecticide.

entry.ety: Orig. an adj. from lind linden tree, AS. lind; akin to D. & G. linde, OHG. linta, Icel., Sw., & Dan. lind. Cf. Lime linden
entry.def: A handsome tree (Tilia Europæa), having cymes of light yellow flowers, and large cordate leaves. The tree is common in Europe.
In America, the basswood, or Tilia Americana.
A genus of aromatic evergreen or deciduous dioecious shrubs or trees of eastern Asia and North America.
A genus having only one species, the Texas star.

entry.ety: NL
entry.def: A peculiar genus of rotifers, remarkable for the absence of ciliated disks. By some zoölogists it is thought to be like the ancestral form of the Arthropoda.

entry.ety: Lindia + -form
entry.def: Resembling the genus Lindia; -- said of certain apodous insect larvæ.
an energetic American dance that was popular in the 1930s (probably named for the aviator Charles Lindbergh).

entry.ety: OE. lin. See Linen

sn.def: Flax; linen.
sn.q: Garments made ofline.

sn.def: The longer and finer fiber of flax.

cs.cd: gold foil having a lining of another metal.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Lined līnd; p. pr. & vb. n. Lining
entry.ety: See Line flax

sn.def: To cover the inner surface of; as, to line a cloak with silk or fur; to line a box with paper or tin.
sn.q: The inside lined with rich carnation silk.

sn.def: To put something in the inside of; to fill; to supply, as a purse with money.
sn.q: The charge amounteth very high for any one man's purse, except lined beyond ordinary, to reach unto.
Till coffee has her stomach lined.

sn.def: To place persons or things along the side of for security or defense; to strengthen by adding anything; to fortify; as, to line works with soldiers.
sn.q: Line and new repair our towns of war With men of courage and with means defendant.

sn.def: To impregnate; -- applied to brute animals.

entry.cs:
Hard lines hard lot. C. Kingsley. [See Def. 18.]Line breeding Stockbreeding breeding by a certain family line of descent, especially in the selection of the dam or mother. Line conch Zoöl a spiral marine shell (Fasciolaria distans), of Florida and the West Indies. It is marked by narrow, dark, revolving lines. Line engraving. Engraving in which the effects are produced by lines of different width and closeness, cut with the burin upon copper or similar material; also, a plate so engraved. A picture produced by printing from such an engraving. Line of battle. Mil. Tactics The position of troops drawn up in their usual order without any determined maneuver. Naval The line or arrangement formed by vessels of war in an engagement. Line of battle ship. See Ship of the line, below. Line of beauty Fine Arts,an abstract line supposed to be beautiful in itself and absolutely; -- differently represented by different authors, often as a kind of elongated Slike the one drawn by Hogarth). Line of centers. Mach A line joining two centers, or fulcra, as of wheels or levers. A line which determines a dead center. See Dead center, under Dead. Line of dip Geol a line in the plane of a stratum, or part of a stratum, perpendicular to its intersection with a horizontal plane; the line of greatest inclination of a stratum to the horizon. Line of fire Mil the direction of fire. Line of force Physics any line in a space in which forces are acting, so drawn that at every point of the line its tangent is the direction of the resultant of all the forces. It cuts at right angles every equipotential surface which it meets. Specifically Magnetism, a line in proximity to a magnet so drawn that any point in it is tangential with the direction of a short compass needle held at that point. Faraday. Line of life Palmistry a line on the inside of the hand, curving about the base of the thumb, supposed to indicate, by its form or position, the length of a person's life. Line of lines. See Gunter's line. Line of march. Mil Arrangement of troops for marching. Course or direction taken by an army or body of troops in marching. Line of operations that portion of a theater of war which an army passes over in attaining its object. H. W. Halleck. Line of sight Firearms the line which passes through the front and rear sight, at any elevation, when they are sighted at an object. Line tub Naut a tub in which the line carried by a whaleboat is coiled.
Mason and Dixon's line Mason-Dixon line
the boundary line between Pennsylvania and Maryland, as run before the Revolution (1764-1767) by two English astronomers named Charles Mason and Jeremiah Dixon. In an extended sense, the line between the free and the slave States; as, below the Mason-Dixon line, i.e. in the South. On the line on a level with the eye of the spectator; -- said of a picture, as hung in an exhibition of pictures. at risk (dependent upon success) in a contest or enterprise; as, the survival of the company is on the line in this project. Right line a straight line; the shortest line that can be drawn between two points. Ship of the line formerly, a ship of war large enough to have a place in the line of battle; a vessel superior to a frigate; usually, a seventy-four, or three-decker; -- called also line of battle ship or battleship. Totten. To cross the line to cross the equator, as a vessel at sea. To give a person line to allow him more or less liberty until it is convenient to stop or check him, like a hooked fish that swims away with the line. Water line Shipbuilding the outline of a horizontal section of a vessel, as when floating in the water.
entry.ety: OE. line, AS. līne cable, hawser, prob. from L. linea a linen thread, string, line, fr. linum flax, thread, linen, cable; but the English word was influenced by F. ligne line, from the same L. word linea. See Linen

sn.def: A linen thread or string; a slender, strong cord; also, a cord of any thickness; a rope; a hawser; as, a fishing line; a line for snaring birds; a clothesline; a towline.
sn.q: Who so layeth lines for to latch fowls.

sn.def: A more or less threadlike mark of pen, pencil, or graver; any long mark; as, a chalk line .
The course followed by anything in motion; hence, a road or route; as, the arrow descended in a curved line; the place is remote from lines of travel.
Direction; as, the line of sight or vision.
A row of letters, words, etc., written or printed; esp., a row of words extending across a page or column.
A short letter; a note; as, a line from a friend.
A verse, or the words which form a certain number of feet, according to the measure.
sn.q: In the preceding line Ulysses speaks of Nausicaa.

sn.def: Course of conduct, thought, occupation, or policy; method of argument; department of industry, trade, or intellectual activity.
sn.q: He is uncommonly powerful in his own line, but it is not the line of a first-rate man.

sn.def: That which has length, but not breadth or thickness.
The exterior limit of a figure, plat, or territory; boundary; contour; outline.
sn.q: Eden stretched her line From Auran eastward to the royal towers Of great Seleucia.

sn.def: A threadlike crease marking the face or the hand; hence, characteristic mark.
sn.q: Though on his brow were graven lines austere.
He tipples palmistry, and dines On all her fortune-telling lines.

sn.def: Lineament; feature; figure.
sn.q: Thelinesof my boy's face.

sn.def: A straight row; a continued series or rank; as, a line of houses, or of soldiers; a line of barriers.
sn.q: Unite thy forces and attack their lines.

sn.def: A series or succession of ancestors or descendants of a given person; a family or race; as, the ascending or descending line; the line of descent; the male line; a line of kings.
sn.q: Of his lineage am I, and his offspring By very line, as of the stock real.

sn.def: A connected series of public conveyances, and hence, an established arrangement for forwarding merchandise, etc.; as, a line of stages; an express line.

sd.def: A circle of latitude or of longitude, as represented on a map.
The equator; -- usually called the line, or equinoctial line; as, to cross the line .

sn.def: A long tape, or a narrow ribbon of steel, etc., marked with subdivisions, as feet and inches, for measuring; a tapeline.

sd.def: A measuring line or cord.
sd.q: He marketh it out with a line.

sd.def: That which was measured by a line, as a field or any piece of land set apart; hence, allotted place of abode.
sd.q: The lines are fallen unto me in pleasant places; yea, I have a goodly heritage.

sd.def: Instruction; doctrine.
sd.q: Their line is gone out through all the earth.

sn.def: The proper relative position or adjustment of parts, not as to design or proportion, but with reference to smooth working; as, the engine is in line or out of line .
The track and roadbed of a railway; railroad.

sd.def: A row of men who are abreast of one another, whether side by side or some distance apart; -- opposed to column.
The regular infantry of an army, as distinguished from militia, guards, volunteer corps, cavalry, artillery, etc.
A trench or rampart.
Dispositions made to cover extended positions, and presenting a front in but one direction to an enemy.

sn.def: Form of a vessel as shown by the outlines of vertical, horizontal, and oblique sections.
One of the straight horizontal and parallel prolonged strokes on and between which the notes are placed.
A number of shares taken by a jobber.
A series of various qualities and values of the same general class of articles; as, a full line of hosiery; a line of merinos, etc.
The wire connecting one telegraphic station with another, or the whole of a system of telegraph wires under one management and name.
The reins with which a horse is guided by his driver.
A measure of length; one twelfth of an inch.

cs.cd: to track wild bees to their nest by following their line of flight.
to put in alignment; to put in correct adjustment for smooth running. See 3d Line, 19.

sn.def: To mark with a line or lines; to cover with lines; as, to line a copy book.
sn.q: He had a healthy color in his cheeks, and his face, though lined, bore few traces of anxiety.

sn.def: To represent by lines; to delineate; to portray.
sn.q: Pictures fairestlined.

sn.def: To read or repeat line by line; as, to line out a hymn.
sn.q: This custom of reading or lining, or, as it was frequently called “deaconing” the hymn or psalm in the churches, was brought about partly from necessity.

sn.def: To form into a line; to align; as, to line troops.

entry.ety: OE. linage, F. lignage, fr. L. linea line. See 3d Line
entry.def: Descent in a line from a common progenitor; progeny; race; descending line of offspring or ascending line of parentage.
entry.q: Both the lineage and the certain sire From which I sprung, from me are hidden yet.

cs.cd: the measure of length; -- usually written linear measure.

entry.ety: L. linealis belonging to a line, fr. linea line: cf. F. linéal. See 3d Line

sn.def: Descending in a direct line from an ancestor; hereditary; derived from ancestors; -- opposed to collateral; as, a lineal descent or a lineal descendant.
sn.q: The prime and ancient right of lineal succession.

sn.def: Inheriting by direct descent; having the right by direct descent to succeed (to).
sn.q: For only you are lineal to the throne.

sn.def: Composed of lines; delineated; as, lineal designs.
In the direction of a line; of or pertaining to a line; measured on, or ascertained by, a line; linear; as, lineal magnitude.

entry.def: The quality of being lineal.
In a lineal manner; as, the prince is lineally descended from the Conqueror.

entry.ety: L. lineamentum, fr. linea line: cf. F. linéament. See 3d Line
entry.def: One of the outlines, exterior features, or distinctive marks, of a body or figure, particularly of the face; feature; form; mark; -- usually in the plural.
entry.q: Thelineamentsof the body.
Lineamentsin the character.
Man he seems In all his lineaments.

cs.cd: an equation which is of the first degree, when the expression which is equated to zero is regarded as a function of the dependent variable and its differential coefficients.
an equation of the first degree between two variables; -- so called because every such equation may be considered as representing a right line.
the measurement of length.
such numbers as have relation to length only: such is a number which represents one side of a plane figure. If the plane figure is square, the linear figure is called a root.
a problem which may be solved geometrically by the use of right lines alone.
a change of variables where each variable is replaced by a function of the first degree in the new variable.

entry.ety: L. linearis linearius, fr. linea line: cf. F. linéaire. See 3d Line

sn.def: Of or pertaining to a line; consisting of lines; in a straight direction; lineal.
Like a line; narrow; of the same breadth throughout, except at the extremities; as, a linear leaf.
Thinking in a step-by-step analytical and logical fashion; contrasted with holistic, i.e. thinking in terms of complex interrelated patterns; as, linear thinkers.

q.au: David Morris (Conference presentation, Fairfield University, October 31, 1997)

sn.q: Linear thinkers concluded that by taking the world apart, the actions of people were more predictable and controllable.

entry.def: Having the form of a sword, but very long and narrow.
In a linear manner; with lines.
Of a linear shape.
Linear.

entry.ety: L. lineatus, p. p. of lineare to reduce to a straight line, fr. linea line

sn.def: Marked with lines.
Marked longitudinally with depressed parallel lines; as, a lineate leaf.

entry.ety: L. lineatio the drawing of a line, fr. lineare
entry.def: Delineation; a line or lines.
Anything having an outline.
a print obtained from a line drawing.

sn.def: a block that has been etched or engraved.

entry.note: Often used in hyphenated form, prefixed by the item arranged in a line; as, tree-lined streets.

sn.def: furnished with items in a line or as if in a line.
having visible lines; -- used especially of skin; as, their lined faces were immeasurably sad. Contrasted to smooth.
having a lining or a liner; often used in combination; as, a lined skirt; a silk-lined jacket. Opposite of unlined.

entry.def: resembling a line; long, thin, and narrow.

entries.entry:
Line"man līn"măn n.; pl.Linemen līn"mĕn.
One who carries the line in surveying, etc.; the surveyor who marks positions with a range pole.
A man employed to examine the rails of a railroad to see if they are in good condition; also, a man employed to install or repair telegraph, telephone, television cable, or power lines. Also called linesman.
Football A player whose position is in the first (forward) line, as opposed to a back; one who plays on the line of scrimmage. specifically: a center, guard, or tackle.
A ladies' man who is especially adept at inventing effective introductory phrases (pick-up lines) to gain a woman's attention. Colloq
the position of a player on a football team who is stationed on the line of scrimmage. wns=4

linemen n. pl.
lineman . the football players who line up on the line of scrimmage. WN hypen is odd for this def.

entry.ety: OE., fr. lin linen. See Linen n.

sn.def: Made of linen; as, linen cloth; a linen stocking.
Resembling linen cloth; white; pale.

cs.cd: a dealer in linen.
a small microscope for counting the threads in a given space in linen fabrics.
an ornament for filling panels, copied from the folds of a piece of stuff symmetrically disposed.

entry.ety: Prop. an adj. from OE. lin flax, AS. līn flax, whence līnen made of flax; akin to OS., Icel., & MHG. līn flax and linen, G. lein leinen, linen, Sw. lin flax, Goth. lein linen, L. linum flax, linen, Gr. li`non. Cf. Line Linseed

sn.def: Thread or cloth made of flax or (rarely) of hemp; -- used in a general sense to include cambric, shirting, sheeting, towels, tablecloths, etc.; as, bed linens
sn.q: Inlinenwhite as milk.

sn.def: Underclothing, esp. the shirt, as being, in former times, chiefly made of linen.

entry.def: A dealer in linen; a linen draper.

entry.ety: L. lineola, dim. of linea line

sn.def: Marked with little lines.
Marked longitudinally with fine lines.
One who lines, as, a liner of shoes or clothing.
An airplane or ship belonging to a transportation company;
a line-of-battle ship; a ship of the line.
A thin piece placed between two parts to hold or adjust them, fill a space, etc.; a shim.
A lining2}.
A lining within the cylinder, in which the piston works and between which and the outer shell of the cylinder a space is left to form a steam jacket.
A slab on which small pieces of marble, tile, etc., are fastened for grinding.
A ball which, when struck, flies through the air in a nearly straight line not far from the ground; also called line drive; as, he hit a sharp liner to right.
A protective envelope for a phonograph record or other object.
A lining; as, a removable coat liner .
Same as eyeliner.

entry.def: a very boastful and talkative person.

sn.def: the official (in tennis or soccer) who watches the lines.
a person who installs or repairs electrical or telephone lines.
The members of a team who are scheduled to play a game.
The formation of football players before the start or a restart of play.
a list of batters in the order in which they will bat.
any arrangement of persons (rarely, of things), esp. when having a common purpose or sentiment; as, the line-up at a ticket-office window; the line-up of political factions.

A group of persons including a suspect in a police investigation, arranged so as to be observed by a witness, who is requested to identify the perpetrator, if he/she is present in the group. Such an identification may be used as evidence of guilt of the suspect. Also called a police lineup.

entry.ety: AS. -ling
entry.def: A noun suffix, commonly having a diminutive or a depreciatory force; as in duckling, gosling, hireling, fosterling, firstling, underling.

entries.entry: -ling. An adverbial suffix; as, darkling, flatling .

entry.ety: OE. lenge; akin to D. leng, G. länge, Dan. lange, Sw. långa, Icel. langa. So named from its being long. See Long a.
entry.def: A large, marine, gadoid fish (Molva vulgaris) of Northern Europe and Greenland. It is valued as a food fish and is largely salted and dried. Called also drizzle.
The burbot of Lake Ontario.
An American hake of the genus Phycis.
A New Zealand food fish of the genus Genypterus. The name is also locally applied to other fishes, as the cultus cod, the mutton fish, and the cobia.

cs.cd: a sort of wild honey, made from the flowers of the heather.

entry.ety: Icel. lyng; akin to Dan. lyng, Sw. ljung
entry.def: Heather (Calluna vulgaris).

entry.ety: Skr. liṅga
entry.def: The phallic symbol under which Siva is principally worshiped in his character of the creative and reproductive power.
The European meadow pipit; -- called also titling.

sn.def: The flesh of a lean-fleshed fish caught off the U.S. Pacific coast.
A food fish (Ophiodon elongatus) of Northern Pacific waters related to greenlings.

entry.ety: F. ligneul, dim. of L. linea a linen thread

sn.def: A shoemaker's thread.
A little tongue or thong of leather; a lacing for belts.

entry.def: low evergreen shrub (Vaccinium vitis-idaea) of high north temperate regions of Europe and Asia and America bearing red edible berries.
entry.syn: cowberry, mountain cranberry, lingonberry, lingberry, foxberry, Vaccinium vitis-idaea.

entry.ety: L. lingere to lick
entry.def: A linctus.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Lingered lĭṉ"gẽrd; p. pr. & vb. n. Lingering
entry.ety: OE. lengen to tarry, AS. lengan to prolong, put off, fr. lang long. √125. See Long a.
entry.def: To delay; to loiter; to remain or wait long; to be slow or reluctant in parting or moving; to be slow in deciding; to be in suspense; to hesitate.
entry.q: Nor cast one longing, lingering look behind.
Perhaps thou linger'st, in deep thoughts detained.
entry.syn: To loiter; lag; saunter; delay; tarry; stop; hesitate.

sn.def: To protract; to draw out.
sn.q: She lingers my desires.

sn.def: To spend or pass in a lingering manner; -- with out; as, to linger out one's days on a sick bed.

entry.def: One who lingers.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: Linen goods collectively; linen underwear or nightclothes, esp. of women; the clothing of linen and cotton with its lace, etc., worn by a women.

sn.def: Delaying.
Drawn out in time; remaining long; protracted; as, a lingering disease.
sn.q: To die is the fate of man; but to die with lingering anguish is generally his folly.

entry.def: With delay; slowly; tediously.

entry.ety: F. lingot, perh. fr. L. lingua tongue (see Tongue). Cf. Ingot
entry.def: An ingot.
A mode of treating certain diseases, as obesity, by gymnastics; -- proposed by Pehr Henrik Ling , a Swede. See Kinesiatrics.
See Lingel.

entry.ety: L. lingua tongue, language. See Lingual
entry.def: Language; speech; dialect.
Amboyna wood.
A linget or ingot; also, a mold for casting metals. See Linget.

entries.entry: ‖Lin"gua lĭṉ"gwȧ n.; pl.Linguæ lĭṉ"gwē. L., the tongue Zoöl A tongue. A median process of the labium, at the under side of the mouth in insects, and serving as a tongue.

entry.ety: L. linguax -acis, loquacious, fr. lingua tongue
entry.def: Given to the use of the tongue; loquacious.

entry.ety: L. lingua tongue + E. dental
entry.def: Formed or uttered by the joint use of the tongue and teeth, or rather that part of the gum just above the front teeth; dentolingual, as the letters d and t.
An articulation pronounced by the aid or use of the tongue and teeth.

entry.ety: It., prop., language of the Franks

sn.def: The commercial language of the Levant, -- a mixture of the languages of the people of the region and of foreign traders.
Any hybrid or other language used over a wide area as a common or commercial tongue among peoples of different speech.

entry.cs: Lingual ribbon. Zoöl See Odontophore.
entry.ety: L. lingua tongue: cf. F. lingual. See Tongue, and cf. Language

sn.def: Of or pertaining to the tongue; uttered by the aid of the tongue; glossal; as, the lingual nerves; a lingual letter.

lying near the tongue; especially, in dentistry, on the surface of the tooth next to the tongue. Contrasted with buccal, the side of a tooth touching the cheek, i. e. the side opposite to the lingual side.

entry.note: ☞ In Sanskrit grammar certain letters, as ṭ ṭh ḍ ḍh ṇ, are called linguals, cerebrals, or cacuminals. They are uttered with the tip of the tongue turned up and drawn back into the dome of the palate.
entry.def: A consonant sound formed by the aid of the tongue; -- a term especially applied to certain articulations (as those of t d th, and n) and to the letters denoting them.
The quality of being lingual.

entry.ety: NL., fr. L. lingua tongue
entry.def: Same as Linguatulina.

entry.note: ☞ The adults of some species inhabit the nostrils and nasal sinuses of dogs and other carnivores. The young, after being swallowed by sheep, rabbits, etc., find their way to the lungs and liver and become encysted. These, when eaten by carnivores, develop into the adult forms.
entry.ety: NL., fr. L. lingua tongue
entry.def: An order of wormlike, degraded, parasitic arachnids. They have two pairs of retractile hooks, near the mouth. Called also Pentastomida.
Linguadental.

entry.ety: L. lingua tongue + -form: cf. F. linguiforme
entry.def: Having the form of the tongue; tongue-shaped.

entry.ety: L. lingua tongue, speech, language: cf. F. linguiste

sn.def: A master of the use of language; a talker.
sn.q: I'll dispute with him; He's a rare linguist.

sn.def: A person skilled in languages.
sn.q: There too were Gibbon, the greatest historian, and Jones, the greatest linguist, of the age.

entry.ety: Cf. F. linguistique.
entry.def: Of or pertaining to language; relating to linguistics, or to the affinities of languages.
In a linguistic manner; from the point of view of a linguist.

entry.ety: Cf. F. linguistique
entry.def: The science of languages, or of the origin, signification, and application of words; glossology.

entries.entry:
‖Lin"gu*la
Lingula flags Geol a group of strata in the lower Silurian or Cambrian system of Wales, in which some of the layers contain vast numbers of a species of Lingula.
lĭṉ"g�*lȧ n.; pl.-læ lĭṉ"g�*lē. L., a little tongue
Anat A tonguelike process or part.
Zoöl Any one of numerous species of brachiopod shells belonging to the genus Lingula, and related genera. See Brachiopoda, and Illustration in Appendix.

entry.ety: L. lingulatus, fr. lingula a little tongue. Cf. Ligulate
entry.def: Shaped like the tongue or a strap; ligulate.

entry.ety: L. linum flax + -gerous
entry.def: Bearing flax; producing linen.

entry.ety: L. linimentum, fr. linire linere, to besmear, anoint : cf. F. liniment. Cf. Letter Lime a viscous substance
entry.def: A liquid or semiliquid preparation of a consistence thinner than an ointment, applied to the skin by friction, esp. one used as a sedative or a stimulant.

entry.ety: See Line to cover the in side

sn.def: The act of one who lines; the act or process of making lines, or of inserting a lining.
That which covers the inner surface of anything, as of a garment or a box; also, the contents of anything.
sn.q: The lining of his coffers shall make coats To deck our soldiers.

entry.ety: Prob. corrupted from lint and this for lunt a torch, match, D. lont match; akin to G. lunte, cf. MHG. lünden to burn. Cf. Lunt Linstock
entry.def: A torch made of tow and pitch, or the like.

entry.ety: OE. linke, AS. hlence; akin to Sw. länk ring of a chain, Dan. lænke chain, Icel. hlekkr; cf. G. gelenk joint, link, ring of a chain, lenken to bend

sn.def: A single ring or division of a chain.
Hence: Anything, whether material or not, which binds together, or connects, separate things; a part of a connected series; a tie; a bond.
sn.q: Linksof iron.
The link of brotherhood, by which One common Maker bound me to the kind.
And so by double links enchained themselves in lover's life.

sn.def: Anything doubled and closed like a link; as, a link of horsehair.
Any one of the several elementary pieces of a mechanism, as the fixed frame, or a rod, wheel, mass of confined liquid, etc., by which relative motion of other parts is produced and constrained.

Any intermediate rod or piece for transmitting force or motion, especially a short connecting rod with a bearing at each end; specifically Steam Engine, the slotted bar, or connecting piece, to the opposite ends of which the eccentric rods are jointed, and by means of which the movement of the valve is varied, in a link motion.
The length of one joint of Gunter's chain, being the hundredth part of it, or 7.92 inches, the chain being 66 feet in length. Cf. Chain n., 4.
A bond of affinity, or a unit of valence between atoms; -- applied to a unit of chemical force or attraction.
Sausages; -- because linked together.

entry.ety: See Linch

sn.def: A hill or ridge, as a sand hill, or a wooded or turfy bank between cultivated fields, etc.
A winding of a river; also, the ground along such a winding; a meander; -- usually in pl.
sn.q: The windings or “links” of the Forth above and below Stirling are extremely tortuous.

sn.def: Sand hills with the surrounding level or undulating land, such as occur along the seashore, a river bank, etc.
sn.q: Golf may be played on any park or common, but its original home is the “links” or common land which is found by the seashore, where the short close tuft, the sandy subsoil, and the many natural obstacles in the shape of bents, whins, sand holes, and banks, supply the conditions which are essential to the proper pursuit of the game.

sn.def: Hence, any such piece of ground where golf is played; a golf course.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Linked lĭṉkt; p. pr. & vb. n. Linking
entry.def: To connect or unite with a link or as with a link; to join; to attach; to unite; to couple.
entry.q: All the tribes and nations that composed it [the Roman Empire] were linked together, not only by the same laws and the same government, but by all the facilities of commodious intercourse, and of frequent communication.

entry.def: To be connected.
entry.q: No one generation could link with the other.

sn.def: The act of linking; the state of being linked; also, a system of links.
Manner of linking or of being linked; -- said of the union of atoms or radicals in the molecule.
A system of straight lines or bars, fastened together by joints, and having certain of their points fixed in a plane. It is used to describe straight lines and curves in the plane.
Any object, factor, or relationship that creates a bond or association between two other objects.

The proximity of two or more genes on the genome of an organism that causes those genes to be inherited, transferred, or moved together with a frequency greater than for genes not associated. The linkage is a continuous variable, and is inversely related to the distance between genes on the genome.
Associated.
Exhibiting linkage5}.
Having a connection.

entry.ety: See 1st Link
entry.def: A boy or man that carried a link or torch to light passengers.

entry.note: ☞ The illustration shows a link motion for a vertical engine, c representing the shaft carrying two eccentrics, a and b, for making the engine run forward and backward, respectively, their rods e and d being jointed to opposite ends of the slotted link f, in the opening of which is a pin g which is attached to the valve rod h. The valve will receive the motion of the forward eccentric when the link is in the position shown, and the motion of the backward eccentric when the link is shifted so far to the right as to bring e in line with h, or a compound motion derived from both eccentrics when the link is shifted to intermediate positions, the compound motion causing the valve to cut off the steam at a point determined by the position to which the link may have been shifted.
entry.def: A valve gear, consisting of two eccentrics with their rods, giving motion to a slide valve by an adjustable connecting bar, called the link, in such a way that the motion of the engine can be reversed, or the cut-off varied, at will; -- used very generally in locomotives and marine engines.

entry.ety: The pl. form of Link, but often construed as a singular
entry.def: A tract of ground laid out for the game of golf; a golfing green.
entry.q: A second links has recently been opened at Prestwick, and another at Troon, on the same coast.

entry.def: something that serves to join or link.

sn.def: A fabric consisting of links made of metal or other material fastened together; also, a chain.
sn.q: And thou shalt make hooks of gold, and two chains of fine gold; linkwork and wreathed.

sn.def: Mechanism in which links, or intermediate connecting pieces, are employed to transmit motion from one part to another.

entry.def: A genus with only one species, the twinflower.

Carolus Linnaeus, also called Karl von Linné. Born at Råshult, Småland, Sweden, May 13, 1707: died at Upsala, Sweden, Jan. 10, 1778. A celebrated Swedish botanist and naturalist, founder of the Linnean system in botany. He made a journey to Lapland in 1732; resided in the Netherlands 1735-38; and became professor of medicine (later of botany) at Upsala in 1741. Among his works are “Systema naturæ” (1735), “Fundamenta botanica” (1736), “Genera plantarum” (1737), “Flora lapponica” (1737), “Philosophia botanica” (1751), and “Species plantarum” (1753).

entry.ety: NL. Linnaeus Linnæan + L. borealis northern
entry.def: The twin flower which grows in cold northern climates.

cs.cd: the system in which the classes of plants are founded mainly upon the number of stamens, and the orders upon the pistils; the artificial or sexual system.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to Linnæus, the celebrated Swedish botanist.

entry.ety: See Linnæan
entry.def: A mineral of pale steel-gray color and metallic luster, occurring in isometric crystals, and also massive. It is a sulphide of cobalt containing some nickel or copper.
Flax. See Linen.

cs.cd: the European green finch.

entry.ety: F. linot linotte, from L. linum flax; or perh. shortened from AS. līnetwige, fr. AS. līn flax; -- so called because it feeds on the seeds of flax and hemp. See Linen
entry.def: Any one of several species of fringilline birds of the genera Linota Acanthis, and allied genera, esp. the common European species (Linota cannabina), which, in full summer plumage, is chestnut brown above, with the breast more or less crimson. The feathers of its head are grayish brown, tipped with crimson. Called also gray linnet red linnet rose linnet brown linnet lintie lintwhite gorse thatcher linnet finch, and greater redpoll. The American redpoll linnet (Acanthis linaria) often has the crown and throat rosy. See Redpoll, and Twite.
A salt of linoleic acid.

Pertaining to, or derived from, linoleum, or linseed oil; specifically Chem, designating an organic acid, a thin yellow oil, found combined as a salt of glycerin in oils of linseed, poppy, hemp, and certain nuts.

entry.ety: L. linum flax + oleum oil

sn.def: Linseed oil brought to various degrees of hardness by some oxidizing process, as by exposure to heated air, or by treatment with chloride of sulphur. In this condition it is used for many of the purposes to which India rubber has been applied.
A kind of floor cloth made by laying hardened linseed oil mixed with ground cork on a canvas backing.

entry.ety: See Line; Type
entry.def: A kind of typesetting machine which produces castings, each of which corresponds to a line of separate types. By pressing the keys of a keyboard like one on a typewriter, the matrices for one line are properly arranged; the entire line, or stereotype, or slug, is then cast and planed, and the matrices are returned to their proper places, the whole process being automatic.
The slug produced by the machine, or matter composed in such lines.

entry.ety: Linoleic + oxygen
entry.def: A resinous substance obtained as an oxidation product of linoleic acid.

Any viverrine mammal of the genus Prionodon, inhabiting the East Indies and Southern Asia. The common East Indian linsang (Prionodon gracilis) is white, crossed by broad, black bands. The Guinea linsang (Porana Richardsonii) is brown with black spots.

cs.cd: the solid mass or cake which remains when oil is expressed from flaxseed.
linseed cake reduced to powder.
oil obtained by pressure from flaxseed.

entry.ety: OE. lin flax + seed. See Linen
entry.def: The seeds of flax, from which linseed oil is obtained.

entry.ety: See Linen
entry.def: Linsey-woolsey.

sn.def: Cloth made of linen and wool, mixed.
Jargon.

entry.def: Made of linen and wool; hence, of different and unsuitable parts; mean.

entry.ety: Corrupt. fr. luntstock, D. lontstok; lont lunt + stok stock, stick. See Link a torch, Lunt, and Stock
entry.def: A pointed forked staff, shod with iron at the foot, to hold a lighted match for firing cannon.

cs.cd: a scraper to remove lint from a printing cylinder.

entry.ety: AS. līnet flax, hemp, fr. līn flax; or, perh. borrowed fr. L. linteum a linen cloth, linen, from linteus linen, a., fr. linum flax, lint. See Linen

sn.def: Flax.
Linen scraped or otherwise made into a soft, downy or fleecy substance for dressing wounds and sores; also, fine ravelings, down, fluff, or loose short fibers from yarn or fabrics.

entry.ety: OF. lintel, F. linteau, LL. lintellus, for limitellus, a dim. fr. L. limes limit. See Limit
entry.def: A horizontal member spanning an opening, and carrying the superincumbent weight by means of its strength in resisting crosswise fracture.

entry.ety: AS. līnetwige. See Linnet
entry.def: See Linnet.
See Linseed.

entry.ety: L., flax
entry.def: A genus of herbaceous plants including the flax (Linum usitatissimum).

cs.cd: the puma or cougar.
the ant-lion.
a fancy dog with a flowing mane, usually clipped to resemble a lion's mane.
the basilisk.
all, or nearly all; the best or largest part; -- from Æsop's fable of the lion hunting in company with certain smaller beasts, and appropriating to himself all the prey.

a famous sculptured lion at Lucerne, Switzerland, designed by Thorwaldsen and dedicated in 1821 as a memorial to the Swiss Guards who fell defending Louis XVI. in the attack of the mob on the Tuileries, Aug. 10, 1792. The animal, which is hewn out of the face of a rock, is represented as transfixed with a broken spear and dying, but still trying to protect with its paw a shield bearing the fleur-de-lis of France.

a winged lion, the emblem of the evangelist Mark, especially that of bronze surmounting a granite column in the Piazzetta at Venice, and holding in its fore paws an open book representing St. Mark's Gospel.
Gustavus Adolphus (1594-1632), King of Sweden, the hero of the Protestant faith in the Thirty Years' War.

entry.ety: F. lion, L. leo -onis, akin to Gr. le`wn. Cf. Chameleon Dandelion Leopard

sn.def: A large carnivorous feline mammal (Panthera leo, formerly Felis leo), found in Southern Asia and in most parts of Africa, distinct varieties occurring in the different countries. The adult male, in most varieties, has a thick mane of long shaggy hair that adds to his apparent size, which is less than that of the largest tigers. The length, however, is sometimes eleven feet to the base of the tail. The color is a tawny yellow or yellowish brown; the mane is darker, and the terminal tuft of the tail is black. In one variety, called the maneless lion, the male has only a slight mane.
A sign and a constellation; Leo.
An object of interest and curiosity, especially a person who is so regarded; as, he was quite a lion in London at that time.
sn.q: Such society was far more enjoyable than that of Edinburgh, for here he was not a lion, but a man.

entry.def: Adorned with lions' heads; having arms terminating in lions' heads; -- said of a cross.

entry.ety: OF., F. lionceau, dim. of lion
entry.def: A small lion, especially one of several borne in the same coat of arms.

entry.ety: OF., dim. of lion
entry.def: The whelp of a lioness; a young lion.

entry.ety: OF. lionesse
entry.def: A female lion.

entry.ety: OF., dim. of lion
entry.def: A young or small lion.
A very brave person.
Very brave; brave and magnanimous.
State of being a lion.

sn.def: someone who tries to attract social lions as guests.
someone who hunts lions.

entry.def: An attracting of attention, as a lion; also, the treating or regarding as a lion.

sn.def: To treat or regard as a lion or object of great interest.
To show the lions or objects of interest to; to conduct about among objects of interest.

entry.def: Like a lion; brave as a lion.
Like a lion; fierce.
A name given in Western South America to certain plants with shaggy tomentose leaves, as species of Culcitium, and Espeletia.
A composite plant of the genus Prenanthes, of which several species are found in the United States.
The edelweiss.
The state of being a lion.
A South European plant of the genus Leontice Leontice leontopetalum), the tuberous roots of which contain so much alkali that they are sometimes used as a substitute for soap.
A genus of labiate plants (Leonurus); -- so called from a fancied resemblance of its flower spikes to the tuft of a lion's tail. Leonurus Cardiaca is the common motherwort.

entries.entry: Li"on's tooth` lī"ŭnz t�th`; pl.Lions' teeth lī"ŭnz tēth`. Bot See Leontodon.

entry.cs: Lip bit a pod auger. See Auger. Lip comfort comfort that is given with words only. Lip comforter one who comforts with words only. Lip labor unfelt or insincere speech; hypocrisy. Bale. Lip reading the catching of the words or meaning of one speaking by watching the motion of his lips without hearing his voice. Carpenter. Lip salve a salve for sore lips. Lip service expression by the lips of obedience and devotion without the performance of acts suitable to such sentiments. Lip wisdom wise talk without practice, or unsupported by experience. Lip work. Talk. Kissing. Humorous B. Jonson. To make a lip to drop the under lip in sullenness or contempt. Shak. To shoot out the lip Script to show contempt by protruding the lip.
entry.ety: OE. lippe, AS. lippa; akin to D. lip, G. lippe lefze, OHG. lefs, Dan. læbe, Sw. läpp, L. labium labrum. Cf. Labial

sn.def: One of the two fleshy folds which surround the orifice of the mouth in man and many other animals. In man the lips are organs of speech essential to certain articulations. Hence, by a figure they denote the mouth, or all the organs of speech, and sometimes speech itself.
sn.q: Thine own lips testify against thee.

sn.def: An edge of an opening; a thin projecting part of anything; a kind of short open spout; as, the lip of a vessel.
The sharp cutting edge on the end of an auger.

sn.sd: One of the two opposite divisions of a labiate corolla.bThe odd and peculiar petal in the Orchis family. See Orchidaceous.

sn.def: One of the edges of the aperture of a univalve shell.
Impudent or abusive talk; as, don't give me any of your lip .

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Lipped lĭpt; p. pr. & vb. n. Lipping -pĭng

sn.def: To touch with the lips; to put the lips to; hence, to kiss.
sn.q: The bubble on the wine which breaks Before you lip the glass.
A hand that kings Have lipped and trembled kissing.

sn.def: To utter; to speak.

entry.def: To clip; to trim.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. li`pos fat + a"i^ma blood
entry.def: A condition in which fat occurs in the blood.

entries.entry: Li*pans" l�*pänz" n. pl.; sing. Lipan l�*pän". Ethnol A tribe of North American Indians, inhabiting the northern part of Mexico. They belong to the Tinneh stock, and are closely related to the Apaches.

entry.def: Any species of a family (Liparidæ) of destructive bombycid moths, as the tussock moths.
A natural family including the snailfishes.
an orchid of the genus Liparis having few leaves and usually fairly small yellow-green or dull purple flowers in terminal racemes.

sn.def: The type genus of the Liparididae, consisting of certain of the snailfishes.

entry.ety: So called from Lipari, the island
entry.def: A quartzose trachyte; rhyolite.

entry.ety: Gr. li`pos fat + 'ai^ma blood
entry.def: The presence of an abnormally high concentration of lipid in the blood. Called also hyperlipemia hyperlipidemia hyperlipoidemia lipidemia lipoidemia.
any of various terrestrial ferns of the genus Cheilanthes; they are cosmopolitan in arid and semi-arid temperate or tropical regions.

entry.ety: Gr. li`pos fat
entry.def: Pertaining to, or derived from, fat. The word was formerly used specifically to designate a supposed acid obtained by the oxidation of oleic acid, tallow, wax, etc.

entry.ety: Gr. li`pos fat
entry.def: Any of a variety of oily or greasy organic compounds found as major structural components of living cells; they are insoluble in water but soluble in organic solvents such as alcohol and ether, and include the common fats cholesterol and other steroids, phospholipids sphingolipids waxes, and fatty acids; some of the lipids, together with proteins and carbohydrates, form an essential structural component of living cells, as in the cell walls and membranes. The term lipid refers to its solubility in nonpolar solvents, and has no significance with regard to chemical structure.
Same as lipid.
Same as lipemia.

Serving to reduce the concentration of lipid, such as cholesterol, in the blood; -- of medications, such as Mevinolin, that are used especially to reduce blood cholesterol, as a preventive measure against heart disease.
A disorder of lipid metabolism, whether congenital or acquired.
Lipic.
Having no lips.
A little lip.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. lei`pesqai to be lacking + kefalh` head
entry.def: Same as Lamellibranchia.

entry.ety: Gr. li`pos fat + chro`a color
entry.def: A yellow coloring matter, soluble in ether, contained in the small round fat drops in the retinal epithelium cells. It is best obtained from the eyes of frogs.

entry.ety: Gr. lei`pein lipei^n, to leave, omit + -gram
entry.def: A writing composed of words not having a certain letter or letters; -- as in the Odyssey of Tryphiodorus there was no A in the first book, no B in the second, and so on.

entry.ety: Gr. lipogra`mmatos: cf. F. lipogrammatique
entry.def: Omitting a letter; composed of words not having a certain letter or letters; as, lipogrammatic writings.

entry.ety: Cf. F. lipogrammatiste
entry.def: One who makes a lipogram.
Same as lipemia.

entry.ety: NL., from Gr. li`pos fat + -oma

having an affinity for lipids; -- of chemical substances or parts of molecules. Contrasted to lipophobic or polar.
Not soluble in lipids, or in non-polar solvents; -- of chemical substances or parts of molecules; as, the lipophobic end of a detergent is solvated in water. Contrasted to lipophilic or nonpolar.

entry.ety: Gr. leipoqymiko`s lipoqymiko`s

having an affinity for lipids.

entry.ety: L. liquefactio: cf. F. liquéfaction. See Liquefy

sn.def: The act or operation of making or becoming liquid; especially, the conversion of a solid into a liquid by the sole agency of heat.
The state of being liquid.
The act, process, or method, of reducing a gas or vapor to a liquid by means of cold or pressure; as, the liquefaction of oxygen or hydrogen.

entry.ety: Cf. F. liquéfiable. See Liquefy
entry.def: Capable of being changed from a solid to a liquid state.

entry.sn: converted to a liquid; as, liquified natural gas; liquified coal.. liquified.

sn.def: rendered liquid by heating; changed from a solid to a liquid state; melted.
rendered liquid by dissolution in a solvent; -- of solids.

entry.def: That which liquefies.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Liquefied -fīd; p. pr. & vb. n. Liquefying -fī`ĭng
entry.ety: F. liquéfier, L. liquere to be liquid + facere -ficarein comp.), to make. See Liquid, and -fy

sn.def: To convert from a solid form to that of a liquid; to melt; to dissolve; and technically, to melt by the sole agency of heat.
To convert from a gaseous form into a liquid; as, to liquefy natural gas.

entry.note: Liquid substances may form a definite interface with gases, whereas the molecules of different gases freely intermingle with each other.

entry.ety: L. liquidus, fr. liquere to be fluid or liquid; cf. Skr. rī to ooze, drop, lī to melt

sn.def: Flowing freely like water; fluid; not solid.
sn.q: Yea, though he go upon the plane and liquid water which will receive no step.

sn.def: Being in such a state that the component molecules move freely among themselves, but have a definite volume changing only slightly with changes of pressure, and do not tend to separate from each other as the particles of gases and vapors do when the volume of the container is increased; neither solid nor gaseous; as, liquid mercury, in distinction from mercury solidified or in a state of vapor.
Flowing or sounding smoothly or without abrupt transitions or harsh tones.
sn.q: Liquidmelody.

sn.def: Pronounced without any jar or harshness; smooth; as, l and r are liquid letters.
Fluid and transparent; as, the liquid air.
Clear; definite in terms or amount.
sn.q: Though the debt should be entirelyliquid.

sn.def: In cash or readily convertible into cash without loss of principle; -- said of assets, such as bank accounts, or short-term bonds tradable on a major stock exchange.

entry.note: ☞ Liquid and fluid are terms often used synonymously, but fluid has the broader signification. All liquids are fluids, but many fluids, as air and the gases, are not liquids.

cs.cd: a measure, or system of measuring, for liquids, by the gallon, quart, pint, gill, etc.

sn.def: A substance whose parts change their relative position on the slightest pressure, and therefore retain no definite form; any substance in the state of liquidity; a fluid that is not gaseous and has a definite volume independent, of the container in which it is held. Liquids have a fixed volume at any given pressure, but their shape is determined by the container in which it is contained. Liquids, in contrast to gases, cannot expand indefinitely to fill an expanding container, and are only slightly compressible by application of pressure.
A letter which has a smooth, flowing sound, or which flows smoothly after a mute; as, l and r, in bla bra . M and n also are called liquids.

entries.entry: Liq"uid air. Physics A transparent limpid liquid, slightly blue in color, consisting of a mixture of liquefied oxygen and nitrogen. It is prepared by subjecting air to great pressure and then cooling it by its own expansion to a temperature below the boiling point of its constituents (N: -194° C; O: -183° C.).

entry.ety: Liquid + amber

sn.def: A genus consisting of two species of tall trees having star-shaped leaves, and woody burlike fruit. Liquidambar styraciflua is the North American sweet qum, and Liquidambar Orientalis is found in Asia Minor.
The balsamic juice which is obtained from these trees by incision. The liquid balsam of the Oriental tree is liquid storax.

entry.def: See Liquidambar.

cs.cd: damages the amount of which is fixed or ascertained.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Liquidated -dā`tĕd; p. pr. & vb. n. Liquidating
entry.ety: LL. liquidatus, p. p. of liquidare to liquidate, fr. L. liquidus liquid, clear. See Liquid

sn.def: To determine by agreement or by litigation the precise amount of (indebtedness); or, where there is an indebtedness to more than one person, to determine the precise amount of (each indebtedness); to make the amount of (an indebtedness) clear and certain.
sn.q: A debt or demand is liquidated whenever the amount due is agreed on by the parties, or fixed by the operation of law.
If our epistolary accounts were fairly liquidated, I believe you would be brought in considerable debtor.

sn.def: In an extended sense: To ascertain the amount, or the several amounts, of, and apply assets toward the discharge of (an indebtedness).
To discharge; to pay off or settle, as an indebtedness.
sn.q: Friburg was ceded to Zurich by Sigismund to liquidate a debt of a thousand florins.

sn.def: To make clear and intelligible.
sn.q: Time only can liquidate the meaning of all parts of a compound system.

sn.def: To make liquid.

To kill; -- used mostly of governments or organizations killing their enemies; as, Stalin liquidated many of the Kulaks.
To dissolve (an organization); to terminate (an activity).

cs.cd: to turn over to a trustee one's assets and accounts, in order that the several amounts of one's indebtedness may be authoritatively ascertained, and that the assets may be applied toward their discharge.

entry.ety: Cf. F. liquidation

An Italian coin equivalent in value to the French franc.

entry.ety: NL., dim. of L. lira a furrow
entry.def: A linear apothecium furrowed along the middle; the fruit of certain lichens.

entry.ety: Lirella + -form
entry.def: Like a lirella.

entries.entry: ‖Lir`i*o*den"dron lĭr`ĭ*�*dĕn"drŏn n.; pl.Liriodendra -drȧ. NL., fr. Gr. lei`rion lily + de`ndron tree Bot A genus of large and very beautiful trees of North America, having smooth, shining leaves, and handsome, tuliplike flowers; tulip tree; whitewood; -- called also canoewood. Liriodendron tulipifera is the only extant species, but there were several others in the Cretaceous epoch.

Acuteness; smartness; also, a smart trick or stratagem.

a fine handmade lace, made at Lisle.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Lisped lĭspt; p. pr. & vb. n. Lisping
entry.ety: OE. lispen lipsen, AS. wlisp stammering, lisping; akin to D. & OHG. lispen to lisp, G. lispeln, Sw. läspa, Dan. lespe

sn.def: To pronounce the sibilant letter s imperfectly; to give s and z the sound of th; -- a defect common among children.
To speak with imperfect articulation; to mispronounce, as a child learning to talk.
sn.q: As yet a child, nor yet a fool to fame, I lisped in numbers, for the numbers came.

sn.def: To speak hesitatingly with a low voice, as if afraid.
sn.q: Lest when my lisping, guilty tongue should halt.

sn.def: To pronounce with a lisp.
To utter with imperfect articulation; to express with words pronounced imperfectly or indistinctly, as a child speaks; hence, to express by the use of simple, childlike language.
sn.q: To speak unto them after their own capacity, and to lisp the words unto them according as the babes and children of that age might sound them again.

sn.def: To speak with reserve or concealment; to utter timidly or confidentially; as, to lisp treason.

entry.def: The habit or act of lisping. See Lisp v. i., 1.
entry.q: I overheard her answer, with a very pretty lisp, “O! Strephon, you are a dangerous creature.”

entry.ety: List Processing
entry.def: a high-level computer programming language in which statements and data are in the form of lists, enclosed in parentheses; -- used especially for rapid development of prototype programs in artificial intelligence applications .

With a lisp; in a lisping manner.

entry.ety: AS. liss

entry.q: Of penance had alisse.

entry.ety: AS. lissan

entry.q: Lissedof his care.

entry.ety: See Listen

sn.def: To desire or choose; to please.
sn.q: The wind bloweth where it listeth.
Them that add to the Word of God what them listeth.
Let other men think of your devices as they list.

An inclination to one side; as, the ship has a list to starboard.

entry.cs: Civil list Great Britain & U.S.), the civil officers of government, as judges, ambassadors, secretaries, etc. Hence, the revenues or appropriations of public money for the support of the civil officers. More recently, the civil list, in England, embraces only the expenses of the reigning monarch's household. Free list. A list of articles admitted to a country free of duty. A list of persons admitted to any entertainment, as a theater or opera, without payment, or to whom a periodical, or the like, is furnished without cost.
entry.usage: List Roll Catalogue Register Inventory Schedule. A list is properly a simple series of names, etc., in a brief form, such as might naturally be entered in a narrow strip of paper. A roll was originally a list containing the names of persons belonging to a public body (as Parliament, etc.), which was rolled up and laid aside among its archives. A catalogue is a list of persons or things arranged in order, and usually containing some description of the same, more or less extended. A register is designed for record or preservation. An inventory is a list of articles, found on hand in a store of goods, or in the estate of a deceased person, or under similar circumstances. A schedule is a formal list or inventory prepared for legal or business purposes.
entry.ety: AS. līst a list of cloth; akin to D. lijst, G. leiste, OHG. līsta, Icel. lista listi, Sw. list, Dan. liste. In sense 5 from F. liste, of German origin, and thus ultimately the same word

sn.def: A strip forming the woven border or selvedge of cloth, particularly of broadcloth, and serving to strengthen it; hence, a strip of cloth; a fillet.
sn.q: Gartered with a red and bluelist.

sn.def: A limit or boundary; a border.
sn.q: The very list, the very utmost bound, Of all our fortunes.

A stripe.
A roll or catalogue, that is, row or line; a record of names; as, a list of names, books, articles; a list of ratable estate.
sn.q: He was the ablest emperor of all the list.

sn.def: A little square molding; a fillet; -- called also listel.
A narrow strip of wood, esp. sapwood, cut from the edge of a plank or board.
A piece of woolen cloth with which the yarns are grasped by a workman.

sd.def: The first thin coat of tin.
A wirelike rim of tin left on an edge of the plate after it is coated.

sn.def: To sew together, as strips of cloth, so as to make a show of colors, or form a border.

cs.cd: to take an interest in.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Listened lĭs"'nd; p. pr. & vb. n. Listening
entry.ety: OE. listnen listen lustnen lusten, AS. hlystan; akin to hlyst hearing, OS. hlust, Icel. hlusta to listen, hlust ear, AS. hlosnian to wait in suspense, OHG. hlosēn to listen, Gr. kly`ein, and E. loud. √41. See Loud, and cf. List to listen

sn.def: To give close attention with the purpose of hearing; to give ear; to hearken; to attend.
sn.q: When we have occasion to listen, and give a more particular attention to some sound, the tympanum is drawn to a more than ordinary tension.

sn.def: To give heed; to yield to advice; to follow admonition; to obey.
sn.q: Listen to me, and by me be ruled.
Soldiers note forts, armories, and magazines; scholars listen after libraries, disputations, and professors.

entry.def: To attend to.
One who listens; a hearkener.
the act of hearing attentively.
One who makes a list or roll.
Same as Leister.

entry.ety: Cf. List a strip, border, prob. applied to the furrow or the ridge of earth along the furrow
entry.def: A double-moldboard plow which throws a deep furrow, and at the same time plants and covers grain in the bottom of the furrow.
Of or pertaining to listerism.
The systematic use of antiseptics in the performance of operations and the treatment of wounds; -- so called from Joseph Lister , an English surgeon.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Listerized lĭs"tẽr*īzd; p. pr. & vb. n. Listerizing lĭs"tẽr*īz*ĭng
entry.def: To make antiseptic.
Attentive.

sn.def: The act or process of one who lists (in any sense of the verb); as, the listing of a door; the listing of a stock at the Stock Exchange.
The selvedge of cloth; list.
The sapwood cut from the edge of a board.
