The throwing up of the soil into ridges, -- a method adopted in the culture of beets and some garden crops.

entry.ety: OE. listles lustles. See Lust
entry.def: Having no desire or inclination; indifferent; heedless; spiritless.
entry.q: Alistlessunconcern.
Benumbed with cold, and listless of their gain.
I was listless, and desponding.
entry.syn: Heedless; careless; indifferent; vacant; uninterested; languid; spiritless; supine; indolent.

entry.def: a form of the imp. & p. p. of Light.

entries.entry: Lit"a*ny lĭt"ȧ*n� n.; pl.Litanies lĭt"ȧ*nĭz. OE. letanie, OF. letanie, F. litanie, L. litania, Gr. litanei`a, fr. litaney`ein to pray, akin to li`tesqai li`ssesqai, to pray, lith` prayer A solemn form of supplication in the public worship of various churches, in which the clergy and congregation join, the former leading and the latter responding in alternate sentences. It is usually of a penitential character. Supplications . . . for the appeasing of God's wrath were of the Greek church termed litanies, and rogations of the Latin.

entry.def: Litharge.

The fruit of a tree native to China (Nephelium Litchi). It is nutlike, having a rough but tender shell, containing an aromatic pulp, and a single large seed. In the dried fruit which is exported the pulp somewhat resembles a raisin in color and form.

sn.def: A genus of East Indian sapindaceous trees consisting of a single species (Litchi Chinensis, syn. Nephelium Litchi) which bears the litchi nut.

entry.def: See -lith.
Little.

entry.ety: F. litre, Gr. li`tra a silver coin
entry.def: A measure of capacity in the metric system, being a cubic decimeter, equal to 61.022 cubic inches, or 2.113 American pints, or 1.76 English pints.
State of being literate.

cs.cd: a contract of which the whole evidence is given in writing.
an equation in which known quantities are expressed either wholly or in part by means of letters; -- distinguished from a numerical equation.

entry.ety: F. litéral littéral, L. litteralis literalis, fr. littera litera, a letter. See Letter

sn.def: According to the letter or verbal expression; real; not figurative or metaphorical; as, the literal meaning of a phrase.
sn.q: It hath but one simple literal sense whose light the owls can not abide.

sn.def: Following the letter or exact words; not free.
sn.q: A middle course between the rigor of literal translations and the liberty of paraphrasts.

sn.def: Consisting of, or expressed by, letters.
sn.q: The literal notation of numbers was known to Europeans before the ciphers.

sn.def: Giving a strict or literal construction; unimaginative; matter-of-fact; -- applied to persons.

entry.def: Literal meaning.

sn.def: That which accords with the letter; a mode of interpreting literally; adherence to the letter.
The tendency or disposition to represent objects faithfully, without abstraction, conventionalities, or idealization.

entry.def: One who adheres to the letter or exact word; an interpreter according to the letter.

entry.ety: Cf. F. littéralité
entry.def: The state or quality of being literal.
The act of literalizing; reduction to a literal meaning.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Literalized lĭt"ẽr*�l*īzd; p. pr. & vb. n. Literalizing lĭt"ẽr*�l*ī*zĭng
entry.def: To make literal; to interpret or put in practice according to the strict meaning of the words; -- opposed to spiritualize; as, to literalize Scripture.
A literalist.

sn.def: According to the primary and natural import of words; not figuratively; as, a man and his wife can not be literally one flesh.
With close adherence to words; word by word.
sn.q: So wild and ungovernable a poet can not be translated literally.

entry.def: The quality or state of being literal; literal import.

entry.cs: Literary property. Property which consists in written or printed compositions. The exclusive right of publication as recognized and limited by law.
entry.ety: L. litterarius literarius, fr. littera litera, a letter: cf. F. littéraire. See Letter

sn.def: Of or pertaining to letters or literature; pertaining to learning or learned men; as, literary fame; a literary history; literary conversation.
sn.q: He has long outlived his century, the term commonly fixed as the test of literary merit.

sn.def: Versed in, or acquainted with, literature; occupied with literature as a profession; connected with literature or with men of letters; as, a literary man.
sn.q: In the literary as well as fashionable world.

entry.ety: L. litteratus literatus. See Letter
entry.def: Instructed in learning, science, or literature; learned; lettered.
entry.q: The literate now chose their emperor, as the military chose theirs.

sn.def: One educated, but not having taken a university degree; especially, such a person who is prepared to take holy orders.
A literary man.

entry.ety: See Literatus
entry.def: Learned or literary men. See Literatus.
entry.q: Shakespearean commentators, and other literati.

entry.ety: LL., fr. L. littera litera, letter
entry.def: Letter for letter.

entry.ety: L. littera litera, letter
entry.def: The act or process of representing by letters.

entry.ety: L. litterator literator. See Letter

sn.def: One who teaches the letters or elements of knowledge; a petty schoolmaster.
A person devoted to the study of literary trifles, esp. trifles belonging to the literature of a former age.
sn.q: That class of subjects which are interesting to the regular literator or black-letter “ bibliomane,” simply because they have once been interesting.

sn.def: A learned person; a literatus.

entry.usage: See Science.Literature Learning Erudition. Literature, in its widest sense, embraces all compositions in writing or print which preserve the results of observation, thought, or fancy; but those upon the positive sciences (mathematics, etc.) are usually excluded. It is often confined, however, to belles-lettres, or works of taste and sentiment, as poetry, eloquence, history, etc., excluding abstract discussions and mere erudition. A man of literaturein this narrowest sense) is one who is versed in belles-lettres; a man of learning excels in what is taught in the schools, and has a wide extent of knowledge, especially, in respect to the past; a man of erudition is one who is skilled in the more recondite branches of learned inquiry.
entry.ety: F. littérature, L. litteratura literatura, learning, grammar, writing, fr. littera litera, letter. See Letter

sn.def: Learning; acquaintance with letters or books.

The collective body of literary productions, embracing the entire results of knowledge and fancy preserved in writing; also, the whole body of literary productions or writings upon a given subject, or in reference to a particular science or branch of knowledge, or of a given country or period; as, the literature of Biblical criticism; the literature of chemistry.

The class of writings distinguished for beauty of style or expression, as poetry, essays, or history, in distinction from scientific treatises and works which contain positive knowledge; belles-lettres.
The occupation, profession, or business of doing literary work.
sn.q: The origin of all positive science and philosophy, as well as of all literature and art, in the forms in which they exist in civilized Europe, must be traced to the Greeks.
Learning thy talent is, but mine is sense.
Some gentlemen, abounding in their university erudition, fill their sermons with philosophical terms.

entries.entry:
‖Lit`e*ra"tus lĭt`�*rä"tŭs; lĭt`�*rā"tŭs n.; pl.Literati lĭt`�*rä"tē; lĭt`�*rā"tī. L. litteratus literatus
A learned man; a man acquainted with literature; -- chiefly used in the plural. Now we are to consider that our bright ideal of a literatus may chance to be maimed.

entry.def: Combining forms fr. Gr. li`qos a stone; -- used chiefly in naming minerals and rocks.
3d pers. sing. pres. of Lie, to recline, for lieth.

entry.ety: AS. lið
entry.def: A joint or limb; a division; a member; a part formed by growth, and articulated to, or symmetrical with, other parts.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. li`qos stone + a"i^ma blood
entry.def: A condition in which uric (lithic) acid is present in the blood.

entry.ety: Gr. li`qos stone + 'agwgo`s leading
entry.def: A medicine having, or supposed to have, the power of expelling calculous matter with the urine.

entry.ety: OE. litarge, F. litharge, L. lithargyrus, Gr. liqa`rgyros the scum or foam of silver; li`qos stone + 'a`rgyros silver. Litharge is found in silverbearing lead ore
entry.def: Lead monoxide; a yellowish red substance, obtained as an amorphous powder, or crystallized in fine scales, by heating lead moderately in a current of air or by calcining lead nitrate or carbonate. It is used in making flint glass, in glazing earthenware, in making red lead or minium, etc. Called also massicot.

entry.ety: NL. See Litharge
entry.def: Crystallized litharge, obtained by fusion in the form of fine yellow scales.
A salt of lithic or uric acid; a urate.

entry.ety: Icel hlȳða. See Listen
entry.def: To listen or listen to; to hearken to.

entry.ety: AS. līðe, for linðe tender, mild, gentle; akin to G. lind gelind, OHG. lindi, Icel. linr, L. lenis soft, mild, lentus flexible, and AS. linnan to yield. Cf. Lenient

sn.def: Mild; calm; as, lithe weather.
Capable of being easily bent; pliant; flexible; limber; as, the elephant's lithe proboscis.

entry.ety: AS. līðian. See Lithe a.
entry.def: To smooth; to soften; to palliate.
In a lithe, pliant, or flexible manner.
The quality or state of being lithe; flexibility; limberness.

entry.note: ☞ Professor Skeat thinks “ the lither sky” as found in Shakespeare's Henry VI. ((Part I. IV. VII., 21) means the stagnant or pestilential sky.
entry.ety: AS. lȳðer bad, wicked
entry.def: Bad; wicked; false; worthless; slothful.
entry.q: Not lither in business, fervent in spirit.

entry.def: Crafty; cunning; mischievous; wicked; treacherous; lazy.
entry.q: He [the dwarf] was waspish, arch, and litherly.

entry.ety: See Lithe a., and cf. Lissom
entry.def: Pliant; limber; flexible; supple; nimble; lissom.

entry.cs: Lithia emerald. See Hiddenite.
entry.ety: NL., from Gr. li`qos stone
entry.def: The oxide of lithium; a strong alkaline caustic similar to potash and soda, but weaker. See Lithium.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. liqi`asis, fr. li`qos stone
entry.def: The formation of stony concretions or calculi in any part of the body, especially in the bladder and urinary passages.

cs.cd: uric acid. See Uric acid, under Uric.

entry.ety: Gr. liqiko`s of or belonging to stones, fr. li`qos stone: cf. F. lithique

sn.def: Of or pertaining to stone; as, lithic architecture.
Pertaining to the formation of uric-acid concretions (stone) in the bladder and other parts of the body; as, lithic diathesis.

entry.def: A medicine which tends to prevent stone in the bladder.

entry.ety: From Lithium
entry.def: Pertaining to or denoting lithium or some of its compounds.

entry.ety: Lithium + Gr. fi`los friend
entry.def: A phosphate of manganese and lithium; a variety of triphylite.

entry.note: ☞ When isolated it is a soft, silver white metal, tarnishing and oxidizing very rapidly in the air. It is the lightest solid element known, specific gravity being 0.59. Symbol Li. Atomic weight 7.0 So called from having been discovered in a mineral.
entry.ety: NL., from Gr. li`qeios of stone, fr. li`qos stone
entry.def: A metallic element of the alkaline group, occurring in several minerals, as petalite, spodumene, lepidolite, triphylite, etc., and otherwise widely disseminated, though in small quantities.
A combining form from Gr. li`qos stone.

entry.ety: Litho + bile
entry.def: Pertaining to or designating an organic acid of the tartaric acid series, distinct from lithofellic acid, but, like it, obtained from certain bile products, as bezoar stones.

entry.ety: Litho- + Gr. karpo`s fruit: cf. F. lithocarpe
entry.def: Fossil fruit; a fruit petrified; a carpolite.
See Lithochromics.

entry.ety: Litho- + Gr. chrw^ma color
entry.def: The art of printing colored pictures on canvas from oil paintings on stone.

entry.ety: Litho- + Gr. kla^n to break
entry.def: An instrument for crushing stones in the bladder.

entry.ety: Litho- + cyst
entry.def: A sac containing small, calcareous concretions (otoliths). They are found in many Medusæ, and other invertebrates, and are supposed to be auditory organs.

entry.ety: Litho- + Gr. do`mos house: cf. F. lithodome
entry.def: Any one of several species of bivalves, which form holes in limestone, in which they live; esp., any species of the genus Lithodomus.
Like, or pertaining to, Lithodomus; lithophagous.

entry.note: ☞ These holes are at first very small and shallow, but are enlarged with the growth of the shell, sometimes becoming two or three inches deep and nearly an inch diameter.
entry.ety: NL. See Lithodome
entry.def: A genus of elongated bivalve shells, allied to the mussels, and remarkable for their ability to bore holes for shelter, in solid limestone, shells, etc. Called also Lithophagus.

entry.ety: Litho- + L. fel fellis, gall
entry.def: Pertaining to, or designating, a crystalline, organic acid, resembling cholic acid, found in the biliary intestinal concretions (bezoar stones) common in certain species of antelope.

entry.ety: F., fr. li`qos stone + L. frangere fractum, to break
entry.def: An explosive compound of nitroglycerin. See Nitroglycerin.

entry.ety: Litho- Gr. ge`nesis origin, generation: cf. F. lithogénésie. See Genesis
entry.def: The doctrine or science of the origin of the minerals composing the globe.

entry.ety: Litho- + -genous
entry.def: Stone-producing; -- said of polyps which form coral.

entry.ety: Gr. liqoglyfi`a; li`qos stone + gly`fein to engrave
entry.def: An engraving on a gem.
One who curs or engraves precious stones.
Of or pertaining to the art of cutting and engraving precious stones.
The art of cutting and engraving gems.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. lithographed; p. pr. & vb. n. lithographing
entry.ety: litho- + -graph: cf. F. lithographier
entry.def: To trace on stone by the process of lithography so as to transfer the design to paper by printing; as, to lithograph a design; to lithograph a painting. See lithography.
A print made by lithography.
One who lithographs; one who practices lithography.

cs.cd: a compact, fine-grained limestone, obtained largely from the Lias and Oölite, esp. of Bavaria, and extensively used in lithography.

entry.ety: Cf. F. lithographique
entry.def: Of or pertaining to lithography; made by lithography; as, the lithographic art; a lithographic picture.

entry.ety: Cf. F. lithographie

sn.def: The art or process of putting designs or writing, with a greasy material, on stone, and of producing printed impressions therefrom. The process depends, in the main, upon the antipathy between grease and water, which prevents a printing ink containing oil from adhering to wetted parts of the stone not covered by the design. See Lithographic limestone, under Lithographic.
a printing process for reproducing images, using any flat surface, such as a metal plate, in a manner similar to lithography{1.

The process of producing patterns on semiconductor crystals by exposing photosensitive coatings on a matrix, such as silicon, to light patterns in the form desired for the circuit, and subsequently treating (e.g., chemically) the patterns thus formed in such a way as to create integrated semiconductor circuits with the desired properties. This is the principle method (1990's) to create the high-density integrated circuits used in the digital computers on which you are reading this.

entry.ety: Litho- + -oid: cf. F. lithoïde
entry.def: Like a stone; having a stony structure.

entry.ety: Litho- + Gr. � worship
entry.def: The worship of a stone or stones.

entry.ety: Cf. F. lithologique

sn.def: Of or pertaining to the character of a rock, as derived from the nature and mode of aggregation of its mineral contents.
Of or pertaining to lithology.

entry.def: From a lithological point of view; as, to consider a stratum lithologically .
One who is skilled in lithology.

entry.ety: Litho- + -logy: cf. F. lithologie

sn.def: The science which treats of rocks, as regards their mineral constitution and classification, and their mode of occurrence in nature.
A treatise on stones found in the body.

entry.ety: Litho- + -mancy: cf. F. lithomancie
entry.def: Divination by means of stones.

entry.ety: Litho- + L. marga marl
entry.def: A clay of a fine smooth texture, and very sectile.

entry.ety: Litho- + Gr. � to crush
entry.def: Same as Lithontriptic.

entry.ety: Gr. li`qos, acc. �, a stone + � to rub, grind: cf. F. lithontriptique
entry.def: Having the quality of, or used for, dissolving or destroying stone in the bladder or kidneys; as, lithontriptic forcéps.

def2.def: A lithontriptic remedy or agent, as distilled water.

entry.def: Same as Lithotriptist.
See Lithotriptor.

entry.ety: Litho- + Gr. � to eat
entry.def: Eating or swallowing stones or gravel, as the ostrich.
Eating or destroying stone; -- applied to various animals which make burrows in stone, as many bivalve mollusks, certain sponges, annelids, and sea urchins. See Lithodomus.

entry.ety: Litho- + Gr. fai`nein to show, reveal
entry.def: Porcelain impressed with figures which are made distinct by transmitted light, as in a lamp shade or when hung in a window.

entry.ety: Litho- + phosphor
entry.def: A stone that becomes phosphoric by heat.
Pertaining to lithophosphor; becoming phosphoric by heat.

entry.ety: Litho- + photography
entry.def: Same as Photolithography.

entry.ety: Gr. li`qos a stone + � a leaf: cf. F. lithophylle
entry.def: A fossil leaf or impression of a leaf.

entry.ety: Litho- + Gr. � a flatus, air bubble
entry.def: A spherulitic cavity often with concentric chambers, observed in some volcanic rocks, as in rhyolitic lavas. It is supposed to be produced by expanding gas, whence the name.

entry.ety: Litho- + Gr. � plant: cf. F. lithophyte
entry.def: A hard, or stony, plantlike organism, as the gorgonians, corals, and corallines, esp. those gorgonians having a calcareous axis. All the lithophytes except the corallines are animals.
Of or pertaining to lithophytes.
Lithophytic.

entry.ety: From NL. Lithosia, the typical genus, fr. Gr. li`qos a stone, a rock
entry.def: Any one of various species of moths belonging to the family Lithosidæ. Many of them are beautifully colored.

entry.ety: Litho- + sphere
entry.def: The solid earth as distinguished from its fluid envelopes, the hydrosphere and atmosphere.

The outer part of the solid earth, the portion undergoing change through the gradual transfer of material by volcanic eruption, the circulation of underground water, and the process of erosion and deposition. It is, therefore, regarded as a third mobile envelope comparable with the hydrosphere and atmosphere.

entry.ety: Litho- + tint

sn.def: A kind of lithography by which the effect of a tinted drawing is produced, as if made with India ink.
A picture produced by this process.

entry.ety: Gr. � cutting stones; li`qos stone + � to cut: cf. F. lithotome

sn.def: A stone so formed by nature as to appear as if cut by art.
An instrument used for cutting the bladder in operations for the stone.

entry.ety: Gr. li`qos stone cutting: cf. F. lithotomique
entry.def: Pertaining to, or performed by, lithotomy.

entry.ety: Cf. F. lithotomiste
entry.def: One who performs the operation of cutting for stone in the bladder, or one who is skilled in the operation.

entry.ety: L. lithotomia, Gr. �: cf. F. lithotomie
entry.def: The operation, art, or practice of cutting for stone in the bladder.

entry.ety: Litho- + Gr. tri`bein to rub, grind: cf. F. lithotripsie
entry.def: The operation of crushing a stone in the bladder or urethra to reduce it to particles small enough to be voided; lithotrity. It may be performed with an instrument called lithotriptor or lithotritealso called a lithoclast); or, more recently, may be accomplished by devices using ultrasonic waves to fragment the stones.
Same as Lithontriptic.
One skilled in breaking and extracting stone in the bladder.
An instrument for triturating the stone in the bladder; a lithotrite.

entry.ety: See Lithotrity
entry.def: A lithotriptor.
A lithotriptist.

entry.ety: Litho- + L. terere tritum, to rub, grind
entry.def: The operation of breaking a stone in the bladder or urethrea into small pieces capable of being voided; lithotripsy.

sn.def: An etched stone surface for printing, having the design in relief; also, the process of printing from such a surface, or that which is printed from it.
A machine, with a keyboard like that of a typewriter, for making a lithographic transfer sheet. It produces a perforated strip of paper which controls the printing.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Lithotyped; p. pr. & vb. n. Lithotyping
entry.def: To prepare for printing with plates made by the process of lithotypy. See Lithotypy.
Of, pertaining to, or produced by, lithotypy.

entry.ety: Litho- + -typy
entry.def: The art or process of making a kind of hard, stereotype plate, by pressing into a mold, taken from a page of type or other matter, a composition of gum shellac and sand of a fine quality, together with a little tar and linseed oil, all in a heated state.

entry.ety: Written also lithoxyle
Litho- + Gr. � wood: cf. F. lithoxyle
entry.def: Petrified wood.
Of or pertaining to Lithuania (formerly a principality united with Poland, then part of the Soviet Union, but since 1992 an independent nation).
A native, or one of the people, of Lithuania; also, the language of the Lithuanian people.

cs.cd: a European shrub (Viburnum Lantana); -- so named from its tough and flexible stem.

entry.ety: See Lithe
entry.def: Easily bent; pliable.
Such as can be litigated.

entry.ety: L. litigans -antis, p. pr. of litigare: cf. F. litigant. See Litigate
entry.def: Disposed to litigate; contending in law; engaged in a lawsuit; as, the parties litigant .
A person engaged in a lawsuit.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Litigated; p. pr. & vb. n. Litigating
entry.ety: See Litigation
entry.def: To make the subject of a lawsuit; to contest in law; to prosecute or defend by pleadings, exhibition of evidence, and judicial debate in a court; as, to litigate a cause.
To carry on a suit by judicial process.

entry.ety: L. litigatio, fr. litigare to dispute, litigate; lis litis, dispute, lawsuit (OL. stlis) + agere to carry on. See Agent
entry.def: The act or process of litigating; a suit at law; a judicial contest.

sn.def: of or pertaining to litigation.
prone to initiate litigation.
same as contentious.
sn.syn: litigatious, litiginous, contentious, disputatious; quarrelsome; argumentative.

entry.ety: L
entry.def: One who litigates.
same as litigatious.

entry.ety: L. litigiosus, fr. litigium dispute, quarrel, fr. litigare: cf. F. litigieux. See Litigation

sn.def: Inclined to initiate lawsuits; given to the practice of contending in law; fond of litigation.
sn.q: A pettifogging attorney or alitigiousclient.
Soldiers find wars, and lawyers find out stillLitigious men, who quarrels move.

sn.def: Quarrelsome; contentious; argumentative.
Subject to contention; disputable; controvertible; debatable; doubtful; precarious.
sn.q: No fences, parted fields, nor marks, nor bounds, Distinguished acres of litigious grounds.

sn.def: Of or pertaining to legal disputes.
sn.q: Nor brothers cite to the litigious bar.

entry.def: In a litigious manner.
The state of being litigious; disposition to engage in or carry on lawsuits.

entry.note: ☞ Litmus is used as a dye, and being turned red by acids and restored to its blue color by alkalies, is a common indicator or test for acidity and alkalinity.

cs.cd: unsized paper saturated with blue or red litmus, -- used in testing for acids or alkalies.

entry.ety: D. lakmoes; lak lacker + moes a thick preparation of fruit, pap, prob. akin to E. meat: cf. G. lackmus. See Lac a resinous substance
entry.def: A dyestuff extracted from certain lichens (Roccella tinctoria Lecanora tartarea, etc.), as a blue amorphous mass which consists of a compound of the alkaline carbonates with certain coloring matters related to orcin and orcein.

sn.def: A test to determine acidity or alkalinity, using litmus as an inddicator.
A test for a single factor, which has only two outcomes, positive or negative;

the question of whether a candidate for office is for or against a particular position on an issue; -- used, e.g. by voters concerned predominantly with a single issue, to decide whether to vote for or against a candidate; as, many voters take a candidate's position on abortion as their litmus test .

entry.def: A genus of East African antelopes including the gerenuks.
See Littoral.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. lito`ths, from lito`s plain, simple
entry.def: A diminution or softening of statement for the sake of avoiding censure or increasing the effect by contrast with the moderation shown in the form of expression; a form of understatement; as, “ a citizen of no mean city,” that is, of an illustrious city; or, “not bad”, meaning “good”.

entry.ety: Gr. li`tra + -meter. See Liter
entry.def: An instrument for ascertaining the specific gravity of liquids.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: Same as Liter.

entry.ety: F. litière, LL. lectaria, fr. L. lectus couch, bed. See Lie to be prostrated, and cf. Coverlet

sn.def: A bed or stretcher so arranged that a person, esp. a sick or wounded person, may be easily carried in or upon it.
sn.q: There is a litter ready; lay him in 't.

sn.def: Straw, hay, etc., scattered on a floor, as bedding for animals to rest on; also, a covering of straw for plants.
sn.q: To crouch in litter of your stable planks.
Take off the litter from your kernel beds.

sn.def: Things lying scattered about in a manner indicating slovenliness; scattered rubbish.
sn.q: Strephon, who found the room was void. Stole in, and took a strict survey Of all the litter as it lay.

sn.def: Disorder or untidiness resulting from scattered rubbish, or from thongs lying about uncared for; as, a room in a state of litter .
The young brought forth at one time, by a cat, dog, sow or other multiparous animal, taken collectively. Also Fig.
sn.q: A wolf came to a sow, and very kindly offered to take care of her litter.
Reflect upon that numerous litter of strange, senseless opinions that crawl about the world.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Littered lĭt"tẽrd; p. pr. & vb. n. Littering

sn.def: To supply with litter, as cattle; to cover with litter, as the floor of a stall.
sn.q: Tell them how they litter their jades.
For his ease, well littered was the floor.

sn.def: To put into a confused or disordered condition; to strew with scattered articles; as, to litter a room.
sn.q: The room with volumes littered round.

sn.def: To give birth to; to bear; -- said of brutes, esp. those which produce more than one at a birth, and also of human beings, in abhorrence or contempt.
sn.q: We might conceive that dogs were created blind, because we observe they were littered so with us.
The son that she did litter here, A freckled whelp hagborn.

sn.def: To be supplied with litter as bedding; to sleep or make one's bed in litter.
sn.q: The inn Where he and his horse littered.

sn.def: To produce a litter.
sn.q: A desert . . . where the she-wolf still littered.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: One who occupies himself with literature; a literary man; a literatus.
entry.q: Befriended by one kind-heartedlittérateurafter another.

entry.def: one who helps carry a stretcher.
a bin (usually in or outside a public building) into which the public can put rubbish.
a person who litters public places with refuse.
having articles scattered about in a disorderly fashion.

sn.def: a person who litters public places with refuse.

entry.def: One of two or more animals born into the same litter.
Covered or encumbered with litter; consisting of or constituting litter.

entry.cs:
Little chief. Zoöl See Chief hare. Little Englander an Englishman opposed to territorial expansion of the British Empire. See Antiimperialism, above. Hence: Little Englandism.Little finger the fourth and smallest finger of the hand. Little go Eng. Universities a public examination about the middle of the course, which is less strict and important than the final one; -- called also smalls. Cf. Great go, under Great. Thackeray. Little hours R. C. Ch the offices of prime, tierce, sext, and nones. Vespers and compline are sometimes included.
Little-neck clamorLittle neck
Zoöl the quahog, or round clam. Little ones young children.
entry.amorph: The regular comparative and superlative of this word, littler and littlest, are often used as comparatives of the sense small; but in the sense fewless, or, rarely, lesser is the proper comparative and least is the superlative. See Lesser. The regular form, littlest, occurs also in some of the English provinces, and occasionally in colloquial language. “ Where love is great, the littlest doubts are fear.” Shak.
entry.ety: OE. litel lutel, AS. lȳtel lītel lȳt; akin to OS. littil, D. luttel, LG. lütt, OHG. luzzil, MHG. lützel; and perh. to AS. lytig deceitful, lot deceit, Goth. liuts deceitful, lutōn to deceive; cf. also Icel. lītill little, Sw. liten, Dan. liden lille, Goth. leitils, which appear to have a different root vowel

sn.def: Small in size or extent; not big; diminutive; -- opposed to big or large; as, a little body; a little animal; a little piece of ground; a little hill; a little distance; a little child.
sn.q: He sought to see Jesus who he was; and could not for the press, because he was little of stature.

sn.def: Short in duration; brief; as, a little sleep.
sn.q: Best him enough: after a little time, I'll beat him too.

sn.def: Small in quantity or amount; not much; as, a little food; a little air or water.
sn.q: Conceited of their little wisdoms, and doting upon their own fancies.

sn.def: Small in dignity, power, or importance; not great; insignificant; contemptible.
sn.q: When thou wast little in thine own sight, wast thou not made the head of the tribes?

sn.def: Small in force or efficiency; not strong; weak; slight; inconsiderable; as, little attention or exertion;little effort; little care or diligence.
sn.q: By sad experiment I know How little weight my words with thee can find.

sn.def: Small in extent of views or sympathies; narrow; shallow; contracted; mean; illiberal; ungenerous.
sn.q: The long-necked geese of the world that are ever hissing dispraise, Because their natures are little.
The men, and the women, and the little ones.
sn.cd: a disease of peaches in which the fruit is much dwarfed, and the leaves grow small and thin. The cause is not known.
Rhode Island; -- a nickname alluding to its small size. It is the smallest State of the United States.
an order of women who care for old men and women and infirm poor, for whom special houses are built. It was established at St. Servan, Britany, France, in 1840, by the Abbé Le Pailleur.
the winning of 12 out of the 13 tricks. It counts 20 points on the honor score. Contrasted with grand slam.

sn.def: That which is little; a small quantity, amount, space, or the like.
sn.q: Much was in little writ.
There are many expressions, which carrying with them no clear ideas, are like to remove but little of my ignorance.

sn.def: A small degree or scale; miniature.
sn.q: His picture inlittle.
A little, to or in a small degree; to a limited extent; somewhat; for a short time. “ Stay a little.”
The painter flattered her a little.
sn.mcol: By little and littleorLittle by little
By little and littleorLittle by little

entry.def: In a small quantity or degree; not much; slightly; somewhat; -- often with a preceding it.
entry.q: The poor sleeplittle.

entry.def: An old slang name for the pillory, stocks, etc., of a prison.

sn.def: a quahog when young and small; frequently eaten raw.
a young quahog suitable to be eaten raw.

entry.def: The state or quality of being little; as, littleness of size, thought, duration, power, etc.
entry.syn: Smallness; slightness; inconsiderableness; narrowness; insignificance; meanness; penuriousness.

entry.ety: compar. of little
entry.def: small or little relative to something else.

entry.ety: superl. of little
entry.def: having or being distinguished by diminutive size.

entry.ety: L. littoralis litoralis, from littus litus, the seashore: cf. F. littoral

sn.def: Of or pertaining to a shore, as of the sea.
Inhabiting the seashore, esp. the zone between high-water and low-water mark.

entry.ety: NL. See Littoral
entry.def: A genus of small pectinibranch mollusks, having thick spiral shells, abundant between tides on nearly all rocky seacoasts. They feed on seaweeds. The common periwinkle is a well-known example. See Periwinkle.
A smooth kind of cartridge paper used for making cards.

entry.ety: See Lituus
entry.def: Forked, with the points slightly curved outward.

entry.ety: Lituus + -form
entry.def: Having the form of a lituus; like a lituite.

entry.ety: See Lituus
entry.def: Any species of ammonites of the genus Lituites. They are found in the Cretaceous formation.

entry.ety: L. lituratus, p. p. of liturare to erase, fr. litura a blur

sn.def: Having indistinct spots, paler at their margins.
Spotted, as if from abrasions of the surface.

entry.ety: Gr. �: cf. F. liturgique
entry.def: Pertaining to, of or the nature of, a liturgy; of or pertaining to public prayer and worship.
In the manner of a liturgy.
The science of worship; history, doctrine, and interpretation of liturgies.
One versed in liturgiology.

entry.ety: Liturgy + -logy
entry.def: The science treating of liturgical matters; a treatise on, or description of, liturgies.
One who favors or adheres strictly to a liturgy.

entries.entry:
Lit"ur*gy lĭt"ŭr*j� n.; pl.Liturgies lĭt"ŭr*jĭz. F. liturgie, LL. liturgia, Gr. leitoyrgi`a a public service, the public service of God, public worship; (assumedle`i:tos lei^tos, belonging to the people, public (fr. lao`s lew`s, the people) + the root of 'e`rgon work. See Lay a., and Work
An established formula for public worship, or the entire ritual for public worship in a church which uses prescribed forms; a formulary for public prayer or devotion. In the Roman Catholic Church it includes all forms and services in any language, in any part of the world, for the celebration of Mass.

‖Lit"u*us n.; pl.Litui #. L
Rom. Antig
A curved staff used by the augurs in quartering the heavens.
An instrument of martial music; a kind of trumpet of a somewhat curved form and shrill note.
Math A spiral whose polar equation is r2θ = a; that is, a curve the square of whose radius vector varies inversely as the angle which the radius vector makes with a given line.

sn.def: Such as can be lived.
Such as is pleasant to live in; fit or suitable to live in.
sn.q: A more delightful or livable region is not easily to be found.

entry.cs: To live out to be at service; to live away from home as a servant. U. S To live with. To dwell or to be a lodger with. To cohabit with; to have intercourse with, as male with female.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Lived lĭvd; p. pr. & vb. n. Living
entry.ety: OE. liven livien, AS. libban lifian; akin to OS. libbian, D. leven, G. leben, OHG. lebēn, Dan. leve, Sw. lefva, Icel. lifa to live, to be left, to remain, Goth. liban to live; akin to E. leave to forsake, and life, Gr. liparei^n to persist, liparo`s oily, shining, sleek, li`pos fat, lard, Skr. lip to anoint, smear; -- the first sense prob. was, to cleave to, stick to; hence, to remain, stay; and hence, to live.]

sn.def: To be alive; to have life; to have, as an animal or a plant, the capacity of assimilating matter as food, and to be dependent on such assimilation for a continuance of existence; as, animals and plants that live to a great age are long in reaching maturity.
sn.q: Thus saith the Lord God unto these bones; Behold, I will . . . lay sinews upon you, and will bring up flesh upon you, and cover you with skin, and put breath in you, and ye shall live.

sn.def: To pass one's time; to pass life or time in a certain manner, as to habits, conduct, or circumstances; as, to live in ease or affluence; to live happily or usefully.
sn.q: O death, how bitter is the remembrance of thee to a man that liveth at rest in his possessions!

sn.def: To make one's abiding place or home; to abide; to dwell; to reside; as, to live in a cottage by the sea.
sn.q: Jacob lived in the land of Egypt seventeen years.

sn.def: To be or continue in existence; to exist; to remain; to be permanent; to last; -- said of inanimate objects, ideas, etc.
sn.q: Men's evil manners live in brass; their virtues We write in water.

sn.def: To enjoy or make the most of life; to be in a state of happiness; as, people want not just to exist, but to live .
sn.q: What greater curse could envious fortune give Than just to die when I began to live?

sn.def: To feed; to subsist; to be nourished or supported; -- with on; as, horses live on grass and grain.
To have a spiritual existence; to be quickened, nourished, and actuated by divine influence or faith.
sn.q: The just shall live by faith.

sn.def: To be maintained in life; to acquire a livelihood; to subsist; -- with on or by; as, to live on spoils.
sn.q: Those who live by labor.

sn.def: To outlast danger; to float; -- said of a ship, boat, etc.; as, no ship could live in such a storm.
sn.q: A strong mast that lived upon the sea.

cs.cd: to live so as to subdue or refute; as, to live down slander.

sn.def: To spend, as one's life; to pass; to maintain; to continue in, constantly or habitually; as, to live an idle or a useful life.
To act habitually in conformity with; to practice.
sn.q: To live the Gospel.

entry.cs: Live birth the condition of being born in such a state that acts of life are manifested after the extrusion of the whole body. Dunglison. Live box a cell for holding living objects under microscopical examination. P. H. Gosse. Live feathers feathers which have been plucked from the living bird, and are therefore stronger and more elastic. Live gang. Sawing See under Gang. Live grass Bot a grass of the genus Eragrostis. Live load Engin a suddenly applied load; a varying load; a moving load; as a moving train of cars on a bridge, or wind pressure on a roof. Live oak Bot a species of oak (Quercus virens), growing in the Southern States, of great durability, and highly esteemed for ship timber. In California the Quercus chrysolepis and some other species are also called live oaks. Live ring Engin a circular train of rollers upon which a swing bridge, or turntable, rests, and which travels around a circular track when the bridge or table turns. Live steam , steam direct from the boiler, used for any purpose, in distinction from exhaust steam. Live stock horses, cattle, and other domestic animals kept on a farm. whole body. live wire Elec a wire connected to a power source, having a voltage potential; -- used esp. of a power line with a high potential relative to ground, capable of harming a person who touches it. Fig a person who is unusually active, alert, or aggressive.
entry.ety: Abbreviated from alive. See Alive Life

sn.def: Having life; alive; living; not dead.
sn.q: If one man's ox hurt another's, that he die; then they shall sell the live ox, and divide the money of it.

sn.def: Being in a state of ignition; burning; having active properties; as, a live coal; live embers.
sn.q: Theliveether.

sn.def: Full of earnestness; active; wide awake; glowing; as, a live man, or orator.
Vivid; bright.
sn.q: Thelivecarnation.

sn.def: Imparting power; having motion; as, the live spindle of a lathe; live steam.
Connected to a voltage source; as, a live wire.
Being transmitted instantaneously, as events occur, in contrast to recorded.
Still in active play; -- of a ball being used in a game; as, a live ball.
Pertaining to an entertainment event which was performed (and possibly recorded) in front of an audience; contrasted to performances recorded in a studio without an audience.

cs.cd: in life; alive.

entry.def: Life.
Same as livable; as, liveable conditions. Opposite of unlivable.
Any fish of the family Poeciliiidae, small usually brightly-colored viviparous surface-feeding fishes of fresh or brackish warm waters, often used in mosquito control.
Having life; -- used only in composition; as, long-lived; short-lived.
having residents; as, a house with a lived-in look.
A plant (Sedum Telephium) with fleshy leaves, which has extreme powers of resisting drought; garden ox-pine.
See Livelihood.

entry.ety: OE. livelode liflode, prop., course of life, life's support, maintenance, fr. AS. līf life + lād road, way, maintenance. Confused with livelihood liveliness. See Life, and Lode
entry.def: Subsistence or living, as dependent on some means of support; the means for support of life; maintenance.
entry.q: The opportunities of gaining an honest livelihood.
It is their profession and livelihood to get their living by practices for which they deserve to forfeit their lives.

entry.ety: Lively + -hood
entry.def: Liveliness; appearance of life.
In a lively manner.

entry.ety: From Lively

sn.def: The quality or state of being lively or animated; sprightliness; vivacity; animation; spirit; as, the liveliness of youth, contrasted with the gravity of age.
An appearance of life, animation, or spirit; as, the liveliness of the eye or the countenance in a portrait.
Briskness; activity; effervescence, as of liquors.
sn.syn: Sprightliness; gayety; animation; vivacity; smartness; briskness; activity.Liveliness Gayety Animation Vivacity. Liveliness is an habitual feeling of life and interest; gayety refers more to a temporary excitement of the animal spirits; animation implies a warmth of emotion and a corresponding vividness of expressing it, awakened by the presence of something which strongly affects the mind; vivacity is a feeling between liveliness and animation, having the permanency of the one, and, to some extent, the warmth of the other. Liveliness of imagination; gayety of heart; animation of countenance; vivacity of gesture or conversation.

entry.ety: See 1st Livelihood
entry.def: Course of life; means of support; livelihood.

entry.ety: For lifelong. Cf. Lifelong

sn.def: Whole; entire; long in passing; -- used of time, as day or night, in adverbial phrases, and usually with a sense of tediousness.
sn.q: The obscure bird Clamored the livelong night.
How could she sit the livelong day, Yet never ask us once to play?

sn.def: Lasting; durable.
sn.q: Thou hast built thyself a livelong monument.

cs.cd: saints, as being quickened by the Spirit, and active in holiness.

entry.ety: For lifely. Cf. Lifelike

sn.def: Endowed with or manifesting life; living.
sn.q: Chaplets of gold and silver resembling lively flowers and leaves.

sn.def: Brisk; vivacious; active; as, a lively youth.
sn.q: But wherefore comes old Manoa in such haste, With youthful steps ? Much livelier than erewhile He seems.

sn.def: Gay; airy; animated; spirited.
sn.q: From grave to gay, from lively to severe.

sn.def: Representing life; lifelike.
sn.q: I spied the lively picture of my father.

sn.def: Bright; vivid; glowing; strong; vigorous.
sn.q: The colors of the prism are manifestly more full, intense, and lively that those of natural bodies.
His faith must be not only living, but lively too.
sn.syn: Brisk; vigorous; quick; nimble; smart; active; alert; sprightly; animated; spirited; prompt; earnest; strong; energetic; vivid; vivacious; blithe; gleeful; airy; gay; jocund.

sn.def: In a brisk, active, or animated manner; briskly; vigorously.
With strong resemblance of life.
sn.q: Thou counterfeitest most lively.

entry.def: to make lively; -- sometimes used with up; as, to liven up the party with some music.
entry.syn: enliven, liven up, make lively, invigorate, animate.

entry.def: The quality of having animal life as distinguished from plant life.

cs.cd: one who lives in an extravagant and dissipated way.
one given to the pleasures of the table.
a person who lives a somewhat dissolute life.

sn.def: One who, or that which, lives.
sn.q: And try if life be worth the liver's care.

sn.def: A resident; a dweller; as, a liver in Brooklyn.
One whose course of life has some marked characteristic (expressed by an adjective); as, a free liver .

entry.note: ☞ Most of the venous blood from the alimentary canal passes through it on its way back to the heart; and it secretes the bile, produces glycogen, and in other ways changes the blood which passes through it. In man it is situated immediately beneath the diaphragm and mainly on the right side. See Bile Digestive, and Glycogen. The liver of invertebrate animals is usually made up of cæcal tubes, and differs materially, in form and function, from that of vertebrates.
entry.cs:
Floating liver. See Wandering liver, under Wandering.
Liver of antimony Liver of sulphur . Old Chem See Hepar.
Liver brown Liver color
the color of liver, a dark, reddish brown. Liver shark Zoöl a very large shark (Cetorhinus maximus), inhabiting the northern coasts both of Europe and North America. It sometimes becomes forty feet in length, being one of the largest sharks known; but it has small simple teeth, and is not dangerous. It is captured for the sake of its liver, which often yields several barrels of oil. It has gill rakers, resembling whalebone, by means of which it separates small animals from the sea water. Called also basking shark bone shark hoemother homer, and sailfish; it is sometimes referred to as whale shark, but that name is more commonly used for the Rhincodon typus, which grows even larger.Liver spots yellowish brown patches on the skin, or spots of chloasma.
entry.ety: AS. lifer; akin to D. liver, G. leber, OHG. lebara, Icel. lifr, Sw. lefver, and perh. to Gr. � fat, E. live, v
entry.def: A very large glandular and vascular organ in the visceral cavity of all vertebrates.
The glossy ibis (Ibis falcinellus); -- said to have given its name to the city of Liverpool.
Having a color like liver; dark reddish brown.
Having (such) a liver; used in composition; as, white-livered .
Having an enlarged liver.
Wearing a livery. See Livery, 3.
entry.q: The liveried servants wait.

entry.def: A kind of pudding or sausage made of liver or pork.
Same as Liverwort.

sn.def: of or pertaining to the inhabitants of Liverpool; as, Liverpudlian street urchins.
of or pertaining to Liverpool; as, Liverpudlian streets.

entry.def: A resident of Liverpool.

entry.note: ☞ From this plant many others of the same order (Hepaticæ) have been vaguely called liverworts, esp. those of the tribe Marchantiaceæ. See Illust. of Hepatica.

sn.def: A ranunculaceous plant (Anemone Hepatica) with pretty white or bluish flowers and a three-lobed leaf; -- called also squirrel cups.
A flowerless plant (Marchantia polymorpha), having an irregularly lobed, spreading, and forking frond.

entries.entry:
Liv"er*y ☞ It is usual to say, livery of seizin, which is a feudal investiture, made by the delivery of a turf, of a rod, a twig, or a key from the feoffor to the feoffee as a symbol of delivery of the whole property. There was a distinction of livery in deed when this ceremony was performed on the property being transferred, and livery in law when performed in sight of the property, but not on it. In the United States, and now in Great Britain, no such ceremony is necessary, the delivery of a deed being sufficient as a livery of seizin, regardless of where performed.
Livery gown the gown worn by a liveryman in London.
n.; pl.Liveries #. OE. livere, F. livrée, formerly, a gift of clothes made by the master to his servants, prop., a thing delivered, fr. livrer to deliver, L. liberare to set free, in LL., to deliver up. See Liberate
Eng. Law
The act of delivering possession of lands or tenements.
The writ by which possession is obtained. Black's 4th Ed.
Release from wardship; deliverance. It concerned them first to sue out their livery from the unjust wardship of his encroaching prerogative.
That which is delivered out statedly or formally, as clothing, food, etc.; especially: The uniform clothing issued by feudal superiors to their retainers and serving as a badge when in military service.
The peculiar dress by which the servants of a nobleman or gentleman are distinguished; as, a claret-colored livery .
Hence, also, the peculiar dress or garb appropriated by any association or body of persons to their own use; as, the livery of the London tradesmen, of a priest, of a charity school, etc.; also, the whole body or company of persons wearing such a garb, and entitled to the privileges of the association; as, the whole livery of London. A Haberdasher and a Carpenter, A Webbe, a Dyer, and a Tapicer, And they were clothed all in one livery Of a solempne and a gret fraternite. From the periodical deliveries of these characteristic articles of servile costume (blue coats) came our word livery.
Hence, any characteristic dress or outward appearance. April'slivery. Sir P. Sidney. Now came still evening on, and twilight gray Had in her sober livery all things clad.
An allowance of food statedly given out; a ration, as to a family, to servants, to horses, etc. The emperor's officers every night went through the town from house to house whereat any English gentleman did repast or lodge, and served their liveries for all night: first, the officers brought into the house a cast of fine manchet [white bread], and of silver two great pots, and white wine, and sugar.
The feeding, stabling, and care of horses for compensation; boarding; as, to keep one's horses at livery . What livery is, we by common use in England know well enough, namely, that is, allowance of horse meat, as to keep horses at livery, the which word, I guess, is derived of livering or delivering forth their nightly food. It need hardly be observed that the explanation of livery which Spenser offers is perfectly correct, but . . . it is no longer applied to the ration or stated portion of food delivered at stated periods.
The keeping of horses in readiness to be hired temporarily for riding or driving; the state of being so kept; also, the place where horses are so kept, also called a livery stable. Pegasus does not stand at livery even at the largest establishment in Moorfields.
A low grade of wool.

entry.def: To clothe in, or as in, livery.

entries.entry:
Liv"er*y*man n.; pl.Liverymen.
One who wears a livery, as a servant.
A freeman of the city, in London, who, having paid certain fees, is entitled to wear the distinguishing dress or livery of the company, guild, or district to which he belongs, and also to enjoy certain other privileges, as the right of voting in an election for the lord mayor, sheriffs, chamberlain, etc.
One who keeps a livery stable.

entry.def: A stable where horses are kept for hire, and where stabling is provided. See Livery n., 3 & .

entries.entry: Lives līvz n.; pl. of Life.

entry.ety: Orig. a genitive sing. of life
entry.def: Alive; living; with life.
entry.q: Anylivescreature.

entry.ety: L. lividus, from livere to be of a blush color, to be black and blue: cf. F. livide

sn.def: Black and blue; grayish blue; of a lead color; discolored, as flesh may be from a contusion.
sn.q: There followed no carbuncles, no purple or livid spots, the mass of the blood not being tainted.

sn.def: Extremely angry; enraged; infuriated.
Pallid; ashen; -- of the skin.

entry.ety: Cf. F. lividité
entry.def: The state or quality of being livid.
Lividity.

entry.cs:
Living force. See Vis viva, under Vis. Living gale Naut a heavy gale.
Living rockorLiving stone
rock in its native or original state or location; rock not quarried. “ I now found myself on a rude and narrow stairway, the steps of which were cut out of the living rock.” Moore. The living those who are alive, or one who is alive.
entry.ety: From Live v. i.

sn.def: Being alive; having life; as, a living creature. Opposed to dead.
Active; lively; vigorous; -- said esp. of states of the mind, and sometimes of abstract things; as, a living faith; a living principle.
sn.q: Livinghope.

sn.def: Issuing continually from the earth; running; flowing; as, a living spring; -- opposed to stagnant.
Producing life, action, animation, or vigor; quickening.
sn.q: Livinglight.

sn.def: Ignited; glowing with heat; burning; live.
sn.q: Then on the living coals wine they pour.

sn.def: The state of one who, or that which, lives; lives; life; existence.
sn.q: Health andliving.

sn.def: Manner of life; as, riotous living; penurious living; earnest living.
sn.q: A viciousliving.

sn.def: Means of subsistence; sustenance; estate; as, to make a comfortable living from writing.
sn.q: She can spin for her living.
He divided unto them his living.

sn.def: Power of continuing life; the act of living, or living comfortably.
sn.q: There is no living without trusting somebody or other in some cases.

sn.def: The benefice of a clergyman; an ecclesiastical charge which a minister receives.
sn.q: He could not get a deanery, a prebend, or even a living

entry.def: In a living state.
The state or quality of being alive; possession of energy or vigor; animation; quickening.

entries.entry: Liv"ing pic"ture. A tableau in which persons take part; also, specif., such a tableau as imitating a work of art.

liv"ing room`. A room in a house used by all or most of the family, where the family entertain guests or relax together for leisure activities. It usually contains at least one couch, and does not contain a dining table.
liv"ing wage". A wage or salary that permits a worker to live at least with minimal customary amenities, and above conditions of poverty.

liv"ing will. A document signed by an individual expressing his/her desire that, in the event of an illness from which there is no reasonable expectation of recovery, aggressive or extraordinary measures to prolong life, such as resuscitation and life-support equipment, should not be used.

entry.def: A genus of fan palms of Asia and Australia and Malaysia.
Of or pertaining to Livonia, a district on the Baltic Sea formerly part of Russia, now part of Latvia and Estonia.
A native or an inhabitant of Livonia; the language (allied to the Finnish) of the Livonians.

entry.ety: L
entry.def: Malignity.

entry.ety: F., fr. L. liberatio a setting free, in LL., a delivering up. See Liberation
entry.def: A part of a book or literary composition printed and delivered by itself; a number; a part.

entry.ety: F., fr. L. libra a pound of twelve ounces. Cf. Lira
entry.def: A French money of account, afterward a silver coin equal to 20 sous. It is not now in use, having been superseded by the franc.

cs.cd: salts which are obtained by passing water through ashes, or by pouring it on them.

entry.ety: L. lixivius, fr. lix ashes, lye ashes, lye: cf. F. lixiviel

sn.def: Impregnated with, or consisting of, alkaline salts extracted from wood ashes; impregnated with a salt or salts like a lixivium.
Of the color of lye; resembling lye.
Having the qualities of alkaline salts extracted from wood ashes.

entry.ety: From Lixivium

sn.def: Of or pertaining to lye or lixivium; of the quality of alkaline salts.
Impregnated with salts from wood ashes.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Lixiviated; p. pr. & vb. n. Lixiviating
entry.def: To subject to a washing process for the purpose of separating soluble material from that which is insoluble; to leach, as ashes, for the purpose of extracting the alkaline substances.

entry.ety: Cf. F. lixiviation
entry.def: Lixiviating; the process of separating a soluble substance from one that is insoluble, by washing with some solvent, as water; leaching.
See Lixivial.

entry.ety: L. lixivium lixivia. See Lixivial
entry.def: A solution of alkaline salts extracted from wood ashes; hence, any solution obtained by lixiviation.
2d pers. sing. pres. of Lige, to lie, to tell lies, -- contracted for ligest.
The American white mullet (Mugil curema).

entry.note: ☞ Most lizards have an elongated body, with four legs, and a long tail; but there are some without legs, and some with a short, thick tail. Most have scales, but some are naked; most have eyelids, but some do not. The tongue is varied in form and structure. In some it is forked, in others, as the chameleons, club-shaped, and very extensible. See Amphisbæna Chameleon Gecko Gila monster Horned toad Iguana, and Dragon, 6.

cs.cd: the garter snake (Eutænia sirtalis).
a kind of serpentine from near Lizard Point, Cornwall, England, -- used for ornamental purposes.

entry.ety: OE. lesarde, OF. lesarde, F. lézard, L. lacerta lacertus. Cf. Alligator Lacerta

sn.def: Any one of the numerous species of reptiles belonging to the order Lacertilia; sometimes, also applied to reptiles of other orders, as the Hatteria.
A piece of rope with thimble or block spliced into one or both of the ends.
A piece of timber with a forked end, used in dragging a heavy stone, a log, or the like, from a field.

entry.note: A freshwater perch, the sauger, a different fish, is also called the sand pike.
entry.def: Any of several mostly tropical marine scopeloid fish of the family Synodontidae having large mouths in lizardlike heads, especially the inshore lizardfish Synodus foetens syn. Synodus poeyi) of Mideastern and Southern United States and West Indies; -- sometimes called sand pike.

A perennial plant of the genus Saururus Saururus cernuus), growing in marshes, and having white flowers crowded in a slender terminal spike, somewhat resembling in form a lizard's tail; whence the name.

entry.ety: Peruv

sn.def: A South American ruminant (Auchenia llama), allied to the camels, but much smaller and without a hump. It is supposed to be a domesticated variety of the guanaco. It was formerly much used as a beast of burden in the Andes, and is also kept on some ranches in the United States.
The fleece of the llama{1}, a fine, soft wool-like hair.

entries.entry: Llan*dei"lo group`. Geol A series of strata in the lower Silurian formations of Great Britain; -- so named from Llandeilo in Southern Wales. See Chart of Geology.

entry.ety: Sp. Amer
entry.def: One of the inhabitants of the llanos of South America.

entries.entry:
Lla"no n.; pl.Llanos #. Sp., plain even, level. See Plain
An extensive plain with or without vegetation. Spanish America

entry.note: ☞ The name is derived from Lloyd's Coffee House, in Lombard Street, where there were formerly rooms for the same purpose. The name Lloyd or Lloyd's has been taken by several associations, in different parts of Europe, established for purposes similar to those of the original association.

cs.cd: persons employed in various parts of the world, by the association called Lloyd's, to serve its interests.
a publication of the latest news respecting shipping matters, with lists of vessels, etc., made under the direction of Lloyd's.
a register of vessels rated according to their quality, published yearly.

sn.def: An association of underwriters and others in London, for the collection and diffusion of marine intelligence, the insurance, classification, registration, and certifying of vessels, and the transaction of business of various kinds connected with shipping.
A part of the Royal Exchange, in London, appropriated to the use of underwriters and insurance brokers; -- called also Lloyd's Rooms.

entry.def: A mountain in Argentina and Chile, 22,057 feet high.
the sea personified, father of Manawydan; corresponds to the Irish Ler.

entry.ety: OE. lo low; perh. akin to E. look, v
entry.def: Look; see; behold; observe.
entry.q: Lo, here is Christ.
Lo, we turn to the Gentiles.

entry.ety: OE. loche, F. loche
entry.def: Any one of several small, fresh-water, cyprinoid fishes of the genera Cobitis Nemachilus, and allied genera, having six or more barbules around the mouth. They are found in Europe and Asia. The common European species (Nemachilus barbatulus) is used as a food fish.

cs.cd: the line on the outside of a vessel indicating the depth to which it sinks in the water when loaded.

entry.ety: OE. lode load, way; properly the same word as lode, but confused with lade load, v. See Lade Lead v. Lode

sn.def: A burden; that which is laid on or put in anything for conveyance; that which is borne or sustained; a weight; as, a heavy load .
sn.q: He might such a load To town with his ass carry.

sn.def: The quantity which can be carried or drawn in some specified way; the contents of a cart, barrow, or vessel; that which will constitute a cargo; lading.
That which burdens, oppresses, or grieves the mind or spirits; as, a load of care.
sn.q: A . . .loadof guilt.
Our life's aload.

sn.def: A particular measure for certain articles, being as much as may be carried at one time by the conveyance commonly used for the article measured; as, a load of wood; a load of hay; specifically, five quarters.
The charge of a firearm; as, a load of powder.
Weight or violence of blows.
The work done by a steam engine or other prime mover when working.
The amount of work that a person, group, or machine is assigned to perform; as, the boss distributed the load evenly among his employees.
The device or devices that consume power from a power supply.
The weight or force that a structural support bears or is designed to bear; the object that creates that force.
sn.syn: Burden; lading; weight; cargo. See Burden.

cs.cd: dice with one side made heavier than the others, so that the number on the opposite side will come up oftenest.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Loaded; p. pr. & vb. n. Loading. Loaden is obsolete, and laden belongs to lade

sn.def: To lay a load or burden on or in, as on a horse or in a cart; to charge with a load, as a gun; to furnish with a lading or cargo, as a ship; hence, to add weight to, so as to oppress or embarrass; to heap upon.
sn.q: I strive all in vain to load the cart.
I have loaden me with many spoils.
Those honors deep and broad, wherewith Your majesty loads our house.

sn.def: To adulterate or drug; as, to load wine.
To magnetize.

entry.def: Supporting a load{10} from parts of a structure above; as, a load-bearing wall.

sn.def: containing as much or as many as is possible; -- of containers, vehicles, trays, etc.; as, a tray loaded with dishes
containing a shell or an explosive charge ready for firing; -- of firearms. Opposite of unloaded.
charged with associative significance and often meant to mislead or influence; -- of statements or questions; as, a loaded question.
having an abundant supply of money or possessions of value; as, She was not merely rich but loaded .
very drunk.
sn.syn: blotto, crocked, fuddled, pissed, pixilated, plastered, potty, slopped, sloshed, smashed, soused, sozzled, squiffy, stiff, tiddly, tiddley, tight, tipsy, wet.

entry.def: One who, or that which, loads; a mechanical contrivance for loading, as a gun.

sn.def: The act of putting a load on or into.
A load; cargo; burden.

entry.def: Pilotage; skill of a pilot or loadsman.
A large quantity; a lot; as, loads of fun.
The act or process of disconnecting the electric current on certain lines when the demand becomes greater than the supply.

entry.ety: Load lode + man. See Lode
entry.def: A pilot.

entry.ety: Load lode + star. See Lode

sn.def: A star that leads; a guiding star; esp., the polestar, Polaris; also, the constellation containing the pole star, the cynosure (Ursa Minor).
sn.q: Your eyes arelodestars.
The pilot can no loadstar see.

sn.def: Something that serves as a guide or provides direction; a cynosure{2}.
Something that attracts attention or on which the atention is fixed; a cynosure{3}.

entry.ety: Load lode + stone
entry.def: A piece of magnetite, a magnetic iron ore, possessing polarity like a magnetic needle, having the power to attract as well as to be attracted magnetically. See Magnetite.

entries.entry:
Loaf
Loaf sugar refined sugar that has been formed into a conical loaf in a mold.
n.; pl.Loaves #. OE. lof laf, AS. hlāf; akin to G. laib, OHG. hleip, Icel. hleifr, Goth. hlaifs, Russ. khlieb', Lith. klëpas. Cf. Lady Lammas Lord
Any thick lump, mass, or cake; especially, a large regularly shaped or molded mass, as of bread, sugar, or cake.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Loafed; p. pr. & vb. n. Loafing
entry.ety: G. laufen to run, Prov. G. loofen. See Leap
entry.def: To spend time in idleness; to lounge or loiter about.
entry.q: Loafingvagabonds.

entry.def: To spend in idleness; -- with away; as, to loaf time away.

entry.ety: G. läufer a runner, Prov. G. laufer lofer, fr. laufen to run. See Leap

sn.def: One who loafs; a lazy lounger.
A type of shoe without laces which can be easily slipped on or off; -- originally a trademark; as, he bought a new pair of loafers .

entry.def: having no employment; being idle intentionally.

cs.cd: a mold made with loam. See Loam n., 2.
the process or business of making loam molds.
an iron plate upon which a section of a loam mold rests, or from which it is suspended.
loam molding or loam molds.

entry.ety: AS. lām; akin to D. leem, G. lehm, and E. lime. See 4th Lime

sn.def: A kind of soil; an earthy mixture of clay and sand, with organic matter to which its fertility is chiefly due.
sn.q: We wash a wall of loam; we labor in vain.

sn.def: A mixture of sand, clay, and other materials, used in making molds for large castings, often without a pattern.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Loamed; p. pr. & vb. n. Loaming
entry.def: To cover, smear, or fill with loam.
having no loam; -- of soil; as, a stony loamless yard. Contrasted with loamy.
Consisting of loam; partaking of the nature of loam; resembling loam.

entry.ety: See Lawn
entry.def: A loanin.

entry.cs: Loan office. An office at which loans are negotiated, or at which the accounts of loans are kept, and the interest paid to the lender. A pawnbroker's shop.
entry.ety: OE. lone lane, AS. lān læn, fr. león to lend; akin to D. leen loan, fief, G. lehen fief, Icel. lān, G. leihen to lend, OHG. līhan, Icel. ljī, Goth. leihwan, L. linquere to leave, Gr. lei`pein, Skr. ric. √119. Cf. Delinquent Eclipse Eleven Ellipse Lend License Relic

sn.def: The act of lending; a lending; permission to use; as, the loan of a book, money, services.
That which one lends or borrows, especially a sum of money lent at interest; as, he repaid the loan .

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Loaned; p. pr. & vb. n. Loaning
entry.def: To lend; -- sometimes with out.
entry.q: By way of location or loaning them out.

entry.def: Such as can be lent; available for lending; as, loanable funds; -- used mostly in financial business and writings.
a word that is composed of parts from different languages; e.g. monolingual has a Greek prefix and a Latin root.

sn.def: someone who lends money or gives credit in business matters.
Something borrowed or lent.

entry.ety: From Scotch loan, E. lawn
entry.def: An open space between cultivated fields through which cattle are driven, and where the cows are sometimes milked; also, a lane.
A dealer in, or negotiator of, loans.
entry.q: The millions of the loanmonger.

entry.def: a word borrowed from another language; e.g. blitz is a German word borrowed into modern English.
any of various perennial South American plants of the genus Loasa having stinging hairs and showy white or yellow or reddish-orange flowers.
A natural family of bristly hairy sometimes climbing plants; America and Africa and Southern Arabia.

entry.ety: OE. looth loth, AS. lāð hostile, odious; akin to OS. lāð, G. leid, Icel. leiðr, Sw. led, G. leiden to suffer, OHG. līdan to suffer, go, cf. AS. līðan to go, Goth. leipan, and E. lead to guide

sn.def: Hateful; odious; disliked.
Filled with disgust or aversion; averse; unwilling; reluctant; as, loath to part.
sn.q: Full loth were him to curse for his tithes.
Why, then, though loath, yet must I be content.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Loathed lō�d; p. pr. & vb. n. Loathing
entry.ety: AS. lāðian to hate. See Loath

sn.def: To feel extreme disgust at, or aversion for.
sn.q: Loathing the honeyed cakes, I Ionged for bread.

sn.def: To dislike greatly; to abhor; to hate; to detest.
sn.q: The secret which I loathe.
She loathes the vital sir.
sn.syn: To hate; abhor; detest; abominate. See Hate.

entry.def: To feel disgust or nausea.
One who loathes.

sn.def: Full of loathing; hating; abhorring.
sn.q: Loathfuleyes.

sn.def: Causing a feeling of loathing; disgusting.
sn.q: Above the reach of loathful, sinful lust.

entry.def: Extreme disgust; a feeling of aversion, nausea, abhorrence, or detestation.
entry.q: The mutual fear and loathing of the hostile races.

entry.def: With loathing.
Loathsomeness.

entry.ety: AS. lāðlic
entry.def: Loathsome.
entry.q: Loathlymouth.

sn.def: Unwillingly; reluctantly.
sn.q: This shows that you from nature loathly stray.

sn.def: So as to cause loathing.
sn.q: With dust and blood his locks were loathly dight.

entry.def: Unwillingness; reluctance.
entry.q: A general silence and loathness to speak.

entry.def: Fitted to cause loathing; exciting disgust; disgusting; as, a loathsome disease.
entry.q: The most loathsome and deadly forms of infection.

entry.def: Loathsome.

entry.ety: W. llob an unwieldy lump, a dull fellow, a blockhead. Cf. Looby Lubber

sn.def: A dull, heavy person.
sn.q: Countrylobs.

sn.def: Something thick and heavy.

cs.cd: to strike a ball so as to send it up into the air.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Lobbed lŏbd; p. pr. & vb. n. Lobbing

sn.def: To let fall heavily or lazily.
sn.q: And their poor jadesLob down their heads.

sn.def: to propel (relatively slowly) in a high arcing trajectory; as, to lob a grenade at the enemy.

entry.def: See Cob v. t.

entry.ety: Dan. lubbe
entry.def: The European pollock.
The act of lobbing;
an (often gentle) stroke which sends a ball up into the air, as in tennis to avoid a player at the net.
Of or pertaining to a lobe; characterized by, or like, a lobe or lobes.

entry.ety: See Lobe

sn.def: Consisting of, or having, lobes; lobed; as, a lobate leaf.

sd.def: Having lobes; -- said of the tails of certain fishes having the integument continued to the bases of the fin rays.
Furnished with membranous flaps, as the toes of a coot. See Illust. m under Aves.

entry.def: As a lobe; so as to make a lobe; in a lobate manner.
Like a lob; consisting of lobs.

entries.entry:
Lob"by
Lobby member a lobbyist. Humorous cant, U. S
n.; pl.Lobbies #. LL. lobium lobia laubia, a covered portico fit for walking, fr. OHG. louba, G. laube, arbor. See Lodge
Arch A passage or hall of communication, especially when large enough to serve also as a waiting room. It differs from an antechamber in that a lobby communicates between several rooms, an antechamber to one only; but this distinction is not carefully preserved.
That part of a hall of legislation not appropriated to the official use of the assembly; hence, the persons, collectively, who frequent such a place to transact business with the legislators; hence: any persons, not members of a legislative body, who strive to influence its proceedings by personal agency; a group of lobbyists for a particular cause; as, the drug industry lobby . U. S
Naut An apartment or passageway in the fore part of an old-fashioned cabin under the quarter-deck.
Agric A confined place for cattle, formed by hedges. trees, or other fencing, near the farmyard.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Lobbied; p. pr. & vb. n. Lobbying
entry.def: To address or solicit members of a legislative body in the lobby or elsewhere, with the purpose to influence their votes; in an extended sense, to try to influence decision-makers in any circumstance.
To urge the adoption or passage of by soliciting members of a legislative body; as, to lobby a bill; -- also used with the legislators as object; as, to lobby the state legislatuire for protection.
A member of the lobby; a person who solicits members of a legislature for the purpose of influencing legislation.
A dull, sluggish person; a lubber; a lob.

entries.entry:
Lobe
Lobe of the ear the soft, fleshy prominence in which the human ear terminates below, also called the earlobe. See. Illust. of Ear.
lōb n. F. lobe, Gr. lobo`s
Any projection or division, especially one of a somewhat rounded form; as: Bot A rounded projection or division of a leaf. Gray. Zoöl A membranous flap on the sides of the toes of certain birds, as the coot. Anat A round projecting part of an organ, as of the liver, lungs, brain, etc. See Illust. of Brain. Mach The projecting part of a cam wheel or of a non-circular gear wheel.

entry.def: surgical removal of a lobe from any organ of the body (such as the lung or brain).
Having lobes; lobate.
A bird having lobate toes; esp., a phalarope.
Lobiped.
A small lobe; a lobule.

entry.ety: NL. So called from Lobel, botanist to King James I
entry.def: A genus of plants, including a great number of species. Lobelia inflata, or Indian tobacco, is an annual plant of North America, whose leaves contain a poisonous white viscid juice, of an acrid taste. It has often been used in medicine as an emetic, expectorant, etc. Lobelia cardinalis is the cardinal flower, remarkable for the deep and vivid red color of its flowers.
A natural family of plants not recognized in all classification systems; in some classifications lobeliaceous plants are included in family Campanulaceae.
Of or pertaining to a natural order of plants of which the genus Lobelia is the type.
A yellowish green resin from Lobelia, used as an emetic and diaphoretic.
A poisonous narcotic alkaloid extracted from the leaves of Indian tobacco (Lobelia inflata) as a yellow oil, having a tobaccolike taste and odor.

entry.ety: Lobe + L. pes pedis, foot
entry.def: Having lobate toes, as a coot.

cs.cd: an elegant white-flowered evergreen shrub or small tree, of the genus Gordonia Gordonia Lasianthus), growing in the maritime parts of the Southern United States. Its bark is sometimes used in tanning. Also, a similar West Indian tree (Laplacea hæmatoxylon).
a surgeon's attendant on shipboard.
a kind of pitch pine found from Delaware southward along the coast; old field pine (Pinus Tæda). Also, Pinus Bahamensis, of the West Indies.
a name of several West Indian trees, having more or less leathery foliage, but alike in no other respect; as Pisonia subcordata Cordia alba, and Cupania glabra.

entry.ety: Etymol. uncertain
entry.def: Gruel; porridge; -- so called among seamen.

entry.ety: NL. See Lobe
entry.def: An order of Rhizopoda, in which the pseudopodia are thick and irregular in form, as in the Amœba.
The type genus of the Lobotidae.
A natural family of fishes including the tripletails.
The surgical interruption of nerve tracts to and from the frontal lobe of the brain, by cutting into the brain.

entry.ety: Written also lobscourse from which lobscouse is corrupted
Lob + course
entry.def: A combination of meat with vegetables, bread, etc., usually stewed, sometimes baked; an olio.
See Lopsided.

entry.ety: Lob + pound a prison
entry.def: A prison.

cs.cd: the caterpillar of a European bombycid moth (Stauropus fagi); -- so called from its form.
a copepod crustacean (Nicothoë astaci) parasitic on the gills of the European lobster.

entry.ety: AS. loppestre lopystre prob., corrupted fr. L. locusta a marine shellfish, a kind of lobster, a locust. Cf. Locust

sn.def: Any large macrurous crustacean used as food, esp. those of the genus Homarus; as the American lobster (Homarus Americanus), and the European lobster (Homarus vulgaris). The Norwegian lobster (Nephrops Norvegicus) is similar in form. All these have a pair of large unequal claws. The spiny lobsters of more southern waters, belonging to Palinurus Panulirus, and allied genera, have no large claws. The fresh-water crayfishes are sometimes called lobsters.
As a term of opprobrium or contempt: A gullible, awkward, bungling, or undesirable person.

entry.def: A British soldier in the 1700's; -- so-called because of his red coat, esp. during the American Revolutionary War.
Of or pertaining to British soldiers during the Revolutionary War in America; -- so called because of their red coats.

a device used to trap lobsters, consisting of a semi-cylindrical structure made of wooden slats, with openings formed of funnel-shaped nets allowing lobsters to enter, but impeding their exit. It is also called a lobster trap.
a dish of lobster meat cooked with a rich creamy wine sauce, stuffed back into the lobster shell, sprinkled with grated cheese, and browned.
same as lobster pot.

entry.ety: Cf. F. lobulaire
entry.def: Like a lobule; pertaining to a lobule or lobules.
the property of having lobules.
Made up of, or divided into, lobules; as, a lobulated gland.

entry.cs: Lobule of the ear. Anat Same as Lobe of the ear.
entry.ety: Cf. F. lobule, dim. of lobe. See Lobe
entry.def: A small lobe; a subdivision of a lobe.

entry.ety: Dim. of lobule
entry.def: A little lobule, or subdivision of a lobule.
The lugworm.

entry.cs: Local actions Law actions such as must be brought in a particular county, where the cause arises; -- distinguished from transitory actions. Local affection Med a disease or ailment confined to a particular part or organ, and not directly affecting the system. Local attraction Magnetism an attraction near a compass, causing its needle to deviate from its proper direction, especially on shipboard. Local battery Teleg the battery which actuates the recording instruments of a telegraphic station, as distinguished from the battery furnishing a current for the line. Local circuit Teleg the circuit of the local battery. Local color. Paint The color which belongs to an object, and is not caused by accidental influences, as of reflection, shadow, etc. Literature Peculiarities of the place and its inhabitants where the scene of an action or story is laid. Local option the right or obligation of determining by popular vote within certain districts, as in each county, city, or town, whether the sale of alcoholic beverages within the district shall be allowed.
entry.ety: L. localis, fr. locus place: cf. F. local. See Lieu Locus
entry.def: Of or pertaining to a particular place, or to a definite region or portion of space; restricted to one place or region; as, a local custom.
entry.q: Gives to airy nothing A local habitation and a name.

sn.def: A train which receives and deposits passengers or freight along the line of the road; a train for the accommodation of a certain district.
In newspaper cant, an item of news relating to the place where the paper is published.
A train or bus which stops at all stations along a line, as contrasted with an express, which stops only at certain stations designated as express stops.

entry.ety: F. local

sn.def: A place, spot, or location.
A principle, practice, form of speech, or other thing of local use, or limited to a locality.

entry.def: Same as localization.
Same as localize.

sn.def: The state or quality of being local; affection for a particular place.
A method of speaking or acting peculiar to a certain district; a local idiom or phrase.

entries.entry:
Lo*cal"i*ty n.; pl.Localitiees. L. localitas: cf. F. localité
The state, or condition, of belonging to a definite place, or of being contained within definite limits. It is thought that the soul and angels are devoid of quantity and dimension, and that they have nothing to do with grosser locality.
Position; situation; a place; a spot; esp., a geographical place or situation, as of a mineral or plant.
Limitation to a county, district, or place; as, locality of trial.
Phren The perceptive faculty concerned with the ability to remember the relative positions of places.

cs.cd: the localization of the control of special functions, as of sight or of the various movements of the body, in special regions of the brain.

entry.ety: Cf. F. localisation
entry.def: Act of localizing, or state of being localized.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Localized; p. pr. & vb. n. Localizing
entry.ety: Cf. F. localiser. See Local
