entry.def: To make local; to fix in, or assign to, a definite place.

sn.def: confined or restricted to a particular location; as, the localized infection formed a definite abscess. Contrasted with disseminated or systemic.
made local or oriented locally; as, a decentralized and localized political authority.

entry.def: With respect to place; in place; as, to be locally separated or distant.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Located; p. pr. & vb. n. Locating
entry.ety: L. locatus, p. p. of locare to place, fr. locus place. See Local

sn.def: To place; to set in a particular spot or position.
sn.q: The captives and emigrants whom he brought with him were located in the trans-Tiberine quarter.

sn.def: To designate the site or place of; to define the limits of; as, to locate a public building; to locate a mining claim; to locatethe land granted by) a land warrant.
sn.q: That part of the body in which the sense of touch is located.

sn.def: To discover the location or site of; as, to locate the source of a radio transmission; to locate a leak; to locate the malfunction in a system.

entry.def: To place one's self; to take up one's residence; to settle; as, to locate in Seattle.

sn.def: situated in a particular spot or position; as, valuable centrally located urban land.
situated: often used in combination; as, a well-located business.
the act of putting something in a certain place or location.
sn.syn: location, placement, position, positioning, emplacement, situating.

sn.def: a determination of the location of something.

entry.ety: L. locatio, fr. locare

sn.def: The act or process of locating.
Situation; place; locality.
That which is located; a tract of land designated in place.

sd.def: A leasing on rent.
A contract for the use of a thing, or service of a person, for hire.
The marking out of the boundaries, or identifying the place or site of, a piece of land, according to the description given in an entry, plan, map, etc.

entry.def: Indicating place, or the place where, or wherein; as, a locative adjective; locative case of a noun.
One who locates, or is entitled to locate, land or a mining claim.

entry.ety: L. locellus a compartment, dim. of locus a place
entry.def: Divided into secondary compartments or cells, as where one cavity is separated into several smaller ones.

entry.ety: Gael. & Olr. loch. See Lake of water
entry.def: A lake; a bay or arm of the sea.

entry.ety: F. looch, Ar. la'ūg, an electuary, or any medicine which may be licked or sucked, fr. la'ūq to lick
entry.def: A kind of medicine to be taken by licking with the tongue; a lambative; a lincture.

entry.cs: Detector lock a lock containing a contrivance for showing whether it as has been tampered with. Lock bay Canals the body of water in a lock chamber. entry.note: ☞ The name was first applied, in 1834, to a portion of the Democratic party, because, at a meeting in Tammany Hall, New York, in which there was great diversity of sentiment, the chairman left his seat, and the lights were extinguished, for the purpose of dissolving the meeting; when those who were opposed to an adjournment produced locofoco matches, rekindled the lights, continued the meeting, and accomplished their object.
entry.ety: Of uncertain etymol.; perh. for L. loco foci instead of fire; or, according to Bartlett, it was called so from a self-lighting cigar, with a match composition at the end, invented in 1834 by John Marck of New York, and called by him locofoco cigar, in imitation of the word locomotive, which by the uneducated was supposed to mean, self-moving

entry.note: ☞ The common log consists of the log-chip, or logship, often exclusively called the log, and the log line, the former being commonly a thin wooden quadrant of five or six inches radius, loaded with lead on the arc to make it float with the point up. It is attached to the log line by cords from each corner. This line is divided into equal spaces, called knots, each bearing the same proportion to a mile that half a minute does to an hour. The line is wound on a reel which is so held as to let it run off freely. When the log is thrown, the log-chip is kept by the water from being drawn forward, and the speed of the ship is shown by the number of knots run out in half a minute. There are improved logs, consisting of a piece of mechanism which, being towed astern, shows the distance actually gone through by the ship, by means of the revolutions of a fly, which are registered on a dial plate.
entry.cs:
Log board Naut a board consisting of two parts shutting together like a book, with columns in which are entered the direction of the wind, course of the ship, etc., during each hour of the day and night. These entries are transferred to the log book. A folding slate is now used instead.
Log bookorLogbook
Naut a book in which is entered the daily progress of a ship at sea, as indicated by the log, with notes on the weather and incidents of the voyage; the contents of the log board. a book in which a log{4} is recorded.
Log cabin Log house
a cabin or house made of logs. Log canoe a canoe made by shaping and hollowing out a single log; a dugout canoe. Log glass Naut a small sandglass used to time the running out of the log line. Log line Naut a line or cord about a hundred and fifty fathoms long, fastened to the log-chip. See Note under 2d Log n., 2. Log perch Zoöl an ethiostomoid fish, or darter (Percina caprodes); -- called also hogfish and rockfish. Log reel Naut the reel on which the log line is wound. Log slate. Naut See Log boardabove). Rough log Naut a first draught of a record of the cruise or voyage. Smooth log Naut a clean copy of the rough log. In the case of naval vessels this copy is forwarded to the proper officer of the government. To heave the log Naut to cast the log-chip into the water; also, the whole process of ascertaining a vessel's speed by the log.
entry.ety: Icel. lāg a felled tree, log; akin to E. lie. See Lie to lie prostrate

entry.note:
The relation of logarithms to common numbers is that of numbers in an arithmetical series to corresponding numbers in a geometrical series, so that sums and differences of the former indicate respectively products and quotients of the latter; thus,
0 1 2 3 4 Indices or logarithms
1 10 100 1000 10,000 Numbers in geometrical progression
Hence, the logarithm of any given number is the exponent of a power to which another given invariable number, called the base, must be raised in order to produce that given number. Thus, let 10 be the base, then 2 is the logarithm of 100, because 102 = 100, and 3 is the logarithm of 1,000, because 103 = 1,000.
entry.cs:
Arithmetical complement of a logarithm the difference between a logarithm and the number ten. Binary logarithms. See under Binary.
Common logarithmsorBrigg's logarithms
logarithms of which the base is 10; -- so called from Henry Briggs , who invented them. Gauss's logarithms tables of logarithms constructed for facilitating the operation of finding the logarithm of the sum of difference of two quantities from the logarithms of the quantities, one entry of those tables and two additions or subtractions answering the purpose of three entries of the common tables and one addition or subtraction. They were suggested by the celebrated German mathematician Karl Friedrich Gauss died in 1855), and are of great service in many astronomical computations.
Hyperbolic logarithmorNapierian logarithmorNatural logarithm
a logarithm (devised by John Speidell, 1619) of which the base is e (2.718281828459045...); -- so called from Napier , the inventor of logarithms.
Logistic logarithmsorProportional logarithms
See under Logistic.
entry.ety: Gr. lo`gos word, account, proportion + 'ariqmo`s number: cf. F. logarithme
entry.def: One of a class of auxiliary numbers, devised by John Napier, of Merchiston, Scotland (1550-1617), to abridge arithmetical calculations, by the use of addition and subtraction in place of multiplication and division.
See Logarithmic.
Logarithmically.

Having a logarithm in one or more of the unknowns; -- of an equation.

entry.def: By the use of logarithms.
A thin, flat piece of board in the form of a quadrant of a circle attached to the log line; -- called also log-ship. See 2d Log n., 2.
The pileated woodpecker.

entry.ety: F. See Lodge
entry.def: A lodge; a habitation.
See Logan.

entry.ety: Also written logget

sn.def: A small log or piece of wood.
An old game in England, played by throwing pieces of wood at a stake set in the ground.

entry.def: See Lodge.

sn.def: Made slow and heavy in movement; water-logged.
Entered in a logbook.

entry.def: One engaged in logging. See Log v. i.

cs.mcol: To be at loggerheads To fall to loggerheadsorTo go to loggerheads
cs.cd: to quarrel; to be at strife.

entry.ety: Log + head

sn.def: A blockhead; a dunce; a numskull.
A spherical mass of iron, with a long handle, used to heat tar.
An upright piece of round timber, in a whaleboat, over which a turn of the line is taken when it is running out too fast.
A very large marine turtle (Thalassochelys caretta syn. Thalassochelys caouana), common in the warmer parts of the Atlantic Ocean, from Brazil to Cape Cod; -- called also logger-headed turtle.
An American shrike (Lanius Ludovicianus), similar to the butcher bird, but smaller. See Shrike.

entry.def: Dull; stupid.
entry.q: A rabble of loggerheaded physicians.

entry.def: The knapweed.

entry.ety: It. See Lodge
entry.def: A roofed open gallery. It differs from a veranda in being more architectural, and in forming more decidedly a part of the main edifice to which it is attached; from a porch, in being intended not for entrance but for an out-of-door sitting-room.
The business of felling trees, cutting them into logs, and transporting the logs to sawmills or to market.

entry.note: ☞ Logic is distinguished as pure and applied. “Pure logic is a science of the form, or of the formal laws, of thinking, and not of the matter. Applied logic teaches the application of the forms of thinking to those objects about which men do think.” Abp. Thomson.
entry.ety: OE. logike, F. logique, L. logica logice, Gr. logikh`sc. te`chnh), fr. logiko`s belonging to speaking or reason, fr. lo`gos speech, reason, le`gein to say, speak. See Legend

sn.def: The science or art of exact reasoning, or of pure and formal thought, or of the laws according to which the processes of pure thinking should be conducted; the science of the formation and application of general notions; the science of generalization, judgment, classification, reasoning, and systematic arrangement; the science of correct reasoning.
sn.q: Logic is the science of the laws of thought, as thought; that is, of the necessary conditions to which thought, considered in itself, is subject.

sn.def: A treatise on logic; as, Mill's Logic .
correct reasoning; as, I can't see any logic in his argument; also, sound judgment; as, the logic of surrender was uncontestable.
The path of reasoning used in any specific argument; as, his logic was irrefutable.

A function of an electrical circuit (called a gate) that mimics certain elementary binary logical operations on electrical signals, such as AND, OR, or NOT; as, a logic circuit; the arithmetic and logic unit.

entry.ety: Cf. F. logique, L. logicus, Gr. logiko`s

sn.def: Of or pertaining to logic; used in logic; as, logical subtilties.
According to the rules of logic; as, a logical argument or inference; the reasoning is logical; a logical argument; a logical impossibility.
Skilled in logic; versed in the art of thinking and reasoning; as, he is a logical thinker.

entry.def: Logicalness.
In a logical manner; as, to argue logically .
The quality of being logical.

entry.ety: Cf. F. logicien
entry.def: A person skilled in logic.
entry.q: Each fierce logician still expelling Locke.

entry.def: See Logic.
To establish communication with a host computer from a terminal or remote computer.

cs.cd: certain logarithmic numbers used to shorten the calculation of the fourth term of a proportion of which one of the terms is a given constant quantity, commonly one hour, while the other terms are expressed in minutes and seconds; -- not now used.

entry.ety: Gr. � skilled in calculating, � to calculate, fr. lo`gos word, number, reckoning: cf. F. logistique

sn.def: Logical.
Sexagesimal, or made on the scale of 60; as, logistic or sexagesimal, arithmetic.
Of or pertaining to logistics; as, logistic requirements; logistical problems; a logistical nightmare.

entry.def: a person skilled at symbolic logic.

sn.def: That branch of the military art which embraces the details of moving and supplying armies. The meaning of the word is by some writers extended to include strategy.
The planning and coordination of the movement of materials, and other details of any large activity, such as a business or a political campaign.
A system of arithmetic, in which numbers are expressed in a scale of 60; logistic arithmetic.

entries.entry: Log"man n.; pl.Logmen. A man who carries logs.

entry.ety: Gr. �. See Logos, and Dædal
entry.def: Verbal legerdemain; a playing with words.

entry.ety: Gr. lo`gos word + -gram
entry.def: A word letter; a phonogram, that, for the sake of brevity, represents a word; as, |, i. e., t, for it. Cf. Grammalogue.

sn.def: A chronicler; one who writes history in a condensed manner with short simple sentences.
One skilled in logography.

entry.ety: Gr. � of writing speeches: cf. F. logographique
entry.def: Of or pertaining to logography.

entry.ety: Gr. � a writing of speeches; lo`gos word, speech + � to write: cf. F. logographie

sn.def: A method of printing in which whole words or syllables, cast as single types, are used.
A mode of reporting speeches without using shorthand, -- a number of reporters, each in succession, taking down three or four words.

entry.ety: Gr. lo`gos word + gri^fos a fishing net, a dark saying, a riddle: F. logogriphe
entry.def: A sort of riddle in which it is required to discover a chosen word from various combinations of its letters, or of some of its letters, which form other words; -- thus, to discover the chosen word chatter form cat hat rat hate rate, etc.

entry.ety: See Logomachy
entry.def: One who contends about words.

entry.ety: Gr. �; lo`gos word + � fight, battle, contest: cf. F. logomachie

sn.def: Contention in words merely, or a contention about words; a war of words.
sn.q: The discussion concerning the meaning of the word “justification” . . . has largely been a mere logomachy.

sn.def: A game of word making.

entry.ety: Gr. lo`gos word, ratio + me`tron measure
entry.def: Serving to measure or ascertain chemical equivalents; stoichiometric.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. lo`gos the word or form which expresses a thought, also, the thought, fr. � to speak

sn.def: A word; reason; speech.
The divine Word; Christ.

entry.ety: LL. logotheta, fr. Gr. �; lo`gos word, account + � to put
entry.def: An accountant; under Constantine, an officer of the empire; a receiver of revenue; an administrator of a department.

entry.ety: Gr. lo`gos word + -type
entry.def: A single type, containing two or more letters; as, æ Æ ﬁ ﬂ ﬄ, etc.; -- called also ligature.
To engage in logrolling; to accomplish by logrolling.
One who engages in logrolling.
entry.q: The jobbers and logrollers will all be against it.

sn.def: The act or process of rolling logs from the place where they were felled to the stream which floats them to the sawmill or to market. In this labor neighboring camps of loggers combine to assist each other in turn.

A combining or mutual agreement in which one politician supports or assists another in consideration of receiving assistance in return; wheeling and dealing; -- sometimes used of a disreputable mode of accomplishing political schemes or ends.

entry.def: A part of the log. See Log-chip, and 2d Log n., 2.

entry.ety: So called from being imported in logs
entry.def: The heartwood of a tree (Hæmatoxylon Campechianum), a native of South America, It is a red, heavy wood, containing a crystalline substance called hæmatoxylin, and is used largely in dyeing. An extract from this wood is used in medicine as an astringent. Also called Campeachy wood, and bloodwood.

entry.ety: Gr. �, fr. lo`gos word, discourse, fr. le`gein to speak. See Logic
entry.def: A combining form denoting a discourse treatise doctrine theory science; as, theology, geology, biology, mineralogy .

entry.ety: From D. log
entry.def: Heavy or dull in respect to motion or thought; as, a logy horse; feeling logy .
entry.q: Porcupines are . . . logy, sluggish creatures.

entry.def: See Loch, a medicine.

entry.ety: Gr. �, fr. � plague
entry.def: Of or pertaining to the plague or contagious disorders.

entry.ety: OE. loine, OF. logne, F. longe, from (assumed) LL. lumbea, L. lumbus join. Cf. Lends Lumbar Nombles

sn.def: That part of a human being or quadruped, which extends on either side of the spinal column between the hip bone and the false ribs. In human beings the loins are also called the reins. See Illust. of Beef.
A cut of meat taken from this part of a food animal, as from cattle or hogs.
The pubic area; the genitalia, especially in women; as, receptive loins .

entry.def: A cloth covering for the loins, worn around the hips; -- sometimes worn in tropical areas as the only article of clothing.

entry.ety: F., fr. L. glis gliris
entry.def: A large European dormouse (Myoxus glis).
a French river which flows into the North Atlantic.
A genus of plants having only one species, the alpine azalea.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Loitered; p. pr. & vb. n. Loitering
entry.ety: D. leuteren to delay, loiter; cf; Prov. G. lottern to be louse, lotter louse, slack, unsettled, vagrant, OHG. lotar

sn.def: To be slow in moving; to delay; to linger; to be dilatory; to spend time idly; to saunter; to lag behind.
sn.q: Sir John, you loiter here too long.
If we have loitered, let us quicken our pace.

sn.def: To wander as an idle vagrant.
sn.syn: To linger; delay; lag; saunter; tarry.

sn.def: One who loiters; an idler.
An idle vagrant; a tramp.

entry.def: In a loitering manner.

entry.ety: Icel. Loki, perh. akin to lokka locka to allure, entice
entry.def: The evil deity, the author of all calamities and mischief, answering to the Ahriman of the Persians.
A green vegetable dye imported from China.

entry.ety: See Lock a fastening
entry.def: A private path or road; also, the wicket or hatch of a door.
Liquorice.

entry.ety: L., cuttle fish
entry.def: A genus of cephalopods, including numerous species of squids, common on the coasts of America and Europe. They are much used for fish bait.
A genus of plants including the darnel and ryegrass.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Lolled lŏld; p. pr. & vb. n. Lolling
entry.ety: Cf. Icel. lolla to act lazily, loll lolla, laziness, OD. lollen to sit over the fire, and E. lull. Cf. Lill Lull

sn.def: To act lazily or indolently; to recline; to lean; to throw one's self down; to lie at ease; as, to loll around the house on a lazy summer day.
sn.q: Void of care, he lolls supine in state.

sn.def: To hand extended from the mouth, as the tongue of an ox or a log when heated with labor or exertion.
sn.q: The triple porter of the Stygian seat, With lolling tongue, lay fawning at thy feet.

sn.def: To let the tongue hang from the mouth, as an ox, dog, or other animal, when heated by labor; as, the ox stood lolling in the furrow.

entry.def: To let hang from the mouth, as the tongue.
entry.q: Fierce tigers couched around and lolled their fawning tongues.

entry.ety: LL. Lollardi Lullardi, from Walter Lolhardus, a German; cf. LG. & D. lollen to mumble, to hum, sing in a murmuring strain; hence, OD. lollaerd a mumbler, i. e., of prayers or psalms, which was prob. the origin of the name. See Loll Lull
entry.def: One of a sect of early reformers in Germany.
One of the followers of Wyclif in England.
entry.q: By Lollards all know the Wyclifities are meant, so called from Walter Lollardus, one of their teachers in Germany.

entry.def: The doctrines or principles of the Lollards.

entry.ety: See Loll

sn.def: One who lolls.
An idle vagabond.
A Lollard.

entry.def: In a lolling manner.

entry.ety: Perhaps fr. Prov. E. loll to soothe + pope a mixed liquor

sn.def: A kind of sugar confection which dissolves easily in the mouth.
A piece of hard candy, often of discoid shape, attached to the end of a handle of wood or hard paper by which it is held in the hand while being licked; -- it is popular with small children.

entry.ety: From Loll
entry.def: To move heavily; to lounge or idle; to loll.

entries.entry: ‖lo"ma n.; pl.lomata #. NL., fr. Gr. �, �, a fringe Zoöl A lobe; a membranous fringe or flap.

entry.def: any of various ornamental evergreens of the genus Lomatia having attractive fragrant flowers.

entry.ety: See Loma
entry.def: Furnished with lobes or flaps.
Of or pertaining to Lombardy, or the inhabitants of Lombardy.

cs.cd: the principal street in London for banks and the offices of note brokers; hence, the money market and interest of London.

entry.ety: F. lombard, fr. the Longobardi or Langobardi, i. e., Longbeards, a people of Northern Germany, west of the Elbe, and afterward in Northern Italy. See Long, and Beard, and cf. Lumber

sn.def: A native or inhabitant of Lombardy.
A money lender or banker; -- so called because the business of banking was first carried on in London by Lombards.
Same as Lombard-house.
sn.q: A Lombard unto this day signifying a bank for usury or pawns.

sn.def: A form of cannon formerly in use.

entry.def: A pawnbroker.

entry.ety: F. or D. lombard. See Lombard n.

sn.def: A bank or a pawnbroker's shop.
A public institution for lending money to the poor at a moderate interest, upon articles deposited and pledged; -- called also mont de piété.

entry.cs: Lombardic alphabet the ancient alphabet derived from the Roman, and employed in the manuscript of Italy. Lombardic architecture the debased Roman style of architecture as found in parts of Northern Italy. F. G. Lee. Lombardy poplar. Bot See Poplar.
entry.def: Of or pertaining to Lombardy of the Lombards.

entry.ety: L. lomentum a mixture of bean meal and rice, used as a cosmetic wash, bean meal, fr. lavare lotum, to wash
entry.def: An elongated pod, consisting, like the legume, of two valves, but divided transversely into small cells, each containing a single seed.

entry.ety: From Loment
entry.def: Of the nature of a loment; having fruits like loments.
Same as Laumontite.
Lumpish.
A genus of chiefly tropical American shrubs and trees having pinnate leaves and red or white flowers.
Land.

entry.cs: London paste Med a paste made of caustic soda and unslacked lime; -- used as a caustic to destroy tumors and other morbid enlargements. London pride. Bot A garden name for Saxifraga umbrosa, a hardy perennial herbaceous plant, a native of high lands in Great Britain. A name anciently given to the Sweet William. Dr. Prior. London rocket Bot a cruciferous plant (Sisymbrium Irio) which sprung up in London abundantly on the ruins of the great fire of 1667.
entry.def: The capital city of England.
A native or inhabitant of London.
A characteristic of Londoners; a mode of speaking peculiar to London.
To impart to (one) a manner or character like that which distinguishes Londoners.
To imitate the manner of the people of London.

entries.entry: Lon"don smoke. A neutral tint given to spectacles, shade glasses for optical instruments, etc., which reduces the intensity without materially changing the color of the transmitted light.
London tuft. Bot The Sweet William (Dianthus barbatus).

entry.def: A lane. See Loanin.

entry.ety: Abbrev. fr. alone

sn.def: Being without a companion; being by one's self; also, sad from lack of companionship; lonely; as, a lone traveler or watcher.
sn.q: When I have on those pathless wilds a appeared, And the lone wanderer with my presence cheered.

sn.def: Single; unmarried, or in widowhood.
sn.q: Queen Elizabeth being a lone woman.
A hundred mark is a long one for a poor lone woman to bear.

sn.def: Being apart from other things of the kind; being by itself; also, apart from human dwellings and resort; as, a lone house.
sn.q: Aloneisle.
By a lone well a lonelier column rears.

sn.def: Unfrequented by human beings; solitary.
sn.q: Thus vanish scepters, coronets, and balls, And leave you on lone woods, or empty walls.

sn.def: The condition of being lonely; solitude; seclusion.
The state of being unfrequented by human beings; as, the loneliness of a road.
Love of retirement; disposition to solitude.
sn.q: I see The mystery of your loneliness.

sn.def: A feeling of depression resulting from being alone.

entry.ety: Shortened fr. alonely

sn.def: Sequestered from company or neighbors; solitary; retired; as, a lonely situation; a lonely cell.
Alone, or in want of company; forsaken.
sn.q: To the misled and lonely traveler.

sn.def: Not frequented by human beings; as, a lonely wood.
Having a feeling of depression or sadness resulting from the consciousness of being alone; lonesome.
sn.q: I am very often alone. I don't mean I am lonely.
sn.syn: Solitary; lone; lonesome; retired; unfrequented; sequestered; secluded.

entry.def: Solitude; seclusion.

sn.def: Secluded from society; not frequented by human beings; solitary.
sn.q: Like one that on a lonesome road Doth walk in fear and dread.

sn.def: Conscious of, and somewhat depressed by, solitude; as, to feel lonesome .
a disposition toward being alone.
The condition of being alone; the feeling of sadness resulting from being alone.

entry.def: Texas; -- a nickname alluding to the single star on its coat of arms, being the device used on its flag and seal when it was a republic.

entry.note: ☞ Long is used as a prefix in a large number of compound adjectives which are mostly of obvious meaning; as, long-armed, long-beaked, long-haired, long-horned, long-necked, long-sleeved, long-tailed, long- worded, etc.
entry.cs:
In the long run in the whole course of things taken together; in the ultimate result; eventually. Long clam Zoöl the common clam (Mya arenaria) of the Northern United States and Canada; -- called also soft-shell clam and long-neck clam. See Mya. Long cloth a kind of cotton cloth of superior quality. Long clothes clothes worn by a young infant, extending below the feet. Long division. Math See Division. Long dozen one more than a dozen; thirteen. Long home the grave.
Long measure Long meter . See under Measure Meter. Long Parliament Eng. Hist the Parliament which assembled Nov. 3, 1640, and was dissolved by Cromwell, April 20, 1653. Long price the full retail price. Long purple Bot a plant with purple flowers, supposed to be the Orchis mascula. Dr. Prior. Long suit Whist a suit of which one holds originally more than three cards. R. A. Proctor. One's most important resource or source of strength; as, as an entertainer, her voice was her long suit . Long tom. A pivot gun of great length and range, on the dock of a vessel. A long trough for washing auriferous earth. Western U.S Zoöl The long-tailed titmouse. Long wall Coal Mining a working in which the whole seam is removed and the roof allowed to fall in, as the work progresses, except where passages are needed. Of long a long time. Obs Fairfax.
To be long of the marketorTo go long of the market To be on the long side of the market, etc. Stock Exchange to hold stock for a rise in price, or to have a contract under which one can demand stock on or before a certain day at a stipulated price; -- opposed to short in such phrases as, to be short of stock to sell short, etc. Cant See Short. To have a long head to have a farseeing or sagacious mind.
entry.ety: AS. long lang; akin to OS, OFries., D., & G. lang, Icel. langr, Sw. lång, Dan. lang, Goth. laggs, L. longus. √125. Cf. Length Ling a fish, Linger Lunge Purloin

sn.def: Drawn out in a line, or in the direction of length; protracted; extended; as, a long line; -- opposed to short, and distinguished from broad or wide.
Drawn out or extended in time; continued through a considerable tine, or to a great length; as, a long series of events; a long debate; a long drama; a long history; a long book.
Slow in passing; causing weariness by length or duration; lingering; as, long hours of watching.
Occurring or coming after an extended interval; distant in time; far away.
sn.q: The we may us reserve both fresh and strong Against the tournament, which is not long.

sn.def: Having a length of the specified measure; of a specified length; as, a span long; a yard long; a mile long, that is, extended to the measure of a mile, etc.
Far-reaching; extensive.
sn.q: Longviews.

sn.def: Prolonged, or relatively more prolonged, in utterance; -- said of vowels and syllables. See Short a., 13, and Guide to Pronunciation, §§ 22, 30.

Having a supply of stocks or goods; prepared for, or depending for a profit upon, advance in prices; as, long of cotton. Hence, the phrases: to be, or go long of the market to be on the long side of the market, to hold products or securities for a rise in price, esp. when bought on a margin. Contrasted to short.
A note formerly used in music, one half the length of a large, twice that of a breve.
A long sound, syllable, or vowel.
The longest dimension; the greatest extent; -- in the phrase, the long and the short of it, that is, the sum and substance of it.

entry.ety: AS. lance

sn.def: To a great extent in space; as, a long drawn out line.
To a great extent in time; during a long time.
sn.q: They that tarry long at the wine.
When the trumpet soundeth long.

sn.def: At a point of duration far distant, either prior or posterior; as, not long before; not long after; long before the foundation of Rome; long after the Conquest.
Through the whole extent or duration.
sn.q: The bird of dawning singeth all night long.

sn.def: Through an extent of time, more or less; -- only in question; as, how long will you be gone?

entry.ety: Abbreviated fr. along. See 3d Along
entry.def: By means of; by the fault of; because of.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Longed; p. pr. & vb. n. Longing
entry.ety: AS. langian to increase, to lengthen, to stretch out the mind after, to long, to crave, to belong to, fr. lang long. See Long a.

sn.def: To feel a strong or morbid desire or craving; to wish for something with eagerness; -- followed by an infinitive, or by for or after.
sn.q: I long to see you.
I have longed after thy precepts.
I have longed for thy salvation.
Nicomedes, longing for herrings, was supplied with fresh ones . . . at a great distance from the sea.

sn.def: To belong; -- used with to unto, or for.
sn.q: The labor which that longeth unto me.

entry.def: active over a relatively long period of time.
A pulpy fruit related to the litchi, and produced by an evergreen East Indian longanberry Nephelium Longan).

A tree (Dimocarpus longan) of Southeastern Asia to Australia grown primarily for its sweet translucent-fleshed edible fruit (the longan) resembling litchi nuts; -- it is sometimes placed in genera Euphoria or Nephelium.
entry.syn: longan, lungen, Dimocarpus longan Euphoria litchi Nephelium longana.

sn.def: Asian fruit similar to litchi.

entry.ety: L. longanimitas; longus long + animus mind: cf. F. longanimité
entry.def: Disposition to bear injuries patiently; forbearance; patience.
Having long arms; as, the long-armed ape or gibbon.
The American redbellied snipe (Macrorhamphus scolopaceus); -- called also long-billed dowitcher.
a fat-bellied stoneware drinking jug with a long neck; decorated with a caricature of Cardinal Bellarmine17th century).
Formerly, the largest boat carried by a merchant vessel, corresponding to the launch of a naval vessel.

cs.cd: to tell large stories.

entry.def: The ordinary bow, not mounted on a stock; -- so called in distinction from the crossbow when both were used as weapons of war. Also, sometimes, such a bow of about the height of a man, as distinguished from a much shorter one.
Having the power of retaining the breath for a long time; long-winded.
of a gilt-edged security: having more than 15 years to run before redemption.
covering long distances; as, a long-distance runner; a long-distance telephone call.
Extended to a great length.
entry.q: The cicadæ hushed their long-drawn, ear-splitting strains.

sn.def: relatively long in duration; as, a long-drawn-out visit from my mother-in-law.

entry.ety: Abbrev. fr. allonge. See Lunge

sn.def: A thrust. See Lunge.
The training ground for a horse.

entry.def: Same as 4th Lunge.
One who longs for anything.
Long-loved; longevous.

entry.ety: L. longaevitas. See Longevous
entry.def: Long duration of life; length of life.
entry.q: The instances of longevity are chiefly amongst the abstemious.

entry.ety: L. longaevus; longus long + aevum lifetime, age. See Long, and Age
entry.def: Living a long time; of great age.

sn.def: filled with or reflecting gloom.
having a face longer than the usual.

entry.def: frequently seen or experienced; as, a long-familiar face.
having long hair; as, long-haired hippies.
The written characters used in the common method of writing; -- opposed to shorthand; as, took it down in longhand .

sn.def: Having unusual foresight or sagacity.
having a relatively long head with a cephalic index of under 75. Opposite of brachycephalic.
A long-horned animal, as a cow, goat, or beetle. See Long-horned.
The Texas longhorn.

entry.def: Having a long horn or horns; as, a long-horned goat, or cow; having long antennæ, as certain beetles (Longicornia).

entry.ety: L. longus long + cornu horn: cf. F. longicorne
entry.def: Long-horned; pertaining to the Longicornia.

entry.ety: NL., fr. L. longus long + cornu horn
entry.def: A division of beetles, including a large number of species, in which the antennæ are very long. Most of them, while in the larval state, bore into the wood or beneath the bark of trees, and some species are very destructive to fruit and shade trees. See Apple borer, under Apple, and Locust beetle, under Locust.

entry.ety: L. longus long + lateralis lateral, fr. latus side
entry.def: Having long sides; especially, having the form of a long parallelogram.
entry.q: Nineveh . . . was of a longilateral figure, ninety-five furlongs broad, and a hundred and fifty long.

entry.ety: L. langus long + loquentia a talking
entry.def: Long-windedness.
entry.q: American longiloquence in oratory.

entry.ety: L. longus long + manus hand
entry.def: Having long hands.

entry.ety: L. longus long + -metry: cf. F. longimétrie
entry.def: The art or practice of measuring distances or lengths.
An eager desire; a craving; a morbid appetite; an earnest wish; an aspiration.
entry.q: Put on my crown; I have immortal longings in me.

entry.def: With longing.

entry.ety: L. longinquitas, fr. longinquus extensive, remote, fr. longus long
entry.def: Greatness of distance; remoteness.

entry.ety: F. longipalpe, fr. L. longus long + F. palpe a feeler, a palp
entry.def: One of a tribe of beetles, having long maxillary palpi.

entry.ety: L. longus long + E. pennate
entry.def: Having long wings, or quills.

entry.ety: NL., from L. longus long + penna wing
entry.def: A group of longwinged sea birds, including the gulls, petrels, etc.
Of or pertaining to the Longipennes; longipennate.

entries.entry:
Lon`gi*ros"ter n.; pl. L. Longirostres #, E. Longirosters #. L. longus long + rostrum beak: cf. F. longirostre
Zoöl One of the Longirostres.

entry.def: Having a long bill; of or pertaining to the Longirostres.

entry.ety: NL., fr. L. longus long + rostrum beak
entry.def: A group of birds characterized by having long slender bills, as the sandpipers, curlews, and ibises. It is now regarded as an artificial division.
Somewhat long; moderately long.

cs.cd: the longitude of a heavenly body as seen from the earth.
the longitude of a heavenly body, as seen from the sun's center.
certain stars whose position is known, and the data in regard to which are used in observations for finding the longitude, as by lunar distances.

entry.ety: F., fr. L. longitudo, fr. longus long

sn.def: Length; measure or distance along the longest line; -- distinguished from breadth or thickness; as, the longitude of a room; rare now, except in a humorous sense.
sn.q: The longitude of their cloaks.
Mine [shadow] spindling into longitude immense.

sn.def: The arc or portion of the equator intersected between the meridian of a given place and the meridian of some other place from which longitude is reckoned, as from Greenwich, England, or sometimes from the capital of a country, as from Washington or Paris. The longitude of a place is expressed either in degrees or in time; as, that of New York is 74° or 4 h. 56 min. west of Greenwich.

The distance in degrees, reckoned from the vernal equinox, on the ecliptic, to a circle at right angles to the ecliptic passing through the heavenly body whose longitude is designated; as, the longitude of Capella is 79°.

entry.ety: Cf. F. longitudinal

sn.def: Of or pertaining to longitude or length; as, longitudinal distance.
Extending in length; in the direction of the length; running lengthwise, as distinguished from transverse; as, the longitudinal diameter of a body.

entry.def: A railway sleeper lying parallel with the rail.
In the direction of length.
Existing or persisting for a long time; as, a long-lasting friendship.
having long legs.
A daddy longlegs.

sn.def: Having a long life; having constitutional peculiarities which make long life probable; lasting long; as, a long-lived tree; they are a long-lived family; long-lived prejudices.
same as long-lasting.
With longing desire.
For a long time; hence, wearisomely.

entry.def: The sparingly fossiliferous conglomerates, grits, schists, and slates of Great Britain, which lie at the base of the Cambrian system; -- so called, because typically developed in the Longmynd Hills, Shropshire.
Length.
The European garfish.
same as long-playing.
playing at a slower speed and for a longer time than earlier records; -- used of phonograph records.

entry.note: ☞ This line is printed in long primer.
entry.def: A kind of type, in size between small pica and bourgeois.

sn.def: involving an extended span of time; -- of plans, goals, or predictions; as, long-range goals; a long-range weather forecast.
suitable for or reaching long distances; as, a long-range missile; long-range nuclear capability.
relating to or extending over a relatively long time; as, the long-run significance of the elections.

entry.def: having long legs.
The stilt.

entry.ety: Abbrev. from alongshore
entry.def: Belonging to the seashore or a seaport; along and on the shore.
entry.q: Longshorethieves.

entries.entry:
Long"shore`man n.; pl.Longshoremen #. Abbrev. fr. alongshoreman
One of a class of laborers employed about the wharves of a seaport, especially in loading and unloading vessels.

entry.def: Long-sightedness.

sn.def: Able to see objects at a great distance; hence, having great foresight; sagacious; farseeing.
Able to see objects distinctly at a distance, but not close at hand; hypermetropic.
The state or condition of being long-sighted; hence, sagacity; shrewdness.
See Hypermetropia.

entry.ety: AS. langsum
entry.def: Extended in length; tiresome.
Spun out, or extended, to great length; hence, long-winded; tedious.
entry.q: The longspun allegories fulsome grow, While the dull moral lies too plain below.

entry.ety: So called from the length of the hind claw
entry.def: Any one of several species of fringilline birds of the genus Calcariusor Plectrophanes), and allied genera. The Lapland longspur (Calcarius Lapponicus), the chestnut-colored longspur (Calcarius ornatus), and other species, inhabit the United States.
existing since a time in the distant past; as, long-standing policies.
One who is set to stop balls which pass the wicket keeper.

sn.def: Forbearance to punish or resent.
patient endurance of pain or unhappiness.

entry.def: Bearing injuries or provocation for a long time; patient endurance of pain or unhappiness; patient; not easily provoked.
entry.q: The Lord God, merciful and gracious, long-suffering, and abundant in goodness and truth.

entry.def: disposed to bear inconvenience or injury patiently; long patience of offense; as, a long-suffering and uncomplaining wife.
entry.q: Despisest thou the riches of his goodness and forbearance and long-suffering?

entry.note: ☞ A longtail was a gentleman's dog, or the dog of one qualified to bunt, other dogs being required to have their tails cut.

cs.cd: all, gentlefolks and others, as they might come.

entry.def: An animal, particularly a log, having an uncut tail. Cf. Curtail. Dog.
same as long-run; as, the long-term consequences.
The wryneck.

sn.def: Having a long tongue.
Talkative; babbling; loquacious.

entry.ety: L. longus long + -lie
entry.def: A kind of crystallite having a (slender) acicular form.

sn.def: Having a long waist; long from the armpits to the bottom of the waist; -- said of persons.
Long from the part about the neck or shoulder, or from the armpits, to the bottom of the weist, or to the skirt; -- said of garments; as, a long-waisted coat.

entry.def: Lengthwise.
withstanding long use without deterioration; resistant to damage.

sn.def: Long-breathed; hence, tediously long in speaking; consuming much time; as, a long-winded talker.
sn.q: A tedious, long-winded harangue.

sn.def: using or containing too many words; as, long-windedor windy) speakers.

entry.def: Lengthwise.
A genus of vines including the woodbine, Lonicera periclymenum.

A tall fan palm (Borassus flabellifer) of Africa and India and Malaysia yielding a hard wood and sweet sap that is a source of palm wine and sugar; the palmyra; -- its leaves are used for thatching and weaving.
entry.syn: palmyra, palmyra palm, toddy palm, wine palm, longar palm, Borassus flabellifer.

cs.cd: a round table adapted for a circle of persons playing loo.

entry.ety: For older lanterloo, F. lanturelu lanturlu, name of the game; orig., the refrain of a vaudeville
entry.def: An old game played with five, or three, cards dealt to each player from a full pack. When five cards are used the highest card is the knave of clubs or (if so agreed upon) the knave of trumps; -- formerly called lanterloo.
A modification of the game of “all fours” in which the players replenish their hands after each round by drawing each a card from the pack.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Looed l�d; p. pr. & vb. n. Looing
entry.def: To beat in the game of loo by winning every trick.

entry.ety: Corn., slime, sludge
entry.def: The clay or slimes washed from tin ore in dressing.

entry.ety: From Looby
entry.def: Loobylike; awkward.
Awkwardly.

entries.entry:
Loo"by n.; pl.Loobies #. Cf. Lob
An awkward, clumsy fellow; a lubber.

entry.def: See 2d Loch.
The spongelike fibers of the fruit of a cucurbitaceous plant (Luffa Ægyptiaca); called also vegetable sponge.

entry.ety: See Luff
entry.def: Formerly, some appurtenance of a vessel which was used in changing her course; -- probably a large paddle put over the lee bow to help bring her head nearer to the wind.
The part of a ship's side where the planking begins to curve toward bow and stern.
See Luff.

entry.note: ☞ Look, in the imperative, may be followed by a dependent sentence, but see is oftener so used.
entry.cs:
To look about to look on all sides, or in different directions. To look about one to be on the watch; to be vigilant; to be circumspect or guarded. To look after. To attend to; to take care of; as, to look after children. To expect; to be in a state of expectation. Men's hearts failing them for fear, and for looking after those things which are coming on the earth. Luke xxi. 26. To seek; to search. My subject does not oblige me to look after the water, or point forth the place where to it is now retreated. Woodward. To look at to direct the eyes toward so that one sees, or as if to see; as, to look at a star; hence, to observe, examine, consider; as, to look at a matter without prejudice. To look black to frown; to scowl; to have a threatening appearance. The bishops thereat repined, and looked black. Holinshed.
To look down onorTo look down upon
to treat with indifference or contempt; to regard as an inferior; to despise. To look for. To expect; as, to look for news by the arrival of a ship. “Look now for no enchanting voice.” Milton. To seek for; to search for; as, to look for lost money, or lost cattle. To look forth. To look out of something, as from a window. To threaten to come out. Jer. vi. 1. (Rev. Ver.). To look forward to. To anticipate with an expectation of pleasure; to be eager for; as, I am looking forward to your visit. To look into to inspect closely; to observe narrowly; to examine; as, to look into the works of nature; to look into one's conduct or affairs. To look on. To regard; to esteem. Her friends would look on her the worse. Prior. To consider; to view; to conceive of; to think of. I looked on Virgil as a succinct, majestic writer. Dryden. To be a mere spectator. I'll be a candleholder, and look on. Shak. To look out to be on the watch; to be careful; as, the seaman looks out for breakers. To look through. To see through. To search; to examine with the eyes.
To look toorTo look unto . To watch; to take care of. “Look well to thy herds.” Prov. xxvii. 23. To resort to with expectation of receiving something; to expect to receive from; as, the creditor may look to surety for payment. “Look unto me, and be ye saved.” Is. xlv. 22. To look up to search for or find out by looking; as, to look up the items of an account. To look up to to respect; to regard with deference.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Looked; p. pr. & vb. n. Looking
entry.ety: OE. loken, AS. lōcian; akin to G. lugen, OHG. luogēn

sn.def: To direct the eyes for the purpose of seeing something; to direct the eyes toward an object; to observe with the eyes while keeping them directed; -- with various prepositions, often in a special or figurative sense. See Phrases below.
To direct the attention (to something); to consider; to examine; as, to look at an action.
To seem; to appear; to have a particular appearance; as, the patient looks better; the clouds look rainy.
sn.q: It would look more like vanity than gratitude.
Observe how such a practice looks in another person.

sn.def: To have a particular direction or situation; to face; to front.
sn.q: The inner gate that looketh to north.
The east gate . . . which looketh eastward.

sn.def: In the imperative: see; behold; take notice; take care; observe; -- used to call attention.
sn.q: Look, how much we thus expel of sin, so much we expel of virtue.
Look that ye bind them fast.
Look if it be my daughter.

sn.def: To show one's self in looking, as by leaning out of a window; as, look out of the window while I speak to you. Sometimes used figuratively.
sn.q: My toes look through the overleather.

sn.def: To await the appearance of anything; to expect; to anticipate.
sn.q: Looking each hour into death's mouth to fall.

entry.cs: To look daggers. See under Dagger. To look in the face to face or meet with boldness or confidence; hence, sometimes, to meet for combat. To look out to seek for; to search out; as, prudent persons look out associates of good reputation.

sn.def: To look at; to turn the eyes toward.
To seek; to search for.
sn.q: Looking my love, I go from place to place.

sn.def: To expect.
To influence, overawe, or subdue by looks or presence as, to look down opposition.
sn.q: A spirit fit to start into an empire, And look the world to law.

sn.def: To express or manifest by a look.
sn.q: Soft eyes looked love to eyes which spake again.

sn.def: The act of looking; a glance; a sight; a view; -- often in certain phrases; as, to have, get, take, throw, or cast, a look .
sn.q: Threw many a northward look to see his father Bring up his powers; but he did long in vain.

sn.def: Expression of the eyes and face; manner; as, a proud or defiant look .
sn.q: Gentlelooks.
Up ! up! my friends, and clear your looks.

sn.def: Appearance; aspect; as, the house has a gloomy look; the affair has a bad look.
sn.q: Pain, disgrace, and poverty have frighted looks.
There was something that reminded me of Dante's Hell in the look of this.

entry.def: A fish (Selene vomer) similar to the moonfish but with eyes high on the truncated forehead; it was also called moonfish at one time.
same as anticipated, 2; as, his looked-for advancement.

cs.cd: a spectator; an onlooker; one that looks on, but has no agency or part in an affair.

sn.def: One who looks.
A person who is physically very attractive, especially a beautiful woman.
sn.q: Did not this fatal war affront thy coast, Yet sattest thou an idle looker-on ?

entry.def: Having a certain look or appearance; -- often compounded with adjectives; as, good-looking, grand-looking, etc.

entry.cs: Looking for anticipation; expectation. “A certain fearful looking for of judgment.” Heb. x. 27.

sn.def: The act of one who looks; a glance.
The manner in which one looks; appearance; countenance; face.
sn.q: All dreary was his cheer and his looking.

entry.def: A mirror made of glass on which has been placed a backing of some reflecting substance, as quicksilver.
entry.q: There is none so homely but loves a looking-glass.

cs.cd: in search of; looking for.

sn.def: A careful looking or watching for any object or event.
The place from which such observation is made.
A person engaged in watching; a sentinel; a sentry.
Object or duty of forethought and care; responsibility.

entry.def: a swift cursory examination or inspection; as, I gave the car a quick look-over .
an operation that determines whether one or more of a set of items has a specified property; as, they wrote a program to do a table lookup .
A vessel used to receive the washings of ores of metals.
See Loon, the bird.

entry.ety: OE. lome, AS. gelōma utensil, implement

sn.def: A frame or machine of wood or other material, in which a weaver forms cloth out of thread; a machine for interweaving yarn or threads into a fabric, as in knitting or lace making.
sn.q: Hector, when he sees Andromache overwhelmed with terror, sends her for consolation to the loom and the distaff.

sn.def: That part of an oar which is near the grip or handle and inboard from the rowlock.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Loomed l�md; p. pr. & vb. n. Looming
entry.ety: OE. lumen to shine, Icel. ljoma; akin to AS. leóma light, and E. light; or cf. OF. lumer to shine, L. luminare to illumine, lumen light; akin to E. light. √122. See Light not dark

sn.def: To appear above the surface either of sea or land, or to appear enlarged, or distorted and indistinct, as a distant object, a ship at sea, or a mountain, esp. from atmospheric influences; as, the ship looms large; the land looms high.
sn.q: Awful she looms, the terror of the main.

sn.def: To rise and to be eminent; to be elevated or ennobled, in a moral sense.
sn.q: On no occasion does he [Paulloom so high, and shine so gloriously, as in the context.

sn.def: To become imminent; to impend.

entry.def: The state of looming; esp., an unnatural and indistinct appearance of elevation or enlargement of anything, as of land or of a ship, seen by one at sea.
A gentle gale of wind.
The indistinct and magnified appearance of objects seen in particular states of the atmosphere. See Mirage.

entry.ety: Scot. loun lown loon; akin to OD. loen a stupid man; prob. for an older lown, and akin to E. lame
entry.def: A sorry fellow; a worthless person; a rogue.

entry.ety: For older loom, Icel. lōmr; akin to Dan. & Sw. lom
entry.def: Any one of several aquatic, wed-footed, northern birds of the genus Urinatorformerly Colymbus), noted for their expertness in diving and swimming under water. The common loon, or great northern diver (Urinator imber, or Colymbus torquatus), and the red-throated loon or diver (Urinator septentrionalis), are the best known species. See Diver.
someone deranged and possibly dangerous.

entry.ety: Shortened fr. lunatic

sn.def: Crazy; insane; lunatic; mentally unsound.
See Luny.
Very foolish; very impractical; as, loony ideas.

entry.def: someone mentally deranged and possibly dangerous.
An institution for the confinement or treatment of insane persons, such as an insane asylum or the psychiatric ward of a hospital.

entry.ety: G. luppe an iron lump. Cf. Looping
entry.def: A mass of iron in a pasty condition gathered into a ball for the tilt hammer or rolls.

cs.cd: a single knot tied in a doubled cord, etc. so as to leave a loop beyond the knot. See Illust. of Knot.

entry.ety: Cf. Ir. & Gael. lub loop, noose, fold, thong, bend, lub to bend, incline

sn.def: A fold or doubling of a thread, cord, rope, etc., through which another thread, cord, etc., can be passed, or which a hook can be hooked into; an eye, as of metal; a staple; a noose; a bight.
sn.q: That the probation bear no hinge, nor loop To hang a doubt on.

sn.def: A small, narrow opening; a loophole.
sn.q: And stop all sight-holes, every loop from whence The eye of Reason may pry in upon us.

sn.def: A curve of any kind in the form of a loop.
A wire forming part of a main circuit and returning to the point from which it starts.
The portion of a vibrating string, air column, etc., between two nodes; -- called also ventral segment.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Looped l�pt; p. pr. & vb. n. Looping
entry.def: To make a loop of or in; to fasten with a loop or loops; -- often with up; as, to loop a string; to loop up a curtain.

sn.def: Bent, folded, or tied, so as to make a loop; as, a looped wire or string.
Full of holes.
An instrument, as a bodkin, for forming a loop in yarn, a cord, etc.
The larva of any species of geometrid moths. See Geometrid.
A small opening, as in the walls of fortification, or in the bulkhead of a ship, through which small arms or other weapons may be discharged at an enemy.
A hole or aperture that gives a passage, or the means of escape or evasion.

An amibiguity or unintended omission in a law, rule, regulation, or contract which allows a party to circumvent the intent of the text and avoid its obligations under certain circumstances. -- used usually in a negative sense; -- distinguished from escape clause in that the latter usually is included to deliberately allow evasion of obligation under certain specified and foreseen circumstances; as, a loophole in the law big enough to drive a truck through.

entry.def: Provided with loopholes.
Deceitful; cunning; sly.

entry.ety: Cf. D. loopen to run. Cf. Loop a mass of iron, Leap
entry.def: The running together of the matter of an ore into a mass, when the ore is only heated for calcination.

cs.cd: any species of land snail of the genus Truncatella; -- so called because it creeps like the measuring worms.

entry.def: of Loop.
A small narrow opening or window in a tower or fortified wall; a loophole.
a railway line that branches from the trunk line and then rejoins it at another point.

entry.ety: F. lourd heavy, dull
entry.def: A dull, stupid fellow; a drone.

entry.ety: OE. los, fr. OF. los laus
entry.def: Praise; fame; reputation.
entry.q: Good conscience and good loos.

entry.cs: At loose ends not in order; in confusion; carelessly managed. Fast and loose. See under Fast. To break loose. See under Break. Loose pulley. Mach See Fast and loose pulleys, under Fast. To let loose to free from restraint or confinement; to set at liberty.
entry.ety: OE. loos lous laus, Icel. lauss; akin to OD. loos, D. los, AS. leás false, deceitful, G. los, loose, Dan. & Sw. lös, Goth. laus, and E. lose. √127. See Lose, and cf. Leasing falsehood

sn.def: Unbound; untied; unsewed; not attached, fastened, fixed, or confined; as, the loose sheets of a book.
sn.q: Her hair, nor loose, nor tied in formal plat.

sn.def: Free from constraint or obligation; not bound by duty, habit, etc.; -- with from or of.
sn.q: Now I standLoose of my vow; but who knows Cato's thoughts ?

sn.def: Not tight or close; as, a loose garment.
Not dense, close, compact, or crowded; as, a cloth of loose texture.
sn.q: With horse and chariots ranked in loose array.

sn.def: Not precise or exact; vague; indeterminate; as, a loose style, or way of reasoning.
sn.q: The comparison employed . . . must be considered rather as a loose analogy than as an exact scientific explanation.

sn.def: Not strict in matters of morality; not rigid according to some standard of right.
sn.q: The loose morality which he had learned.

sn.def: Unconnected; rambling.
sn.q: Vario spends whole mornings in running over loose and unconnected pages.

sn.def: Lax; not costive; having lax bowels.
Dissolute; unchaste; as, a loose man or woman.
sn.q: Loose ladies in delight.

sn.def: Containing or consisting of obscene or unchaste language; as, a loose epistle.

cs.cd: to give freedom.

sn.def: Freedom from restraint.
A letting go; discharge.
sn.q: Vent all its griefs, and give a loose to sorrow.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Loosed l�st; p. pr. & vb. n. Loosing
entry.ety: From Loose a.

sn.def: To untie or unbind; to free from any fastening; to remove the shackles or fastenings of; to set free; to relieve.
sn.q: Canst thou . . . loose the bands of Orion ?
Ye shall find an ass tied, and a colt with her; loose them, and bring them unto me.

sn.def: To release from anything obligatory or burdensome; to disengage; hence, to absolve; to remit.
sn.q: Art thou loosed from a wife ? seek not a wife.
Whatsoever thou shalt loose on earth shall be loosed in heaven.

sn.def: To relax; to loosen; to make less strict.
sn.q: The joints of his loins were loosed.

sn.def: To solve; to interpret.

entry.def: To set sail.
large enough to leave space for movement over the skin; not tight-fitting; -- of clothing. Opposite of close-fitting tight, and tight-fitting.
having sagging folds of flesh beneath the chin or lower jaw.
having rings that open and close permitting insertion and removal of pages; -- of notebooks and binders and the paper used in them; as, a looseleaf notebook; looseleaf paper.
A type of notebook with hard covers attached to metal rings which open, allowing sheets of writing paper to be conveniently inserted into it and removed from it.
Sheets of writing paper having holes at the edge permitting insertion into and removal from a looseleaf binder.
In a loose manner.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Loosened l�s"'nd; p. pr. & vb. n. Loosening
entry.ety: See Loose v. t.

sn.def: To make loose; to free from tightness, tension, firmness, or fixedness; to make less dense or compact; as, to loosen a string, or a knot; to loosen a rock in the earth.
sn.q: After a year's rooting, then shaking doth the tree good by loosening of the earth.

sn.def: To free from restraint; to set at liberty..
sn.q: It loosens his hands, and assists his understanding.

sn.def: To remove costiveness from; to facilitate or increase the alvine discharges of.

entry.def: To become loose; to become less tight, firm, or compact.

sn.def: having constraints removed.
straightened out; untangled.

entry.def: One who, or that which, loosens.
The state, condition, or quality, of being loose; as, the looseness of a cord; looseness of style; looseness of morals or of principles.

cs.cd: a plant of the genus Ludwigia, which includes several species, most of which are found in the United States.
the plant Lysimachia thyrsiflora, found in the northern parts of the United States and in Europe.

entry.def: The name of several species of plants of the genus Lysimachia, having small star-shaped flowers, usually of a yellow color.
Any species of the genus Lythrum, having purple, or, in some species, crimson flowers.
Somewhat loose.

entry.ety: Hind. lūṭ, Skr. lōtra lōptra, booty, lup to break, spoil; prob. akin to E. rob

sn.def: The act of plundering.
Plunder; booty; especially, the booty taken in a conquered or sacked city.
Anything stolen or obtained by dishonesty.
Valuable objects; as, the child was delighted with all the loot he got for his birthday.
Money; as, you shouldn't carry all that loot around with you in the city; she made a pile of loot from trading in cattle futures.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Looted; p. pr. & vb. n. Looting
entry.def: To plunder; to carry off as plunder or a prize lawfully obtained by war.
entry.q: Looting parties . . . ransacking the houses.

entry.def: wrongfully emptied or stripped of anything of value; as, the robbers left the looted train.
A plunderer.
See Louver.

entry.ety: AS. loppe
entry.def: A flea.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Lopped; p. pr. & vb. n. Lopping
entry.ety: Prov. G. luppen lubben, to cut, geld, or OD. luppen, D. lubben

sn.def: To cut off as the top or extreme part of anything; to shorten by cutting off the extremities; to cut off, or remove, as superfluous parts; as, to lop a tree or its branches.
sn.q: With brancheslopped, in wood or mountain felled.
Expunge the whole, or lop the excrescent parts.

sn.def: To cut partly off and bend down; as, to lop bushes in a hedge.

entry.def: That which is lopped from anything, as branches from a tree.
To hang downward; to be pendent; to lean to one side.
To let hang down; as, to lop the head.
Hanging down; as, lop ears; -- used also in compound adjectives; as, lopeared; lopsided.
of Leap.
entry.q: And, laughing, lope into a tree. Spenser.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Loped; p. pr. & vb. n. Loping
entry.ety: See Leap

sn.def: To leap; to dance.
sn.q: He thatlopeson the ropes.

sn.def: To move with a leaping or bounding stride, as a horse.
To run with an easy, bounding stride; -- of people.
A leap; a long step.
An easy gait, consisting of long running strides or leaps.
sn.q: The mustang goes rollicking ahead, with the eternal lope, . . . a mixture of two or three gaits, as easy as the motions of a cradle.

entry.def: Having ears which droop or hang down; as, a lop-eared hound.
Leaper; ropedancer.

sn.def: One who, or that which, lopes; esp., a horse that lopes.
A swivel at one end of a ropewalk, used in laying the strands.

entry.ety: Gr. � a tuft or crest of feathers
entry.def: A nitrogenous organic base obtained by the oxidation of amarine, and regarded as a derivative of benzoic aldehyde. It is obtained in long white crystalline tufts, -- whence its name.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. lofia` a mane, bristly ridge + my^s a mouse
entry.def: A very singular rodent (Lophiomys Imhausi) of Northeastern Africa. It is the only known representative of a special family (Lophiomyidæ), remarkable for the structure of the skull. It has handlike feet, and the hair is peculiar in structure and arrangement.

entry.ety: Gr. lofia` crest or tuft + bra`gchion gill
entry.def: Of or pertaining to the Lophobranchii.
Of or pertaining to the Lophobranchii.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. lo`fos a crest or tuft + bra`gchion gill
entry.def: An order of teleostean fishes, having the gills arranged in tufts on the branchial arches, as the Hippocampus and pipefishes.

entry.ety: Gr. lo`fos a crest or tuft + fe`rein to bear
entry.def: A disk which surrounds the mouth and bears the tentacles of the Bryozoa. See Phylactolemata.

entry.ety: NL., from Gr. lo`fos a crest or tuft + -poda
entry.def: Same as Phylactolemata.

entries.entry: ‖Lo*phos"te*on n.; pl. L. Lophostea #, E. Lophosteons #. NL., from Gr. lo`fos a crest + � a bone Anat The central keel-bearing part of the sternum in birds.

entry.ety: Lop + -ard
entry.def: A tree, the top of which has been lopped off.
One who lops or cuts off.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Loppered; p. pr. & vb. n. Loppering
entry.ety: Cf. Prov. G. lübbern levern, OHG. giliberōn, G. luppe lab, rennet
entry.def: To turn sour and coagulate from too long standing, as milk.
A cutting off, as of branches; that which is cut off; leavings.
entry.q: The loppings made from that stock whilst it stood.

entry.def: Somewhat lop; inclined to lop.
A perennial herb (Phryma Leptostachya), having slender seedlike fruits.

entry.ety: Lop + side. Cf. Lobsided

sn.def: Leaning to one side because of some defect of structure; as, a lopsided ship.
Unbalanced; poorly proportioned; having much more on one side than the other; -- also used metaphorically; as, a lopsided victory.
Full of idiosyncrasies.

entry.def: A victory in a contest in which one side defeats the other overwhelmingly; -- in sports, meaning one side scores much more than the other; in war, meaning one side has many more casualties than the other.

entry.ety: L. loquax -acis, talkative, fr. loqui to speak; cf. Gr. � to rattle, shriek, shout

sn.def: Given to continual talking; talkative; garrulous.
sn.q: Loquacious, brawling, ever in the wrong.

sn.def: Speaking; expressive.
Apt to blab and disclose secrets.

entry.def: In a loquacious manner.
Loquacity.

entry.ety: L. loquacitas: cf. F. loquacité
entry.def: The habit or practice of talking continually or excessively; inclination to talk too much; talkativeness; garrulity.
entry.q: Too great loquacity and too great taciturnity by fits.

entry.ety: Chinese name
entry.def: The fruit of the Japanese medlar (Photinia Japonica). It is as large as a small plum, but grows in clusters, and contains four or five large seeds. Also, the tree itself.

sn.def: Of or pertaining to the lores.
Of or pertaining to lore{1}.

entry.ety: Acronym, from LOng RAnge Navigation
entry.def: A system of electronic navigation in which a vessel or aircraft determines its latitude and longitude by measuring the time differences between low frequency radio transmissions from two stationary transmitters (slaves) and a stationary master transmitter. Contrary to the name, Loran is a medium range system, usually effective for no more than a few hundred miles from shore. The first commercial system was called Loran A; the latest (and final) development is Loran C.

entry.ety: L. loratus, fr. lorum thong
entry.def: Having the form of a thong or strap; ligulate.

entry.ety: Pg
entry.def: A kind of light vessel used on the coast of China, having the hull built on a European model, and the rigging like that of a Chinese junk.

entry.ety: Cf. Gr. � bent so as to be convex in front
entry.def: A hump-backed person; -- so called sportively.

entry.note: ☞ When Lord, in the Old Testament, is printed in small capitals, it is usually equivalent to Jehovah, and might, with more propriety, be so rendered.
entry.cs:
House of Lords one of the constituent parts of the British Parliament, consisting of the lords spiritual and temporal.
Lord high chancellor Lord high constable
etc. See Chancellor Constable, etc. Lord justice clerk the second in rank of the two highest judges of the Supreme Court of Scotland.
Lord justice generalorLord president
the highest in rank of the judges of the Supreme Court of Scotland. Lord keeper an ancient officer of the English crown, who had the custody of the king's great seal, with authority to affix it to public documents. The office is now merged in that of the chancellor. Lord lieutenant a representative of British royalty: the lord lieutenant of Ireland being the representative of royalty there, and exercising supreme administrative authority; the lord lieutenant of a county being a deputy to manage its military concerns, and also to nominate to the chancellor the justices of the peace for that county. Lord of misrule the master of the revels at Christmas in a nobleman's or other great house. Eng. Cyc. Lords spiritual the archbishops and bishops who have seats in the House of Lords. Lords temporal the peers of England; also, sixteen representative peers of Scotland, and twenty-eight representatives of the Irish peerage. Our lord Jesus Christ; the Savior. The Lord's Day Sunday; the Christian Sabbath, on which the Lord Jesus rose from the dead. The Lord's Prayer Christianity the prayer which Jesus taught his disciples, also called the Our Father. Matt. vi. 9-13. The Lord's Supper. The paschal supper partaken of by Jesus the night before his crucifixion. The sacrament of the eucharist; the holy communion. The Lord's Table. The altar or table from which the sacrament is dispensed. The sacrament itself.
entry.ety: OE. lord laverd loverd, AS. hlāford, for hlāfweard, i. e., bread keeper; hlāf bread, loaf + weardian to look after, to take care of, to ward. See Loaf, and Ward to guard, and cf. Laird Lady

sn.def: One who has power and authority; a master; a ruler; a governor; a prince; a proprietor, as of a manor.
sn.q: But now I was the lord Of this fair mansion.
Man over men He made not lord.

sn.def: A titled nobleman., whether a peer of the realm or not; a bishop, as a member of the House of Lords; by courtesy; the son of a duke or marquis, or the eldest son of an earl; in a restricted sense, a baron, as opposed to noblemen of higher rank.
A title bestowed on the persons above named; and also, for honor, on certain official persons; as, lord advocate, lord chamberlain, lord chancellor, lord chief justice, etc.
A husband.
sn.q: Mylordbeing old also.
Thou worthy lord Of that unworthy wife that greeteth thee.

sn.def: One of whom a fee or estate is held; the male owner of feudal land; as, the lord of the soil; the lord of the manor.
The Supreme Being; Jehovah.
The Savior; Jesus Christ.
To invest with the dignity, power, and privileges of a lord.
To rule or preside over as a lord.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Lorded; p. pr. & vb. n. Lording
entry.def: To play the lord; to domineer; to rule with arbitrary or despotic sway; -- sometimes with over; and sometimes with it in the manner of a transitive verb; as, rich students lording it over their classmates.
entry.q: The whiles she lordeth in licentious bliss.
I see them lording it in London streets.
And lorded over them whom now they serve.

entry.note: ☞ In the plural, a common ancient mode of address equivalent to “Sirs” or “My masters.”
entry.ety: Lord + -ing, 3

sn.def: The son of a lord; a person of noble lineage.
A little lord; a lordling; a lord, in contempt or ridicule.
sn.q: Therefore, lordings all, I you beseech.

entry.def: A little lord.

sn.def: having no lord or master; as, the “ronin” of Japan were lordless samurai.

entry.ety: 2d lord + like. Cf. Lordly

sn.def: Befitting or like a lord; lordly.
Haughty; proud; insolent; arrogant.

entry.ety: From Lordly
entry.def: The state or quality of being lordly.

entry.ety: Lord + -ling
entry.def: A little or insignificant lord.

entry.ety: Lord + -ly. Cf. Lordlike

sn.def: Suitable for a lord; of or pertaining to a lord; resembling a lord; hence, grand; noble; dignified; honorable.
sn.q: She brought forth butter in a lordly dish.
Lordly sins require lordly estates to support them.
The maidens gathered strength and grace And presence, lordlier than before.

sn.def: Proud; haughty; imperious; insolent.
sn.q: Lords are lordliest in their wine.
sn.syn: Imperious; haughty; overbearing; tyrannical; despotic; domineering; arrogant. See Imperious.

entry.def: In a lordly manner.

entry.ety: Lord + -olatry, as in idolatry
entry.def: Worship of, or reverence for, a lord as such.
entry.q: But how should it be otherwise in a country where lordolatry is part of our creed?

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. � , fr. � bent so as to be convex in front
entry.def: A curvature of the spine forwards, usually in the lumbar region.
Any abnormal curvature of the bones.
The European wake-robin (Arum maculatum), -- those with purplish spadix the lords, and those with pale spadix the ladies.

sn.def: The state or condition of being a lord; hence (with his or your), a title applied to a lord (except an archbishop or duke, who is called Grace) or a judge (in Great Britain), etc.
Seigniory; domain; the territory over which a lord holds jurisdiction; a manor.
sn.q: What lands and lordships for their owner know My quondam barber.

sn.def: Dominion; power; authority.
sn.q: They which are accounted to rule over the Gentiles exercise lordship over them.

entry.ety: F. lore, L. lorum thong
entry.def: The space between the eye and bill, in birds, and the corresponding region in reptiles and fishes.
The anterior portion of the cheeks of insects.

entry.ety: See Lose
entry.def: Lost.
entry.q: Neither of them she found where she them lore.

entry.ety: OE. lore lare, AS. lār, fr. lǣran to teach; akin to D. leer teaching, doctrine, G. lehre, Dan. lære, Sw. lära. See Learn, and cf. Lere v. t.

sn.def: That which is or may be learned or known; the knowledge gained from tradition, books, or experience; often, the whole body of knowledge possessed by a people or class of people, or pertaining to a particular subject; as, the lore of the Egyptians; priestly lore; legal lore; folklore.
sn.q: Theloreof war.
His fair offspring, nursed in princely lore.

sn.def: That which is taught; hence, instruction; wisdom; advice; counsel.
sn.q: If please ye, listen to my lore.

sn.def: Workmanship.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to the lore; -- said of certain feathers of birds, scales of reptiles, etc.

entry.ety: �. Cf. Losel
entry.def: A good for nothing fellow; a vagabond.
strong p. p. of Lose.

entry.ety: Lore learning + man
entry.def: An instructor.

entries.entry: Lo*ret"o nunsorLo*ret"to nuns . From Loreto, a city in Italy famous for its Holy House, said to be that in which Jesus lived, brought by angels from Nazareth R. C. Ch Members of a congregation of nuns founded by Mrs. Mary Teresa Ball, near Dublin, Ireland, in 1822, and now spread over Ireland, India, Canada, and the United States. The nuns are called also Ladies of Loreto. They are engaged in teaching girls.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: In France, a name for a woman who is supported by her lovers, and devotes herself to idleness, show, and pleasure; -- so called from the church of Notre Dame de Lorette, in Paris, near which many of them resided.

entry.ety: From Loreto in Italy
entry.def: One of an order of nuns founded in 1812 at Loretto, in Kentucky. The members of the order (called also Sisters of Loretto, or Friends of Mary at the Foot of the Cross) devote themselves to the cause of education and the care of destitute orphans, their labors being chiefly confined to the western United States.
A Loreto nun.

entries.entry: Lor`gnette" n. F An opera glass; pl. elaborate double eyeglasses.

entry.def: Same as Lory.

entries.entry:
Lo*ri"ca n.; pl.Loricæ #. L., lit., a corselet of thongs, fr. lorum thong
Anc. Armor A cuirass, originally of leather, afterward of plates of metal or horn sewed on linen or the like.
Chem Lute{1} for protecting vessels from the fire.
Zoöl The protective case or shell of an infusorian or rotifer.

entry.ety: NL. See Loricate
entry.def: A suborder of edentates, covered with bony plates, including the armadillos.
The crocodilia.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Loricated; p. pr. & vb. n. Loricating
entry.ety: L. loricatus, p. p. of loricare to clothe in mail, to cover with plastering, fr. lorica a leather cuirass, a plastering, fr. lorum thong
entry.def: To cover with some protecting substance, as with lute{1}, a crust, coating, or plates.

entry.ety: See Loricate v.
entry.def: Covered with a shell or exterior made of plates somewhat like a coat of mail, as in the armadillo.
An animal covered with bony scales, as crocodiles among reptiles, and the pangolins among mammals.

entry.ety: L. loricatio
entry.def: The act of loricating; the protecting substance put on; a covering of scales or plates.

Any one numerous species of small brush-tongued parrots or lories, found mostly in Australia, New Guinea and the adjacent islands, with some forms in the East Indies. They are arboreal in their habits and feed largely upon the honey of flowers. They belong to Trichoglossus Loriculus, and several allied genera.

entry.ety: OF. lormier loremier, fr. LL. loranum bridle, L. lorum thong, the rein of a bridle
entry.def: A maker of bits, spurs, and metal mounting for bridles and saddles; hence, a saddler.

entry.ety: See 3d Lore
entry.def: Instructive discourse.

entry.ety: F., fr. OF. loriou, for l'oriol oriol l' being the article. The same word as oriole. See Oriole
entry.def: The golden oriole of Europe. See Oriole.

entry.ety: Loris, or lori, the indigenous East Indian name
entry.def: Any one of several species of small lemurs of the genus Stenops. They have long, slender limbs and large eyes, and are arboreal in their habits. The slender loris (Stenops gracilis), of Ceylon, in one of the best known species.

entry.ety: Strong p. p. of Lose. See Lose Forlorn

sn.def: Lost; undone; ruined.
sn.q: If thou readest, thou art lorn.

sn.def: Forsaken; abandoned; solitary; bereft; as, a lone, lorn woman.

entries.entry:
Lor"rie Lor"ry
n.; pl.Lorries #. Prob. from lurry to pull or lug
A small cart or wagon moving on rails, as those used on the tramways in mines to carry coal or rubbish; also, a barrow or truck for shifting baggage, as at railway stations.
A motorized wheeled land vehicle, esp. a large one, with a cab for the driver and a separate rear compartment for transporting freight; called truck in the U. S. Brit camion.
a large low horse-drawn wagon without sides. wns=1

Lo"ry ☞ The lory, or louri, of South Africa is the white-crested plantain eater or turacou. See Turacou. n.; pl.Lories #. Hind. & Malay. lūrī nūrī
Zoöl Any one of many species of small parrots of the family Trichoglossidæ, generally having the tongue papillose at the tip, and the mandibles straighter and less toothed than in common parrots. They are found in the East Indies, Australia, New Guinea, and the adjacent islands. They feed mostly on soft fruits and on the honey of flowers.

entry.def: Praise. See Loos.
Such as can be lost.
See Lozenge.

entry.cs: To lose ground to fall behind; to suffer gradual loss or disadvantage. To lose heart to lose courage; to become timid. “The mutineers lost heart.” Macaulay. To lose one's head to be thrown off one's balance; to lose the use of one's good sense or judgment, through fear, anger, or other emotion.
entry.ety: OE. losien to loose, be lost, lose, AS. losian to become loose; akin to OE. leosen to lose, p. p. loren lorn, AS. leósan p. p. lorenin comp.), D. verliezen, G. verlieren, Dan. forlise, Sw. förlisa, förlora, Goth. fraliusan, also to E. loose, a & v., L. luere to loose, Gr. ly`ein, Skr. lū to cut. √127. Cf. Analysis Palsy Solve Forlorn Leasing Loose Loss

sn.def: To part with unintentionally or unwillingly, as by accident, misfortune, negligence, penalty, forfeit, etc.; to be deprived of; as, to lose money from one's purse or pocket, or in business or gaming; to lose an arm or a leg by amputation; to lose men in battle.
sn.q: Fair Venus wept the sad disaster Of having lost her favorite dove.

sn.def: To cease to have; to possess no longer; to suffer diminution of; as, to lose one's relish for anything; to lose one's health.
sn.q: If the salt hath lost his savor, wherewith shall it be salted?

sn.def: Not to employ; to employ ineffectually; to throw away; to waste; to squander; as, to lose a day; to lose the benefits of instruction.
sn.q: The unhappy have but hours, and these they lose.

sn.def: To wander from; to miss, so as not to be able to and; to go astray from; as, to lose one's way.
sn.q: He hath lost his fellows.

sn.def: To ruin; to destroy; as destroy; as, the ship was lost on the ledge.
sn.q: The woman that deliberates is lost.

sn.def: To be deprived of the view of; to cease to see or know the whereabouts of; as, he lost his companion in the crowd.
sn.q: Like following life thro' creatures you dissect, You lose it in the moment you detect.

sn.def: To fail to obtain or enjoy; to fail to gain or win; hence, to fail to catch with the mind or senses; to miss; as, I lost a part of what he said.
sn.q: He shall in no wise lose his reward.
I fought the battle bravely which I lost, And lost it but to Macedonians.

sn.def: To cause to part with; to deprive of.
sn.q: How should you go about to lose him a wife he loves with so much passion?

entry.sn:
