To prevent from gaining or obtaining. O false heart! thou hadst almost betrayed me to eternal flames, and lost me this glory. In the excitement of such a discovery, many scholars lost their heads. To lose one's self To lose one's self. To forget or mistake the bearing of surrounding objects; as, to lose one's self in a great city.
To have the perceptive and rational power temporarily suspended; as, we lose ourselves in sleep. To lose sight of.
To cease to see; as, to lose sight of the land.
To overlook; to forget; to fail to perceive; as, he lost sight of the issue.

entry.def: To suffer loss, disadvantage, or defeat; to be worse off, esp. as the result of any kind of contest.
entry.q: We 'll . . . hear poor rogues Talk of court news; and we'll talk with them too, Who loses and who wins; who's in, who's out.

entry.ety: From the root of lose loss. √127. Cf. Lorel
entry.def: One who loses by sloth or neglect; a worthless person; a lorel.
entry.q: One sad losel soils a name for aye.

entry.def: Wasteful; slothful.

entry.ety: OF. losengier losengeor, fr. losengier to deceive, flatter, losenge, flattery, Pr. lauzenga, fr. L. laus praise. Cf. Lozenge
entry.def: A flatterer; a deceiver; a cozener.
entry.q: To a fair pair of gallows, there to end their lives with shame, as a number of such other losengers had done.

entry.ety: OF
entry.def: Flattery; deceit; trickery.

sn.def: One who loses; as, the loser pays for a round of beer.
A person who is habitually unsuccessful at some endeavor, such as employment or personal relationships.
A plan or strategy unlikely to succeed.

entry.ety: See Losenger
entry.def: Given to flattery or deceit; flattering; cozening.
entry.q: Amongst the many simoniacal that swarmed in the land, Herbert, Bishop of Thetford, must not be forgotten; nick-named Losing, that is, the Flatterer.

entry.ety: See Lose v. t.
entry.def: Causing or likely to cause a loss; as, a losing game or business; a losing strategy.
entry.q: Who strive to sit out losing hands are lost.

entry.def: In a manner to incur loss.
something lost, especially money lost at gambling. Inverse of winnings.

cs.cd: to make a loss good; also, to sustain a loss without sinking under it.
to be in a state of uncertainty.

entry.ety: AS. los loss, losing, fr. leósan to lose. √127. See Lose v. t.

sn.def: The act of losing; failure; destruction; privation; as, the loss of property; loss of money by gaming; loss of health or reputation.
sn.q: Assured loss before the match be played.

sn.def: The state of losing or having lost; the privation, defect, misfortune, harm, etc., which ensues from losing.
sn.q: Though thou repent, yet I have still the loss.

sn.def: That which is lost or from which one has parted; waste; -- opposed to gain or increase; as, the loss of liquor by leakage was considerable.
The state of being lost or destroyed; especially, the wreck or foundering of a ship or other vessel.
Failure to gain or win; as, loss of a race or battle.
Failure to use advantageously; as, loss of time.
Killed, wounded, and captured persons, or captured property.

Destruction or diminution of value, if brought about in a manner provided for in the insurance contract (as destruction by fire or wreck, damage by water or smoke), or the death or injury of an insured person; also, the sum paid or payable therefor; as, the losses of the company this year amount to a million of dollars.

entry.def: something lost, especially money lost at gambling. Inverse of winnings.
Detrimental.
an article of merchandise sold at a loss in order to draw customers.
Free from loss.

The compression of binary data into a form which, when it is re-expanded, has most, but not all, of the original information. It is used primarily for compression of images and sounds, and is designed to provide a high degree of compression at the cost of a slight loss of data. It is expemplified by the JPEG compression standard. Images compressed by a lossy compression algorithm are re-expanded into an image close, but not identical to the original image; the difference between the original and the reconstructed image may be imperceptible to normal viewing by the eye.

cs.cd: the difference between the motion of a driver and that of a follower, due to the yielding of parts or looseness of joints.

entry.ety: Prop. p. p. of OE. losien. See Lose v. t.

sn.def: Parted with unwillingly or unintentionally; not to be found; missing; as, a lost book or sheep.
Parted with; no longer held or possessed; as, a lost limb; lost honor.
Not employed or enjoyed; thrown away; employed ineffectually; wasted; squandered; as, a lost day; a lost opportunity or benefit.
Having wandered from, or unable to find, the way; bewildered; perplexed; as, a child lost in the woods; a stranger lost in London.
Ruined or destroyed, either physically or morally; past help or hope; as, a ship lost at sea; a woman lost to virtue; a lost soul.
Hardened beyond sensibility or recovery; alienated; insensible; as, lost to shame; lost to all sense of honor.
Not perceptible to the senses; no longer visible; as, an island lost in a fog; a person lost in a crowd.
Occupied with, or under the influence of, something, so as to be insensible of external things; as, to be lost in thought.

cs.col: To cast in one's lot with
cs.cd: to share the fortunes of.
to use or throw a die, or some other instrument, by the unforeseen turn or position of which, an event is by previous agreement determined.
to determine an event, or make a decision, by drawing one thing from a number whose marks are concealed from the drawer.
to pay taxes according to one's ability. See Scot.

entry.ety: AS. hlot; akin to hleótan to cast lots, OS. hlōt lot, D. lot, G. loos, OHG. lōz, Icel. hlutr, Sw. lott, Dan. lod, Goth. hlauts. Cf. Allot Lotto Lottery

sn.def: That which happens without human design or forethought; chance; accident; hazard; fortune; fate.
sn.q: But save my life, which lot before your foot doth lay.

sn.def: Anything (as a die, pebble, ball, or slip of paper) used in determining a question by chance, or without man's choice or will; as, to cast or draw lots .
sn.q: The lot is cast into the lap, but the whole disposing thereof is of the Lord.
If we draw lots, he speeds.

sn.def: The part, or fate, which falls to one, as it were, by chance, or without his planning.
sn.q: O visions ill foreseen! Each day's lot's Enough to bear.
He was but born to try The lot of man -- to suffer and to die.

sn.def: A separate portion; a number of things taken collectively; all objects sold in a single purchase transaction; as, a lot of stationery; -- colloquially, sometimes of people; as, a sorry lot; a bad lot.
sn.q: I, this winter, met with a very large lot of English heads, chiefly of the reign of James I.

sn.def: A distinct portion or plot of land, usually smaller than a field; as, a building lot in a city.
sn.q: The defendants leased a house and lot in the city of New York.

sn.def: A large quantity or number; a great deal; as, to spend a lot of money; to waste a lot of time on line; lots of people think so.
sn.q: He wrote to her . . . he might be detained in London by a lot of business.

sn.def: A prize in a lottery.

cs.cd: to count or reckon upon; to expect with pleasure.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Lotted; p. pr. & vb. n. Lotting
entry.def: To allot; to sort; to portion.

entry.ety: L. lotus, Gr. �. Cf. Lotus
entry.def: A large tree (Celtis australis), found in the south of Europe. It has a hard wood, and bears a cherrylike fruit. Called also nettle tree.

entry.ety: F. lotte
entry.def: The European burbot.

entry.ety: AS. lutian
entry.def: To lurk; to lie hid.
See Loath Loathly, etc.
strongly opposed.
entry.syn: antipathetic, antipathetical, averse(predicate), averse to(predicate), indisposed(predicate), loath(predicate), opposed.

entry.ety: Name of a character in Rowe's drama, “The Fair Penitent.”
entry.def: A gay seducer of women; a libertine.
Lorraine, a French region rich in iron-ore deposits.

entry.ety: L. lotio, fr. lavare lotum, to wash: cf. F. lotion. See Lave to wash

sn.def: A washing, especially of the skin for the purpose of rendering it fair.
A liquid preparation for bathing the skin, or an injured or diseased part, either for a medicinal purpose, or for improving its appearance.

entry.def: See Lotto.

entry.ety: Malay lūtong
entry.def: An East Indian monkey (Semnopithecus femoralis).

entry.ety: L., fr. Gr. �; � the lotus + � to eat
entry.def: A people visited by Ulysses in his wanderings. They subsisted on the lotus. See Lotus, and Lotus-eater.

entry.ety: NL
entry.def: See Lotus.

entries.entry:
Lot"ter*y ☞ The laws of the United States and of most of the States make private lotteries illegal, except in certain circumstances for charitable institutions; however, many of the states now conduct lotteries tehmselves as a revenue source. n.; pl.Lotteries #.
Lot + -ery, as in brewery, bindery
A scheme for the distribution of prizes by lot or chance; esp., a gaming scheme in which one or more tickets bearing particular numbers draw prizes, and the rest of the tickets are blanks. Fig.: An affair of chance.
Allotment; thing allotted. Obs

entry.ety: F. loto or It. lotto, prop., a lot; of German origin. See Lot
entry.def: A game of chance, played with cards or tickets, on which are inscribed numbers, and any contrivance (as a wheel containing numbered balls) for determining a set of numbers by chance. The player holding a card having on it the set of numbers drawn from the wheel takes the stakes after a certain percentage of them has been deducted for the dealer. In some systems, lesser prizes are awarded for having some but not all of the numbers selected, such as four or five numbers in a six-number drawing. A variety of lotto is called keno. In another variety, the player chooses the numbers for the card or ticket s/he holds. There may be from three to seven different numbers on a card or ticket. In a modern computerized lotto system conducted by state authorities, the player chooses numbers, or allows the computer to choose numbers at random, which are then printed on a ticket that the player holds until the winning number is selected.

entry.ety: L. lotura. See Lotion
entry.def: See Lotion.

cs.cd: a small tree (Diospyros Lotus) of Southern Europe and Asia; also, its rather large bluish black berry, which is called also the date plum.

entry.ety: L. lotus, Gr. lwto`s. Cf. Lote

sd.def: A name of several kinds of water lilies; as Nelumbium speciosum, used in religious ceremonies, anciently in Egypt, and to this day in Asia; Nelumbium luteum, the American lotus; and Nymphæa Lotus and Nymphæa cærulea, the respectively white-flowered and blue-flowered lotus of modern Egypt, which, with Nelumbium speciosum, are figured on its ancient monuments.

The lotus of the lotuseaters, probably a tree found in Northern Africa, Sicily, Portugal, and Spain (Zizyphus Lotus), the fruit of which is mildly sweet. It was fabled by the ancients to make strangers who ate of it forget their native country, or lose all desire to return to it.
The lote, or nettle tree. See Lote.
A genus (Lotus) of leguminous plants much resembling clover.

sn.def: An ornament much used in Egyptian architecture, generally asserted to have been suggested by the Egyptian water lily.

entry.def: One who ate the fruit or leaf of the lotus, and, as a consequence, gave himself up to indolence and daydreams; one of the Lotophagi.
entry.q: The mild-eyed melancholy Lotos-eaters.

entry.def: of questionable taste, decency, or morality; not reputable; as, a louche nightclub; a louche painting.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: Goggles intended to rectify strabismus by permitting vision only directly in front.

entry.ety: OE. loud lud, AS. hlūd; akin to OS. hlūd, D. luid, OHG. lūt, G. laut, L. -clutus, in inclutus, inclitus, celebrated, renowned, cluere to be called, Gr. klyto`s heard, loud, famous, kly`ein to hear, Skr. çru. √41. Cf. Client Listen Slave a serf

sn.def: Having, making, or being a strong or great sound; noisy; striking the ear with great force; as, a loud cry; loud thunder.
sn.q: They were instant with loud voices, requiring that he might be crucified.

sn.def: Clamorous; boisterous.
sn.q: She is loud and stubborn.

sn.def: Emphatic; impressive; urgent; as, a loud call for united effort.
Ostentatious; likely to attract attention; gaudy; as, a loud style of dress; loud colors.
sn.syn: Noisy; boisterous; vociferous; clamorous; obstreperous; turbulent; blustering; vehement.

entry.ety: AS. hlūde
entry.def: With loudness; loudly.
entry.q: To speak loud in public assemblies.

entry.def: Noisy.
In a loud manner.

sn.def: a person who causes trouble by speaking indiscretely.
Aperson who is loud-mouthed.

entry.def: Having a loud voice; talking or sounding noisily; noisily impudent or offensive.
The quality or state of being loud.

A device which converts electrical signals into sounds loud enough to be heard at a distance, usually outdoors; it is used to amplify or transmit over a distance speech from a person, who is typically speaking into a microphone. Sometimes it is used to play recorded speech or music.
entry.syn: speaker, speaker unit, loudspeaker system, speaker system.

entry.def: Having a loud voice; speaking with a loud voice; noisy; clamorous.

entry.ety: See 1st Loch
entry.def: A loch or lake; -- so spelt in Ireland.
of Laugh.

entry.ety: F., gold louis
entry.def: Formerly, a gold coin of France nominally worth twenty shillings sterling, but of varying value; -- first struck in 1640.
a resident of Louisiana.

entry.ety: F., Louis fourteenth
entry.def: Of, pertaining to, or resembling, the art or style of the times of Louis XIV. of France; as, Louis quatorze architecture.
An accomplice; a “pal.”
entry.q: There is no thief without a louk.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Lounged lounjd; p. pr. & vb. n. Lounging loun"jĭng
entry.ety: OE. lungis a tall, slow, awkward fellow, OF. longis longin, said to be fr. Longinus, the name of the centurion who pierced the body of Christ, but with reference also to L. longus long. Cf. Long a.
entry.def: To spend time lazily, whether lolling or idly sauntering; to pass time indolently; to stand, sit, or recline, in an indolent manner.
entry.q: We lounge over the sciences, dawdle through literature, yawn over politics.

sn.def: An idle gait or stroll; the state of reclining indolently; a place of lounging.
sn.q: She went with Lady Stock to a bookseller's whose shop served as a fashionable lounge.

sn.def: A piece of furniture resembling a sofa, upon which one may lie or recline.

entry.def: One who lounges; an idler.
See 1st Loop.

entry.ety: F. Cf. Lusern
entry.def: The Canada lynx. See Lynx.

Any of a variety of small magnifying glasses, having a magnifying power from 2X to 20X, commonly of 10X, which may be held in the hand, or in some cases held within the eyesocket without the use of a hand. It is commonly used by jewelers and watchmakers.

entries.entry:
‖Loup`-ga`rou" n.; pl. Loups-garous # . F., fr. loup wolf + a Teutonic word akin to E. werewolf
A werewolf; a lycanthrope. The superstition of the loup-garou, or werewolf, belongs to the folklore of most modern nations, and has its reflex in the story of “Little Red Riding-hood” and others.

entry.ety: From Loup to leap
entry.def: An enzoötic, often fatal, disease of sheep and other domestic animals, of unknown cause. It is characterized by muscular tremors and spasms, followed by more or less complete paralysis. The principal lesion is an inflammation of the membranes covering the brain and spinal cord.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: The Pomeranian or Spitz dog.

entries.entry: Loups n. pl.; sing. Loup. F., prop., a wolf Ethnol The Pawnees, a tribe of North American Indians whose principal totem was the wolf.

entry.ety: Native name
entry.def: An Asiatic sardine (Clupea Neohowii), valued for its oil.
See Lory.

entries.entry:
Louse ☞ The term is also applied to various other parasites; as, the whale louse, beelouse, horse louse.
Louse fly Zoöl a parasitic dipterous insect of the group Pupipara. Some of them are wingless, as the bee louse. Louse mite Zoöl any one of numerous species of mites which infest mammals and birds, clinging to the hair and feathers like lice. They belong to Myobia Dermaleichus Mycoptes, and several other genera.
lous n.; pl.Lice līs. OE. lous, AS. lūs, pl. lȳs; akin to D. luis, G. laus, OHG. lūs, Icel. lūs, Sw. lus, Dan. luus; perh. so named because it is destructive, and akin to E. lose loose
Zoöl
Any one of numerous species of small, wingless, suctorial, parasitic insects belonging to a tribe (Pediculina), now usually regarded as degraded Hemiptera. To this group belong of the lice of man and other mammals; as, the head louse of man (Pediculus capitis), the body louse Pediculus vestimenti), and the crab louse Phthirius pubis), and many others. See Crab louse Dog louse Cattle louse, etc., under Crab Dog, etc.
Any one of numerous small mandibulate insects, mostly parasitic on birds, and feeding on the feathers. They are known as Mallophaga, or bird lice, though some occur on the hair of mammals. They are usually regarded as degraded Pseudoneuroptera. See Mallophaga.
Any one of the numerous species of aphids, or plant lice. See Aphid.
Any small crustacean parasitic on fishes. See Branchiura, and Ichthvophthira.

entry.def: To clean from lice.
entry.q: You sat andlousedhim.

cs.cd: a plant of the genus Rhinanthus.

entry.def: Any species of Pedicularis, a genus of perennial herbs. It was said to make sheep that fed on it lousy.

entry.ety: From Lousy
entry.def: In a lousy manner; in a mean, paltry manner; scurvily.
The state or quality of being lousy.

sn.def: Infested with lice.
Mean; contemptible; as, lousy knave.
sn.q: Such lousy learning as this is.

sn.def: Very bad; as, to feel lousy; to do a lousy job.

entry.ety: OE. louten luten, AS. lūtan; akin to Icel. lūta, Dan. lude, OHG. lūzēn to lie hid
entry.def: To bend; to box; to stoop.
entry.q: He fair the knight saluted, louting low.

entry.ety: Formerly also written lowt
entry.def: A clownish, awkward fellow; a bumpkin.
To treat as a lout or fool; to neglect; to disappoint.
Clownish; rude; awkward.
entry.q: Loutishclown.

entry.ety: Native names
entry.def: A crested black monkey (Semnopithecus maurus) of Java.

cs.cd: the sloping boards set to shed rainwater outward in openings which are to be left otherwise unfilled; as belfry windows, the openings of a louver, etc.
slatted work.

entry.ety: OE. lover, OF. lover lovier; or l'ouvert the opening, fr. overt ouvert, p. p. of ovrir ouvrir, to open, F. ouvrir. Cf. Overt
entry.def: A small lantern. See Lantern, 2 .

sn.def: Same as louver boards, below

A set of slats resembling louver boards, arranged in a vertical row and attached at each slat end to a frame inserted in or part of a door or window; the slats may be made of wood, plastic, or metal, and the angle of inclination of the slats may be adjustable simultaneously, to allow more or less light or air into the enclosure.

entry.def: To supply with louvers.
supplied with louvers for ventilation; as, a louvered door.
A door having louvers in place of a solid panel, in part or all of the surface of the door.
A window having louvers in place of glass, usually over the entire surface of the window.
Having qualities that excite, or are fitted to excite, love; worthy of love.
entry.q: Elaine the fair, Elaine the lovable, Elaine, the lily maid of Astolat.

entry.ety: F. livèche, fr. L. levisticum ligusticum, a plant indigenous to Liguria, lovage, from Ligusticus Ligustine, Ligurian, Liguria a country of Cisalpine Gaul
entry.def: An umbelliferous plant (Levisticum officinale), sometimes used in medicine as an aromatic stimulant.

entry.note: ☞ Love is often used in the formation of compounds, in most of which the meaning is very obvious; as, love-cracked, love-darting, love-killing, love-linked, love-taught, etc.
entry.cs:
A labor of love a labor undertaken on account of regard for some person, or through pleasure in the work itself, without expectation of reward. Free love the doctrine or practice of consorting with one of the opposite sex, at pleasure, without marriage. See Free love. Free lover one who avows or practices free love. In love in the act of loving; -- said esp. of the love of the sexes; as, to be in love; to fall in love . Love apple Bot the tomato. Love bird Zoöl any one of several species of small, short-tailed parrots, or parrakeets, of the genus Agapornis, and allied genera. They are mostly from Africa. Some species are often kept as cage birds, and are celebrated for the affection which they show for their mates. Love broker a person who for pay acts as agent between lovers, or as a go-between in a sexual intrigue. Shak. Love charm a charm for exciting love. Ld. Lytton. Love child. an illegitimate child. Jane Austen. Love day a day formerly appointed for an amicable adjustment of differences. Obs Piers Plowman. Chaucer. Love drink a love potion; a philter. Chaucer. Love favor something given to be worn in token of love. Love feast a religious festival, held quarterly by some religious denominations, as the Moravians and Methodists, in imitation of the agapæ of the early Christians. Love feat the gallant act of a lover. Shak. Love game a game, as in tennis, in which the vanquished person or party does not score a point. Love grass. G. liebesgras
Bot Any grass of the genus Eragrostis. Love-in-a-mist. Bot An herb of the Buttercup family (Nigella Damascena) having the flowers hidden in a maze of finely cut bracts. The West Indian Passiflora fœtida, which has similar bracts. Love-in-idleness Bot a kind of violet; the small pansy. A little western flower, Before milk-white, now purple with love's wound; And maidens call it love-in-idleness. Shak. Love juice juice of a plant supposed to produce love. Shak. Love knot a knot or bow, as of ribbon; -- so called from being used as a token of love, or as a pledge of mutual affection. Milman. Love lass a sweetheart. Love letter a letter of courtship. Shak. Love-lies-bleeding Bot a species of amaranth (Amarantus melancholicus). Love match a marriage brought about by love alone. Love potion a compounded draught intended to excite love, or venereal desire. Love rites sexual intercourse. Pope Love scene an exhibition of love, as between lovers on the stage. Love suit courtship. Shak. Of all loves for the sake of all love; by all means. Obs “Mrs. Arden desired him of all loves to come back again.” Holinshed.
The god of loveorThe Love god
Cupid. To make love to engage in sexual intercourse; -- a euphemism. To make love to to express affection for; to woo. “If you will marry, make your loves to me.” Shak. To play for love to play a game, as at cards, without stakes. “A game at piquet for love.” Lamb.
entry.ety: OE. love luve, AS. lufe lufu; akin to E. lief believe, L. lubet libet, it pleases, Skr. lubh to be lustful. See Lief

sn.def: A feeling of strong attachment induced by that which delights or commands admiration; preëminent kindness or devotion to another; affection; tenderness; as, the love of brothers and sisters.
sn.q: Of all the dearest bonds we prove Thou countest sons' and mothers' love Most sacred, most Thine own.

sn.def: Especially, devoted attachment to, or tender or passionate affection for, one of the opposite sex.
sn.q: He on his side Leaning half-raised, with looks of cordial love Hung over her enamored.

sn.def: Courtship; -- chiefly in the phrase to make love, i. e., to court, to woo, to solicit union in marriage.
sn.q: Demetrius . . . Made love to Nedar's daughter, Helena, And won her soul.

sn.def: Affection; kind feeling; friendship; strong liking or desire; fondness; good will; -- opposed to hate; often with of and an object.
sn.q: Love, and health to all.
Smit with the love of sacred song.
The love of science faintly warmed his breast.

sn.def: Due gratitude and reverence to God.
sn.q: Keep yourselves in the love of God.

sn.def: The object of affection; -- often employed in endearing address; as, he held his love in his arms; his greatest love was reading.
sn.q: Trust me,love.
Open the temple gates unto my love.

sn.def: Cupid, the god of love; sometimes, Venus.
sn.q: Such was his form as painters, when they show Their utmost art, on naked Lores bestow.
Therefore do nimble-pinioned doves draw Love.

sn.def: A thin silk stuff.
A climbing species of Clematis Clematis Vitalba).
Nothing; no points scored on one side; -- used in counting score at tennis, etc.
sn.q: He won the match by three sets to love.

sn.def: Sexual intercourse; -- a euphemism.
sn.syn: Affection; friendship; kindness; tenderness; fondness; delight.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Loved lŭvd; p. pr. & vb. n. Loving
entry.ety: AS. lufian. √124. See Love n.

sn.def: To have a feeling of love for; to regard with affection or good will; as, to love one's children and friends; to love one's country; to love one's God.
sn.q: Thou shalt love the Lord thy God with all thy heart, and with all thy soul, and with all thy mind.
Thou shalt love thy neighbor as thy self.

sn.def: To regard with passionate and devoted affection, as that of one sex for the other.
To take delight or pleasure in; to have a strong liking or desire for, or interest in; to be pleased with; to like; as, to love books; to love adventures.
sn.q: Wit, eloquence, and poetry. Arts which I loved.

entry.def: To have the feeling of love; to be in love.
See Lovable.
A small Australian parakeet (Melopsittacus undulatus) usually light green with black and yellow markings in the wild but bred in many colors; also called the budgie.
entry.syn: budgerigar, budgereegah, budgerygah, budgie, grass parakeet, shell parakeet, Melopsittacus undulatus.

sn.def: small African parrot noted for showing affection for their mates.

entry.sn: p. p. of love v. t.. Opposite of unloved.Narrower terms: admired, esteemed Also See: wanted.

entry.ety: Love + OF. druerie. Cf. Druery
entry.def: Affection.
One who is loved.
entry.q: The lover andlovee.

entry.def: Full of love.

sn.def: Void of love; void of tenderness or kindness.
Not attracting love; unattractive.
sn.q: These are ill-favored to see to; and yet, as loveless as they be, they are not without some medicinable virtues.

entry.ety: From Lovely
entry.def: In manner to excite love; amiably.

entry.ety: From Lovely
entry.def: The state or quality of being lovely.
entry.q: If there is such a native loveliness in the sex as to make them victorious when in the wrong, how resistless their power when they are on the side of truth!

entry.def: A long lock of hair hanging prominently by itself; an earlock; -- worn by men of fashion in the reigns of Elizabeth and James I.
entry.q: A long lovelock and long hair he wore.

entry.def: Forsaken by one's love.
entry.q: The lovelorn nightingale.

entry.ety: AS. luflic

sn.def: Having such an appearance as excites, or is fitted to excite, love; beautiful; charming; very pleasing in form, looks, tone, or manner.
sn.q: Lovelyto look on.
Not one so fair of face, of speech so lovely.
If I had such a tire, this face of mine Were full as lovely as is this of hers.

sn.def: Lovable; amiable; having qualities of any kind which excite, or are fitted to excite, love or friendship.
sn.q: A most lovely gentlemanlike man.

sn.def: Loving; tender.
sn.q: Alovelykiss.
Many a lovely look on them he cast.

sn.def: Very pleasing; -- applied loosely to almost anything which is not grand or merely pretty; as, a lovely view; a lovely valley; a lovely melody.
sn.q: Indeed these fields Are lovely lovelier not the Elysian lawns.
sn.syn: Beautiful; charming; delightful; delectable; enchanting; lovable; amiable.

entry.def: In a manner to please, or to excite love.

sn.def: Courtship.
Sexual intercourse.

entry.def: One who deals in affairs of love.
a fabled drink credited with magical power; it can make the one who takes it love the one who gave it.
a fabled drink credited with magical power; it can make the one who takes it love the one who gave it.

sn.def: One who loves; one who is in love; -- usually limited, in the singular, to a person of the male sex.
sn.q: Love is blind, and lovers can not see The pretty follies that themselves commit.

sn.def: A friend; one strongly attached to another; one who greatly desires the welfare of any person or thing; as, a lover of his country.
sn.q: I slew my best lover for the good of Rome.

sn.def: One who has a strong liking for anything, as books, science, or music.
sn.q: Aloverof knowledge.

sn.def: One who is involved in a sexual relationship with another; as, she took a lover.

entry.def: See Louver.
As lovers do.
entry.q: As they sat down here loverwise.

sn.def: Languishing with love or amorous desire; as, a love-sick maid.
sn.q: To the dear mistress of my love-sick mind.

sn.def: Originating in, or expressive of, languishing love.
sn.q: Where nightingales their love-sick ditty sing.

entry.def: The state of being love-sick.

entry.ety: AS. lufsum
entry.def: Lovely.
a song about love or expressing love for another person.
something given as a token of love.

sn.def: Affectionate.
sn.q: The fairest and most loving wife in Greece.

sn.def: Expressing love or kindness; as, loving words.

entries.entry:
Lov"ing cup`. A large ornamental drinking vessel having two or more handles, intended to pass from hand to hand, as at a banquet.
an award resembling a loving cup1} that is given to the winner of a competition.

entry.def: Tender regard; mercy; favor.
With love; affectionately.
Affection; kind regard.
entry.q: The only two bands of good will, loveliness and lovingness.

entry.def: A lover.
strong imp. of Laugh.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Lowed lōd; p. pr. & vb. n. Lowing
entry.ety: OE. lowen, AS. hlōwan; akin to D. loeijen, OHG. hlōjan hluojan
entry.def: To make the calling sound of cows and other bovine animals; to moo.
entry.q: The lowing herd wind slowly o'er the lea.

entry.def: The calling sound ordinarily made by cows and other bovine animals.
entry.q: Talking voices and the law of herds.

entry.ety: AS. hlāw; akin to Goth. hlaiw a grave, hlains a hill, and to E. lean to incline
entry.def: A hill; a mound; a grave.

entry.ety: Icel. log logi; akin to E. light n.
entry.def: Fire; a flame; a light.
To burn; to blaze.

entry.note: ☞ Low is often used in the formation of compounds which require no special explanation; as, low-arched, low-browed, low-crowned, low-heeled, low-lying, low-priced, low-roofed, low-toned, low-voiced, and the like.
entry.cs:
Low Church. See High Church, under High. Low Countries the Netherlands.
Low German Low Latin
etc. See under German Latin, etc. Low life humble life. Low milling a process of making flour from grain by a single grinding and by siftings. Low relief. See Bas-relief. Low side window Arch a peculiar form of window common in mediæval churches, and of uncertain use. Windows of this sort are narrow, near the ground, and out of the line of the windows, and in many different situations in the building. Low spirits despondency. Low steam steam having a low pressure. Low steel steel which contains only a small proportion of carbon, and can not be hardened greatly by sudden cooling. Low Sunday the Sunday next after Easter; -- popularly so called. Low tide the farthest ebb of the tide; the tide at its lowest point; low water. Low water. The lowest point of the ebb tide; a low stage of the in a river, lake, etc. Steam Boiler The condition of an insufficient quantity of water in the boiler.
Low water alarmorLow water indicator
Steam Boiler a contrivance of various forms attached to a boiler for giving warning when the water is low. Low water mark that part of the shore to which the waters recede when the tide is the lowest. Bouvier. Low wine a liquor containing about 20 percent of alcohol, produced by the first distillation of wash; the first run of the still; -- often in the plural.
entry.ety: OE. low louh lah, Icel. lāgr; akin to Sw. låg, Dan. lav, D. laag, and E. lie. See Lie to be prostrate

sn.def: Occupying an inferior position or place; not high or elevated; depressed in comparison with something else; as, low ground; a low flight.
Not rising to the usual height; as, a man of low stature; a low fence.
Near the horizon; as, the sun is low at four o'clock in winter, and six in summer.
Sunk to the farthest ebb of the tide; as, low tide.
Beneath the usual or remunerative rate or amount, or the ordinary value; moderate; cheap; as, the low price of corn; low wages.
Not loud; as, a low voice; a low sound.
Depressed in the scale of sounds; grave; as, a low pitch; a low note.
Made, as a vowel, with a low position of part of the tongue in relation to the palate; as, ă (ăm), � (�ll. See Guide to Pronunciation, §§ 5, 10, 11.
Near, or not very distant from, the equator; as, in the low northern latitudes.
Numerically small; as, a low number.
Wanting strength or animation; depressed; dejected; as, low spirits; low in spirits.
Depressed in condition; humble in rank; as, men of low condition; the lower classes.
sn.q: Why but to keep ye low and ignorant ?

sn.def: Mean; vulgar; base; dishonorable; as, a person of low mind; a low trick or stratagem.
Not elevated or sublime; not exalted in thought or diction; as, a low comparison.
sn.q: In comparison of these divine writers, the noblest wits of the heathen world are low and dull.

sn.def: Submissive; humble.
sn.q: Lowreverence.

sn.def: Deficient in vital energy; feeble; weak; as, a low pulse; made low by sickness.
Moderate; not intense; not inflammatory; as, low heat; a low temperature; a low fever.
Smaller than is reasonable or probable; as, a low estimate.
Not rich, high seasoned, or nourishing; plain; simple; as, a low diet.

entry.def: The lowest trump, usually the deuce; the lowest trump dealt or drawn.

sn.def: In a low position or manner; not aloft; not on high; near the ground.
Under the usual price; at a moderate price; cheaply; as, he sold his wheat low .
In a low or mean condition; humbly; meanly.
In time approaching our own.
sn.q: In that part of the world which was first inhabited, even as low down as Abraham's time, they wandered with their flocks and herds.

sn.def: With a low voice or sound; not loudly; gently; as, to speak low .
sn.q: The . . . odorous wind Breathes low between the sunset and the moon.

sn.def: With a low musical pitch or tone.
sn.q: Can sing both high and low.

sn.def: In subjection, poverty, or disgrace; as, to be brought low by oppression, by want, or by vice.

In a path near the equator, so that the declination is small, or near the horizon, so that the altitude is small; -- said of the heavenly bodies with reference to the diurnal revolution; as, the moon runs low, that is, is comparatively near the horizon when on or near the meridian.

entry.def: To depress; to lower.
The Australian moundbird (Leipoa ocellata); it incubates eggs naturally in sandy mounds.
entry.syn: mallee fowl, mallee-fowl, leipoa, Leipoa ocellata.

entry.def: A poker game in which the lowest-ranking hand wins.
to give a deceptively low estimate of the price of (merchandise or services); -- a sales tactic to induce a person to buy.

entry.ety: Low a flame + bell

sn.def: A bell used in fowling at night, to frighten birds, and, with a sudden light, to make them fly into a net.
sn.q: The fowler's lowbell robs the lark of sleep.

sn.def: A bell to be hung on the neck of a sheep.
sn.q: A lowbell hung about a sheep's . . . neck.

entry.def: To frighten, as with a lowbell.
Born in a low condition or rank; -- opposed to highborn.
A chest of drawers not more than four feet high; -- applied commonly to the lower half of a tallboy from which the upper half has been removed.
Bred, or like one bred, in a low condition of life; characteristic or indicative of such breeding; rude; impolite; vulgar; as, a lowbred fellow; a lowbred remark.
having relatively few calories.
having a lower than normal ceiling.
Not placing a high estimate on ecclesiastical organizations or forms; -- applied especially to Episcopalians, and opposed to high-church. See High Church, under High.
The principles of the low-church party.

entries.entry: Low"-church`man n.; pl.-men. One who holds low-church principles.

entry.def: The state of being a low-churchman.

entry.sn: Occupying the lowest socioeconomic position in a society. Contrasted with middle-class and upper-class.Narrower terms: propertyless, wage-earning, working-class, blue-collar Also See: lowborn proletarian propertyless. lower-class (vs. upper-class).

entry.def: inexpensive; cheap. Opposite of expensive.

sn.def: having a neckline low enough to expose part of the breast; -- of a woman's garment; as, a low-cut party dress.
having a back exposing skin between the shoulder blades.

entry.def: true confidential information.
entry.syn: details, dope, poop, inside dope, inside information.

entry.def: of the most contemptible kind; contemptible; mean; base; vile; -- of people or the actions of people; as, a lowdown sneak thief.
entry.syn: abject, base, despicable, low, lowdown, miserable, vile.

sn.def: having the soulful feeling of early blues; -- of jazz.

entry.def: producing little emission of atmospheric pollutants; as, a low-emission vehicle.
Compar. of Low a.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Lowered; p. pr. & vb. n. Lowering
entry.ety: From Low a.

sn.def: To let descend by its own weight, as something suspended; to let down; as, to lower a bucket into a well; to lower a sail or a boat; sometimes, to pull down; as, to lower a flag.
sn.q: Lowered softly with a threefold cord of love Down to a silent grave.

sn.def: To reduce the height of; as, to lower a fence or wall; to lower a chimney or turret.
To depress as to direction; as, to lower the aim of a gun; to make less elevated as to object; as, to lower one's ambition, aspirations, or hopes.
To reduce the degree, intensity, strength, etc., of; as, to lower the temperature of anything; to lower one's vitality; to lower distilled liquors.
To bring down; to humble; as, to lower one's pride.
To reduce in value, amount, etc.; as, to lower the price of goods, the rate of interest, etc.

entry.def: To fall; to sink; to grow less; to diminish; to decrease; as, the river lowered as rapidly as it rose.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Lowered; p. pr. & vb. n. Lowering
entry.ety: OE. lowren luren; cf. D. loeren, LG. luren. G. lauern to lurk, to be on the watch, and E. leer lurk

sn.def: To be dark, gloomy, and threatening, as clouds; to be covered with dark and threatening clouds, as the sky; to show threatening signs of approach, as a tempest.
sn.q: All the clouds that lowered upon our house.

sn.def: To frown; to look sullen.
sn.q: But sullen discontent sat lowering on her face.

sn.def: Cloudiness; gloominess.
A frowning; sullenness.
relating to small or noncapital letters which were kept in the lower half of a compositor's type case.

entry.def: Pertaining to, or kept in, the lower case; -- used to denote the small letters, in distinction from capitals and small capitals; as, lowercase letters a and b and c etc.. Contrasted with uppercase. See the Note under 1st Case n., 3.
same as low-class. Contrasted with middle-class and upper-class.
an undergraduate who is not yet a senior.
pointed downward; as, with lowered eyes. Opposite of raised.
Dark and threatening; gloomy; sullen; as, lowering clouds or sky.
In a lowering manner; with cloudiness or threatening gloom.
the limit on the lower (or southernmost) side of something.
occupying the lower part of the middle socioeconomic range in a society.

entry.mord: Irreg. superl. of Low. Cf. Uppermost Foremost, etc
entry.def: Lowest.
inferior in rank or status.
entry.syn: junior-grade, inferior, lower, lowly, petty(prenominal), secondary, subaltern, subordinate.

entry.def: Cloudy; gloomy; lowering; as, a lowery sky; lowery weather.
strong imp. of Laugh.
entry.ety: Cf. 1st Low and 2d Lough

entry.def: inferior; as, low-grade ore. Opposite of high-grade.
The calling sound made by cows and other bovine animals.
Somewhat low.
See Louk.
restrained in style or quality; not flashy or intense; understated; as, a little masterpiece of low-keyed eloquence.

cs.cd: Belgium and Holland; the Netherlands; also, the southern part of Scotland.

entry.def: Land which is low with respect to the neighboring country; a low or level country; -- opposed to highland.
A native or inhabitant of the Lowlands, especially of the Lowlands of Scotland, as distinguished from Highlander.

sn.def: weak; not intense; as, low-level radiation.

entry.sn: lower in rank or importance.Narrower terms: adjunct, assistant; associate(prenominal; buck ; deputy(prenominal), proxy(prenominal; subject, dependent ; subservient ] [Narrower terms: under(prenominal; ruled ; secondary Also See inferior, subordinate. Antonym: dominant. subordinate.

sn.def: at a low level in rank or importance; as, a low-level job; low-level discussions.
occurring at a relatively low altitude; as, a low-level strafing run; low-level bombing.

entry.def: A lowly state.
In a lowly place or manner; humbly.
entry.q: Thinking lowlily of himself and highly of those better than himself.

entry.ety: From Lowly

sn.def: The state or quality of being lowly; humility; humbleness of mind.
sn.q: Walk . . . with all lowliness and meekness.

sn.def: Low condition, especially as to manner of life.
sn.q: The lowliness of my fortune has not brought me to flatter vice.

entry.def: Characteristic of, or like, one bred in a low and vulgar condition of life; mean; dishonorable; contemptible; as, low-lived dishonesty.

entry.ety: Low a. + -ly

sn.def: Not high; not elevated in place; low.
sn.q: Lowlylands.

sn.def: Low in rank or social importance.
sn.q: One common right the great and lowly claims.

sn.def: Not lofty or sublime; humble.
sn.q: These rural poems, and their lowly strain.

sn.def: Having a low esteem of one's own worth; humble; meek; free from pride.
sn.q: Take my yoke upon you, and learn of me, for I am meek and lowly in heart.

sn.def: In a low manner; humbly; meekly; modestly.
sn.q: Belowlywise.

sn.def: In a low condition; meanly.
sn.q: I will show myself highly fed, and lowly taught.

sn.def: having a small elevation above the ground or horizon or sea level; as, low-lying clouds.
at a low elevation above sea level.

entry.def: Inclined in mind to low or unworthy things; showing a base mind.
entry.q: Low-minded and immoral.
All old religious jealousies were condemned as low-minded infirmities.

entry.def: The quality of being low-minded; meanness; baseness.

entry.ety: See Loon
entry.def: A low fellow.
Cut low in the neck; decollete; low-cut; -- said of a woman's dress.
The state or quality of being low.

entry.sn: low in pitch or frequency; -- used of sounds and voices. Opposite of high-pitched.Narrower terms: alto, contralto ; baritone ; bass, deep ; contrabass, double-bass ; throaty low.

sn.def: set at a low angle or slant; having a low degree of pitch; as, a low-pitched roof.

entry.def: producing little pollution, especially air pollution; as, a low-polluting electric car.

cs.cd: a steam engine in which low steam is used; often applied to a condensing engine even when steam at high pressure is used. See Steam engine.

sn.def: Having, employing, or exerting, a low degree of pressure.
same as easygoing, 4; as, a low-pressure salesman.

entry.def: same as low-cost.
producing images that are not sharply defined; -- of optical instruments or image display devices. Opposite of high-resolution.

entries.entry: low-rise adj. Lower than the highest heights; -- used of buildings of one or only a few stories; as, a low-rise apartment building.Narrower terms: three-story, three-storied, three-storey, three-storeyed high-rise

entry.def: An open box car used on railroads. Compare Lorry.
short and thick; especially having short legs and heavy musculature; -- of people.
entry.syn: chunky, dumpy, squat, squatty, stubby, stumpy, stocky.

entry.def: Deficient in animation and courage; dejected; depressed; dispirited; not sprightly.
entry.syn: depressed, dispirited, down(predicate), downcast, downhearted, low.

entries.entry: Low steel. See under Low.

entry.def: Furnished or built with short studs; as, a low-studded house or room.
causing little foam to form; -- used of e.g. detergents. Contrasted with high-sudsing.
not involving high technology; using long-established technology. Opposite of high-tech.
subjected to or capable of operating under relative low voltage. Contrasted with high-tension.
Having one's thoughts directed toward mean or insignificant subjects.
relatively low in volume; soft; -- of sound; as, making low-toned noises with their mouths that went as an undercurrent of sound. Opposite of loud.

sn.def: subjected to or capable of operating under relative low voltage, usually considered as no greater than 250 volts. Contrasted with high-voltage.

entry.def: a hand loom in which the warp is carried horizontally; for weaving tapestry.

cs.cd: a line on the surface of a sphere, which always makes an equal angle with every meridian; the rhumb line. It is the line on which a ship sails when her course is always in the direction of one and the same point of the compass.

entry.ety: Gr. � slanting, oblique + � a running, course; cf. F. loxodromique
entry.def: Pertaining to sailing on rhumb lines; as, loxodromic tables.
The art or method of sailing on the loxodromic or rhumb line.
The act or process of tracing a loxodromic curve; the act of moving as if in a loxodromic curve.

entry.ety: Cf. F. loxodromic
entry.def: The science of loxodromics.
A long, narrow spade for stony lands.

entry.ety: F. loyal, OF. loial leial, L. legalis, fr. lex legis, law. See Legal, and cf. Leal

sn.def: Faithful to law; upholding the lawful authority; faithful and true to the lawful government; faithful to the prince or sovereign to whom one is subject; unswerving in allegiance.
sn.q: Welcome, sir John ! But why come you in arms ? To help King Edward in his time of storm, As every loyal subject ought to do.

sn.def: True to any person or persons to whom one owes fidelity, especially as a wife to her husband, lovers to each other, and friend to friend; constant; faithful to a cause or a principle.
sn.q: Your true and loyal wife.
Unhappy both, but loyaltheir loves.

entry.def: A person who adheres to his sovereign or to the lawful authority; especially, one who maintains his allegiance to his prince or government, and defends his cause in times of revolt or revolution.
In a loyal manner; faithfully.
Loyalty.

entry.note: ☞ “Loyalty . . . expresses, properly, that fidelity which one owes according to law, and does not necessarily include that attachment to the royal person, which, happily, we in England have been able further to throw into the word.”
entry.ety: Cf. F. loyauté. See Loyal, and cf. Legality
entry.def: The state or quality of being loyal; fidelity to a superior, or to duty, love, etc.
entry.q: He had such loyalty to the king as the law required.
Not withstanding all the subtle bait With which those Amazons his love still craved, To his one love his loyalty he saved.

cs.cd: the coach of a dowager, having her coat of arms painted on a lozenge.
a kind of molding, used in Norman architecture, characterized by lozenge-shaped ornaments.

entry.ety: F. lozange losange; perh. the same as OF. losengef flattery, praise, the heraldic sense being the oldest (cf. E. hatchment blazon). Cf. Losenger Laudable

sd.def: A diamond-shaped figure usually with the upper and lower angles slightly acute, borne upon a shield or escutcheon. Cf. Fusil.
A form of the escutcheon used by women instead of the shield which is used by men.

sn.def: A figure with four equal sides, having two acute and two obtuse angles; a rhomb.
Anything in the form of lozenge.
A small cake of sugar and starch, flavored, and often medicated. -- originally in the form of a lozenge.

entry.def: Having the form of a lozenge or rhomb.
entry.q: The lozenged panes of a very small latticed window.

entry.ety: F. losangé. See Lozenge
entry.def: Divided into lozenge-shaped compartments, as the field or a bearing, by lines drawn in the direction of the bend sinister.

entry.ety: long-playing
entry.def: a long-playing phonograph record; designed to be played at 33.3 rpm.
a square plate bearing the letter L that is attached to both ends of a car to indicate that the driver is a learner.
The chemical symbol for lawrencium, a transuranic element of atomic number 103.
lysergic acid diethylamide, a powerful hallucinogenic drug.
A term attached to the name of a company that is organized to give its owners limited liability; it corresponds to Inc. in the United States.
long-term memory, the term for the set of neurons and neural processes responsible for the general store of information remembered for more than a day.
See Loo.
The chemical symbol for lutetium.

entry.ety: See Lubber
entry.def: A lubber.
Lubberly.

cs.cd: a name given in contempt by sailors to a person who lives on land.
a large, stout, clumsy grasshopper; esp., Brachystola magna, from the Rocky Mountain plains, and Romalea microptera, which is injurious to orange trees in Florida.
a hole in the floor of the “top,” next the mast, through which sailors may go aloft without going over the rim by the futtock shrouds. It is considered by seamen as only fit to be used by lubbers.
a line or point in the compass case indicating the head of the ship, and consequently the course which the ship is steering.

entry.ety: Cf. dial. Sw. lubber. See Looby Lob
entry.def: A heavy, clumsy, or awkward fellow; a sturdy drone; a clown.
entry.q: Lingering lubbers lose many a penny.

entry.def: Like a lubber; clumsy.
entry.q: A great lubberly boy.

entry.def: Clumsily; awkwardly.

entry.ety: L. lubricus: cf. F. lubrique

sn.def: Having a smooth surface; slippery.
Lascivious; wanton; lewd.
sn.q: This lubric and adulterate age.

entry.ety: L. lubricans, p. pr. of lubricare, See Lubricate
entry.def: Lubricating.
That which lubricates; specifically, a substance, as oil, grease, graphite, etc., used for reducing the friction of the working parts of machinery.

entry.ety: L. lubricatus, p. p. of lubricare to lubricate. See Lubric

sn.def: To make smooth or slippery; as, mucilaginous and saponaceous remedies lubricate the parts to which they are applied.
sn.q: Supples, lubricates, and keeps in play, The various movements of this nice machine.

sn.def: To apply a lubricant to, as oil or tallow.
To reduce social frictions or difficulties between people, thus making cooperation easier and joint action smoother.
To inebriate by supplying with alcoholic beverages.

entry.def: smeared with oil or grease to reduce friction.
The act of lubricating; the act of making slippery.

sn.def: One who, or that which, lubricates.
sn.q: Lubricatorof the fibers.

sn.def: A contrivance, as an oil cup, for supplying a lubricant to machinery.

entry.def: See Lubricate.

entry.ety: L. lubricitas: cf. F. lubricité

sn.def: Smoothness; freedom from friction; also, property which diminishes friction; as, the lubricity of oil.
Slipperiness; instability; as, the lubricity of fortune.
Lasciviousness; propensity to lewdness; lewdness; lechery; incontinency.
sn.q: As if wantonness and lubricity were essential to that poem.

entry.ety: L. lubricus
entry.def: Lubric.

entry.ety: L. lubricus lubric + facere to make
entry.def: The act of lubricating, or making smooth.

entry.ety: F., fr. L. lucerna a lamp. See Luthern
entry.def: A dormer window.

entry.ety: It. Lucchese
entry.def: A native or inhabitant of Lucca, in Tuscany; in the plural, the people of Lucca.

entry.ety: OF. lus, L. lucius a kind of fish
entry.def: A pike when full grown.
The quality of being lucent.

entry.ety: L. lucens, p. pr. of lucere to shine, fr. lux lucis, light
entry.def: Shining; bright; resplendent.
entry.q: The sun'slucentorb.

entry.ety: Etymology uncertain

sn.def: A sort of hunting dog; -- perhaps from Lucerne, in Switzerland.
sn.q: My lucerns, too, or dogs inured to hunt Beasts of most rapine.

sn.def: An animal whose fur was formerly much in request (by some supposed to be the lynx).
sn.q: The polecat, mastern, and the richskinned lucern I know to chase.

entry.ety: F. luzerne
entry.def: A leguminous plant (Medicago sativa), having bluish purple cloverlike flowers, cultivated for fodder; -- called also alfalfa.

entry.ety: L. lucerna
entry.def: A lamp.

cs.cd: a form of the microscope in which the object is illuminated by means of a lamp, and its image is thrown upon a plate of ground glass connected with the instrument, or on a screen independent of it.

entry.ety: L. lucerna a lamp
entry.def: Of or pertaining to a lamp.

entry.ety: NL., fr. L. lucerna a lamp
entry.def: A genus of acalephs, having a bell-shaped body with eight groups of short tentacles around the margin. It attaches itself by a sucker at the base of the pedicel.
Of or pertaining to the Lucernarida.

entry.ety: NL. See Lucernaria
entry.def: A division of acalephs, including Lucernaria and allied genera; -- called also Calycozoa.
A more extensive group of acalephs, including both the true Lucernarida and the Discophora.
See Lucern, the plant.

entry.ety: L. lucidus, fr. lux lucis, light. See Light n.

sn.def: Shining; bright; resplendent; as, the lucid orbs of heaven.
sn.q: Lucid, like a glowworm.
A court compact of lucid marbles.

sn.def: Clear; transparent.
sn.q: Lucidstreams.

sn.def: Presenting a clear view; easily understood; clear.
sn.q: A lucid and interesting abstract of the debate.

sn.def: Bright with the radiance of intellect; not darkened or confused by delirium or madness; marked by the regular operations of reason; as, a lucid interval.
sn.syn: Luminous; bright; clear; transparent; sane; reasonable. See Luminous.

entry.ety: Cf. F. lucidité. See Lucid
entry.def: The quality or state of being lucid.
In a lucid manner.
The quality of being lucid; lucidity.

entry.ety: L., bringing light, n., the morning star, fr. lux lucis, light + ferre to bring

sn.def: The planet Venus, when appearing as the morning star; -- applied in Isaiah by a metaphor to a king of Babylon.
sn.q: How art thou fallen from heaven, O Lucifer, son of the morning! how art thou cut down to the ground which didst weaken the nations!
Tertullian and Gregory the Great understood this passage of Isaiah in reference to the fall of Satan; in consequence of which the name Lucifer has since been applied to Satan.

sn.def: Hence, Satan.
sn.q: How wretched Is that poor man that hangs on princes' favors! . . . When he falls, he falls like Lucifer, Never to hope again.

sn.def: A match{1} made of a sliver of wood tipped with a combustible substance, and ignited by friction; -- called also lucifer match, and locofoco, now most commonly referred to as a friction match. See Locofoco.
A genus of free-swimming macruran Crustacea, having a slender body and long appendages.
Of or pertaining to Lucifer; having the pride of Lucifer; satanic; devilish.
Of or pertaining to the Luciferians or their leader.

entry.def: One of the followers of Lucifer, bishop of Cagliari, in the fourth century, who separated from the orthodox churches because they would not go as far as he did in opposing the Arians.

any of several substances found in luminescent organisms (such as the firefly, Photinus pyralis) which, when oxidized, produces an almost heatless light. It was first isolated from fireflies, and is the source of the firefly luminescence. See also firefly luciferin
an enzyme which catalyzes the oxidation of luciferin, thereby producing bioluminescence.

entry.ety: See Lucifer
entry.def: Giving light; affording light or means of discovery.
In a luciferous manner.

entry.ety: L. lucificus; lux lucis, light + facere to make
entry.def: Producing light.

entry.ety: L. lux lucis, light = -form
entry.def: Having, in some respects, the nature of light; resembling light.
Luciferian; satanic.

entry.ety: L. lux lucis, light + -meter
entry.def: an instrument for measuring the intensity of light; a photometer.

A brand name for a transparent plastic based on methyl methacrylate esters; the term is often used generically to refer to any similar transparent plastic. It is sold in various forms, including rigid sheets which may be used as a substitute for glass in windows.

cs.cd: a small sum given back for luck to one who pays money.
to receive some good, or to meet with some success, in an unexpected manner, or as the result of circumstances beyond one's control; to be fortunate.

entry.ety: Akin to D. luk geluk, G. glück, Icel. lukka, Sw. lycka, Dan. lykke, and perh. to G. locken to entice. Cf. 3d Gleck
entry.def: That which happens to a person; an event, good or ill, affecting one's interests or happiness, and which is deemed casual; a course or series of such events regarded as occurring by chance; chance; hap; fate; fortune; often, one's habitual or characteristic fortune; as, good, bad, ill, or hard luck . Luck is often used by itself to mean good luck; as, luck is better than skill; a stroke of luck .
entry.q: If thou dost play with him at any game, Thou art sure to lose; and of that natural luck, He beats thee 'gainst the odds.

entry.ety: From Lucky
entry.def: In a lucky manner; by good fortune; fortunately; -- used in a good sense; as, they luckily escaped injury.

sn.def: The state or quality of being lucky; as, the luckiness of a man or of an event.
Good fortune; favorable issue or event.

entry.def: Being without luck; unpropitious; unfortunate; unlucky; meeting with ill success or bad fortune; as, a luckless gamester; a luckless maid.
entry.q: Prayers made and granted in a luckless hour.

sn.def: A city in India, the site of the Indian Mutiny (1857) when the British were beseiged.
Favored by luck; fortunate; meeting with good success or good fortune; -- said of persons; as, a lucky adventurer.
sn.q: Luckywight.

sn.def: Producing, or resulting in, good by chance, or unexpectedly; favorable; auspicious; fortunate; as, a lucky mistake; a lucky cast; a lucky hour.
sn.q: We doubt not of a fair and lucky war.

entry.def: See Fatherlasher.

entry.ety: L. lucrativus, fr. lucrari to gain, fr. lucrum gain: cf. F. lucratif. See Lucre

sn.def: Yielding lucre; gainful; profitable; making increase of money or goods; as, a lucrative business or office.
sn.q: The trade of merchandise being the most lucrative, may bear usury at a good rate.

sn.def: Greedy of gain.
sn.q: Such diligence as the most part of our lucrative lawyers do use, in deferring and prolonging of matters and actions from term to term.

entry.def: In a lucrative manner.

entry.ety: F. lucre, L. lucrum
entry.def: Gain in money or goods; profit; riches; -- often in an ill sense.
entry.q: The lust of lucre and the dread of death.

entry.ety: L. lucrum gain +-ferous
entry.def: Gainful; profitable.

entry.ety: L. lucrificus; lucrum gain + facere to make
entry.def: Producing profit; gainful.

entry.ety: L. luctatio, fr. luctari to wrestle, strive
entry.def: Effort to overcome in contest; struggle; endeavor.

entry.ety: L. luctus mourning, sorrow, fr. lugere, fr. luctum, to mourn
entry.def: Producing grief; saddening.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Lucubrated; p. pr. & vb. n. Lucubrated
entry.ety: L. lucubratus, p. p. of lucubrare to work by lamplight, fr. lux light. See Light n.
entry.def: To study by candlelight or a lamp; to study by night.
To elaborate, perfect, or compose, by night study or by laborious endeavor.

entry.ety: l. lucubratio;cf. F. lucubration

sn.def: The act of lucubrating, or studying by candlelight; nocturnal study; meditation.
sn.q: After long lucubration I have hit upon such an expedient.

sn.def: That which is composed by night; that which is produced by meditation in retirement; hence (loosely) any literary composition.
sn.q: Thy lucubrations have been perused by several of our friends.

entry.def: One who studies by night; also, one who produces lucubrations.

entry.ety: L. lucubratorius
entry.def: Composed by candlelight, or by night; of or pertaining to night studies; laborious or painstaking.

entry.ety: Dim. fr. L. lux lucis, light
entry.def: A spot or fleck on the sun brighter than the surrounding surface.

entry.ety: L. luculentus, from lux lucis, light

sn.def: Lucid; clear; transparent.
Clear; evident; luminous.
sn.q: Mostluculenttestimonies.

sn.def: Bright; shining in beauty.
sn.q: Most debonair and luculent lady.

entry.def: In a luculent manner; clearly.

entry.ety: From Lucullus, a Roman consul, famous for his great wealth and luxury: cf. F. lucullite
entry.def: A variety of black limestone, often polished for ornamental purposes.

entry.note: ☞ Lucuma mammosum is called natural marmalade in the West Indies; Lucuma Caimito, of Peru, furnishes a delicious fruit called lucuma and caimito.
entry.def: An American genus of sapotaceous trees bearing sweet and edible fruits.

One of a number of riotous persons in England, who for six years (1811-17) tried to prevent the use of labor-saving machinery by breaking it, burning factories, etc.; -- so called from Ned Lud , a half-witted man who some years previously had broken stocking frames.

entry.ety: L. ludibrium mockery, derision, from ludere to play, sport
entry.def: Sportive; ridiculous; wanton.

entry.ety: L. ludibundus
entry.def: Sportive.

entry.usage: Ludicrous Laughable Ridiculous. We speak of a thing as ludicrous when it tends to produce laughter; as laughable when the impression is somewhat stronger; as ridiculous when more or less contempt is mingled with the merriment created.
entry.ety: L. ludicrus, or ludicer, from ludus play, sport, fr. ludere to play

sn.def: Adapted to excite laughter, without scorn or contempt; sportive.
sn.q: A chapter upon German rhetoric would be in the same ludicrous predicament as Van Troil's chapter on the snakes of Iceland, which delivers its business in one summary sentence, announcing, that snakes in Iceland -- there are none.

sn.def: Ridiculously absurd.
sn.syn: Laughable; sportive; burlesque; comic; droll; ridiculous.

entry.ety: L. ludificatio, fr. ludificare to make sport of; ludus sport + -ficarein comp.) to make. See -fy
entry.def: The act of deriding.

entry.ety: L. ludificatorius
entry.def: Making sport; tending to excite derision.

entry.ety: Named after Mr. Ludlam , of London
entry.def: A mineral occurring in small, green, transparent, monoclinic crystals. It is a hydrous phosphate of iron.
A subdivision of the British Upper Silurian lying below the Old Red Sandstone; -- so named from the Ludlow, in Western England. See the Chart of Geology.

entry.ety: Named after the chemist Ludwig
entry.def: A borate of iron and magnesia, occurring in fibrous masses of a blackish green color.

cs.cd: syphilis; -- called also simply lues.

entry.ety: L

sn.def: Disease, especially of a contagious kind.
syphilis; -- called also Lues venerea.

cs.cd: a purchase composed of a double and single block and fall, used for various purposes.
a luff tackle attached to the fall of another luff tackle.

entry.ety: OE. lof, prob. a sort of timber by which the course of a ship was directed, perh. a sort of paddle; cf. D. loef luff, loeven to luff. The word is perh. akin to E. glove. Cf. Aloof
entry.def: The side of a ship toward the wind.
The act of sailing a ship close to the wind.
The roundest part of a ship's bow.
The forward or weather leech of a sail, especially of the jib, spanker, and other fore-and-aft sails.

cs.cd: to make the extreme of this movement, for the purpose of throwing the ship's head into the wind.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Luffed lŭft; p. pr. & vb. n. Luffing

sn.def: To turn the head of a vessel toward the wind; to sail nearer the wind; to turn the tiller so as to make the vessel sail nearer the wind.
To flutter or shake from being aligned close to the direction of the wind; -- said of a sail.

entry.def: See Louver.

cs.cd: a bolt terminating in a long, flat extension which takes the place of a head; a strap bolt.
a large nut fitting a heavy bolt; -- used especially of the nuts used to attach wheels to vehicles.

a wrench used to tighten or loosen lug nuts, usually a steel rod having a hexagonally shaped socket which fits closely over the lug nut; sometimes in the shape of a cross, having several such sockets, one at the end of each arm, to accommodate nuts of different sizes.

entry.ety: Sw. lugg the forelock

sn.def: The ear, or its lobe.

That which projects like an ear, esp. that by which anything is supported, carried, or grasped, or to which a support is fastened; an ear; as, the lugs of a kettle; the lugs of a founder's flask; the lughandle) of a jug.
A projecting piece to which anything, as a rod, is attached, or against which anything, as a wedge or key, bears, or through which a bolt passes, etc.
The leather loop or ear by which a shaft is held up.
The lugworm.
A man; sometimes implying clumsiness.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Lugged lŭgd; p. pr. & vb. n. Lugging lŭg"gĭng
entry.ety: OE. luggen, Sw. lugga to pull by the hair, fr. lugg the forelock
entry.def: To pull with force; to haul; to drag along; to carry with difficulty, as something heavy or cumbersome.
entry.q: They must divide the image among them, and so lug off every one his share.

entry.def: To move slowly and heavily.

sn.def: The act of lugging; as, a hard lug ; that which is lugged; as, the pack is a heavy lug .
Anything which moves slowly.

cs.cd: a pole on which a kettle is hung over the fire, either in a chimney or in the open air.

entry.ety: Etymol. uncertain

sn.def: A rod or pole.
A measure of length, being 161/2 feet; a rod, pole, or perch.
sn.q: Eightlugsof ground.

entry.def: the language of the Buganda; spoken in Uganda.
a racing sled for one or two people; it is raced down a chute of packed snow or ice, and the occupant(s) lie down on it with feet in the direction of motion.
someone who races the luge.

cs.cd: a vehicle for carrying luggage; a railway car, or compartment of a car, for carrying luggage.
the compartment in a train, bus or other vehicle designed for storage of luggage during a journey. Separate from the passenger compartment.

entry.ety: From 4th Lug
entry.def: That which is lugged; anything cumbrous and heavy to be carried; especially, a traveler's trunks, baggage, etc., or their contents.
entry.q: I am gathering up my luggage, and preparing for my journey.
What do you mean, To dote thus on such luggage!

entry.def: A small vessel having two or three masts, and a running bowsprit, and carrying lugsails. See Illustration in Appendix.
An Indian falcon (Falco jugger), similar to the European lanner and the American prairie falcon.

entry.ety: From Lug an ear
entry.def: A mark cut into the ear of an animal to identify it; an earmark.
A square sail bent upon a yard that hangs obliquely to the mast and is raised or lowered with the sail.

entry.ety: L. lugubris, fr. lugere to mourn; cf. Gr. lygro`s sad, Skr. ruj to break
entry.def: Mournful; indicating sorrow, often ridiculously or feignedly; doleful; woful; pitiable; as, a whining tone and a lugubrious look.
entry.q: Crossbones, scythes, hourglasses, and other lugubrious emblems of mortality.

sn.def: excessive sadness and mournfulness.

entry.ety: 1st lug + worm
entry.def: A large marine annelid (Arenicola marina) having a row of tufted gills along each side of the back. It is found burrowing in sandy beaches, both in America and Europe, and is used for bait by European fishermen. Called also lobworm, and baitworm.

entry.ety: Prob. fr. lew, perh. influenced by AS. wlæc warm, lukewarm, remiss. Cf. Lew
entry.def: Moderately warm; not hot; tepid; lukewarm.
entry.q: Nine penn'orth o'brandy and water luke.

entry.ety: See Luke

sn.def: Moderately warm; neither cold nor hot; tepid.
Not ardent; not zealous; cool; indifferent.
sn.q: Lukewarmblood.
Lukewarmpatriots.
An obedience so lukewarm and languishing that it merits not the name of passion.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Lulled lŭld; p. pr. & vb. n. Lulling
entry.ety: Akin to OD. lullen to sing to sleep, G. lullen, Dan. lulle, Sw. lulla; all of imitative origin. Cf. Loll Lollard
entry.def: To cause to rest by soothing influences; to compose; to calm; to soothe; to quiet.
entry.q: Tolullhim soft asleep.
Such sweet compulsion doth in music lie, To lull the daughters of necessity.

entry.def: To become gradually calm; to subside; to cease or abate for a time; as, the storm lulls .

sn.def: The power or quality of soothing; that which soothes; a lullaby.
A temporary cessation of storm or confusion.

entry.ety: From Lull v. t.

sn.def: A song to quiet babes or lull them to sleep; that which quiets.
Hence: Good night; good-by.

entry.def: One who, or that which, lulls.
In a lulling manner; soothingly.

entry.ety: W. llumon chimney, llum that shoots up or ends in a point

sn.def: A chimney.
A ventilating chimney over the shaft of a mine.
A woody valley; also, a deep pool.

entry.ety: F. lumachelle, It. lumachella, fr. lamachella a little snail, dim. of lumaca a snail, fr. L. limax -acis
entry.def: A grayish brown limestone, containing fossil shells, which reflect a beautiful play of colors. It is also called fire marble, from its fiery reflections.
Of or pertaining to lumbago.

entry.ety: L., fr. lumbus loin. See Lumbar
entry.def: A rheumatic pain in the loins and the small of the back.

cs.cd: the region of the loin; specifically, a region between the hypochondriac and iliac regions, and outside of the umbilical region.

entry.ety: L. lumbus loin. See Loin
entry.def: Of, pertaining to, or near, the loins; as, the lumbar arteries.

cs.cd: a room in which timber or lumber is dried by artificial heat.
a room in which unused furniture or other lumber is kept.
a heavy rough wagon, without springs, used for general farmwork, etc.
lumber, usually of pine, which is sold as beams or planks having a specified nominal cross-section, usually in inches, such a two-by-four two-by-six four-by-four, etc.

entry.ety: Prob. fr. Lombard, the Lombards being the money lenders and pawnbrokers of the Middle Ages. A lumber room was, according to Trench, originally a Lombard room, or room where the Lombard pawnbroker stored his pledges. See Lombard

sn.def: A pawnbroker's shop, or room for storing articles put in pawn; hence, a pledge, or pawn.
sn.q: They put all the little plate they had in the lumber, which is pawning it, till the ships came.

sn.def: Old or refuse household stuff; things cumbrous, or bulky and useless, or of small value.
Timber sawed or split into the form of beams, joists, boards, planks, staves, hoops, etc.; esp., that which is smaller than heavy timber.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Lumbered; p. pr. & vb. n. Lumbering

sn.def: To heap together in disorder.
sn.q: Stufflumberedtogether.

sn.def: To fill or encumber with lumber; as, to lumber up a room.
To move heavily, as if burdened.

sn.ety: Cf. dial. Sw. lomra to resound
sn.def: To make a sound as if moving heavily or clumsily; to rumble.
To cut logs in the forest, or prepare timber for market.

entry.def: One employed in lumbering, cutting, and getting logs from the forest for lumber; a lumberman.
entry.q: Lumberers have a notion that he (the woodpecker) is harmful to timber.

entry.def: The business of cutting or getting timber or logs from the forest for lumber.

sn.def: a person who works at lumbering; a lumberman.
The grey jay.

entries.entry: Lum"ber*man n.; pl.Lumbermen. One who is engaged in lumbering as a business or employment. U.S
Lum"ber State. Maine; -- a nickname.

entry.ety: L. lumbus loin + E. sacral
entry.def: Of or pertaining to the loins and sacrum; as, the lumbosacral nerve, a branch of one of the lumber nerves which passes over the sacrum.

entry.ety: L. lumbricus
entry.def: An earthworm, or a worm resembling an earthworm.

entry.ety: Cf. F. lombrical. See Lumbric
entry.def: Resembling a worm; as, the lumbrical muscles of the hands of the hands and feet.

entry.ety: L. lumbricus worm + -form
entry.def: Resembling an earthworm; vermiform.

entry.ety: Lumbricus + -oid
entry.def: Like an earthworm; belonging to the genus Lumbricus, or family Lumbricidæ.

entry.ety: L. See Lumbric
entry.def: A genus of annelids, belonging to the Oligochæta, and including the common earthworms. See Earthworm.

entries.entry:
‖Lu"men n.; pl. L. Lumina #, E. Lumens # . L., light, an opening for light
Photom
A unit of illumination, being the amount of illumination of a unit area of spherical surface, due to a light of unit intensity placed at the center of the sphere.
A unit of light flux, being the flux through one square meter of surface the illumination of which is uniform and of unit brightness.
Biol An opening, space, or cavity, esp. a tubular cavity; a vacuole.

entry.def: Luminous.

entries.entry:
Lu"mi*na*ry n.; pl. Luminaries # F. luminaire, L. luminare a light or lamp, which was lighted in the churches, a luminary, fr. lumen luminis, light, fr. lucere to be light, to shine, lux lucis, light. See Light
Any body that gives light, especially one of the heavenly bodies. Radiantluminary. Where the great luminary . . . Dispenses light from far.
One who illustrates any subject, or enlightens mankind; as, Newton was a distinguished luminary .

entry.ety: L. luminatus, p. p. of luminare to illumine, fr. lumen light. See Limn
entry.def: To illuminate.
Illumination.
To illumine.

entry.ety: See Luminescent

sn.def: Any emission of light not ascribable directly to incandescence, and therefore occurring at low temperatures, as in phosphorescence and fluorescence or other luminous radiation resulting from vital processes, chemical action, friction, solution, or the influence of light or of ultraviolet or cathode rays, etc.

sd.def: The faculty or power of producing light by biological processes, as in the firefly and glowworm. Also called bioluminescence.
The light produced by biological or biochemical processes. Also called bioluminescence.

entry.ety: L. luminare to illuminate + -escent
entry.def: Shining with a light due to any of the various causes which produce luminescence.

entry.ety: L. lumen light + -ferous
entry.def: Producing light; yielding light; transmitting light; as, the luminiferous ether.
The quality or state of being luminous; luminousness.

cs.cd: a paint made up with some phosphorescent substance, as sulphide of calcium, which after exposure to a strong light is luminous in the dark for a time.

entry.ety: L. luminosus, fr. lumen light: cf. F. lumineux. See Luminary Illuminate

sn.def: Shining; emitting or reflecting light; brilliant; bright; as, the is a luminous body; a luminous color.
sn.q: Fire burneth wood, making it . . . luminous.
The mountains lift . . . their lofty and luminous heads.

sn.def: Illuminated; full of light; bright; as, many candles made the room luminous .
sn.q: Up the staircase moved a luminous space in the darkness.

sn.def: Enlightened; intelligent; also, clear; intelligible; as, a luminous mind.
sn.q: Luminouseloquence.
Aluminousstatement.

entry.def: the quality of being luminous; emitting or reflecting light.
A fat, ungainly, stupid person; an awkward bungler.

cs.cd: the whole together; in gross.
cs.q: They may buy them in the lump.
cs.cd: coal in large lumps; -- the largest size brought from the mine.
a gross sum without a specification of items; as, to award a lump sum in satisfaction of all claims and damages.

a single sum paid once in satisfaction of a claim, as contrasted with the alternate choice of several payments over a period of time; -- sometimes allowed, e.g., as an alternative to periodical pension payments for a lifetime.

entry.ety: Cf. OD. lompe piece, mass. Cf. Lunch

sn.def: A small mass of matter of irregular shape; an irregular or shapeless mass; as, a lump of coal; a lump of iron ore.
sn.q: Alumpof cheese.
Thislumpof clay.

sn.def: A mass or aggregation of things.
A projection beneath the breech end of a gun barrel.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Lumped; p. pr. & vb. n. Lumping

sn.def: To throw into a mass; to unite in a body or sum without distinction of particulars.
sn.q: The expenses ought to be lumped together.

sn.def: To take in the gross; to speak of collectively.
sn.q: Not forgetting all others, . . . whom for brevity, but out of no resentment to you, I lump all together.

sn.def: To get along with as one can, although displeased; as, if he doesn't like it, he can lump it.

entry.def: the removal of a cyst or tumor from the breast by surgery. This is one method of treating breast tumors when in an early stage, and is preferred for cosmetic reasons, when medically feasible, to radical mastectomy, the removal of the entire breast along with nearby muscles.

sn.def: mentally sluggish.
same as lumpenproletariat.
The European eelpout; -- called also lumper.

entry.def: the lowest level of the proletariat, comprising unskilled workers, the unemployed, and the dispossessed, alienated from the class with with they would normally identify and having little or no class solidarity; -- an important element in Marxist theory.

entry.ety: Cf. Lamper eel
entry.def: The European eelpout; -- called also lumpen.

sn.def: One who lumps.
A laborer who is employed to load or unload vessels when in harbor.

entry.ety: From Lump, on account of its bulkiness: cf. G. & D. lump, F. lompe
entry.def: A large, thick, clumsy, marine fish (Cyclopterus lumpus) of Europe and America. The color is usually translucent sea green, sometimes purplish. It has a dorsal row of spiny tubercles, and three rows on each side, but has no scales. The ventral fins unite and form a ventral sucker for adhesion to stones and seaweeds. Called also lumpsucker cock-paddle sea owl.
Bulky; heavy.
Like a lump; inert; gross; heavy; dull; spiritless.
entry.q: Lumpish, heavy, melancholy.

entry.def: The lumpfish.
To combine (various items) and treat them as a unit. See lump v. i.
Full of lumps, or small compact masses; as, a lumpy bed; a lumpy batch of dough.

entries.entry: Lump"y-jaw`. Med Actinomycosis. Colloq

cs.cd: horn silver, or fused silver chloride, a tough, brown, translucent mass; -- so called from its resemblance to horn.

a very large and beautiful American moth (Actias luna). Its wings are delicate light green, with a stripe of purple along the front edge of the anterior wings, the other margins being edged with pale yellow. Each wing has a lunate spot surrounded by rings of light yellow, blue, and black. The caterpillar commonly feeds on the hickory, sassafras, and maple.

entry.ety: L.; akin to lucere to shine. See Light n., and cf. Lune

sn.def: The moon.
Silver.

entries.entry:
Lu"na*cy n.; pl.Lunacies #. See Lunatic
Insanity or madness; properly, the kind of insanity which is broken by intervals of reason, -- formerly supposed to be influenced by the changes of the moon; any form of unsoundness of mind, except idiocy; mental derangement or alienation. Your kindred shuns your house As beaten hence by your strange lunacy.
A morbid suspension of good sense or judgment, as through fanaticism. Derangement; craziness; mania. See Insanity.

entry.cs: Lunar caustic Med. Chem silver nitrate prepared to be used as a cautery; -- so named because silver was called luna by the ancient alchemists. Lunar cycle. Same as Metonic cycle. See under Cycle. Lunar distance the angular distance of the moon from the sun, a star, or a planet, employed for determining longitude by the lunar method. Lunar method the method of finding a ship's longitude by comparing the local time of taking (by means of a sextant or circle) a given lunar distance, with the Greenwich time corresponding to the same distance as ascertained from a nautical almanac, the difference of these times being the longitude. Lunar month. See Month.
