Lunar observation an observation of a lunar distance by means of a sextant or circle, with the altitudes of the bodies, and the time, for the purpose of computing the longitude. Lunar tables. Astron Tables of the moon's motions, arranged for computing the moon's true place at any time past or future. Navigation Tables for correcting an observed lunar distance on account of refraction and parallax. Lunar year the period of twelve lunar months, or 354 days, 8 hours, 48 minutes, and 34.38 seconds.
entry.ety: L. lunaris, fr. luna the moon. See Luna, and cf. Lunary

sn.def: Of or pertaining to the moon; as, lunar observations.
Resembling the moon; orbed.
Measured by the revolutions of the moon; as, a lunar month.
Influenced by the moon, as in growth, character, or properties; as, lunar herbs.
A lunar distance.
The middle bone of the proximal series of the carpus; -- called also semilunar, and intermedium.

entry.def: A small genus of European herbs of the mustard family, including the herb honesty Lunaria annua), which is also called moonwort and lunary.

entry.ety: See Lunar Luna
entry.def: An inhabitant of the moon.

entry.ety: Cf. F. lunaire. See Lunar
entry.def: Lunar.

entry.ety: Cf. F. lunaire
entry.def: The herb moonwort or “honesty”.
A low fleshy fern (Botrychium Lunaria) with lunate segments of the leaf or frond.

entry.ety: L. lunatus crescent-shaped, p. p. of lunare to bend like a crescent, fr. luna the moon
entry.def: Crescent-shaped; resembling the crescent moon; as, a lunate leaf; a lunate beak; a lunated cross.

entry.ety: F. lunatique, L. lunaticus, fr. luna the moon. See Lunar

sn.def: Affected by lunacy; insane; mad; crazy; demented.
sn.q: Lord, have mercy on my son; for he is lunatic.

sn.def: Of or pertaining to, or suitable for, an insane person; evincing lunacy; as, lunatic gibberish; a lunatic asylum.

entry.def: A person affected by lunacy; an insane person, esp. one who has lucid intervals; a madman; a person of unsound mind.
entry.q: The lunatic, the lover, and the poet, Are of imagination all compact.

entry.def: the members of a political or social group espousing extreme, fanatical, or seemingly irrational views.

entry.ety: Cf. Lunated
entry.def: The period of a synodic revolution of the moon, or the time from one new moon to the next; varying in length, at different times, from about 291/4 to 295/6 days, the average length being 29 d., 12h., 44m., 2.9s.

entry.ety: Of uncertain etymol. Cf. Prov. Eng. nunc a lump
entry.def: A luncheon; specifically, a light repast between breakfast and dinner, most commonly about noontime.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Lunched; p. pr. & vb. n. Lunching
entry.def: To take luncheon.

entry.ety: Prov. E. luncheon lunchion lunshin, a large lump of food, fr. lunch. See Lunch

sn.def: A lump of food.
A portion of food taken at any time except at a regular meal.
A lunch, especially one organized by a group as a formal social gathering.

entry.def: To take luncheon.
someone who is eating lunch.
the act of eating lunch.
a dining room (in a school, business, or other non-domestic facility) where lunch can be purchased.
the time for eating lunch; as, he observed a regular lunchtime .
A genus of birds including some of the puffins.

entry.ety: L. luna moon: cf. F. lune. See Luna

sn.def: Anything in the shape of a half moon.
A figure in the form of a crescent, bounded by two intersecting arcs of circles.
A fit of lunacy or madness; a period of frenzy; a crazy or unreasonable freak.
sn.q: These dangerous, unsafe lunes i' the king.

entry.ety: See Lunette
entry.def: A little moon or satellite.

cs.cd: a window which fills or partly fills a lunette.

entry.ety: F., dim. of lune moon, L. luna. See Lune a crescent

sn.def: A fieldwork consisting of two faces, forming a salient angle, and two parallel flanks. See Bastion.
A half horseshoe, which lacks the sponge.
A kind of watch crystal which is more than ordinarily flattened in the center; also, a species of convexoconcave lens for spectacles.
A piece of felt to cover the eye of a vicious horse.
Any surface of semicircular or segmental form; especially, the piece of wall between the curves of a vault and its springing line.
An iron shoe at the end of the stock of a gun carriage.

entry.note: ☞ In all air-breathing vertebrates the lungs are developed from the ventral wall of the esophagus as a pouch which divides into two sacs. In amphibians and many reptiles the lungs retain very nearly this primitive saclike character, but in the higher forms the connection with the esophagus becomes elongated into the windpipe and the inner walls of the sacs become more and more divided, until, in the mammals, the air spaces become minutely divided into tubes ending in small air cells, in the walls of which the blood circulates in a fine network of capillaries. In mammals the lungs are more or less divided into lobes, and each lung occupies a separate cavity in the thorax. See Respiration.

cs.cd: pneumonia.
a species of gentian (Gentian Pneumonanthe).
tree lungwort. See under Lungwort.
one of the breathing organs of spiders and snails.

entry.ety: OE. lunge, AS. lunge, pl. lungen; akin to D. long, G. lunge, Icel. & Sw. lunga, Dan. lunge, all prob. from the root of E. light. √125. See Light not heavy
entry.def: An organ for aërial respiration; -- commonly in the plural.
entry.q: My lungs began to crow like chanticleer.

entry.ety: Also spelt longe, fr. allonge. See Allonge Long
entry.def: A sudden thrust or pass, as with a sword.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Lunged; p. pr. & vb. n. Lunging
entry.def: To make a lunge.
To cause to go round in a ring, as a horse, while holding his halter.
Same as Namaycush.
Having lungs, or breathing organs similar to lungs.
a person with pulmonary tuberculosis.
Any fish belonging to the Dipnoi; -- so called because they have both lungs and gills.
Having lungs that adhere to the pleura.
A guillemot.

entry.ety: OF. longis. See Lounge
entry.def: A lingerer; a dull, drowsy fellow.
Being without lungs.

entry.ety: Hind. langūr
entry.def: A long-tailed monkey (Semnopithecus schislaceus), from the mountainous districts of India.
the ability to speak loudly.

Any one of several species of parasitic nematoid worms which infest the lungs and air passages of cattle, sheep, and other animals, often proving fatal. The lungworm of cattle (Strongylus micrurus) and that of sheep (Strongylus filaria) are the best known.

cs.cd: mullein.
Mertensia maritima, found on the seacoast of Northern Europe and America.
a lichen (Sticta pulmonacea) growing on trees and rocks. The thallus is lacunose, and in appearance somewhat resembles the lungs, for diseases of which it was once thought a remedy.

entry.def: An herb of the genus Pulmonaria Pulmonaria officinalis), of Europe; -- so called because the spotted appearance of the leaves resembles that of a diseased lung.
Any plant of the genus Mertensiaesp. Mertensia Virginica and Mertensia Sibirica), plants nearly related to Pulmonaria. The American lungwort is Mertensia Virginica, Virginia cowslip.

entry.ety: L. luna moon + E. current
entry.def: Having relation to changes in currents that depend on the moon's phases.

entry.ety: L. luna moon + -form: cf. F. luniforme
entry.def: Resembling the moon in shape.

cs.cd: that portion of the annual precession of the equinoxes which depends on the joint action of the sun and moon.

a period of time, at the end of which, in the Julian calendar, the new and full moons and the eclipses recur on the same days of the week and month and year as in the previous period. It consists of 532 common years, being the least common multiple of the numbers of years in the cycle of the sun and the cycle of the moon.

entry.ety: L. luna moon + E. solar: cf. F. lunisolaire
entry.def: Resulting from the united action, or pertaining to the mutual relations, of the sun and moon.

entry.ety: L. luna moon + sistere to cause to stand. Cf. Solstice
entry.def: The farthest point of the moon's northing and southing, in its monthly revolution.

entry.cs: Lunitidal interval. See Retard n.
entry.def: Pertaining to tidal movements dependent on the moon.

entry.ety: D. lont; akin to Dan. & G. lunte, Sw. lunta. Cf. Link a torch

sn.def: The match cord formerly used in firing cannon.
A puff of smoke.

entries.entry:
‖Lu"nu*la n.; pl.Lunulæ #. L., prop., a little moon. See Lunule
Anat. & Zoöl Same as Lunule.

entry.ety: Cf. F. lunulaire. See Lunula
entry.def: Having a form like that of the new moon; shaped like a crescent; lunate.

entry.ety: See Lunula
entry.def: Resembling a small crescent.

entry.ety: F., fr. L. lunula, dim. of luna moon

sn.def: Anything crescent-shaped; a crescent-shaped part or mark; a lunula; a lune.
A lune. See Lune.

sd.def: A small or narrow crescent.
A special area in front of the beak of many bivalve shells. It sometimes has the shape of a double crescent, but is oftener heart-shaped. See Illust. of Bivalve.

entry.ety: Dim. of lunule
entry.def: A small spot, shaped like a half-moon or crescent; as, the lunulet on the wings of many insects.

entry.ety: Lunule + -life: cf. F. lunulithe. See Lunula
entry.def: Any bryozoan of the genus Lunulites, having a more or less circular form.

entry.ety: Shortened fr. lunatic
entry.def: Crazy; insane; mentally unsound.
Of or pertaining to the Lupercalia.
A grotto on the Palatine Hill sacred to Lupercus, the Lycean Pan.

entry.ety: L. luperealis, fr. Lupercus the Lycean Pan, so called fr. lupus a wolf, because he kept off the wolves
entry.def: A feast of the Romans in honor of Lupercus, or Pan.

entry.ety: L. lupinus lupinum, apparently fr. lupinus belonging to a wolf, fr. lupus a wolf; perh. so called because it was supposed to exhaust the soil: cf. F. lupin. Cf. Wolf
entry.def: A leguminous plant of the genus Lupinus, especially Lupinus albus, the seeds of which have been used for food from ancient times. The common species of the Eastern United States is Lupinus perennis. There are many species in California.

entry.ety: See Lupine n.
entry.def: Wolfish; ravenous.
A glucoside found in the seeds of several species of lupine, and extracted as a yellowish white crystalline substance.

entry.note: Chemically it is a a bicyclic saturated quinolizine 1-R-trans]-Octahydro-2H-quinolizine-1-methanol, with the structure: CH2OH | /\ H /\ / \|/ \ | | | | N | \ / \ / \/ \/
entry.def: An alkaloid found in several species of lupine (Lupinus luteus Lupinus albus, etc.), and extracted as a bitter crystalline substance, having a formula C10H19NO. Called also l-lupinine

entry.ety: Cf. F. lupulin. See Lupuline

sn.def: A bitter principle extracted from hops.
The fine yellow resinous powder found upon the strobiles or fruit of hops, and containing this bitter principle.

entry.ety: NL. lupulus the hop, fr. L. lupus the hop: cf. F. lupuline
entry.def: An alkaloid extracted from hops as a colorless volatile liquid.
Pertaining to, or obtained from, hops; specifically, designating an acid obtained by the decomposition of lupulin.

entry.note: ☞ Lupus erythematosus is characterized by an eruption of red patches, which become incrusted, leaving superficial scars. Lupus vulgaris is marked by the development of nodules which often ulcerate deeply and produce great deformity. Prior to 1900 the latter was often confounded with cancer, and some varieties of cancer were included under Lupus. Systemic lupus erythematosus is an inflammatory connective tissue disease occurring mostly in women, characterized by skin rash, fever, and arthritic symptoms, and often accompanied by hemolytic anemia, inflammation of the pericardium, glomerular lesions, and hyperglobulinemia; the condition shows positive in the LE cell test. Stedman
entry.ety: L., a wolf. See Wolf

sn.def: originally, a cutaneous disease with the appearance of the skin having been gnawed, and occurring under two distinct forms. Now used as a generic term for over ten distinguishable diseases having visible cutaneous symptoms.
The Wolf, a constellation situated south of Scorpio.

entry.ety: See its Lurch
entry.def: Gluttony; gormandizing.

entry.ety: L. lurcare lurcari
entry.def: To swallow or eat greedily; to devour; hence, to swallow up.
entry.q: Too far off from great cities, which may hinder business; too near them, which lurcheth all provisions, and maketh everything dear.

entry.cs: To leave one in the lurch. In the game of cribbage, to leave one's adversary so far behind that the game is won before he has scored thirty-one. To leave one behind; hence, to abandon, or fail to stand by, a person in a difficulty. Denham. But though thou'rt of a different church, I will not leave thee in the lurch. Hudibras.
entry.ety: OF. lourche name of a game; as adj., deceived, embarrassed

sn.def: An old game played with dice and counters; a variety of the game of tables.
A double score in cribbage for the winner when his adversary has been left in the lurch.
sn.q: Lady --- has cried her eyes out on losing a lurch.

sn.def: To leave in the lurch; to cheat.
sn.q: Never deceive or lurch the sincere communicant.

sn.def: To steal; to rob.
sn.q: And in the brunt of seventeen battles since He lurched all swords of the garland.

entries.entry: Lurch n. Cf. W. llerch llerc, a frisk, a frisking backward or forward, a loitering, a lurking, a lurking, llercian llerciaw, to be idle, to frisk; or perh. fr. E. lurch to lurk A sudden roll of a ship to one side, as in heavy weather; hence, a swaying or staggering movement to one side, as that by a drunken man. Fig.: A sudden and capricious inclination of the mind.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Lurched lûrcht; p. pr. & vb. n. Lurching
entry.def: To roll or sway suddenly to one side, as a ship or a drunken man; to move forward while lurching.

entry.ety: A variant of lurk

sn.def: To withdraw to one side, or to a private place; to lurk.
To dodge; to shift; to play tricks.
sn.q: I . . . am fain to shuffle, to hedge, and to lurch.

entry.ety: See Lurch to lurk

sn.def: One that lurches or lies in wait; one who watches to pilfer, or to betray or entrap; one who lurks; a lurker; a poacher.
One of a mongrel breed of dogs said to have been a cross between the sheep dog, greyhound, and spaniel. It hunts game silently, by scent, and is often used by poachers.

entry.ety: L. lurco lurcho, a glutton. See 1st Lurch
entry.def: A glutton; a gormandizer.
The line by which a fowling net was pulled over so as to inclose the birds.
Stupid; blockish.

entry.ety: OF. lourdin, fr. lourd heavy, dull, thick-headed. See Lord
entry.def: A blockhead.

entry.ety: OF. loire loirre loerre, F. leurre lure, decoy; of German origin; cf. MHG. luoder, G. luder lure, carrion

sn.def: A contrivance somewhat resembling a bird, and often baited with raw meat; -- used by falconers in recalling hawks.
Any enticement; that which invites by the prospect of advantage or pleasure; a decoy.
A velvet smoothing brush.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Lured; p. pr. & vb. n. Luring
entry.ety: OF. loirer loirier, F. leurrer. See Lure n.
entry.def: To draw to the lure; hence, to allure or invite by means of anything that promises pleasure or advantage; to entice; to attract.
entry.q: I am not lured with love.
And various science lures the learned eye.

entry.def: To recall a hawk or other animal.
A large marine annelid (Nephthys cæca), inhabiting the sandy shores of Europe and America. It is whitish, with a pearly luster, and grows to the length of eight or ten inches.

entry.ety: L. luridus

sn.def: Pale yellow; ghastly pale; wan; gloomy; dismal.
sn.q: Fierce o'er their beauty blazed the lurid flame.
Wrapped in drifts of lurid smoke On the misty river tide.

sn.def: Having a brown color tinged with red, as of flame seen through smoke.
Of a color tinged with purple, yellow, and gray.
Vivid, sensational, or shocking; graphic or melodramatic; as, the lurid details of a murder.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Lurked lûrkt; p. pr. & vb. n. Lurking
entry.ety: OE. lurken lorken, prob. a dim. from the source of E. lower to frown. See Lower, and cf. Lurch, a sudden roll, Lurch to lurk

sn.def: To lie hidden; to lie in wait.
sn.q: Like wild beasts, lurking in loathsome den.
Let us . . . lurk privily for the innocent.

sn.def: To keep out of sight.
sn.q: The defendant lurks and wanders about in Berks.

sn.def: One who lurks.
A small fishing boat.

entry.ety: W. llwry precipitant, a provision
entry.def: A confused heap; a throng, as of persons; a jumble, as of sounds.
entry.q: To turn prayer into a kind of lurry.

entry.def: A genus of birds including the nightingale Luscinia megarhyncos.

entry.ety: Prob. for lustious, fr. lusty, or perh. a corruption of luxurious. Cf. Lush Lusty

sn.def: Sweet; delicious; very grateful to the taste; toothsome; excessively sweet or rich.
sn.q: And raisins keep their luscious, native taste.

sn.def: Cloying; fulsome.
sn.q: He had a tedious, luscious way of talking.

sn.def: Gratifying a depraved sense; obscene.

entry.ety: F. loup-cervier, L. lupus cervarius
entry.def: A lynx. See 1st Lucern and Loup-cervier.

entry.ety: Prob. an abbrev. of lushious, fr. luscious

sn.def: Full of juice or succulence.
sn.q: How lush and lusty the grass looks! how green!

sn.def: Having thick and luxurient vegetation.
Characterized by abundance or luxurience; rich.

entry.ety: Etymol uncertain; said to be fr. Lushington, name of a London brewer

sn.def: Liquor, esp. intoxicating liquor; drink.
an habitual drunkard.

entry.def: See Lussheburgh.
An ancient region and Roman province of the Iberian peninsula, corresponding roughly to modern Portugal and parts of Spain.
Pertaining to Lusitania, the ancient name of the region almost coinciding with Portugal.

def2.def: One of the people of Lusitania.

entry.def: Lazy; slothful.
A lazy fellow; a lubber.
To be idle or unemployed.
Inclined to be lazy.

entry.ety: L. lusorius. See Illusory
entry.def: Used in play; sportive; playful.
A spurious coin of light weight imported into England from Luxemburg, or Lussheburgh, as it was formerly called.
entry.q: God wot, no Lussheburghes payen ye.

entry.ety: AS. lust lust, pleasure, longing; akin to OS., D., G., & Sw. lust, Dan. & Icel. lyst, Goth lustus, and perh. tom Skr. lush to desire, or to E. loose. Cf. List to please, Listless

sn.def: Pleasure.
Inclination; desire.
sn.q: For little lust had she to talk of aught.
My lust to devotion is little.

sn.def: Longing desire; eagerness to possess or enjoy; -- in a had sense; as, the lust of gain.
sn.q: The lust of reigning.

sn.def: Licentious craving; a strong sexual appetite.
Hence: Virility; vigor; active power.

entry.note: ☞ In earlier usage lust was impersonal.In the water vessel he it cast When that him luste. Chaucer.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Lusted; p. pr. & vb. n. Lusting
entry.ety: AS. lystan. See Lust n., and cf. List to choose

sn.def: To list; to like.
sn.q: Do so if thoulust.

sn.def: To have an eager, passionate, and especially an inordinate or sinful desire, as for the gratification of the sexual appetite or of covetousness; -- often with after.
sn.q: Whatsoever thy soul lusteth after.
Whosoever looketh on a woman to lust after her, hath committed adultery with her already in his heart.
The spirit that dwelleth in us lusteth to envy.

entry.def: One who lusts.

entry.ety: L. lustrum: cf. F. lustre
entry.def: A period of five years; a lustrum.
entry.q: Both of us have closed the tenth luster.

entry.note: ☞ There is a tendency to limit the use of luster, in this sense, to the brightness of things which do not shine with their own light, or at least do not blaze or glow with heat. One speaks of the luster of a diamond, or of silk, or even of the stars, but not often now of the luster of the sun, a coal of fire, or the like.

☞ The principal kinds of luster recognized are: metallic adamantine vitreous resinous greasy pearly, and silky. With respect to intensity, luster is characterized as splendent shining glistening glimmering, and dull.

cs.cd: earthenware decorated by applying to the glazing metallic oxides, which acquire brilliancy in the process of baking.

entry.ety: F. lustre; cf. It. lustro; both fr. L. lustrare to purify, go about (like the priests at the lustral sacrifice), traverse, survey, illuminate, fr. lustrum a purificatory sacrifice; perh. akin to E. loose. But lustrare to illuminate is perhaps a different word, and akin to L. lucere to be light or clear, to shine. See Lucid, and cf. Illustrious Lustrum

sn.def: Brilliancy; splendor; brightness; glitter.
sn.q: The right mark and very true luster of the diamond.
The scorching sun was mounted high, In all its luster, to the noonday sky.

sn.def: Renown; splendor; distinction; glory.
sn.q: His ancestors continued about four hundred years, rather without obscurity than with any great luster.

sn.def: A candlestick, chandelier, girandole, or the like, generally of an ornamental character.
The appearance of the surface of a mineral as affected by, or dependent upon, peculiarities of its reflecting qualities.
A substance which imparts luster to a surface, as graphite and some of the glazes.
A fabric of wool and cotton with a lustrous surface, -- used for women's dresses.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Lustred; p. pr. & vb. n. LusteringorLustring
entry.def: To make lustrous.
entry.q: Flooded and lustered with her loosened gold.

sn.def: The act or process of imparting a luster, as to pottery.
The brightening of a metal in the crucible when it becomes pure, as in certain refining processes.

entry.def: Destitute of luster; dim; dull.

sn.def: Full of lust; excited by lust.
Exciting lust; characterized by lust or sensuality.
sn.q: Lustfulorgies.

sn.def: Strong; lusty.
sn.q: Lustfulhealth.
sn.syn: sensual; fleshly; carnal; inordinate; licentious; lewd; unchaste; impure; libidinous; lecherous.

entry.def: Lusty; vigorous.

entry.ety: Lusty + -head
entry.def: See Lustihood.

entry.ety: Lusty + -hood
entry.def: State of being lusty; vigor of body.
entry.q: Full oflustihood.

entry.def: In a lusty or vigorous manner.
State of being lusty; vigor; strength.

entry.ety: CF. Listless

sn.def: Lacking vigor; weak; spiritless.
Free from sexual lust.

entry.ety: L. lustralis, fr. lustrum: cf. F. lustral. See Lustrum

sn.def: Of or pertaining to, or used for, purification; as, lustral days; lustral water.
Of or pertaining to a lustrum.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Lustrated; p. pr. & vb. n. Lustrating
entry.ety: L. lustratus, p. p. of lustrare to lustrate, fr. lustrum. See Lustrum
entry.def: To make clear or pure by means of a propitiatory offering; to purify.
entry.q: We must purge, and cleanse, and lustrate the whole city.

entry.ety: L. lustratio: cf. F. lustration

sn.def: The act of lustrating or purifying.
sn.q: And holy water for lustration bring.

sn.def: A sacrifice, or ceremony, by which cities, fields, armies, or people, defiled by crimes, pestilence, or other cause of uncleanness, were purified.

entry.def: Same as Luster.

entry.ety: L. lustricus, fr. lustrum. See Lustrum
entry.def: Pertaining to, or used for, purification.

entry.ety: F. lustrine, It. lustrino, fr. lustrare to polish, L. lustrare. See 3d Luster, and cf. Lutestring
entry.def: A kind of glossy silk fabric. See Lutestring.

entry.ety: Cf. F. lustreux. See 3d Luster
entry.def: Bright; shining; luminous.
entry.q: Good sparks andlustrous.

entries.entry:
Lus"trum n.; pl. E. Lustrums #, L. Lustra #. L. Cf. 2d & 3d Luster
A lustration or purification, especially the purification of the whole Roman people, which was made by the censors once in five years. Hence: A period of five years.

entry.def: See Sundew.

entry.ety: From Lust. See Lust, and cf. Luscious

sn.def: Exhibiting lust or vigor; stout; strong; vigorous; robust; healthful; able of body.
sn.q: Neither would their old men, so many as were yet vigorous and lusty, be left at home.

sn.def: Beautiful; handsome; pleasant.
Of large size; big.
sn.q: Threelustyvessels.
sn.def: pregnant.
Lustful; lascivious.

entry.ety: L., fr. lusus sport + naturae, gen. of natura nature
entry.def: Sport or freak of nature; a deformed or unnatural production.

entry.ety: LL. lutanista, fr. lutana lute. See Lute the instrument
entry.def: A person that plays on the lute.

entry.ety: L. lutarius fr. lutum mud
entry.def: Of, pertaining to, or like, mud; living in mud.

entry.ety: L. lutare lutatum, to bedaub with mud, fr. lutum mud: cf. F. lutation
entry.def: The act or method of luting vessels.

entry.ety: L. lutum mud, clay: cf. OF. lut

sn.def: A cement of clay or other tenacious infusible substance for sealing joints in apparatus, or the mouths of vessels or tubes, or for coating the bodies of retorts, etc., when exposed to heat; -- called also luting.
A packing ring, as of rubber, for fruit jars, etc.
A straight-edged piece of wood for striking off superfluous clay from mold.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Luted; p. pr. & vb. n. Luting
entry.def: To close or seal with lute; as, to lute on the cover of a crucible; to lute a joint.

entry.ety: OF. leut, F. luth; skin to Pr. laút, It. liúto leúto, Sp. laúd, Pg. alaude; all fr. Ar. al‘ūd; al the + ‘ūd wood, timber, trunk or branch of a tree, staff, stick, wood of aloes, lute or harp
entry.def: A stringed instrument formerly much in use. It consists of four parts, namely, the table or front, the body, having nine or ten ribs or “sides,” arranged like the divisions of a melon, the neck, which has nine or ten frets or divisions, and the head, or cross, in which the screws for tuning are inserted. The strings are struck with the right hand, and with the left the stops are pressed.

entries.entry: Lute v. i. To sound, as a lute. Piers Plowman. Keats.

entry.def: To play on a lute, or as on a lute.
entry.q: Knaves are men That lute and flute fantastic tenderness.

entry.def: Having a curved spine.
same as Lutetium; -- an older spelling.
Pertaining to, or derived from, weld (Reseda luteola).
Pertaining to, or designating, an acid resembling luteolin, but obtained from the flowers of Euphorbia cyparissias.

entry.ety: From corpus luteum
entry.def: A substance of a strongly marked yellow color, extracted from the yolk of eggs, and from the tissue of the corpus luteum.
Same as Lutanist.

entry.ety: L. luteus
entry.def: A combining form signifying orange yellow or brownish yellow.

cs.cd: a brilliant reddish yellow crystalline compound, Co2Cl6(NH3)12, obtained by the action of ammonium chloride on an ammoniacal solution of cobaltic chloride.

entry.def: Pertaining to, or designating, certain compounds of cobalt having a yellow color. Cf. Cobaltic.

entry.ety: From NL. Reseda luteola, fr. L. luteolus yellowish, fr. luteus: cf. F. lutéoline. See Luteous
entry.def: A yellow dyestuff obtained from the foliage of the dyer's broom (Reseda luteola).

entry.ety: L. luteus, fr. lutum dyer's broom, weld, which is used as a yellow dye
entry.def: Yellowish; more or less like buff.

entry.ety: From 3d Lute
entry.def: One who plays on a lute.

entry.ety: From Ist Lute
entry.def: One who applies lute.

entry.ety: L. luteus yellow
entry.def: Of a yellowish color.

entry.ety: Corrupted fr. lustring
entry.def: A plain, stout, lustrous silk, used for ladies' dresses and for ribbon.

A metallic element separated from ytterbium in 1907, by Urbain in Paris and by von Welsbach in Vienna. It is a member of the Lanthanide rare earth group. Symbol, Lu; atomic number 71; atomic weight 174.967 [C=12.011]. Previously spelled Lutecium.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: The leatherback.
Of or pertaining to Luther; adhering to the doctrines of Luther or the Lutheran Church.
One who accepts or adheres to the doctrines of Luther or the Lutheran Church.
The doctrines taught by Luther or held by the Lutheran Church.

entry.ety: F. lucarne a dormer, dormer window, garret window, L. lucerna lamp, fr. lucere to be light or clear, fr. lux light. See Light n., and cf. Lucarne
entry.def: A dormer window. See Dormer.

entry.note: A guitarmaking Web site can be found at: http://www.cybozone.com/luthier/
entry.def: One who makes wooden stringed instruments, such as violins, guitars, etc.

entry.ety: From toluidine, by transposition
entry.def: Any one of several metameric alkaloids, C5H3N.(CH3)2, of the pyridine series, obtained from bone oil as liquids, and having peculiar pungent odors. These alkaloids are also called respectively dimethyl pyridine ethyl pyridine, etc.
See Lute, a cement.
One who plays on a lute.

entry.ety: L. lutosus, fr. lutum mud
entry.def: Covered with clay; miry.
A genus which in some classifications considered a genus of the subfamily Lutrinae.
A subdivision of mammals including the otters; it is not used in some classifications.
The state or quality of being lutulent.

entry.ety: L. lutulentus, fr. lutum mud
entry.def: Muddy; turbid; thick.
A battle in the Thirty Years' War (1632) at which the Swedes under King Gustavus Adolphus defeated the Imperialists under Wallenstein, and in which Adolphus was killed.
A natural family including the louvars.
The type genus of the Luvaridae.
See Paradoxure.

entry.ety: Cf. F. luxer. See Luxate
entry.def: To put out of joint; to luxate.

entry.ety: L. luxatus, p. p. of luxare to dislocate
entry.def: Luxated.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Luxated; p. pr. & vb. n. Luxating
entry.def: To displace, or remove from its proper place, as a joint; to put out of joint; to dislocate.

entry.ety: L. luxatio: cf. F. luxation
entry.def: The act of luxating, or the state of being luxated; a dislocation.

cs.cd: A sumptuous edition as regards paper, illustrations, binding, etc.

entry.ety: L. luxus: cf. F. luxe
entry.def: Luxury.
a native or inhabitant of Luxembourg.
of or pertaining to Luxembourg (definition 2); as, Luxembourgian food.

sn.def: a native or inhabitant of Luxembourg.
of or pertaining to Luxemburg; as, Luxemburger streets.
of or pertaining to Luxemburg (definition 2); as, Luxemburger castles.
of or pertaining to the inhabitants of Luxemburg; as, our Luxemburger neighbors.

entry.def: Given to luxury; voluptuous.

entry.ety: So called from Luxullian, in Cornwall
entry.def: A kind of granite from Luxullian, Cornwall, characterized by the presence of radiating groups of minute tourmaline crystals.
self-indulgent sexual desire (personified as one of the deadly sins).

entry.ety: Cf. F. luxuriance
entry.def: The state or quality of being luxuriant; rank, vigorous growth; excessive abundance produced by rank growth.
entry.q: Tropicalluxuriance.

entry.def: The state or quality of being luxuriant; luxuriance.
entry.q: Flowers grow up in the garden in the greatest luxuriancy and profusion.

cs.cd: one in which the floral envelopes are overdeveloped at the expense of the essential organs.

entry.ety: L. luxurians, p. pr. of luxuriare: cf. F. luxuriant. See Luxuriate

sn.def: Exuberant in growth; rank; excessive; profuse; very abundant; as, a luxuriant growth of grass; luxuriant foliage.
sn.q: Prune the luxuriant, the uncouth refine.

sn.def: Producing luxuriant growth; very fertile; -- of soil.
Having or producing an abundance of elaborate details; unrestrained; -- of imagery or ornamentation.

entry.def: In a luxuriant manner.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Luxuriated; p. pr. & vb. n. Luxuriating
entry.ety: L. luxuriatus, p. p. of luxuriari -are, to luxuriate. See Luxury

sn.def: To grow exuberantly; to grow to superfluous abundance.
sn.q: Cornluxuriatesin a better mold.

sn.def: To feed or live luxuriously; as, the herds luxuriate in the pastures.
To indulge with unrestrained delight and freedom; as, to luxuriate in description.

entry.def: The act or process of luxuriating.
Luxuriance.

entry.ety: L. luxuriosus: cf. F. luxurieux. See Luxury
entry.def: Of or pertaining to luxury; ministering to luxury; supplied with the conditions of luxury; as, a luxurious life; a luxurious table; luxurious ease.
entry.q: Luxuriouscities.

entry.def: One given to luxury.

entries.entry:
Lux"u*ry n.; pl.Luxuries #. L. luxuria, fr. luxus: cf. F. luxure
A free indulgence in costly food, dress, furniture, or anything expensive which gratifies the appetites or tastes. Riches expose a man to pride and luxury.
Anything which pleases the senses, is not necessary for life, and is also costly, or difficult to obtain; an expensive rarity; as, silks, jewels, and rare fruits are luxuries; in some countries ice is a great luxury. Contrasted to necessity. He cut the side of a rock for a garden, and, by laying on it earth, furnished out a kind of luxury for a hermit.
Lechery; lust. Obs
Luxury is in wine and drunkenness.
Luxuriance; exuberance. Obs Voluptuousness; epicurism; effeminacy; sensuality; lasciviousness; dainty; delicacy; gratification.

entry.def: A bone of the human body which was supposed by certain Rabbinical writers to be indestructible. Its location was a matter of dispute.
the Roman numeral representation of sixty; six times ten; -- a determinate quantifier.
the Roman numeral representation of seventy; seven times ten; -- a determinate quantifier.
the Roman numeral representation of eighty; eight times ten; -- a determinate quantifier.

entry.ety: OE. -lich, AS. -lic, orig. the same word as E. like, a. See Like a.
entry.def: A suffix forming adjectives and adverbs, and denoting likeness or resemblance; as, housewifely duties.

entry.ety: See Leam
entry.def: A leash.
variant spelling of Libyan.
The type genus of the Lycaenidae; small slender butterflies with upper surface of wings usually metallic blue or green or copper.
any of various butterflies of the family Lycaenidae.
A natural family of small usually brilliantly colored butterflies; males have short forelegs.
A genus of canids including the African hunting dog.

entry.ety: Gr. �; � a wolf + � a man

sn.def: A human being fabled to have been changed into a wolf; a werewolf.
One affected with lycanthropy.

entry.ety: NL
entry.def: See Lycanthropy, 2.
Pertaining to lycanthropy.
One affected by the disease lycanthropy.
Lycanthropic.

entry.ety: Gr. �: cf. F. lycanthropie

sn.def: The supposed act of turning one's self or another person into a wolf.
A kind of erratic melancholy, in which the patient imagines himself a wolf, and imitates the actions of that animal.

entry.ety: F. Cf. Lyceum
entry.def: A French lyceum, or secondary school for students intermediate between elementary school and college, supported by the French government, for preparing students for the university.
entry.syn: secondary school, lyceum, Gymnasium, middle school.

entries.entry:
Ly*ce"um n.; pl. E. Lyceums #, L. Lycea #. L. lyceum, Gr. �, so named after the neighboring temple of � � Apollo the wolf slayer, prob. fr. � belonging to a wolf, fr � wolf. See Wolf
A place of exercise with covered walks, in the suburbs of Athens, where Aristotle taught philosophy.
A house or apartment appropriated to instruction by lectures or disquisitions.
A higher school, in Europe, which prepares youths for the university.
An association for debate and literary improvement.

entry.def: Like.
See Litchi.
See under Lich.

entry.ety: L., a kind of red flower, Gr. lychni`s; cf. ly`chnos a lamp
entry.def: A genus of Old World plants belonging to the Pink family (Caryophyllaceæ). Most of the species have brilliantly colored flowers and cottony leaves, which may have anciently served as wicks for lamps. The botanical name is in common use for the garden species. The corn cockle (Lychnis Githago) is a common weed in wheat fields.

entry.ety: Gr. ly`chnos a lamp + bi`os life
entry.def: One who labors at night and sleeps in the day.

entry.ety: Gr. � + -scope
entry.def: Same as Low side window, under Low, a.
A weak base identical with betaine; -- so called because found in the boxthorn (Lycium barbarum). See Betaine.
A genus of deciduous and evergreen shrubs often spiny; cosmopolitan in temperate and subtropical regions.
A natural family of fungi including the genus Lycoperdon, consisting of puffballs.
A small order of basidiomycetous fungi having fleshy often globose fruiting bodies: puffpalls; earthstars.

entry.ety: NL., from Gr. � wolf + � to break wind
entry.def: A genus of fungi, remarkable for the great quantity of spores, forming a fine dust, which is thrown out like smoke when the plant is compressed or burst; puffball.
The genus including tomatoes.
A term used in some classifications for the class Lycopsida: club mosses.

entry.ety: Cf. F. lycopode
entry.def: A plant of the genus Lycopodium.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: Same as Lycopodium powder. See under Lycopodium.
Belonging, or relating, to the Lycopodiaceæ, an order of cryptogamous plants (called also club mosses) with branching stems, and small, crowded, one-nerved, and usually pointed leaves.
An alternative designation for the class Lycopsida.
An old name for a fossil club moss.

cs.cd: a fine powder or dust composed of the spores of Lycopodium, and other plants of the order Lycopodiaceæ. It is highly inflammable, and is sometimes used in the manufacture of fireworks, and the artificial representation of lightning.

entry.ety: NL., from Gr. � wolf + �, �, a foot
entry.def: A genus of mosslike plants, the type of the order Lycopodiaceæ; club moss.
The class including club mosses and related forms: includes Lycopodiales; Isoetales; Selaginellales; and extinct Lepidodendrales; sometimes considered a subdivision of Tracheophyta.
A small genus of nonaromatic herbs of the mint family.
The type genus of the family Lycosidae.
The natural family of arachnids including the wolf spiders.

entry.ety: Gr. � hook + � to turn
entry.def: Campylotropous.
A high explosive consisting principally of picric acid, used as a shell explosive in the British service; -- so named from the proving grounds at Lydd, England.
See Leden.

cs.cd: a flint slate used by the ancients to try gold and silver; a touchstone. See Basanite.

entry.ety: L. Lydius, fr. Lydia, Gr. �
entry.def: Of or pertaining to Lydia, a country of Asia Minor, or to its inhabitants; hence, soft; effeminate; -- said especially of one of the ancient Greek modes or keys, the music in which was of a soft, pathetic, or voluptuous character.
entry.q: Softly sweet in Lydian measures, Soon he soothed his soul to pleasures.

entry.def: A violet dye derived from aniline.

entry.ety: AS. leáh; akin to D. loog, OHG. louga, G. lauge; cf. Icel. laug a bath, a hot spring

sn.def: A strong caustic alkaline solution of potassium salts, obtained by leaching wood ashes. It is much used in making soap, etc.
Sodium hydroxide or potassium hydroxide, or a concentrated aqueous solution of either compound.

entry.def: A short side line, connected with the main line; a turn-out; a siding.
A falsehood.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. � to loose + � the brain
entry.def: A group of Mammalia, including the marsupials and monotremes; -- so called because the corpus callosum is rudimentary.
Pertaining to, or characteristic of, the Lyencephala.
The cicada.
A natural family comprising the lygaeid bugs.
An order of fossil gymnospermous trees or climbing plants from the Devonian: the seed ferns.
A genus of fossil seed ferns of the Carboniferous.

entry.note: ☞ Lygodium palmatum, much prized for indoor ornament, inhabits shaded and moist grassy places, from Massachusetts to Virginia and Kentucky, and sparingly southwards.
entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. � flexible; � a willow twig + e'i^dos form
entry.def: A genus of ferns with twining or climbing fronds, bearing stalked and variously-lobed divisions in pairs.
A genus of plant-sucking bugs.
of Lie, to tell a falsehood.

cs.cd: a panel in which the grain of the wood is horizontal.
having the sails so disposed as to counteract each other.

entry.def: of Lie, to be supported horizontally.

sn.def: The state attending, and consequent to, childbirth; confinement; as, a lying-in hospital.
The act of bearing a child.

entry.def: In a lying manner; falsely.

entry.ety: See Like v. t.
entry.def: To please; -- chiefly used impersonally.
entry.q: Sith itlykethyou.

entry.def: A dog held in a leam; a bloodhound; a limehound.
See Limaille.
A dull-colored moth whose larvae have tufts of hair on the body and feed on the leaves of many deciduous trees.
The natural family comprising the tussock moths.
A coarse perennial grass of several species of Elymus, esp. Elymus Canadensis, and the European Elymus arenarius.

entry.cs: Lymph corpuscles Anat finely granular nucleated cells, identical with the colorless blood corpuscles, present in the lymph and chyle. Lymph duct Anat a lymphatic. Lymph heart. See Note under Heart n., 1.
entry.ety: L. lympha: cf. F. lymphe

sn.def: A spring of water; hence, water, or a pure, transparent liquid like water.
sn.q: A fountain bubbled up, whose lymph serene Nothing of earthly mixture might distain.

sn.def: An alkaline colorless fluid, contained in the lymphatic vessels, coagulable like blood, but free from red blood corpuscles. It is absorbed from the various tissues and organs of the body, and is finally discharged by the thoracic and right lymphatic ducts into the great veins near the heart.
A fibrinous material exuded from the blood vessels in inflammation. In the process of healing it is either absorbed, or is converted into connective tissue binding the inflamed surfaces together.
A fluid containing certain products resulting from the growth of specific microorganisms upon some culture medium, and supposed to be possessed of curative properties.

entry.ety: NL. See Lymph, and Adenitis
entry.def: Inflammation of the lymphatic glands; -- called also lymphitis.

entry.ety: NL. See Lymph Aden-, and -oma
entry.def: See Lymphoma.

entry.ety: NL., from L. lympha lymph + Gr. � vessel + -itis
entry.def: Inflammation of the lymphatic vessels.

entry.ety: See Lymphangeitis
entry.def: Of or pertaining to the lymphatics, or lymphoid tissue; lymphatic.

entry.ety: L. lymphatus, p. p. of lymphare to water, dilute with water, to drive out of one's senses, to make mad
entry.def: Frightened into madness; raving.

cs.cd: one of the solid glandlike bodies connected with the lymphatics or the lacteals; -- called also lymphatic ganglion, and conglobate gland.

a temperament in which the lymphatic system seems to predominate, that is, a system in which the complexion lacks color and the tissues seem to be of loose texture; hence, a temperament lacking energy, inactive, indisposed to exertion or excitement. See Temperament.

entry.ety: L. lymphaticus distracted, frantic: cf. F. lymphatique
entry.def: pertaining to, containing, or conveying lymph.

sn.def: Madly enthusiastic; frantic.
sn.q: Lymphaticrapture.

sn.def: One of the lymphatic or absorbent vessels, which carry lymph and discharge it into the veins; lymph duct; lymphatic duct.
A mad enthusiast; a lunatic.

entry.ety: NL
entry.def: See Lymphadenitis.

entries.entry: Lymph node. Anat A lymphatic gland.

entry.ety: Lymph + root of L. gignere to produce
entry.def: Connected with, or formed in, the lymphatic glands.

entry.ety: Lymph + -graphy
entry.def: A description of the lymphatic vessels, their origin and uses.

entry.ety: Lymph + -oid
entry.def: Resembling lymph; also, resembling a lymphatic gland; adenoid; as, lymphoid tissue.

cs.cd: a fatal disease characterized by the formation in various parts of the body of new growths resembling lymphatic glands in structure.

entry.ety: NL. See Lymph, and -oma
entry.def: A tumor having a structure resembling that of a lymphatic gland; -- called also lymphadenoma.
Containing, or like, lymph.
A waterfall. See Lin.

entry.ety: See Lynx
entry.def: Of or pertaining to the lynx.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Lynched; p. pr. & vb. n. Lynching
entry.ety: See Note under Lynch law
entry.def: To inflict punishment upon, especially death, without the forms of law, as when a mob captures and hangs a suspected person. See Lynch law.
One who assists in lynching.

entry.note: ☞ The term Lynch law is said to be derived from a Virginian named Lynch, who took the law into his own hands. But the origin of the term is very doubtful.
entry.def: The act or practice by private persons of inflicting punishment for crimes or offenses, without due process of law.
See Linden.
Linen.

entry.note: ☞ Among the well-known species are the European lynx (Felis borealis); the Canada lynx or loup-cervier (Felis Canadensis syn. Lynx lynx); the bay lynx of America (Felis rufa), and its western spotted variety (var. maculata); and the pardine lynx (Felis pardina) of Southern Europe.
entry.ety: L. lynx lyncis, Gr. ly`gx; akin to AS. lox, G. luchs, prob. named from its sharp sight, and akin to E. light. See Light n., and cf. Ounce an animal

sn.def: Any one of several species of feline animals of the genus Felis, and subgenus Lynx. They have a short tail, and usually a pencil of hair on the tip of the ears.
One of the northern constellations.

entry.def: Having acute sight.
A genus of evergreen or deciduous shrubs or small trees of the U. S. to the Antilles and eastern Asia to Himalaya.
a former province of east central France; now administered by Rhone-Alpes.

entry.ety: F. lyonnaise, fem. of lyonnais of Lyons
entry.def: Applied to boiled potatoes cut into small pieces and heated in oil or butter. They are usually flavored with onion and parsley.

sn.def: same as lyophilize.
same as lyophilized.

entry.def: to freeze-dry; -- a technique used to dry serum, tissue, unstable chemicals and other sensitive materials.
dried by freezing and subsequent evaporation of the water in a high vacuum; -- used of tissue or blood or serum or other biological or sensitive substances.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. � to loose + �, �, a lid
entry.def: An order of brachiopods, in which the valves of shell are not articulated by a hinge. It includes the Lingula, Discina, and allied forms.

entry.ety: L. lyra, Gr. �. See Lyre

sn.def: A northern constellation, the Harp, containing a white star of the first magnitude, called Alpha Lyræ, or Vega.
The middle portion of the ventral surface of the fornix of the brain; -- so called from the arrangement of the lines with which it is marked in the human brain.

entry.def: Same as Lyrid.

entry.ety: NL. lyratus. See Lyre

sn.def: Lyre-shaped, or spatulate and oblong, with small lobes toward the base; as, a lyrate leaf.
Shaped like a lyre, as the tail of the blackcock, or that of the lyre bird.

entry.note: ☞ The lyre was the peculiar instrument of Apollo, the tutelary god of music and poetry. It gave name to the species of verse called lyric, to which it originally furnished an accompaniment.

cs.cd: a small bat (Megaderma lyra), inhabiting India and Ceylon. It is remarkable for the enormous size and curious shape of the nose membrane and ears.
the leatherback.

entry.ety: OE. lire, OF. lyre, L. lyra, Gr. �. Cf. Lyra

sn.def: A stringed instrument of music; a kind of harp much used by the ancients, as an accompaniment to poetry.
One of the constellations; Lyra. See Lyra.

entry.def: Any one of two or three species of Australian birds of the genus Menura. The male is remarkable for having the sixteen tail feathers very long and, when spread, arranged in the form of a lyre. The common lyre bird (Menura superba), inhabiting New South Wales, is about the size of a grouse. Its general color is brown, with rufous color on the throat, wings, tail coverts and tail. Called also lyre pheasant and lyre-tail.
A garden plant (Dicentra spectabilis) having deep-pink drooping heart-shaped flowers.

entry.ety: L. lyricus, Gr. �: cf. F. lyrique. See Lyre

sn.def: Of or pertaining to a lyre or harp.
Fitted to be sung to the lyre;
appropriate for song; suitable for or suggestive of singing; -- of music or poetry.
expressing deep personal emotion; -- said especially of poetry which expresses the individual emotions of the poet; as, the dancer's lyrical performance.
sn.q: Sweetlyricsong.

sn.def: A lyric poem; a lyrical composition.
A composer of lyric poems.
A verse of the kind usually employed in lyric poetry; -- used chiefly in the plural.
The words of a song.
the property of being suitable for singing.

entry.def: In a lyrical manner.
A lyric composition.

One of the group of shooting stars which come into the air in certain years on or about the 19th of April; -- so called because the apparent path among the stars if traced backwards crosses the constellation Lyra.

entry.ety: Icel. hlȳri a sort of fish
entry.def: A European fish (Peristethus cataphractum), having the body covered with bony plates, and having three spines projecting in front of the nose; -- called also noble pluck pogge sea poacher, and armed bullhead.

entry.ety: Lyre + -ferous
entry.def: Having a lyre-shaped shoulder girdle, as certain fishes.

entry.ety: Cf. Gr. lyrismo`s
entry.def: The act of playing on a lyre or harp.

entry.ety: L. lyristes, Gr. lyristh`s: cf. F. lyriste
entry.def: A musician who plays on the harp or lyre; a composer of lyrical poetry.
A genus of plants including one of the skunk cabbages.
A small genus of tropical American trees and shrubs with pinnate leaves and flat straight pods.

sn.def: a cosmopolitan genus of plants, including some of the loosestrifes, found in damp or swampy terrain having usually yellow flowers; they are inclined to be invasive.

entry.ety: Gr. ly`sis a loosing + -meter
entry.def: An instrument for measuring the water that percolates through a certain depth of soil.

entry.note: ☞ It is usually contrasted with crisis, in which the improvement is sudden and marked; as, pneumonia ends by crisis, typhoid fever by lysis.
entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. ly`sis
entry.def: The resolution or favorable termination of a disease, coming on gradually and not marked by abrupt change.

entry.note: ☞ The plural (Lyssæ) has been used to signify the pustules supposed to be developed under the tongue in hydrophobia.
entry.ety: NL. See Lytta
entry.def: Hydrophobia.

entry.ety: Gr. lyth`rios healing, fr. lyth`r a deliverer, fr. ly`ein to loosen
entry.def: Terminating a disease; indicating the end of a disease.
The European pollack; -- called also laith, and leet.

entry.ety: See Lithe a.
entry.def: Soft; flexible.
See Lithontriptic.

entries.entry: ‖Lyt"ta lĭt"tȧ n.; pl.Lyttæ -tē. L., a worm said to grow under the tongue of dogs, and to cause canine madness, fr. Gr. ly`tta ly`ssa, lit., madness Anat A fibrous and muscular band lying within the longitudinal axis of the tongue in many mammals, as the dog.
